abstract: The police returns, yesterday, reported a compliant which had been preferred by Mr. MOSES ADLER, of No. 173 Stanton-street, for robbery in the first degree. Mr. ADLER makes affidavit that between 9 and 10 o'clock yesterday morning, while he was passing through Ridge-street, near Broome, a young ruffian sprang upon him, and, grasping his throat with one hand, attempted with the other to steal his wallet from his pantaloons pocket. Mr. ADLER struggled with the robber, and, releasing himself from his clutch, fled into a butcher's shop across the street; but the fellow, not to be foiled, pursued him and made a second attempt, and might have succeeded, but for the interference of the butcher. The bandit now fled, and was in turn pursued by Mr. ADLER and the buthcer until they reached a street corner near which Policeman MURRAY was patrolling, and the alarm being given him, he headed off the fugitive, and with a number of well directed blows with his baton, brought him to terms. At court the prisoner described himself as WILLIAM FISHER, peddler, 22 years of age. The magistrate, having listened to the testimony, declined to accept bail, and committed him for trial. Mr. ADLER's wallet contained $2,000 in treasury notes. The foregoing is the police account. What [???] it more curious is, none of the police mag[???] have any knowledge of any such case.

abstract: the Colchester Trial, >amp;c. Judge Edmonds' Letter
snippet: the Colchester Trial, >amp;c. Judge Edmonds' Letter
lead_paragraph: The article entitled "Spiritualism and Jugglery," which appeared in our columns a few days ago, was prompted by a sense of the value of "fair play" a desire to do justice to our many intelligent and respected friends who are, in various degrees, believers in those manifestations, as against some of the daily papers, who were inclined to draw most sweeping and unwarrantable inferences from the results of the Colchester trial. We believed that article, coming from an outsider -- a professed non-believer in the supernatural origin of the phenomena -- to be, in its statements, its analyses and its strictures, eminently just and reasonable; indeed, to our personal knowledge, it was such as to command the acquiescence (except as to the extent of the matter conceded) of the most intelligent class of Spiritualists themselves.

abstract: We commend to the notice of the City Inspector the obstructions to travel in Broadway, in the shape of two enormous piles of old brick, between Fulton and Ann streets, The effect of these impediments is to choke up Broadway, from Wall-street to Barclay, adding greatly to the danger and disorder always peculiar to these [???] [???] busy blocks, Both these unsightly mounds together cannot be worth more than a thousand dollars, while ten times that amount must be lost each day in the breaking of vehicles, injuring of horses, and intolerable delays and risks to pedestrians. Will the City Inspector be kind enough to set a limit to this yielding of the public welfare to a paltry private interest?

abstract: Ball >amp; Wheelock's Double Flange Railroad Wheels
snippet: Ball >amp; Wheelock's Double Flange Railroad Wheels
lead_paragraph: We have seen a new invention, designed to effectually prevent cars from running off the track, the spreading of rails around sharp curves, and the breaking of axles by the strain and force of friction being transferred from one end of the axle to the other, which is effected by the action of the outer flange in conjunction with the inner on the opposite rails; and it seems from the tests afforded us, while examining the model, that it will perform all that is claimed for it. In the running of these wheels it will be seen that they cling to the track with tenfold the usual tenacity, the outer flange coming into immediate action on an abrupt curve, and the force of the strain, as well as friction, being equally distributed between rails, wheels and ends of axles. The whole superstructure is vastly strengthened thereby, this improvement insuring safety to life, limb and property, and immunity from accident arising from ordinary causes, such as running off the track. It is not pretended that this wheel will prevent collisions, the reckless infringement of the rules of railroads, or the criminal displacement of rails, or ties, or obstructions heaped upon the track by the malicious and evil disposed. These cannot be classed under the head of ordinary causes of accidents. Nearly two-thirds of the accidents resulting in loss of life and property (it is a well known fact) have been caused by the throwing of cars from the track when running at a full rate of speed.
headline: {'main': 'Double Flange Railroad Car Wheels.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Double Flange Railroad Car Wheels.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Wait, Lieut. E. D.
snippet: Wait, Lieut. E. D.
lead_paragraph: Among the passengers lost in the steamer Brother Jonathan, upon the Pacific coast, was Lieut. EDWARD D. WAIT, of the United States Army, and Aid-de-camp to Gen. WRIGHT, who also perished. Lieut. WAIT was a native of Albany, and in the twenty-ninth year of his age. His childhood and youth gave promises of talent, which his subsequent life realized. Though designed for the occupation of his father -- a merchant -- when the war broke out he desired to go into the army, and a commission in the regular army was obtained for him in 1861, since which time he has been constantly with his regiment, discharging his duties faithfully and honorably. His remains have been recovered, and are to be interred in the family grounds in the cemetery at Albany.

abstract: -Walking down Broadway, the other day, we saw the feet of a respectable old gentleman slip and fly up from the pavement, by contact with a simple piece of peach skin, and only the prompt intervention of a friendly arm kept the octogenarian from coming to profound grief. Scarcely had this little circumstance passed from our thoughts, when we met a friend, a younger man, the side of whose face was fearfully swollen, and his eye clothed in "a suit of sables." He had slipped on the skin of some fruit thrown heedlessly on the pavement; had bean taken up insensible, and awaked in the apothecary's shop to find him self a grieved and battered man. These incidents, together with one or two little ill-timed Pickwickian slides, undertaken at short notices on our own account, have reminded us that the [???] fatal, [???] are caused by the reprehensible practice to which we allude.

abstract: The Providence Steam Engine Company, of Providence, R.I., the builders of the engines of the United States steamers Pawtuxet and Algonquin are now engaged upon two pair of 60-inch cylinder engines for the new fast sloops in process of construction. They are also engaged on a pair of engines with ...
lead_paragraph: The Providence Steam Engine Company, of Providence, R.I., the builders of the engines of the United States steamers Pawtuxet and Algonquin are now engaged upon two pair of 60-inch cylinder engines for the new fast sloops in process of construction. They are also engaged on a pair of engines with 23-inch cylinders and four feet stroke. They are building for the Erie Railway a new locomotive, with Dickinson's boiler, which is truly a novel piece of workmanship and arrangement. The engine-driver is placed forward of the boiler, directly over the spot where the smoke-chimney of the engines now in use are placed. The fireman still will retain his station behind the boiler. The boiler being of an entirely different form from these in use at the present time, will enable the locomotive water-tank and coal-box to be in one continuous frame, so that there will be no tender. The cylinder will be 20 inches in diameter, with 26-inch stroke of piston. The valve-motion and cut-off will be on a new plan. Great things are expected of this new arrangement, and certainly in these days of railroad accidents, it seems right and proper that the engine-driver should be so placed as to receive, the first fruits of his negligence. This company are also engaged in building a number of portable engines.

abstract: UNITED SERVICE SOCIETY, S.N.Y. EIGHTH ASSEMBLY DISTRICT. A meeting of ex-officers and men of the army and navy was held, on Wednesday evening, at STEINWAHR'S Hall, No. 415 Grand-street, for the purpose of organizing a United Service Club ...
lead_paragraph: UNITED SERVICE SOCIETY, S.N.Y. -- EIGHTH ASSEMBLY DISTRICT. -- A meeting of ex-officers and men of the army and navy was held, on Wednesday evening, at STEINWAHR'S Hall, No. 415 Grand-street, for the purpose of organizing a United Service Club in the Eighth Assembly District Col. A.B. SAGE, of the central organization, called the meeting to order, and after stating the objects of the society, read the constitution of the central body, and the platform adopted last July, and recommended their adoption by the club. On motion, they were unanimously adopted, and the club proceeded to the election of officers and delegates. The following-named gentlemen were elected, viz.: President, Maj. S.V. PILGRIM; Secretary, Lieut. RICHARD VALLOTTON; Delegates, Messrs. SPENCER, DE GRUSKE and PILGRIM. After addresses by the chairman, Mr. LEWIS and Col. SAGE, the meeting adjourned to Thursday evening, Sept. 6.

abstract: Besson, Theodore, Arrested for False Pretence
snippet: Besson, Theodore, Arrested for False Pretence
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon last, GEORGE W. WILLIS, otherwise Irwin, of No. 47 Vandam-street, a young clerk in the employ of Mr. ALPHEUS FOBES, of the New-York Pension Agency office, at the intersection of Exchange-place and Hanover-street, received from his employer a tin box containing $3,000, which he was to deposit in a bank; but, instead of making a deposit, he absconded to Albany and thence to Troy, and there, before Monday morning, he had cultivated a[???] relations with a Trojan miss, and with her contrived to spend nearly $500 of the stolen money, Repenting, on Monday afternoon, he returned $2,000 by express to Mr. FOBES. This act revealed his whereabouts, and Detective-Officer OBER was sent to arrest him. He was found at one of the best hotels in Troy, and had in his possession $541 05. Justice DOWLING, declining to accept bail, committed him for trial.

abstract: Letter on Southern Issues of the Past; People; Leadership, the great want of
snippet: Letter on Southern Issues of the Past; People; Leadership, the great want of
lead_paragraph: No Southern publication did so much as DE Bow's Review to prepare the South for secession. It never identified itself with any political party, or committed itself directly to the scheme of a Southern Confederacy, until the politicians has already practically set it on foot. It did its work by enforcing with great ability and persistency what it held to be two great necessities of the South, namely: the slavery of the black race, and the commercial independence of the North. These once being established in the Southern mind as vital essentials, it did not cost the demagogues very much effort to precipitate the people into secession, as the way of securing them forever.

lead_paragraph: -- The waiter-girl nuisance is about as bad in Philadelphia as in New-York. On Sunday last a man supposed to be EDWARD T. HARRIS, soldier in a NewYork regiment, committed suicide at Camden, N.J. From letters in his pockets it seems that he was enamored of a concert saloon syren in the Quaker City, and wanted to kill her. He spoke indirectly of his wife in one of his letters. These tawdry demons of the saloons can outdo Circe; she only changed her victims to swine -- these modern enchantresses change their worshipers first to fools, and then in rapid succession to thieves, forgers, defaulters, sots and suicides.

abstract: the Law Affecting
snippet: the Law Affecting
lead_paragraph: The machinery of the law of New-York City about Coroners' inquests is arranged to take advantage of the insular situation of New-York. That is: First, it prohibits interments within the city, except in certain specified cases. Second, it prohibits anyone from conveying out of the city the body of anyone who has died within it, except under a permit from the City Inspector. Third, it directs the Inspector to grant such permit on receipt of a proper certificate, either from the Coroner of from the physician who attended the deceased; or if there was none, from some one of the family. Fourth, it specifies that the physician who makes such a certificate shall, among other things, specify "the direct and indirect cause of the death of such person;" and that if the Coroner holds an inquest, he shall do the same in his certificate.

abstract: Williamsburgh; Mr. Keith's, Lee-avenue, of $2,800
snippet: Williamsburgh; Mr. Keith's, Lee-avenue, of $2,800
lead_paragraph: DARING BURGLARY IN THE NINETEENTH WARD. -- About 4 A.M. yesterday some daring burglar placed a ladder against one of the front windows of the residence of Mr. MINOR H. KEITH, corner of Lee-avenue and Hews-street, E.D., and by that means entered the house and noiselessly explored the different unoccupied rooms, where he found and carried off notes for $2,800, one gold and one silver watch, and several minor articles. The ladder was left behind by the burglar.

abstract: Yesterday morning Detective Officer WALLING, having been informed that one L. HAYWARD, of the firm of HAYWARD & CO., of No. 229 Broadway, had been engaged in the swindling business through the Post-office, laid in wait for the accused at the Post-office, and took him into custody at the moment when he was receiving forty-two letters that had arrived in the morning mail. These missives were from the Eastern, Middle and Western States, and contained money that had been forwarded in response to HAYWARD & CO.'s circular, representing that they could sell jewelry at half the usual cost price, and for $5 would mail to any address certain prizes ranging between gold sleeve-buttons and gold watches. The prisoner was taken before District-Attorney HALL, and measures were taken to prosecute him for violation of the laws regarding lotteries.

abstract: George Appold and Kent, Collision in Chesapeake Bay; on Democratic Party of Ohio
snippet: George Appold and Kent, Collision in Chesapeake Bay; on Democratic Party of Ohio
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT was prodigal of his words at St. Paul, Minn., on Aug. 26. He made two speeches. The first, when he entered the town, thus: "Ladies and Gentlemen: It is not my habit to make speeches, but I thank you for this very cordial welcome which you have given me to St. Paul." The second in response to a serenade, thus: "Gentlemen and Firemen of St. Paul: I am just about to leave, after a very pleasant visit to your city and State. I am much obliged to you for the cordial welcome I have received. Good night."

abstract: (colored,) Experiences Among Freedmen
snippet: (colored,) Experiences Among Freedmen
lead_paragraph: A meeting was held last evening, in the lecture-room of Zion Church, corner of West Tenthstreet and Bleecker, under the auspices of the American and British Freedmen's Commission. The purpose of the meeting was to enable Bishop CLINTON, President of the commission, to present an address relating to his interesting tour through the South, from which he has but just returned. The meeting was presided over by Prof. W. HOWARD DAY, Secretary of the commission, and was well attended by a large congregation of the colored people in the city, who are interested in the great question of ameliorating the condition of the South.

abstract: Hayti, the Revolution in
snippet: Hayti, the Revolution in
lead_paragraph: The colored population of Hayti have been in a state of civil war for several months. It seems to have been a slight trouble to the republican inhabitants of that country for the last fifty odd years, that their Presidents have usually undertaken to sit for a longer term than they were elected. Several of them, to avoid the trouble of a reelection, have continued to hold on to office till they died. One of them took to the Imperial purple, and reigned in the most approved Imperial style as long as his sable subjects would allow him. The present President, FABRE JEFFRARD, although constitutionally elected, has, it is said, the same lofty ambition as his predecessor, SOULOUQUE, and has taken the same steps to deprive the citizens of Hayti of their rights. He is charged with having made a concordat with Rome, for the express purpose of having an Archbishop appointed to crown him. He has absorbed all the gold and silver in his special coffers, and given the citizens worthless promissory notes in exchange. He summarily tries and hangs those who oppose his pretensions, without recourse to any civil process. And he maintains a rigid system of hostility to the foreign resident population. Foreigners are placed under the most serious disabilities. They cannot even intermarry with the natives; and many equally desirable privileges are denied them.
headline: {'main': 'The Revolution Among the Haytians.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Revolution Among the Haytians.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Magazines for September
snippet: Magazines for September
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's New Monthly Magazine. (New-York: HARPER Brothers) gives us the conclusion of "A Trip to Bodies' Bluff and the Dead Sea of the West," a paper both cleverly written and illustrated. "Miss Pink's First Season," a sketch of fashionable life, evidently of English origin, but awkwardly altered in the attempt to fit it to New-York localities, &c. "Sketches of Social Life in China," with many queer-looking illustrations from the artists of the celestial empire. "Milfort," an account of the singular career of a French adventurer among the Creek Indians, who afterward became a general in the Imperial service, by J.T. HEADLEY. "Recollections of an Old Fogy," abridged in an unnecessary rude and illnatured tone, from the reminiscences of Capt. GRONOW; the usual variety of short stories and poetry and further installments of "Armadale," and "Our Mutual Friend." Mystery continues to thicken around the fortunes of the dramatis personae of the former story, somewhat indeed to the exclusion of anything like healthy, open daylight feeling of reality in the plot and its actors. They are too much like lay figures or puppets put into startling positions at the call of their showman, WILKIE COLLINS. DICKENS is preparing to wind up the tangled thread of his narration, and in the present number disposes of two of his characters by an almost impromptu marriage, and prepares the way for getting rid of two more by hints of a coming murder that looms grimly in the distance. With occasional snatches of his old power, "Our Mutual Friend" will, we fear, be ranked low in the scale of its author's writings.

lead_paragraph: Rev. J.J. CLINTON Superintendent Bishop of the African Church of Zion, and President of the American and British Freedmen's Commission, gave, last evening, an interesting account of his recent tour through the South, at Zion Church, corner of Tenth and Bleecker streets. The address was listened to with deep attention by a large audience of colored people, and the remarks of Mr. CLINTON made a deep impression upon them. Mr. CLINTON gave some startling facts, and presented several very interesting pictures of life among the freedman, and stated that he wanted to send down colored teachers to the benighted freedmen of the South.

abstract: SUDDEN DEATH -- THE CORONER THREATENED. -- On Wednesday Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, learned of the sudden death of a laboring man named MICHAEL DUNN, at his boarding-house in North First-street. Upon going to the premises the family demanded to know what right he had there, and threatened to pitch him out of the window if he did not leave immediately, and the suggestion to leave was acted upon without loss of time. The Coroner then called upon Dr. CRAIG, the attending physician, who stated that DUNN was attacked with cholera morbus on Monday afternoon, caused by eating stale vegetables, and died that night, and upon his giving a certificate to that effect, the Coroner gave a permit for burial.
lead_paragraph: SUDDEN DEATH -- THE CORONER THREATENED. -- On Wednesday Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, learned of the sudden death of a laboring man named MICHAEL DUNN, at his boarding-house in North First-street. The Coroner then called upon Dr. CRAIG, the attending physician, who stated that DUNN was attacked with cholera morbus on Monday afternoon, caused by eating stale vegetables, and died that night, and upon his giving a certificate to that effect, the Coroner gave a permit for burial.

abstract: We have now the official figures of the customs revenue of the government through the port of New-York in August. The month's revenue amounted (in hard cash) to $13,190,400, or an average of $488,533 a day for each of the twenty-seven business days of the month. Thus far in the current calendar year the coin receipts for customs at this port have reached $60,185,538. This is the total for eight months, making the monthly average nearly $7,525,000, equal to a yearly aggregate of $90,300,000, or full twenty-six million dollars in excess of the grand total annual coin interest charge on the funded debt of the nation. And this is the result for the port of New-York alone! It would seem as though Uncle Samuel cannot fail to meet, with his uniform punctuality, all the specie claims of his bond-holding creditors. The noble old fellow appears just now to enjoy a prodigious measure of prosperity. Long may he flourish.

abstract: Eureka of Newark vs. Atlantic
snippet: Eureka of Newark vs. Atlantic
lead_paragraph: We gave an account of a finely contested game of base ball yesterday, between the Mutuals and Actives, in which the Mutuals came very near being beaten, and to-day we have to record its equal for closeness, but its superior for heavy batting and fine fielding. The first game between the Eurekas one the Atlantics, played at Newark, was won by the champions by a score of 21 to 20, and the Brooklyn boys considered themselves mighty lucky in securing the trophy -- for they crawled out of the smallest hole they have been in since 1863.

abstract: Patrick Rafferty, a laborer, aged 30, was charged with stealing $29, the property of William Burke. From the evidence it appears that complainant and defendant made a street-acquaintance, and both went on a spree. Finally they reached a liquor saloon, near Rafferty's house, and Mrs. Rafferty dropped in, too. After having several drinks, Rafferty became very communicative, and told Burke of the vice and dangers of the city. "Arrah," my friend," said Pat to Burke, as he testified, "if yese was in many a store, ye'd a been robbed long ago." Burke nodded an assent to the remark made, and soon after that took his pocket-book out to pay for the liquors, when, to get at the small change, he had to take out the larger bills to find the stamps. In doing this he displayed $59. While the pocket-book lay on the counter, Rafferty asked Burke, as he gave him a gentle poke in the side, if he over enjoyed a Corkonian embrace. Burke wanted to know what that was, when Pat said the shins, elbows and sides joined in fraternal embrace. The two were in a wrestle in a twinkling, and in the short scuffle the pocket-book was forgotten by the one and whipped up by the other, as he passed it in this Corkonian polka. After the short scuffle of legs, shins and arms, Rafferty was seized with a sudden attack of cholera morbus and left the room in agony. The wife followed shortly after, and Burke remain 3d in the store wondering by what means the pocket-book had disappeared, when back came Mrs. Rafferty with the missing book. Burke counted the money and found it minus $29, when he caused the arrest of Rafferty, who was sentenced to one month in the Penitentiary.

abstract: Elevation of, Conditions of
snippet: Elevation of, Conditions of
lead_paragraph: If this is true of South Carolina negroes, it establishes the fact in respect to all those of the rest of the South; for the slaves of South Carolina remained the nearest of any to the primitive African type. Their ancestors immediately after being landed at Charleston have settled upon the large cotton and rice plantations of the State, and the succeeding generations have lived almost entirely secluded from contact with white men, excepting overseers, and consequently have made very little advance The experiment with the freedmen upon the Carolina coast we have always regarded as the crucial test. What can be made of the African race there, can surely be made of them anywhere in the South.
headline: {'main': 'The Elevation of the Freedmen An Indispensable Condition.; Our South Carolina correspondent, after a constant and close observation of over two years, testifies with great emphasis to the capacity of the freedmen to make rapid improvement physically and morally, under friendly and wise management.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Elevation of the Freedmen An Indispensable Condition.; Our South Carolina correspondent, after a constant and close observation of over two years, testifies with great emphasis to the capacity of the freedmen to make rapid improvement physically and morally, under friendly and wise management.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Moral, S. G. Letter of Resignation
snippet: Moral, S. G. Letter of Resignation
lead_paragraph: We receive from Mexico a curious document -- so curious, indeed, and so extraordinary that we cannot venture to receive it without reserve, notwithstanding the excellence of the source through which it is obtained. It is a letter in which the Political Prefect of the department of Michoacan sends in his resignation to the Minister of the Interior. The policy of the government and the particular position of Michoacan are characterized therein in terms of so much acerbity that one hesitates to believe such severe criticisms could have issued from an official pen. We append this document:

abstract: The last mail from England brings a report, on good authority, that the Great Eastern will be at once dispatched from Sheerness to Newfoundland. The object of this trip is to fish up, on the way, the fragments of the dissevered cable, which, it is hoped, will be recovered by means of grapnels and buoys. The promoters of the enterprise in England are determined to lay another cable next year, making use of the recovered portions of the old one.

abstract: THE U.S. SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS' PROTECTIVE SOCIETY GREAT RENDEZVOUS PIC-NIC OF VETERANS ON THE l2TH INST. The second meeting of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Protective Society, of which Maj.Gen. DIX was elected President, and Col. J.B. HERMAN ...
lead_paragraph: THE U.S. SOLDIERS' AND SAILORS' PROTECTIVE SOCIETY -- GREAT RENDEZVOUS PIC-NIC OF VETERANS ON THE l2TH INST. -- The second meeting of the Soldiers' and Sailors' Protective Society, of which Maj.Gen. DIX was elected President, and Col. J.B. HERMAN elected Manager, will take place this evening, at 7 o'clock precisely, at Pythagoras Hall, No. 136 Canal-street, when important resolutions will be adopted for the interest of the society, and especially for the arrangements of the great Congratulation Pic-nic, which is to take place on Tuesday, the 12th of September, at Jones' Wood, for the benefit of the society. It is understood that all soldiers and sailors now without employment or means, and the widows and children of the brave men who died in defence of their country, will receive a free ticket of admission. Arrangements are being made to render that pic-nic a public manifestation of general fraternization between the discharged veterans and the people of this great metropolis. Several militia regiments will participate in the demonstration, and our prominent generals and government officials will be invited to attend. Besides the members of the Protective Society, those who wish to be admitted to the meeting this evening should bring their discharge papers with them.

abstract: the Shenandoah
snippet: the Shenandoah
lead_paragraph: The month of August has closed, and we have to record the loss of thirty-five merchant vessels, whose total value is estimated at two million seven hundred and seventeen thousand dollars ($2,717,000.) Three of these vessels were steamers, six ships, sixteen barks, three brigs and seven schooners. Sixteen of these vessels were destroyed by the British pirate steamer Shenandoah, and but for her career on the high seas, we should have had a less number of marine losses to record for last month than of a corresponding month for many years.

abstract: -- At a meeting of the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners last evening Mr. JOSHUA G. ABBE was elected to fill the vacancy in the board created by the resignation of Mr. JAMES W. BOOTH. Mr. ABBE is a practical fireman, having been connected with the department for fifteen years. For four years he was foreman of Hose Company No. 20, and he was also Secretary of the old board of commissioners for some time. It is to be hoped that the commissioners will now proceed to reorganize the department at once. The causes of their delay in so doing are not apparent, and it can only be surmised that the tardiness arose from the commissioners not working harmoniously together. We trust that the difficulties have now been removed and that the commissioners will proceed with the work before them without further waste of time.
lead_paragraph: -- At a meeting of the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners last evening Mr. JOSHUA G. ABBE was elected to fill the vacancy in the board created by the resignation of Mr. JAMES W. BOOTH. abstract: -- Summer goes spitefully out, spitting fire at timid Autumn, who blushes with her burden of fruit as she hesitatingly follows the retreating steps of the August vixen. Summer was over on Thursday, according to the popular tradition; but if yesterday was not a full dog-day, we never suffered one. It is September -- the month with an r, in which we may gulp the bivalve at Dorlon's, without fear of offending the fashion or the stomach. But what a hot Autumn -- what a fierce September -- ember days, indeed! they are furnace blasts from h_____; no matter. And this heat of the dying Summer sticks to one like that adhesive undergarment given to Hercules by Miss Dejanira; or like that first "biled shirt" that Sut Lovengood got out of only at the expense of half his skin. This poor-man's plaster sort of heat, clinging around one "like sea-weed round a clam," is the worst sort of heat known to man, here or hereaf -- well, never mind. We stay-at-homes can scarcely endure it; but those fortunates who have lolled away the Summer on the mountains and by the margin of the sea, who religiously retired at the close of the season, and, in obedience to the behest of fashion, came home on the last day of August -- how do they like it? Not much, we reckon. However, there is one unfailing consolation amid all our sufferings; and that is the moral and physical certainty that Old Time will "fix things." His track is clear; there are no switches out of place, no draw-bridges open, no breaking axles, nothing to cast doubt upon his schedule of arrivals; and he will be here in a few days with such a supply of fine weather -- of crisp, frosty mornings, and hazy and dreamy afternoons, such cool and soothing nights -- that we shall speedily forget our present perspiring torments, and rejoice exceedingly in that most glorious period of all time -- an American Autumn.

WARD, the Union candidate for Governor, to be voted for at the ensuing election.

lead_paragraph: Were an immediate war with Mexico and France necessary for our national safety or honor, or for the assortion of public justice, we should certainly favor it. We have not, thus far, thought war with MAXIMILIAN demanded on any of these grounds. This has been the position of the government.

abstract: By the Africa's mail wehave reports in various shapes, that the picking up of the lost cable will be proceeded with during the month of October -- the Great Eastern, of course, being again employed in the service. We think it well that the friends of the enterprise should receive these unofficial and unauthorized reports with great allowance. The more probable eventuality is, that the purses of New-York capitalists will be gently laid siege to, with the view of raising additional funds to make seven or eight hundred miles of new cable, and try the adventure over again next Spring.
lead_paragraph: By the Africa's mail wehave reports in various shapes, that the picking up of the lost cable will be proceeded with during the month of October -- the Great Eastern, of course, being again employed in the service. We think it well that the friends of the enterprise should receive these unofficial and unauthorized reports with great allowance. The more probable eventuality is, that the purses of New-York capitalists will be gently laid siege to, with the view of raising additional funds to make seven or eight hundred miles of new cable, and try the adventure over again next Spring.

abstract: -Superintendent KENNEDY does well in seeing to the revival of the law regulating the stopping of omnibuses and street -- cars at the street crossings. Half the cases of blocking-up in the great thoroughfares grow out of this very practice of halting stages and cars in the very middle of the intersecting streets. Ten dollars of a fine -- regularly imposed where a violation of the law takes place -- ought to be a sufficient caution against the infraction of the law. The question is, will the police see that the order of their chief is thoroughly executed.

abstract: On Monday night, the 7th ult., SIMON SHEEHAN, of No. 244 Cherry-street, was stabbed thrice in the left side and once in the right side, while in a drunken brawl in the Seventh Ward Hotel, at No. 173 Madisonstreet, and on the morning of the 8th he appeared at court and made affidavit against one WILLIAM LONG.
lead_paragraph: On Monday night, the 7th ult., SIMON SHEEHAN, of No. 244 Cherry-street, was stabbed thrice in the left side and once in the right side, while in a drunken brawl in the Seventh Ward Hotel, at No. 173 Madisonstreet, and on the morning of the 8th he appeared at court and made affidavit against one WILLIAM LONG. LONG fled immediately subsequent to the homicidal assault, and was not again seen in the city until yesterday, when he surrendered to Policeman WALKER, of the Seventh Ward. LONG was taken to Essex Market Police Court, and there committed to prison, in default of $1,000 bail.

abstract: The Board of Fire Commissioners held their usual afternoon session yesterday. Among a mass of routine business, the board organized another new company, "Metropolitan No. 2," to be located in Engine Company No. 1, in Forty-seventh-street. They elected a new commissioner in place of Mr. BOOTH, resigned. The name of the new member of the board is Mr. JOSHUA G. ABBE, who has been connected with the department fifteen years.

abstract: -As the Secretary of the treasury did not publish an exhibit of the public finances yesterday, there is an excellent opportunity now for the propagation of such canards as were sent abroad so plentifully during the month of July. No financial exhibit was published on the 1st of that month, and advantage was taken of this circumstance to circulate all sorts of falsehoods. The Secretary dared not give the facts; the debt was nearly four thousand millions; the Treasury was in a frightful condition, and so on. The official statement of the 1st of August exploded these fictions in a very effectual style, showing that, the increase of the debt was unexpectedly small -- that the entire debt did not reach near three thousand millions -- that the financial situation was strong and healthy and the prospects excellent. But the explosion of these fallacies then need not prevent their repetition during the current month, or the invention of others equally baseless. We should think, however, that fewer people would be taken in by them on this occasion.
lead_paragraph: -As the Secretary of the treasury did not publish an exhibit of the public finances yesterday, there is an excellent opportunity now for the propagation of such canards as were sent abroad so plentifully during the month of July. No financial exhibit was published on the 1st of that month, and advantage was taken of this circumstance to circulate all sorts of falsehoods. The Secretary dared not give the facts; the debt was nearly four thousand millions; the Treasury was in a frightful condition, and so on. The official statement of the 1st of August exploded these fictions in a very effectual style, showing that, the increase of the debt was unexpectedly small -- that the entire debt did not reach near three thousand millions -- that the financial situation was strong and healthy and the prospects excellent. But the explosion of these fallacies then need not prevent their repetition during the current month, or the invention of others equally baseless. We should think, however, that fewer people would be taken in by them on this occasion.

abstract: Essex Market Police Court and Justice Mansfield--Failures of Justice
snippet: Essex Market Police Court and Justice Mansfield--Failures of Justice
lead_paragraph: We have no personal difference with Justice MANSFIELD, who presides at the Essex Market Police Court. We have not even the honor of his acquaintance. No unworthy motive can, therefore, be attributed to us when we call attention to the disgraceful state of affairs which some of our most trustworthy policemen feel impelled to charge as existing in his court. We know that our Police Justices have a thankless task to perform at best, and all good citizens should sustain them as long as they have the shadow of right on their side. But when one of these police courts has been, and continues to be prostituted at the will of a junta of ward politicians, and given over absolutely into the hands of a gang of thieves, it clearly appears to us that the fact should be made known to the public.
headline: {'main': 'A Mockery of Law The Manner of Conducting Business in the Essex Police Court.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Mockery of Law The Manner of Conducting Business in the Essex Police Court.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Admiral GOLDSBOROUGH, commanding the United States squadron in European waters, leaves here today for the Texel, whence his command will visit the principal harbors of Western Europe. It is expected to arrive at Bremerhaven next Spring. The United States frigate Colorado, 42, sails immediately, in consequence of an order just received from President JOHNSON, for England, to convey Mr. BRIGHT to America, whither he is invited as the guest of the American nation in recognition of his friendly sentiments toward the Union.

abstract: Last evening at 8 o'clock, as the Staten Island boat was within about two feet of its bridge, a man stepping ashore missed, and fall into the water. He was pulled out as the boat was being chained. He was in imminent danger of going down, and came up out out of the water two or three times. About two or three days ago, a man jumped overboard from the 7 o'clock boat from the city. He was lost.

abstract: SHEEP GONE CRAZY. -- A gentleman who came down on the Hempfield train yesterday, informs us that two miles this side of Claysville there was a flock of sheep inclosed in a pasture field. At one point the fence ran along the edge of a high precipice. On Wednesday a stampede occurred among the flock, when the frightened or crazy sheep commenced jumping the fence at the point indicated, going over the precipice at the same time. Two hundred and eighty of the animals were killed. -- Wheeling Intelligencer.

abstract: the Future of, Reforms, >amp;c.
snippet: the Future of, Reforms, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: NAPOLEON I. said at St. Helena, that within fifty years Europe would be either Republican or Cossack; and Prince TALLEYRAND declared that the Russian Government (of his time) was a despotism tempered with assassination. Great changes have taken place since this prophecy and statement, though it is not impossible but that the former may be fulfilled. The government of NAPOLEON III. is assimilating with that of Russia, and there are indications that even that of Great Britain is following on the same track. But the Russia of to-day is very different from that of ALEXANDER I., or even, that of NICHOLAS.
headline: {'main': 'A Glance at the Future of Europe.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Glance at the Future of Europe.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Sanitary and Social Reform
snippet: Sanitary and Social Reform
lead_paragraph: The alarming increase of atrocious crimes, and the unblushing effrontery with which they are perpetrated, compel us to urge upon the attention of the public the consideration of the above-mentioned subject. It must be confessed, to the disgrace of the nation, that here even human life is at a discount, and strict obedience to the laws the exception rather than the rule. The enemies of Republicanism use the above facts as arguments against human liberty, and quote all our delinquencies as evidences of the necessity of despotism. Philanthropists and even statesmen are to be found who erringly attach to our form of government evils which properly belong only to ourselves; and attribute to false legislation, that which is indeed only a criminal neglect, on our part, of the enforcement of the just laws we have enacted, and which we profess, and ought if necessary, to be compelled to obey.
headline: {'main': 'Sanitary and Social Reform.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Sanitary and Social Reform.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Corresponding to Newspapers
snippet: Corresponding to Newspapers
lead_paragraph: The Jackson (Miss.) News is favored with a fair correspondent, who begs him to "let that horrid negro-suffrage question alone;" and, if he really has the interest of future generations in view, to consider, rather, what she regards as the great question of the day: "How and whom to marry?" Miss "SUSAN" pertinently asks, "What's the use of having a Government if there's nobody to govern?" and, rather inconsistently with her request to the editor to abstain from politics, wishes him to take her word for it that, "if the holy estate of matrimony is not more intimately cultivated in this country, we shall lose our balance of power" -- which she ought to know is a great thing in political economy. "Do stir up the Benedicts," she feelingly exclaims, "to a full consideration of the great matrimonial question. Not that I particularly wish to marry, but I think this great country ought to go on, and if people won't marry how can it?"

abstract: Mr. DAVID SCHWARTS, of No. 521 Greenwich-street, made affidavit that on Friday night, while he was passing through Eldridge-street he encountered FERDINAND HERDSMAN, of No. 223 Delancy-street, and HERDSMAN seized him by the throat, thrust one hand into his pantaloons pocket, and stole his pipe and wallet, the latter containing all the money he had on his prison. HERDSMAN then fled and made his escape. He was arrested yesterday, by Officer SMITH, of the Third District Court, and committed in default of $1,000 bail.

abstract: Central Park; Report, Statistics, >amp;c.
snippet: Central Park; Report, Statistics, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The attendance at the Park yesterday was quite small, owing to the threatening state of the weather. In all there were not more than five or six thousand persons present. The programme furnished by HARVEY B. DODWORTH and his superb Park Band was fully up to the high established standard so long maintained since the inauguration of these popular al fresco concerts, the Saturday music-days. Still a very small crowd assembled at 4 o'clock to hear the music yesterday afternoon; scarcely enough to fill the benches furnished by the commissioners. The usual number of Indian awnings were stretched for the accommodation of visitors, but their shelter was more available against the rain than to shield anyone from the heat of the sun's rays. We noticed that very few strayed away from the music pavilion, evidencing the fact that those who came were influenced more by the love of music than anything else.

abstract: Active, New-York vs. Enterprise of Brooklyn
snippet: Active, New-York vs. Enterprise of Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: The return game between these clubs was played yesterday at Brooklyn, on the Capitoline grounds, and was won by the Actives, by a score of 28 to 18, in a full game of nine innings. The first game played at Hoboken was won by the Actives, by a score of 27 to 12, but yesterday the Enterprise boys did better. Both clubs had out good nine, although the Actives were minus the services of WALKER, their pitcher, and ROGERS, right fielder, STOCKMAN taking WALKER'S position, while CRAWFORD played short, and HATFIELD, (a new accession from the Gothams,) played rightfield. The Enterprise were short of their regular catcher, DICK going behind in his place. The game opened favorably for the Actives, but the Brooklyn boys soon obtained the lead, and held it up to the end of the fifth inning, when the score stood 14 to 13. In the next four innings the Actives added fifteen to their score, while they allowed their opponents to make only four. The playing on both sides was very good, "Redman," of the Actives, making a pretty one-hand catch, putting out two players; KELLEY, though still suffering from the severe sprain he received in Philadelphia, marked his play with a nicely taken fly-tip from the bat, which was decidedly "red hot." HATFIELD fielded and batted well, as he always does, and made two home runs, while "Arthur," ROONEY and CRAWFORD played their respective positions in good style. Of the play on the Enterprise side, COOK, JEWELL and MURDOCH did very well in the field, the two latter each making a home run. Owing to the absenee of their regular catcher, the Enterprise were weak in their base playing, the Actives running them all with impunity. Mr. SUTTON, of the Atlantic Club, acted as umpire, and discharged his duties in an exceedingly impartial manner. We append the score:

abstract: JOHN TIETJEN, a young German who was employed as clerk and bar-tender for PETER CAULKIN, was apprehended, yesterday morning, by Policeman SANDS, of the Ninth Precinct, and Mr. CAULKIN appeared before Justice LEDWITH and made affidavit that on Friday night he left $200 in a cigar-box under the counter in his grocery, and that TIETJEN was seen to break open the box and take its contents. The accused, who professed to be perfectly innocent, was committed in default of bail.

abstract: DIFFICULTY BETWEEN WHITE AND COLORED SOLDIERS NEAR BURKESVILLE JUNCTION. -- Monday afternoon, an affray, which might have resulted more seriously under other circumstances, occurred at the Junction of the Danville and Southside Railroad. A detachment of several hundred negro soldiers are stationed at the Junction, and a train carrying a regiment of white troops, en route for Petersburgh, to be mustered out of service, came down from Danville. At the Junction the troops disembarked to take the Southside train. One of the negro guards preambulating the platform, is said to have remarked, "I wish I could get a sight of one of dem Louisiana rebels," or words to that effect. One of the white soldiers, who overheard him, cursed the negro, styling him "a d -- d black _____." The negro replied. "If I am a black _____, you are a white one." The two clinched, blows passed, and the white and black elements immediately took sides and a fight ensued. No firearms or deadly weapons were used, we believe, but one white and one colored soldier were severely beaten. The white troops retired apart to themselves, though they carried their muskets, they were unloaded, and their cartridge boxes were empty. The negro guard at the depot were speedily reinforced from the camp, and for a few moments the aspect of affairs looked threatening indeed. Railroad officials, residents, and native negroes, hastily deserted the scene. Had the white soldiers had ammunition, the affair would probably have eventuated in bloodshed. Finally, the troops were embarked, and the train left for Petersburgh.

abstract: Officer SLOWEY, of the Detective Police, observing two colored persons of suspicious appearance dodging through the Sixth Ward, yesterday afternoon, followed them to a shop which, in the rogues' lexicon, is denominated a "fence," where he witnessed the sale of a gold watch. Feeling assured that the fellows were thieves, Detective SLOWEY arrested and took them to the office of the Detective Police, and there, on search, found on their persons fifteen silver watches that had probably been stolen from some retailing jeweler in this vicinity. The prisoners, who rendered the names of CHARLES SMITH and JOHN MARSHALL, were committed to the cells at No. 300 Mulberry-street, and the watches were turned over to Sergt. JOHN S. YOUNG, Chief of the Detective Force, and may be seen by the owner. The prisoners, when first questioned at Police Headquarters, said that they had purchased the watches from "a man down the street," and they added that if permitted they could point out the man. Detective SLOWEY went out with thorn to find this person, but at last accounts he had not been captured.

abstract: The Liverpool Mercury, of the 17th, contains an account of the sinking, in March last, of the ship Sam. Dunning, from Rangoon for Liverpool. Out of a crew of thirty-one men, only six survived. These survivors kept afloat on a raft for several days, enduring terrible sufferings. They had to eat leather belts and pitch out of the seams, and to drink salt water.

abstract: to ascertain just at present the exact number of volunteers, drafted men and substitutes furnished to the armies of the United States by New-Jersey during the war. We are informed, however, that it will not vary much from eighty thousand, and is probably rather over that number. The same proportion in all the Free States would give about 2,500,000 as the whole number of men furnished to the armies of the Union. The enrollment made by the United States authorities included (or was intended to include) all persons between twenty and forty-five years of age, whether already in the army or not, and whether fit for service or not. This enrollment was made under the Enrollment Act, and the whole number returned was not much over between sixty and seventy thousand. It appears from this that New-Jersey has actually furnished more soldiers than the enrollment lists showed the State to contain. This is accounted for thus: Of the men who served three months and nine months -- four regiments of the former and eleven of the latter -- about fourteen thousand in number, a large proportion reenlisted; in several of the three years' regiments the great majority of the men reenlisted, preserved their regimental organization, and never left the service, and many who were discharged enlisted again, after a short holiday. A considerable number of substitutes were obtained from other States, but not more than enough to balance the number of Jerseymen who, in the first year of the war, volunteered in Pennsylvania, New-York and New-England regiments. -- Trenton Republican.

abstract: Antietam Cemetery, Statistics of
snippet: Antietam Cemetery, Statistics of
lead_paragraph: THE ANTIETAM BATTLE-FIELD CEMETERY. -- The last session of the Maryland Legislature appropriated $7,000 for the purchase of a site for a cemetery on the Antietam battle-field, in which to place the remains of the men who fell in that ever-memorable battle. Through the untiring energies of the trustees, (especially Mr. T.A. BOULIT, of Washington County, Md.,) ten acres of ground have been purchased near the bridge where BURNSIDE's troops fought so bravely, and within sight of the house where the rebel Gen. LEE viewed the progress of the battle. The ground has been inclosed with a neat fence. The work of interring the remains in the cemetery is now in progress. There are some 7,000 or 8,000 buried on the field. Thus far 2,620 bodies have been identified, 1,704 by name, regiment and State, and 916 by their respective States. The remains of many others will yet be identified, as the work progresses.

abstract: Mary Duell, an inveterate sneak thief, was charged with purloining a large quantity of groceries from the door of the dry goods store of Francis Sandon, No. 176 Delancey-street. The evidence of her guilt was positive, yet before and after her trial she persisted in asserting her innocence, and claimed that a woman had given her the goods. Mr. Sandon said he had often seen the woman around the door of his store, and had missed goods time and again to the amount of hundreds of dollars. Suspecting this woman, he "laid for her," saw her go into the alley adjoining the store, dart suddenly out, seize a package of flour, put it under her shawl and walk off, when he arrested her. It happened to be next door to the station-house, and Capt. Steers saw the goods taken from the woman. In the face of this evidence, she had the hardihood to persist in declaring her innocence.

abstract: We heard an absurd man, yesterday, remark that it was hot. We say absurd, not that the man was per se absurd, but because such a piece of supererogtory information was quite ridiculous. The mortal who did not ardently feel that yesterday was hot, need not trouble himself about his hereafter it won't take the chill off his hyberborean blood.
lead_paragraph: -- We heard an absurd man, yesterday, remark that it was hot. We say absurd, not that the man was per se absurd, but because such a piece of supererogtory information was quite ridiculous. The mortal who did not ardently feel that yesterday was hot, need not trouble himself about his hereafter -- it won't take the chill off his hyberborean blood. It we remember, we remarked yesterday that Summer did not yield with becoming grace to incoming Autumn -- that she (Summer) spitefully clung to us, and fairly shriveled poor Autumn with her furnace glare. So did she, and more so, yesterday; for the air was smitten with her torrid breath and hung motionless, so entirely dead that one needed to hold a mirror to the fare of Nature to be sure that respectable old spinster still breathed. When the Pompeiians were buried in ashes and lava, nineteen hundred years ago, they doubtless experienced about the sensations undergone yesterday by those hereabouts, except that the Pompeiians gave it up and slept with their forefathers, while "we 'uns" live to suffer other inflictions. To be serious -- and really this is no joking matter -- Sept. 2 was too much for uncomplaining endurance; it was a sort of totalization, an aggregating, a summing of all Summer hotness -- a mass meeting of volcanic elements with the Sodomic rain, and the Babylonian furnace, and the nameless place seen by Apocalyptic seer, all mingled in one crucible -- and in the centre of the bottom of that crucible was New-York. But the subject is too warm for us. Like the exstatic poet, we gasp for expression,
headline: {'main': 'NOTES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'NOTES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SUICIDE AT CAMDEN, N.J. -- The young man who committed suicide near Camden on Sunday afternoon, as mentioned in the Ledger yesterday, still remains unrecognized. From papers found upon his person it would seem that in December, 1864, be was appointed corporal in Company E, Ninety-seventh New-York State Infantry, Col. JOHN P. SPAFFORD commanding, and that he was discharged July 18, 1865, at Washington City. In the order for his appointment as corporal, it is stared that he was born in England, is five feet eight inches, light complexion and hair, and blue eyes. There was found in his pocket a letter addressed "Miss JESSIE, No. 136 South Sixth-street." This young lady was examined by Coroner ROBERTS, and stated that she had only been acquainted with deceased a few days, and he gave his name as HARRIS, though in all the papers discovered upon him he is called JOHN THOMAS. She also says that he made several proposals of marriage, which she declined. The proprietor of the boarding-house in Dock-street, where he was stopping, testifies that he was a quiet, inoffensive man, and but little addicted to the use of liquor. From all the evidence in the case, it would seem that he committed the rash act on account of the young lady's inability to requite his passion. The letter found upon the body runs as follows: SUNDAY MORNING, PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 27, 1865.

abstract: Chinese Emigration to U. S.
snippet: Chinese Emigration to U. S.
lead_paragraph: It is very often said that the great thing needed for the development of our country is a full supply of labor. With abundant labor, the vast and uncultivated surfaces of the great West might be made to produce unparalleled crops of all the cereals used as food by man. With abundant labor, our vast mining Territories, whose mineral wealth, with our present population, will not even be explored for centuries, might quickly be made to disgorge their golden crops. With abundant labor, the vast spaces of the South, which, under present circumstances, will not be reduced to cultivation for ages, would produce untold crops of cotton, and rice, and sugar, and tobacco, not to speak of tea and silk and other articles, to the growth of which it is so admirably adapted. Take for example, the State of Texas -- had it an abundance of labor, instead of its present limited crop of cotton, it is estimated that it could easily produce five millions of bales per annum, or a quantity greater than was ever grown in the entire South in any one year. Take the State of Nevada -- had it an abundance of labor, instead of the thirty millions worth of silver and gold, which it will give us this year, it could be made to produce three hundred millions, or more than a tenth of the entire debt of the nation. Take the fertile State of Louisiana -- how much greater would be its production of the elements of national wealth, had it instead of its small number of inhabitants, a population of three millions which it could easily sustain. Had we ten times our present population, we should soon have a hundred times our present wealth and power.
headline: {'main': 'The Growth of the United States through Emigration--The Chinese.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Growth of the United States through Emigration--The Chinese.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- On Thursday, the 23d, the wife of Mr. WINTER, a butcher in North Easton, who had been sick for two weeks with typhoid fever, during an attack of delirium, got up from her bed, took a razor and cut her throat, from the effects of which she died in about two hours. To add to his calamities, on the next day Mr. WINTER's barn, from some cause unknown, caught fire and was entirely consumed, together with six or eight tons of hay, $4,000 worth of hides, ice-house, slaughter-house, &c. His horses and carriages were saved. Mr. WINTER's loss by the fire cannot be less than $6,000, though he was probably insured. Mr. WINTER has but recently recovered from a severe attack of typhoid.

abstract: Address to Corveta, Ga., Circuit, on Reopening Courts; Bingham, Judge, Address to Coweta Circuit on Resumption of Courts
snippet: Address to Corveta, Ga., Circuit, on Reopening Courts; Bingham, Judge, Address to Coweta Circuit on Resumption of Courts
lead_paragraph: Agreeably to the proclamation of Hon. JAMES JOHNSON, Provisional Governor, the Superior Courts of the Coweta Circuit will henceforth resume the exercises of their functions, not as irregular subordinate quasi tribunals, but as Courts of the State of Georgia, discharging important duties under the high sanction of an order from the President of the United States, according to the laws in existence prior to the 1st of January, 1861, so far as the same are not inconsistent with our present condition.

abstract: SERIOUS PRANKS OF A MAD COW, -- About 4 o'clock, Friday afternoon, a drove of cattle belonging to MOSES MAY, No. 136 Romsen-street, E.D., was being driven down Bushwick-avenue, a mad cow in the drove attacked a horse belonging to PETER KONIG, corner of Flashing and Bushwick avenues, and when Mr. KONIG went to the rescue of his horse, he was himself attacked by the ferocious animal and severely injured. The cow then rushed down the street in a franticmanner, going at everything, who met and [???]ng the greatest consternation among pedestrians. When she arrived at WALL's ropewalk, however, a citizen dealt her a blow with a cart-rung, which had the effect of stunning her. She was then taken to the slaughter-house on the Johnson-street plank-road, and finally dispatched. It is reported that the same cow yesterday gored an unknown man at the corner of broadway and Myrtle-avenue, injuring him so severely that he is not expected to recover.

abstract: THE DEMOCRATIC STATE CONVENTION. -- The following delegates have been elected to represent the Democratic party of Kings County, in the State Convention at Albany, as per call of the Citizens' Democratic General Committee: First District -- Tunis G. abstract: INQUEST AT HOBOKEN. -- Coroner AVERY, of Hoboken, held an inquest on Friday over the body of the unknown man mentioned Thursday as having been found in the water foot of Second-street. In the vest pocket of deceased was found a letter, partially obliterated by tobacco stains, dated New-York, August 25, 1865, supposed to have been written by deceased to his parents, in Holland, in which he states that in consequence of his business being dull he had shipped on board the vessel Janahan or Sonahan for a trip to the Mediterranean, and asking them to direct an answer to No. 148 First-street, New-York. Coroner AVERY dispatched an officer to the place indicated in New-York, but no knowledge of the man could be obtained. The signature to the letter, as near as it could be made out, is "Schape." The supposition is, that deceased had gone on board the vessel, and having occasion to get up in the night, slipped on his vest and gaiters, and while on the chains over the bow fell into the water and was drowned. A verdict of found drowned was rendered. Owing to the neglect of the Hoboken authorities to provide a dead house, the remains lay festering in the sun in the lot adjoining the station-house from Thursday until yesterday afternoon.

abstract: -We print this morning a sketchy report of the situation of Brooklyn and Kings County politics, and the make-up of the party slates as these matters present themselves from the present outlook. It is never safe, however, to say who is Governor until after election, and we therefore will not hazard an indorsement of the statements as herewith published. New combinations may be made and new candidates be trotted out between now and nomination day, which will have the effect of knocking present calculations into a cocked hat.

abstract: and the Pirate Shenandoah; Mason, J. M., and the Pirate Shenandoah
snippet: and the Pirate Shenandoah; Mason, J. M., and the Pirate Shenandoah
lead_paragraph: -It would appear from the British news, which we publish to-day, that MASON, the Confederate emissary in London, still holds himself obligated to discharge certain functions of an ambassador. He writes in that capacity to the London Times a letter relating to the Shenandoah, which we publish elsewhere. MASON's principal object probably is to give the world an intimation of his existence, and to make it known that his official career is not yet entirely closed. He says that as soon as it was known in England that the war in the United States was ended, letters were sent by a sure channel to the commander of the Shenandoah, ordering him to bring his cruise to a close. MASON is confident that these letters, being sent by a sure messenger, have reached the Shenandoah, and that her career has closed long before the date of his letter to the Times.

abstract: A telegram from Vienna, of Aug. 19, says: The convention based on the Austro-Prusso-Danish Treaty of Peace was concluded at Gastein, on the 14th. Prussia gets Lauenburg, and pays Austria pecuniary indemnification. The Provisorium in Schleswig-Holstein is prolonged. Prussia is to rule in Schleswig, Austria in Holstein, until the future of the Duchies has been decided on.

abstract: to be tried for treason
snippet: to be tried for treason
lead_paragraph: It is now settled that the rebel chief will be tried for treason, and as soon as practicable. Ample time has been given for all popular excitement to subside, so that his jury may be as dispassionate as possible; and for the complete preparation by his counsel of every available defence in law and in fact. The delay of the government in making the arraignment may not have suited some impatient spirits, but has best comported with the sanctity of justice, and with its own dignity.

abstract: -Capt. ANDERSON's letter, which we publish in another column, takes on exceedingly hopeful view of the Atlantic cable. The commander of the Great Eastern, who was long doubtful of the feasibility of the enterprize, now avows himself sanguine of complete and early success. There is no notion, however, of attempting a renewal of the work during the present year. But the directors and the shareholders generally, are evidently in no degree disheartened, and the necessary funds for making good the lost cable will, without question, be had when called for.

abstract: Western Butter Washing
snippet: Western Butter Washing
lead_paragraph: If any ambitious young fellow can be found who, without $50 to begin with as capital, desires to clear $5,000 the first year, we advise him by all means to go into the butter trade. At the end of twelve months, without anxiety, risk, much labor, or any loss, he may find himself the owner of a handsome income; and the second or third summer thereafter take his family to Saratoga or Newport. To become a butter-merchant, in these times, is, in more senses than one, equivalent to "striking oil."

abstract: Debt on Sept. 1
snippet: Debt on Sept. 1
lead_paragraph: The present exhibit of Secretary McCULLOCH affords the gratifying news that the Treasury of the United States paid its own way through the month of August. The Taxes and Customs begin to tell most substantially against any further considerable borrowing. There is no increase of the Public Debt since the close of July, save a trifling difference in the grand total of less than half a million. The Gold balances on hand have been increased about ten millions and the Treasury now holds the large total in Gold and Silver of forty-five and a half millions; a sum unprecedented in the history of the Department. The Currency balances are not so heavy as at the close of July, but the unadjusted requisitions on the Treasury are more closely settled up than on any previous report during or since the War. The Funded Debt bearing Interest in Gold is a few hundred thousand dollars less than on the 1st of August The Legal Tender Notes a million less.

abstract: This most important trotting match, between the famous stallions Commodore Van[???]ll and Toronto Chief, was to have come off on Saturday, and a large attendance of the patrons of the trotting turf were present, in anticipation of a keenly-contested race. A postponement, however, was inevitable, owing to the rain-storm early in the morning, which made the track unfit for trotting purposes. However, if to-day proves fair, this great match will be decided. It has been, and is, creating much excitement in trotting circles, owing to the fame of the competitors, and the deep interest manifested by their respective owners in the result. Toronto Chief has the call in the betting, owing to the fact that he will go under the saddlle, whilst Commodore Vanderbill, not being a saddle horse, will have to go in harness. Notwithstanding this discrepancy of rig, and the advantage it is supposed to give Toronto Chief, the owner of the Comodore is sanguine of handling the stake. If the track be in good condition to-day, some extraordinary fast time may be anticipated.

lead_paragraph: The London Times goes over a Liverpool judge pretty roughly because he insisted that a Quaker juror should take off his hat. Says the Times: "An unusual episode a,t the Liverpool Assizes deserves some passing attention. Upon the jury taking their seats in the box on Monday, a Quaker who was among their number, kept his hat on. This irregularity disturbed the equanimity of the Judge, Mr. Baron BRAMWELL, and he requested the removal of the hat. The Quaker urged that conscience compelled him to keep it on. The Judge replied that "conscience no more compelled him to keep his hat on than it did his shoes, and that be must have respect for others," and threatened to fine him 10 if he did not take of the hat. "It is a reverence for the Almighty," said the juryman, "which compels me to keep it on." "Don't be nonsensical," retorted the Judge; "your reason is discreditable to common sense." The Quaker persisted, and the Judge at length fined him 10 and ordered him to leave the box. "Any person," he added, "with such nonsense in his head is not fit to sit upon a jury. I shall call upon him again to-morrow, and if he still persists in his nonsense I shall fine him again."

abstract: "TWO YEARS IN TEXAS." Mrs. WALLING will speak on this theme at the Cooper Institute this evening. The lady resided in Texas for several years prior ...
lead_paragraph: "TWO YEARS IN TEXAS." -- Mrs. WALLING will speak on this theme at the Cooper Institute this evening. The lady resided in Texas for several years prior to the breaking out of the rebellion, but disgusted with the secession sentiments which prevailed, she left, soon after hostilities had commenced, accompanied by a younger brother and three children of tender years. After suffering great hardships she reached the North, and did good service for the Union cause by canvassing several States during the Presidential campaign. Mrs. WALLING is said to be an eloquent speaker, and she comes among us with lotters of recommendation from the late Gov. BROUGH and Gov. YATES, MORTON and other distinguished men. Her lecture will doubtless be both interesting and instructive.

abstract: Return in the M. E. Church
snippet: Return in the M. E. Church
lead_paragraph: Last evening the St. Luke's Independent Methodist Church, in Forty first-street, near Broadway, was filled in every part by a large gathering, to hear Prof. MATTISON's reasons for his contemplated return to the Methodist Episcopal Church. Mr. MATTISON has been for some years a seceder from the Episcopal Methodists, and during that time has been considered a brilliant light among the independent preachers of the day. His return, therefore, to the church from which he had seceded some five years ago was a phenomenon many wished to understand.

abstract: Mayor of Brooklyn, Political History of
snippet: Mayor of Brooklyn, Political History of
lead_paragraph: While the magnates of our country are bothering their brains and tiring their heads with plans and theories concerning reconstruction and reorganization of States and parties, the minor but equally engrossing perplexities of local politics find their devotees, their wise men, and their doctors. In this city "division" is the cry. Our Democratic brethren constitute a large but exceedingly unhappy family. There are more wings than heads, more discords than harmonies, more quarrels than love-feasts, by long odds, and we hear unmistakable signs of dissension and trouble in the camp of every organization. Not content with fighting the common enemy, the members of this not wholly naturalized party take genuine pleasure in outgeneraling each other, and if by good luck any considerable number of them present at any time a solid front on the day of contest, one has but to wait a few days to find the battle more fiercely waged in their ranks among themselves than upon the field against their foe.

abstract: This morning, on the arrival of the steamer Adelaide, from Baltimore, two darkies were taken from the steamer to the lock-up by the guard. On inquiry we ascertained that they were pickpockets, and during the passage down the bay had robbed a gentleman of $1,000 and a lady of her jewelry.

abstract: Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Saturday night, CHARLES ASHENFELT and EDWARD KELLY, follow-workmen in Messrs, KELLY  BURTIS' morocco-dressing works, engaged in a scuffle in THOS. HIGGINS' porter-house, at No. 545 First-avenue, and ASHENFELT falling, and his head striking a corner of the counter, was instantly killed. Coroner GOVER held an inquest at the Thirty-fifthstreet Police-station, last evening, and the jury found that the killing was unintentional.

abstract: 1st Annual Meeting
snippet: 1st Annual Meeting
lead_paragraph: The "White Star Union," a social organization formed in the field prior to the disbandment of the army, by the officers of the Second Division, Twentieth Corps, held its first annual meeting in Philadelphia on Saturday last, the anniversary of the occupation of Atlanta by the " White Star Division." The troops comprising this division belonged to the States of New-York, Pennsylvania, New-Jersey and Ohio, and all these Sates were well represented at the meeting.

abstract: By the Saxonia here, and the Peruvian at Father Point, we have five days' later intelligence from Europe. Mr. MASON, the rebel envoy, has written a letter to state that as soon as the surrender of the rebel armies was known orders were dispatched to the commander of the Shenandoah to stop cruising, seek the first available port and discharge his men. Mr. MASON thinks those orders should long ago have reached the pirate. Capt. ANDERSON, of the Great Eastern, is sanguine of ultimate success in laying the cable, and urges another trial early next Summer. Continental news is unimportant. The town of Mont de Marsan has almost unanimously elected Count WALEWSKI to the Corps Legislatif. The ravages of cholera in Turkey are fearful, and it is still strong at Malta, but generally it does not seem to be violent in Western Europe. The convention based on the Austro-Prusso-Danish treaty of peace was concluded at Gastein, on the 14th. Prussia gets Lauenberg, and pays Austria pecuniary indemnification. The Provisorium in Schleswig-Holstein is prolonged. Prussia is to rule in Schleswig, Austria in Holstein, until the future of the Duchies has been decided on.

abstract: Mr. BATEMAN'S artists have arrived from Europe, with the exception of Mr. LEVEY, and the first concert of the series will take place at Irving Hall, on Monday next, the 11th inst. We shall be greatly disap- ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. BATEMAN'S artists have arrived from Europe, with the exception of Mr. LEVEY, and the first concert of the series will take place at Irving Hall, on Monday next, the 11th inst. We shall be greatly disappointed if the company does not prove to be one of the finest we have ever had in this country, and as the prices are arranged on a thoroughly popular basis, it will be strange indeed if the concerts are not thoroughly successful, both in a pecuniary and artistic point. The performers are Mme. PAREPA, Mr. DANNREUTHER, CARL ROSA, and Mr. LEVEY, with a full orchestra under the direction of Mr. THEODORE THOMAS.

abstract: Yesterday forenoon, Mr. JOHN SWINTON, of the NEW-YORK TIMES, having breakfasted at the Maison Doree, paid charges at the office and carelessly left his wallet, containing $4,000, on the counter at the office of the hotel. Half an hour subsequently, missing his wallet, and recollecting the fact that he had it in the Maison Doree, he returned and learned that it had been taken by one ARTHUR OTTO, of No. 40 Rivington-street, a waiter who had recently been taken into the employ of Mr. MARTINEZ, the landlord, and that had fled. Information was at once lodged with the Detective Police, and the case was given to Detective officers PHILIP FARLEY and JOHN C. TIEMANN, and they, having ascertained that OTTO dwelt at No. 40 Rivington-street, "piped" that place, and at 8 o'clock last evening captured him and recovered every dollar of Mr. SWINTON's money. The detective police send compliments to Mr. SWINTOS, and hope that hereafter be may be a more careful man.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday forenoon, Mr. JOHN SWINTON, of the NEW-YORK TIMES, having breakfasted at the Maison Doree, paid charges at the office and carelessly left his wallet, containing $4,000, on the counter at the office of the hotel. abstract: Japanese Gunboat and the Britishers; Japanese Frigate Fusiyama and British Authorities
snippet: Japanese Gunboat and the Britishers; Japanese Frigate Fusiyama and British Authorities
lead_paragraph: The selfishness and avarice of the British Government have another exemplification in the case of the screw war steamer Fusiyama, built in this city last year for the Imperial Government of Japan. This vessel was ordered through our Minister resident in Japan, and was constructed by and with the consent of the United States authorities. When completed and ready for sea it was discovered that she was the pioneer of at least three more vessels, some of which were to be of larger dimensions and even more formidable, and as the construction of these vessels would not only give employment to American ship-builders, and consequently bring a considerable sum in gold into our coffers, and act as an advertisement in Japan for our ship-builders, John Bull immediately set himself to work to throw obstacles in the way of this enterprise, and, if possible, to obtain the custom of the Tycoon in the building of a navy for him, and at the same time to strike a blow at our growing name for ship-building with foreign Powers.
