abstract: White's, R. G., Manner of the Life of Shakespeare; Lambert's, F. L. Systematic Human Physiology; Raymond's, Hon. H. J., Life of Abraham Lincoln; Cox, Hon. S. S.; Eight Years in Congress
snippet: White's, R. G., Manner of the Life of Shakespeare; Lambert's, F. L. Systematic Human Physiology; Raymond's, Hon. H. J., Life of Abraham Lincoln; Cox, Hon. S. S.; Eight Years in Congress
lead_paragraph: As a student and editor Of SHAKESPEARE, Mr. GRANT WHITE has acquired fame and reputation in the two countries where the "Great Bard" rules supreme over the realms of literature. His edition of SHAKESPEARE's works has met with general approbation, and -- when the first volume (necessary for its completion) has appeared -- his impression may be regarded as the most elegant and sympathetic contribution to Shakesperean criticism that this nation has produced. The work before us is not, as many may imagine, the long missing volume I of the "Works;" that will contain SHAKESPEARE's poems and a condensation of some of the biographical and historical matter, here presented in a graceful and classical shape, as a separate and independent introduction to the study of SHAKESPEARE. Viewed in this light, we think it is destined to meet with great success. It is not a controversial book -- a point certainly in its favor. Every fact and supposition current respecting SHAKESPEARE, has long been a battle-ground for succeeding editors, each bent upon discrediting their rivals' hypothesis, and eager to trumpet forth any trifling addition to the shreds and fragments that constitute our meagre stock of information respecting the dramatist. Divested of doubtful and spurious additions, the ascertained facts of his career are few and isolated, so that Mr. GRANT WHITE has need of all his ingenuity to weave them into a continuous narrative. With some obvious inconsistency, he is severe on the "laborious men who have wasted sunlight and candles and worn good eyes in poring over sentences as murky as the parchments on which they were written, and as dry as the dust which covered them," in pursuit of knowledge respecting SHAKESPEARE's personal history. Yet to these very diggers and delvers into antiquity, and the facts they produce from "parish registers, old account-books, inventories, last wills and testaments, leases, deeds, bonds, declarations," &c., he is indebted for the documentary materials of his biography; for all, indeed, that depends upon anything more certain than the vague and shifting breath of popular tradition. To explain the double life that SHAKESPEARE must have led, is of course beyond the power of any commentator, with our present materials only at command, and probably will never be rightly understood. How the man, as known to his fellows -- companionable, genial and jocular, indeed, but at the same time, sharp, thrifty, business-like and hard in money matters; who left the intellectual world of the metropolis without a pang as soon as a reasonable fortune was secured by steady pursuit of the main chance, to bury himself among the petty interests and narrow bovine instincts of a Boetian neighborhood -- how this man could be one and the same with he whose "shaping spirit of imagination" broods like an intellectual presence at once over the minds of the highest and lowest of those who speak his language, winning their glad suffrages to his immeasurable mental superiority, as they feel the larger life he lends to an ennobled nation -- is indeed a mystery passing our present skill in psychology to explain. One key to a knowledge of his inner life exists, however, in the "Sonnets;" revelations that seem wrung from the depths of his inmost nature, but comparatively useless to our purpose for want of the clue that should guide us in applying them toward the illustration of their writer's career. In Mr. GRANT WHITE's memoir every available source of information has been carefully examined. In his natural desire to people the empty canvass of his sketch he lends a more favorable ear to many of the petty local traditions -- all inspired apparently by a desire to bring down SHAKESPEARE to the dead level of his country neighbors -- than we should be disposed to do. The notices of SHAKESPEARE by his contemporaries are given at greater length than we have elsewhere seen them; no collateral stores, indeed, have been neglected, and the memoir consequently assumes a completeness to which it is to be feared that few additions may be expected. The careful study given to the subject by the author leads him to the positive conclusion that "even to SHAKESPEARE, with his surpassing genius, his worldly wisdom, his prudence and his thrift, all culminating in a success which made him the mark of envy at the end, as he had been at the beginning of his career, life was unsatisfying. He returned to Stratford a disappointed man." The grounds for this conclusion must be sought in the biography. Other new views will be found in it, and ingenious applications of circumstances never before brought to bear in their full significance on the poet's life. The second portion of the work, entitled (it seems to us rather awkwardly) an Essay Toward the Expression of Shakespeare's Genius, is written from a good old English standpoint, and will be refreshing to those who have toiled through the German commentators, in the wild hope of condensing some substantial information from the fog-banks of verbiage that they raise around any subject they may discuss. The favorite catchwords "organic life," "objective," "subjective," &c., are never once made use of, we believe, nor can it be said that they are greatly missed. The author, indeed, avows "his abiding faith, which no criticism that I have yet seen has shaken, that most of those who read SHAKESPEARE worthily and lovingly, understand what he meant, as thoroughly as COLERIDGE did, or as GERVINUS does, with all their metaphysics and philosophy." To afford the means of judging SHAKESPEARE's merits as an writer and as a dramatist, and to explain intelligently the characteristics that distinguish him from others of the like pursuits, is the object of the essay. It is achieved, in a manner to please the great majority of readers. An Account of the Rise and Progress of the English Drama to the Time of Shakespeare, is a fitting introduction to the study of his writings, showing the normal condition of things around him; how far his works took form and color from his contemporaries, and how far they themselves advanced toward perfection a rude and unsharpened species of composition then in a lusty and struggling infancy. The account is naturally founded on, and in some measure coincides with, Mr. COLLIER's History of the Early Drama in England, but is the fruit of independent research, and the shape into which it is thrown renders it more inviting to the general reader than any previous statement of the facts has been, altogether, Mr. GRANT WHITE's volume is creditable to the taste, tact and intelligence of the writer, as much as its elegant outward form evinces the enlightened cooperation of his publisher. A few misprints and trifling errors may be detected by microscopic scrutiny, but it would be invidious to particularize them, in a volume that does honor to all concerned in it.

abstract: The King of Prussia and the Emperor or Austria are at present at Ischl. It is officially stated, that at the Salzburg Conference it was also agreed to between the Emperor of Austria and the King of Prussia, that the harbor of Kiel, although situated in Holstein, which is to be under Austrian administration, is to be occupied by Prussia. Austria and Prussia have also agreed to propose to the Federal Diet the construction of a German fleet.
lead_paragraph: The King of Prussia and the Emperor or Austria are at present at Ischl. It is officially stated, that at the Salzburg Conference it was also agreed to between the Emperor of Austria and the King of Prussia, that the harbor of Kiel, although situated in Holstein, which is to be under Austrian administration, is to be occupied by Prussia. Austria and Prussia have also agreed to propose to the Federal Diet the construction of a German fleet.

The force on that line has been promptly increased, and assistance is now available at the Greenwich and Washington streets crossings, and the main crossing at West-street has another officer added. The obstructions on the sidewalk will, we are assured, be attended to, and already a great improvement is discernible. We trust that the owners of the stores between West and Washington streets will instruct their subordinates to second the efforts of the police in regard to this latter matter, and that the subject need not be referred to again.

abstract: TROUBLE AT THE RAILROAD DEPOT. At 6 o'clock last evening Mr. H. DIEFFEBACH, of the firm of BALBACH, DIEFFENBACH  CO., owners of the smelting and refining works at No. 65 last Riverstreet, Newark, was arrested by officer CARROLL on ...
lead_paragraph: TROUBLE AT THE RAILROAD DEPOT. -- At 6 o'clock last evening Mr. H. DIEFFEBACH, of the firm of BALBACH, DIEFFENBACH CO., owners of the smelting and refining works at No. 65 last Riverstreet, Newark, was arrested by officer CARROLL on a charge of creating a disturbance at the entrance to the railroad depot in Jersey City, and attempting to strike the gate-keeper. For some months past gatekeepers have been stationed at the entrance to the depot, and all passengers are required to show their tickets before they are allowed to enter. To this rule the commuters demur, and sometimes attempt to force their way in, which case the case last evening, as well as on two or three evenings previous. Mr. DIEFFENBACH denies having made any assault on the gate-keeper, and when entering the gate, had his wallet in his hand to show his commutation ticket, when the crowd in the rear forced him forward, when he was seized and his shirt bosom torn, and was them arrested by the officer. He gave bonds to appear for examination.

abstract: Prof. Lowe's Excursions
snippet: Prof. Lowe's Excursions
lead_paragraph: Ballooning is a luxury few care to enjoy, and not many can afford. It costs a pile of greenbacks to go up in a balloon, and it requires great nerve and a love of danger to determine any one to venture in the slight and crazy-looking craft that is generally used to go sailing among the clouds. One need not say that those who go up in a balloon are as crazy as the machine that carries them, for usually those who do go up are anything but madmen. It is true that we have read in our time thrilling tales of the maniac aeronaut, who sought to gain a higher altitude by throwing overboard his no less maddened companion, but no one believes such romantic and terrific accounts now-a-days.

abstract: five months Record of
snippet: five months Record of
lead_paragraph: Writers upon American morals and manners have seldom failed to allude, in terms of reprobation, to the criminal disregard of human life, which as a nation we display. We are accused of valuing dollars more than the safety of our fellow men. We are taunted with a selfish nonchalance when the daily records of disasters and death are brought before us. The following statement is designed to bear upon this alleged feature of our national character. And if, after the perusal, the feeling of horror and shame does not possess the reader, the accusation is proved, the reprobation justified.

abstract: The reception of the Forty-Seventh New-York, (or as they prefer to be known, the Forty-seventh Brooklyn,) who arrived from Raleigh, N.C., on Sunday, was a brilliant affair.
lead_paragraph: The reception of the Forty-Seventh New-York, (or as they prefer to be known, the Forty-seventh Brooklyn,) who arrived from Raleigh, N.C., on Sunday, was a brilliant affair. During the morning the regiment fell in, and was exercised in what probably will be their last battalion drill, and the regiment performed the several evolutions with credit to themselves. At noon the command was dismissed for dinner, and enjoyed the good things spread for them by Mr. BAKER, with gusto. Among those present were the numerous friends and relatives of the veterans, who seemed to take a decided interest in the affair. Dinner being over they were again marched out to the square, and there rested until the arrival of the Eighth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., which escorted them up town at 3 o'clock. The Eighth turned out nearly 300 muskets, under command of Col. VARIAN, and were proceeded by ROBERTSON's bond, and looked remarkably well, as did also the veterans with their tattered flags. On their march up Broadway, the Forty-seventh were enthusiastically cheered by crowds of people who lined the street. At the City Hall they were reviewed by His Honor Mayor GUNTHER, after which they marched up Broadway to Fourteenth-street, and subsequently took the boat for Hart's Island, where they will be paid off and dispersed.

abstract: That Irish-French Yankee, Monsieur DION BOUCICAULT, seems to have been innoculated by our own BARNUM. The great showman is reported once to have said that the brand secret of his success was ...
lead_paragraph: -- That Irish-French Yankee, Monsieur DION BOUCICAULT, seems to have been innoculated by our own BARNUM. The great showman is reported once to have said that the brand secret of his success was "printers' ink," thereby meaning that, whatever might be said about virtue, advertising was certainly its own reward. BOUCICAULT, whose trashy chowder called "Arrah na Pogue" is now the main dish in theatrical entertainments all over the world, is every day advertising the play at Niblo's Garden, New-York; Metropolitan Theatre, San Francisco; and Theatre Royal, Melbourne, in the amusement column of the London Times; and he has also set afloat a paragraph to the effect that his "Pogue" is so distributed that it is being played from hour to hour, without cessation, from sunset to sunset again, (Sundays excepted,) the curtain going up in one place as it descends in another, from London westward to Botany Bay; in fact, that it takes the place of the British morning drum-beat, that once "circled round the world." BOUCICAULT is a shrewd fellow; he has had a great many ups and downs, and has sometimes found Jordan a hard road to travel; but he knows the usefulness of printers' ink, the beauties of the secession flag, and the value of the Confederate cotton loan.

CURTISS, late Receiving Clerk of the Eastern Department of the American Telegraph Company, died at his residence in Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon, after a short but severe illness. Mr. CURTISS has been well known by our merchants and the telegraphic community, since the first introduction of the telegraph into public use, as one of the most courteous, gentlemanly and affable persons with whom the patrons of the American Company have come in contact, and his pleasant countenance will be missed by thousands whose business passed through his hands.

abstract: A serious riot occurred yesterday afternoon, at the Battery Barracks, among the members of the Forty-seventh New-York Regiment, and some citizens who were passing by at the time. It appears that while the Forty-seventh were waiting for the steamer to take them to Hart's Island, some of the men, who were drunk got into a fight, and for a time the battle was a furious one. The officers endeavored to quell the riot, but had to call upon the guard on duty at the barracks before they succeeded. As the guard had their muskets loaded, their arguments prevailed, and the men surrendered, not however, before several people had been hurt.

abstract: Police, Detective, Cleverness of
snippet: Police, Detective, Cleverness of
lead_paragraph: The "working up" or the case of robbery committed upon one of the editors of the TIMES on Sunday last was extremely ingenious and highly creditable to the detective force. The robbery was committed at 3 o'clock in the afternoon at a public restaurant, and the waiter, that is, the culprit, was an entire stranger in the city, having but lately come here from Constantinople. Shortly after the commission of the deed, information of it was conveyed to Police Headquarters, and Chief JOHN YOUNG, with the sagacity and promptitude which have given him such a great reputation, at once detailed three of his best detective officers (Messrs. FARLEY, VAUGHAN and TIEMAN) to work up the case. The culprit had fled immediately upon committing the robbery, and there was hardly a clue of any kind by which he could be traced up. Nevertheless, so admirably did the detectives do their work, that in four hours from the commission of the crime, and after a search extending over miles of the city, both the thief and the $4,000 he had stolen were in the hands of the officers of justice. To the energetic action of Chief YOUNG, to the patience and faithfulness of Detective VAUGHAN, to the hard and vigorous search of Detective FARLEY, to the remarkable astuteness of Detective TIEMAN, (who finally secured the thief and his booty.) the fortunate result in this pretty [???] is [???]

abstract: Sinclair Tousey, et. al., vs. Nathan Hollister. -- This action was brought by plaintiffs to recover of the defendant the sum of about $84, for papers, periodicals, &c., sold and delivered. plaintiffs are news agents in this city, and defendant resides and does business in U[???] [???]u[???] County, in this State. A motion is now made by defendant to change the place of trial from this city to Oneida, on the ground of the convenience of witnesses, and also the further motion is made to preclude the plaintiffs from giving evidence as to the items of the account, on the ground that they had failed to serve a bill of particulars within the time prescribed by the code. On the part of the plaintiffs, it was claimed that they had thirty-eight witnesses resident in the city, who were necessary and material on the trial. As to the service of the bill of particulars, the fault was with the express company, by which they sent it to Saratoga Springs, to be verified by Mr. Tousey. The items of the account occupied one hundred and four pages, and it had taken a long time to prepare them after the notice was served. The court, after argument, denied the motion to change the place of trial, with costs.

abstract: Fu???iyama, frigate, Description and Departure; Onward Steamship; Officers of
snippet: Fu???iyama, frigate, Description and Departure; Onward Steamship; Officers of
lead_paragraph: Yesterday (Monday) the new steam corvette Fusiyama, Capt. F, HALLETT, sailed from the Battery for Japan, and will touch at Rio Janeiro, Cape of Good Hope, Hong kong, from whence she will proceed direct to the main naval depot of the Tycoon. This vessel was built for the Imperial Government of Japan, through an order of the American Minister resident in Japan, and with the consent of the United States Government, under the superintendence of Capt. JOSEPH J. COMSTOCK, by WESTERVELT & SON, of this city. She is 207 feet in length, 34 feet beam, and 15 feet depth of hold, and draws only 11 feet of water. She is brig rigged, and has a bowsprit, jib and flying jibboom, and in every respect is a war vessel of the first-class and speed, having made nearly 13 knots by actual measurement, under steam alone. It is a great pity that we are not possessed of some vessels like her, instead of the scores of slow tubs which are on our navy list.

abstract: Gov. Sharkey and State Militia
snippet: Gov. Sharkey and State Militia
lead_paragraph: of Mississippi has been traveling a little too fast in ordering, the organization of the State militia. It will be time enough to set about this part of the business of reconstruction when Mississippi has resumed her place in the Union. At present there is enough to occupy Gov. SHARKEY in the reestablishment of the civil machinery of the State. The military requirements of the hour will be fully met by Gen. SLOCUM's army. And by postponing the equipment of a local militia until Mississippi has her representatives in Congress, as formerly, all conflict of authority will be avoided. They can be no real friends of the State who present the temporary disability which this arrangement implies, as a political grievance. Mississippi has only the disbanded Confederate soldiers of the State, from whom she can fill up the militia ranks. It could hardly be either prudent or rational to put arms in the hands of these, until the national garrison is first relieved from duty.

abstract: a Five Months' Record of
snippet: a Five Months' Record of
lead_paragraph: Three thousand one hundred and eightyone persona lost their lives, and nine hundred and thirty-five other persons suffered bodily injuries by accidents, upon American railroads or steamboats, or by explosions of powder magazines or the fall of buildings, in America, during the period between the close of the war for the Union and the 31st ultimo -- just five months. These figures, supposing the whole year to present a similar record, would give a total of seven thousand six hundred and thirty-two deaths, and two thousand two hundred and forty-four persons wounded within the space of twelve months.

abstract: Many of our occasional correspondents write briefly and to the point. And they will bear witness that we do not begrudge them space. Some of our correspondents write well and sensibly, but at too great length. We have often to deny them admission to our columns solely for want of space. The remedy is in their own hands. We wish to hear from the people, whether they agree with us or not. But they must write briefly. That makes variety for those who don't, or who can't write, and it enables us to gratify our disposition to publish sensible communications from all quarters.

abstract: Draper's Thoughts on Future Policy of America; Politics of
snippet: Draper's Thoughts on Future Policy of America; Politics of
lead_paragraph: The title of this volume is apt to induce misapprehension as to the character and scope of the topics it discusses. It is no political manual; it advocates no particular theory of government, urges no special policy of legislation, proposes no plan of "reconstruction," and avows no opinion concerning "negro suffrage."

abstract: Hon. RICHARD BUSTEED, the Judge for the District of Alabama, and JAMES Q. SMITH, Esq., the Attorney for the same, reached Huntsville on the 5th for the purpose of organizing the Federal courts for that State. ED. E. DOUGLAS, of ...
lead_paragraph: Hon. RICHARD BUSTEED, the Judge for the District of Alabama, and JAMES Q. SMITH, Esq., the Attorney for the same, reached Huntsville on the 5th for the purpose of organizing the Federal courts for that State. ED. E. DOUGLAS, of Madison, having received the appointment of Marshal for the Northern District, has qualified and is now in office. JOHN H. KING, Esq., has been appointed Clerk of the Court and United States Commissioner. He will be ready to administer the amnesty oath by Friday. Each person has to subscribe to two oaths, one for himself and the other to be sent on to Washington to the Secretary of State. The cost will be $110 to each person. The records, papers, &c., of the United States and also of the Confederate Court for this district have been sent for. The Judge and Attorney proceed from here to Montgomery and Mobile, to organize the courts in the Middle and Southern Districts of Alabama. It will thus be seen that the Judicial machinery of the United States will soon be in operation in this State.

abstract: Anti-Monopoly Ice Company
snippet: Anti-Monopoly Ice Company
lead_paragraph: This company, whose offices are at No. 247 Broadway, has been formed to protect the citizens of New-York against the combinations and impositions of ice dealers. The organization is a joint stock one, the capital, $500,000, divided into 100,000 shares at $5 each. Parties who subscribe for the stock will be entitled to receive their supply of ice in each succeeding season, at the actual cost of ice and delivery, as follows, viz.: I share will entitle the holder to receive 10 pounds per day, 2 shares will entitle the holder to receive 25 pounds per day, 4 shares will entitle the holder to receive 50 pounds per day, 6 shares will entitle the holder to receive 100 pounds per day, 10 shares will entitle the holder to receive 500 pounds per day, 15 shares will entitle the holder to receive 1,000 pounds per day, 20 shores will entitle the holder to receive 1 ton per day, and 1 ton for every additional 20 shares.

abstract: Registry Law, The Annual Democratic Shriek Upon
snippet: Registry Law, The Annual Democratic Shriek Upon
lead_paragraph: Democratic papers in this State are opening in the usual annual form upon the Registry Law. That law has already prevented a great deal of illegal voting, and by just about the same extent the Democratic majorities in their strongholds have fallen off. Last session the law was amended, mainly with a view to prevent obstruction at the polls, so as to require voters to be absolutely registered before the day of election. In reality this provision shuts off a crowd of latter-day saints who were too busy to get registered, or had some other convenient excuse, but who regularly came to the polls to swear in their votes. A great many of them were not entitled to vote, but in the hurry and bustle of the poll they took the oath which they dared not venture before the cooler scrutiny of a Board of Registry. The Democratic wrath at the choking off of these useful citizens is most furious. With characteristic effrontery they denounce the law as "unconstitutional," and quote the qualifications for voters as being all the constitution says upon the subject. They know well enough, as they quote the first two sections, that the fourth section of the same article says : "Laws shall be made for ascertaining, by proper proofs, the citizens who shall be entitled to the right of suffrage hereby established." We do not look for honesty in arguments against a Registry law; but when they quote from the constitution, they might at least remember that others also can read that document, and that there are a great many good citizens who distinctly remember that the words we have quoted were put in the constitution expressly to give the power which these brazen fellows say does not exist.

abstract: Paris Debats on the Mexican Question
snippet: Paris Debats on the Mexican Question
lead_paragraph: -- The Paris Debats, a journal always friendly to the Union, in recently discussing our relations with the Mexican Empire, quoted from an English organ the remark that "the vulnerable point of the United States is the South; the South, during the civil war, would have asked for nothing better than to make an alliance with the Mexican Empire, and with France who protects it; and even at the present moment, although the war is virtually terminated, nothing would be easier than to rekindle it, for the South would rise again if it could reckon on our [French] assistance."

abstract: Staten Island; Holt Shot by Soldiers; Hoppel, a Boy, in Pitt-street
snippet: Staten Island; Holt Shot by Soldiers; Hoppel, a Boy, in Pitt-street
lead_paragraph: MURDER ON STATEN ISLAND. -- For some days past, two soldiers have been noticed loitering about New Brighton. On Sunday evening, about 8 o'clock, as these soldiers were passing Richmond Terrace, New-Brighton, they fired two shots at a young man named JOHN HOLT, a carpenter by trade, and a mother's only son. One ball was sent through his temple and lodged in his brain, the other took effect in his shoulder. He was alive on Monday morning at 5 o'clock, but the doctor could render him no possible assistance. A second doctor was called to aid the Buffering young man if possible. Immediately after the man was shot, several of the neighbors saw the soldiers move slowly off from the murdered man seemingly quite unconcerned. They entered the woods and concealed them selves there. Hundreds of men in the neighborhood are scouring the woods, and the ferries are guarded on all sides. So excited are those in pursuit of the two murderers, that report says they will be shot down at sight. It is said there was no provocation for the murder; that HOLT was unknown to the soldiers, and they to him. The murder is pronounced purely a wanton outrage.

abstract: N. Y. Remarkable Escape from; New-York; Ninth-avenue and Twenty-fourth-street
snippet: N. Y. Remarkable Escape from; New-York; Ninth-avenue and Twenty-fourth-street
lead_paragraph: Ever since tho murder of Policeman THOMAS WALKER, Captains HEDDEN, of the Sixteenth Precinct, and SPEIGHT, of the Twenty-ninth, have kept keen eyes on the porter-house loungers and frequenters of brothels that infest the Sixteenth Ward, and the result has been that the police have forced the banditti to observe extreme caution in their movements. Yesterday morning, however, the gang ventured forth in quest of game, and found Mr. BARTHOLOMEW FOLEY, of No. 104 West Twenty-eighth-street, asleep on a stoop at the southwest corner of Twenty-fifth-street and Sixth-avenue, and, not perceiving Officer JOHN H. MCCARTY, who was concealed near by, they undertook to "go through" Mr. FOLEY, when Officer MCCARTY sprang upon THOMAS SHANNON, the leader of the gang, and gave the signal rap for aid. SHANNON, resolved to escape if possible, dealt Officer MCCARTY a blow on the head but did not stun him, and MCCARTY, instantly resuming the attack with his baton, brought the fellow to terms before the arrival of Officers KENNEDY, DAVIS and MCGOWAN. The latter, reaching the scene of conflict before the gang had attempted to fly, captured JAMES FLEMING and FRANCIS COYLE, and the trio were bundled off to Jefferson Market Police Court, and there, nothwithstanding their protestations of innocence, committed to prison without permission to send for bail. SHANNON is 21 years of age, FLEMING 22, and COYLE 30.

abstract: House Question, the, in Philadelphia
snippet: House Question, the, in Philadelphia
lead_paragraph: of Philadelphia for people of limited means are vastly superior to those of New-York. Yet house-building is being carried on in Philadelphia with the utmost activity, and on a scale to which we can show no parallel. "At the northern end of the Tenth-street Railroad," says the North American, "some six squares of dwellings are in process of construction, and in all parts of the city new houses are to be seen going up." It seems they are not afraid in Philadelphia that the value of their property will be adversely affected by a return to specie payments. Such a fear in this city is absurd. Even at the value of our currency to-day, thousands of houses could be built that would yield handsome returns if we had specie payments to-morrow. The people of New-York are continually getting into greater straits for want of house accommodation, and capitalists are missing the finest opportunities for profitable investment.

abstract: THE SOLDIERS' PROTECTIVE UNION. -- A meeting of veterans, heretofore belonging to different regiments, was held at SAWYER & THOMPSON's Hall, corner of Fulton-avenue and Jay-street, last night. The object was to form an association with the view of protecting soldiers and procuring employment for such as required it Col. HEMSTREET presided, and addresses in favor of the object of the association were made by Gens. CROOKE and PRATT. Resolutions were passed in favor of the soldiers, and pledging themselves to oppose any man for office who did not pledge himself to their interests.

abstract: English and American
snippet: English and American
lead_paragraph: agricultural organ, the Mark-lane Express, of the 21st ult., in its weekly review, gives a gloomy view of the prospects of the British corn-trade at that date, and adds: "Foreign accounts too much agree with our own as to defective and injured crops, to give much expectation of a return to very low prices. France, Belgium, Holland, Germany, some parts of Russia and Southern Europe, all tell the same tale, and prices generally have risen." The same authority judges from "Western failure and Southern discontent," that the United States will be a very uncertain dependence for breadstuff's in case of extremity. The Express is mistaken as to the crop prospects of the United States. Taking the whole country through, the yield of wheat will be very large, and the corn crop will be enormous. We shall be able to furnish England, and all Europe all the breadstuffs they need, at fair prices, and the appearances now are that they will take all we give.

abstract: Cor. TIMES on
snippet: Cor. TIMES on
lead_paragraph: The sickening effluvia arising from these establishments has been the subject of complaint for many years past, longer, perhaps, than the " oldest inhabitant" can remember. Neighboring cities have compelled the owners of such establishments to close them up, and this has hitherto appeared to be the only remedy for the nuisance. It seems, however, from the following communication, that an apparatus can be constructed for neutralizing or retaining the odors arising from the bones and fat and that an establishment fitted with such a contrivance gives out no effluvia unpleasant to the smell or prejudicial to health. Of course, it is not to be expected that bone boilers and fat melters will avail themselves of such an apparatus, however trifling its cost, until they are compelled to do so, and it, therefore, remains tor our city authorities to give them the choice of removing their establishments altogether, or of adopting the expedient referred to or some similar one:

abstract: At the last meeting of the United States Soldiers' and Sailors' Protective Society, it was resolved to give 5,000 free tickets of admission to the unemployed, destitute or disabled soldiers, and also to the widows and children of the brave men who have died for their country. Those tickets are daily delivered, between 9 and 4 o'clock, until Monday, including Sunday, by applying at the office of the Metropolitan Employment Agency, No. 136 Canal-street, and presenting the discharge, pension or other official papers of the deceased. The tickets of admission for the public, which are at fifty cents each, admitting one lady and gentleman, may be obtained at the above office, and also at all the principal hotels and public places. It is expected that the congratulation feast, which it is believed will be honored by the presence of some of our most illustrious Generals, will be a monster affair, and result in much good to the unemployed veterans.

abstract: Leschot's Annular Drill
snippet: Leschot's Annular Drill
lead_paragraph: We were present yesterday at a series of experiments with the newly invented annular drill, for blasting and mining purposes. To say that the tests applied were successful, is to say all that is necessary; but our readers may not know exactly what the annular drill is, so we will explain. The term "annular (or circular) describes the manner of cutting the rock by diamonds, firmly set in the edge of a tubular crown or cylinder with a rotary and direct forward movement, cutting a circular groove, destroying but little of the rock, and leaving a core which is easily removed. When applied to the stone and set in motion, a stream of water is turned on and the thing is complete. With very moderate power this drill will bore three inches per minute, and can be made to bore two inches every minute of the day's work. Diamonds are the hardest of all known substances, and have been used for cutting other stones, like the onyx, sapphire, &c., from the earliest dates. More recently they have been found to be the most efficient and successful cutting instrument for dressing Burr millstones, but it has remained for modern engineering science to develop their highest practical value. In 1860 M. RODOLPH LESCHOT, a civil engineer of Geneva, Switzerland, resident in Paris, undertook a series of experiments for the purpose of discovering some method of perforating rock with more rapidity than can be accomplished in the usual method by percussion. After repeated trial he found the diamond the only substance with which he could arm his cutting tool so as to enable him to attack the hardest rocks, like granite and porphyry, with success. Patents having been granted the inventor in the United States the Annular Drill Company of New-York, became the proprietors, and have had a steam machine in operation for more than three months past. Granite, gneiss, North River blue stone, sandstone and marble have been pierced with remarkable success.

abstract: graph on Secretary MCCULLOCH's highly creditable exhibit of the public debt, the leading and only editorial article -- over a column, and such a column! in length -- in a morning journal of Monday, was on "Social Epidemics," the burden of which was a sketch of the history of the tulip mania in Holland two centuries ago, and of the "Morus multicaulis * * * epidemic in this country about thirty years ago" -- subjects which, according to our longitudinal cotemporary, commend themselves "to the philosopher, and the statesman, and the Christian." We sincerely hope that this thrilling appeal will not overwhelm the enlightened readers of the enterprising journal.

abstract: Aliens and Rate of Mortality; City Inspectors and their Work, a ten years' Review of
snippet: Aliens and Rate of Mortality; City Inspectors and their Work, a ten years' Review of
lead_paragraph: Death is always an interesting, if not an attractive subject. The doctor, the nurse and the undertaker come to all of us at last -- unless we suffer railway martyrdom, in which case the doctor and the nurse are of little account. Long familiarity with this teeming city, and some considerable acquaintance with its internal economy, or rather lack of economy, have awakened in us an interest concerning the way the people die, as well as how they live, and have impelled us to make a brief examination of the history and doings of that now immense branch of the city government which is directly charged with our sanitary security -- the City Inspector's Department. We have gone rapidly over the official reports of that department for the past ten years; we have carefully sought to find therein some practical results from the vast expenditures incurred by the City Inspector, but really cannot find anything like satisfaction. We know that a great many valuable suggestions from the department have been ignored by the Common Council; yet we are sure that much might have been done that has been neglected, had the department been devoted less to partisan politics and more to public health. With this brief introduction we proceed to a review of the annual reports; for the past ten years:

abstract: This accident, which occurred during the fog on Monday morning, appears to have been greatly exaggerated. The Bridgeport left her dock at 11 o'clock on Sunday night to come to this city. Just after passing Hurl Gate, the fog being quite thick, the speed of the boat was slackened. When off the dry-dock the engines were stopped, as the fog was too dense to run with safety. There was a strong flood-tide at the time, and upon consultation, the Captain decided to make some one of the docks, as it was not safe to drift with the tide into the track, perhaps, of ferryboats crossing the river. Accordingly, the engines were again started, and sufficient speed was attained to give the boat steerage-way. In a few moments a vessel was discovered by the lookout, the engines reversed, and just as the boat was backing she collided with the Margaret Evans. The shock was not very severe, and some of the passengers did not learn of the occurrence until they reached the dock. The damage to the vessel is comparatively slight, and can be repaired, it is thought, for $300. The steamer sustained no injury. The accident may be considered, under the circumstances, to have been unavoidable.

abstract: THINK OF IT! -- The New-York correspondent of the London Times lets fall a sentence in his last letter which may well cause every American to blush, and ask, in the language of the olden time, "Can these things be?" The sentence to which we allude succeeds one which enumerates the opinions of a "large class of Northern society," to the effect that the war was unjust; the South was right in seceding; the constitution has been violated; slavery is not abolished, &c., &c., and is as follows: "A very large section of the party called Democratic, which aspires to rule the next elections, and which seems likely to do so, maintaining these opinions."

abstract: Recorder, and Gov. Fenton's Summons
snippet: Recorder, and Gov. Fenton's Summons
lead_paragraph: CORD. -- Recorder HOFFMAN, in a letter published yesterday, declines to respond to the summons of Gov. FENTON, and asserts that he has no right to demand his appearance for trial before him. He tells him that he can present his charges against him to the State Senate, if he pleases, and that he will, when called upon, make his defence before that body; but he is not bound to pay any heed to the simple summons of the Governor himself. Mayor GUNTHER on the other hand, is very impatient for an opportunity to defend himself. He cannot, with any regard for his peace of mind, wait until the 26th inst. He fears the effect upon his constitution, or his character, of being compelled to rest under such charges as the Governor prefers, for such a "cruel and unnatural length of time." We suggest that he go to the Recorder for counsel and consolation, and if his health should suffer, or his strong mind give way, under the infliction, let him apply to the City Inspector. But if the Recorder is right, we don't see how the Mayor's request can possibly be granted.

abstract: New-York Census, Health and Mortality; Mortality of City Inspector's Report for Ten Years
snippet: New-York Census, Health and Mortality; Mortality of City Inspector's Report for Ten Years
lead_paragraph: We print elsewhere an elaborate review of the annual reports from the City Inspector's Department for several years past, quoting therefrom the most important facts and recommendations from time to time set forth. Appended to this sketch we give a complete return of deaths for a series of years, showing especially a great proportion of infant mortality. For the current year we give the deaths in each week up to Monday last; the whole number, the number of adults and children, and of children under one year of age. It will be seen that the total is a little less than last year, and nearly the same as in 1863; that is, the mortality for the first eight months of the past three years has been about the same in each period. At this rate the annual total will be about say 25,000.

abstract: THE FORTH-EIGHTH VETERAN REGIMENT VOLUNTEERS -- THEIR COOL RECEPTION IN BROOKLYN. -- The Forty-eighth Veteran Regiment which was raised in Brooklyn, four years ago, by Rev. Mr. PERRY, of the Fleet-street Methodist Church, assisted by Mr. LUTHER B. WYMAN, a distinguished citizen of this city, arrived home yesterday. Mr, WYMAN and his lady received them on the part of the citizens, and when the regiment passed through the City Hall Park they were reviewed by Lieut. CHARLES SCHURIG and two reporters. The Lieutenant was a member of the Fourteenth Regiment Militia, and served three years, during which time he lost his arm. He now occupies the position of Mayor's messenger, and as such represented the city. Supervisor SAMUEL BOOTH was also present, and that ends the list of either city or county officials. The regiment departed from Brooklyn about 1,100 strong, and after being recruited on several occasions to make up for losses in battle and by disease, comes back 800 strong, and as fine a looking set of men as ever shouldered a musket. They participated in the battles of Pocotaligo, Morris Island, the siege of Fort Wagner, Pulaski, Olustee, Chester Heights, in Virginia, Drewry's Bluff, Coal Harbor, Petersburgh, Deep Bottom, Strawberry Plains, Explosion of the Mine at Petersburgh, Cemetery Hill, Chapin's Farm, Fort Gilmore, New-Market Road, Fort Fisher and Wilmington. The regiment left Raleigh, N.C., on the 2d of September, and arrived here yesterday. Dodworth's Band, hired at the expense of Mr. L.B. WYMAN, furnished the music in their march through the streets of the city, and they were provided with lodgings for the night in the Armory of the Fifty-sixth Regiment, Raymond-street. They doubtless had their own rations, as nothing was provided for them.

abstract: The Wirz trial was resumed yesterday. Several witnesses testified to the cruelties practiced by Capt. WIRZ, and confirmed the evidence previously given of the bad treatment and distressing mortality among our prisoners. Among the witnesses examined in the afternoon was FRANK MATTOX, a negro soldier, who testified as to the cruelties he had seen, including the lashing on the bare body of some of the prisoners of his own color. He said that Capt. WIRZ, while in the grave-yard, remarked that they had given the Yankees the land they came to fight for, meaning the ground in which they were buried.

abstract: THE HUBBUB ABOUT THE CENSUS. -- The other day our Board of Supervisors, viewing the official figures of the census returns as a sorry show indeed, compared to what was expected, threw themselves into a state of mingled rage and disappointment, and asked Mr. Secretary of State DEPEW to have the work of taking the census done over again. In a letter, published in another column, it will be seen that Mr. DEPEW, without having taken offence at the unjust imputations, or, to say the least, the grossly unpleasant tone of the missive, kindly enlightens these, indignant county officers on the law and the facts.

abstract: The Scotia brings news from Europe to the 27th ult. The papers are occupied with the cholera, the cattle disease and the Atlantic telegraph. Vessels arriving at Venice from Marsoilles are to be subject to quarantine regulations. All vessels arriving at Genoa from Gibraltar and French Mediterranean ports are subjected to seven days' quarantine.
lead_paragraph: The Scotia brings news from Europe to the 27th ult. The papers are occupied with the cholera, the cattle disease and the Atlantic telegraph. Vessels arriving at Venice from Marsoilles are to be subject to quarantine regulations. All vessels arriving at Genoa from Gibraltar and French Mediterranean ports are subjected to seven days' quarantine. The Board of Health at Lisbon declares the ports of Gibraltar and Greece to be infected with cholera. The Moldo-Wallachian Government has established quarantine regulations for vessels arriving at Galatz from the ports of Turkey. Vessels having performed five days' quarantine in the Dardanelles, and not having had any case of cholera on board, will not be subject to quarantine at Odessa. The cattle disease is spreading over England, though the measures taken for its suppression seem to have lessened it in some localities. There is naturally serious alarm in Ireland, which has become to a great extent a grazing country, and from which cattle to the amount of 8,000,000 are annually imported into England, large numbers of which are sent there to be fattened. To keep out the disease it is proposed to stop this importation. The friends of the Atlantic cable keep up stout heart, and are resolved to lay another wire next year. Continental news generally does not seem to be important. We learn from China that BURGWINE is still in custody, but the American Minister has again demanded his release, with the intimation that a refusal will be considered a casus belli. The Taeping rebellion appears to be extinguished. A severe typhoon had occurred in the vicinity of Hong-Kong, and several shipping casualties are reported. Intelligence from Japan states that affairs in that country were quiet.

The first of these designs has been accomplished.

abstract: A CALL FOR AN INCREASE OF THE POLICE FORCE. -- At a meeting of influential citizens of the Nineteenth Ward , held at the house of Victory Engine, Clymer-street, on Monday night, it was resolved to make an effort to have the police force of the Eastern District increased, and to that end a committee of leading citizens of the ward was appointed to wait on the Metropolitan Police Commissioners. The committee consists of Capt. W.B. Ostrom, Messrs. Eli Beard, H.B. Hodges, S.F. Shonnard, Robert Crowley and R.R. Prince. This action was deemed necessary in consequence of the many audacious burglaries that have been committed with impunity in the ward.

abstract: Where are our harbor police? The audacity of the dock thieves about the wharves of our city is such that it has become next to impossible to prevent their depredations at particular wharves when coffee and like merchandise are loaded. Yesterday while the barge Bullrush, belonging to the New-Jersey Lighteraga Company, was taking in a cargo of coffee at Pier No. 40 East River, three men, having concealed themselves in a boat under the dock, about noonday male an attempt to drag a sack of coffee into their boat from the deck of the vessel. Being observed by the Captain, he ran promptly and seized the sack. The thieves were in noways daunted, but maintained their hold, and in the struggle the bag of coffee went overboard, and was lost. The thieves slipped under he dock, and soon after made their escape across the river to Brooklyn. This is, we understand, the third sack of coffee lost by this company from their vessels within two weeks at the same pier. Cannot something be done to prevent these bold thieves from pursuing their vacation openly along our docks in broad daylight.

abstract: Mississippi Convention Repudiate the Right of; Convention; the Right of Secession Repudiated by
snippet: Mississippi Convention Repudiate the Right of; Convention; the Right of Secession Repudiated by
lead_paragraph: One of the most interesting questions relative to the Southern conventions is, whether they will positively repudiate or simply abandon the secession ordinances--in other words, whether they will discard the right of secession, or content themselves with merely giving up the secession attempt. Of course, they must do the latter, for it is inexorably forced by the triumph of the government. But the admission of the fact that secession is a failure is in itself no recognition that its principle is an error. President JOHNSON, in his reconstruction plan, requires but two conditions -- an abandonment of slavery, and an oath to support the Constitution of the United States. He makes no account of the fact that it has been claimed that this constitution itself does not exclude the right of peaceable secession. He exacts no pledge that any particular construction of the constitution shall be accepted; and in no way does he insist upon any abjuration of the false constitutional doctrines upon which the rebellion rested its justification before the world. He leaves that for the Southern States to do of their own accord, if they so please. The work of reconstruction which occupies him is a business of facts, not theories; and it was wisdom in him to confine himself to a practical restoration of the South, irrespective of any speculative ideas which the South might still hold in reserve.
headline: {'main': 'Repudiation of the Right of Secession-- The Mississippi Convention.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Repudiation of the Right of Secession-- The Mississippi Convention.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- This popular establishment will reopen to-night, under the direction of Mr. W. STUART. The first "star" of the season is Mr. J.S. CLARKE, whose success in the pieces "Everybody's Friend" and the "Toodles," has justified their revival for the moment. We are glad to notice that, apart from the attraction of Mr. CLAREE, these somewhat over-worn dramas may still be made interesting to regular theatre-goers. Although Miss ROSE EYTINGE can do but little in so small a part as Mrs. Swandown, it is at least a promise of better things that her name is in the bill. No young artist of late times has earned so honestly the right to public consideration as Miss EYTINGE. Her performances with the Wallack-Davenport combination were in many respects remarkable, and displayed a progress which true artistic enthusiasm only could have achieved.

abstract: Educating Boys for Merchant Service; The Need of
snippet: Educating Boys for Merchant Service; The Need of
lead_paragraph: The captains of our merchant ships are daily appealed to by promising young lads who are anxious to make a voyage to sea, with a view of learning to become professional seamen. Of late the number has increased so rapidly as to create quite a sensation along our docks, but a majority of the captains have no power or authority to ship these lads, and many of them feel a delicacy in referring them to the ship-owners, feeling almost certain the applicant will be refused.

abstract: Parkes, Joseph, of London
snippet: Parkes, Joseph, of London
lead_paragraph: Few figures were better known in Pall Mall, and about the Houses of Parliament, than that of Mr. JOSEPH PARKES. He belonged to the Liberal side in politics, and in the midst of his party held a position of considerable influence. Few men in a secondary position were more trusted than he, few had a larger circle of friends, few were more completely in the current and full tide of political life. He had in his day been an ardent political soldier; he had entered with all his heart into the battle for reform, and from that time forward he held in the great Whig army a place, if not of command, yet of trust and influence. Perhaps no man was better acquainted than he with the secret history of politics during the last 30 or 40 years. Latterly, he was an important link of connection between the steady-going Whigs and the swifter-going Radicals. He was on the most intimate terms with every section of the Liberal party. He was not only an earnest politician, he was an excellent lawyer: and he had literary tastes, faculty and ambition. Any one who, without knowing him, saw him two or three times in the Reform Club, or slouching along Pall-mall, slightly bent with years, would soon discover what manner of man he was. He seemed to know every second person he met, and not only to know him but to be on confidential terms with him, and to have something particular to say to him. He always seemed to have somebody by the buttonhole, and to be engaged in secret conclave. There was a question to be put, or a question to be answered, and who so ready as Mr. PARKES? If anybody on his side of politics wanted information whether of the past or of the present, Mr. PARKES was the man to apply to. If he could not at once give it he could get it. So people clung about him, and he was a most useful man in his party -- useful not only because he was so well informed and had such a wide circle of friends, but also because his judgment was of the soundest, and he was ever active and loyal in offices of friendship. What was particularly pleasant about him was that to the craft of a good politician he united the blunt sincerity of a frank, honest, kindly man. JOSEPH PARKES was born at Warwick on the 22d of January, 1796. He went to a school at Worcester, and afterwards to the Glasgow University; but in his general reading Dr. PARR, who took a great interest in him, directed his studies and recommended a course to which he rigidly adhered. His reading in this course was of the widest range, and comprehended many works that lie quite out of the beaten path. He chose his path in life as a solicitor, and saving gone through a course of training of the highest kind, started in Birmingham first by himself, and afterward in partnership with Mr. SOLOMON BRAY, the first Town-clerk of the Corporation of Birmingham. At the time of the Birmingham Political Union, Mr. PARKES was adviser to Mr. ATWOOD, the leader of that movement. He did not quite approve its tendency, but at a later period in the tumult of the Reform agitation he and some forty or fifty others who had hitherto held aloof joined it, and thenceforward he took a prominent part in its proceedings. He thus became acquainted with Mr. EDWARD ELLICE, a most active member of Lord GREY's Ministry; he became a political agent of the party, and he had a great deal to do with its election business. This necessitated his removal to London in 1832, where he practiced as solicitor and parliamentary agent till about the year 1850, when he was appointed Taxing Master to the Court of Exchequer, an office which he held till his death. These are the leading facts of his life. He died at his house in Wimpole-street yesterday afternoon, and will be much missed and widely regretted.

abstract: Free Schools for Whites; Poor Whites, Education for
snippet: Free Schools for Whites; Poor Whites, Education for
lead_paragraph: danger that the next generation of negroes in the South may be more intelligent and better educated than the great mass of the whites. So much public attention and effort are devoted to the former, and the latter seem left so entirely to their own resources, (which are scanty at best,) that such a result seems by no means impossible. The blacks, themselves, moreover, seem to be far more thoroughly alive to the value of mental culture than the poor class of Southern whites. They are showing a most admirable and praise-worthy interest in the schools provided for them, and are likely to profit by them very thoroughly.

abstract: SUPPOSED MURDER IN MULBERRY-STREET. -- Yesterday afternoon Mrs. CATHARINE GALLAGHER died at her dwelling in the rear of No. 190 Mulberry-street, from wounds which are supposed to have been inflicted by her husband, HUGH GALLAGHER. Dr. JOHN BEACH viewed the body, last evening, and found a deep incision near the lower jaw, and black and blue marks about the head and face. Coroner GROVER, having learned that on Monday night GALLAGHER beat his wife and locked her out of doors, ordered his arrest, and Officer FRANCIS SMITH was sent in quest of the accused, but at a late hour last evening no arrest had been made. An inquest is to be held, this morning, by Coroner GROVER.

abstract: JERSEY CITY COMMON COUNCIL PROCEEDINGS. -- At the meeting of the Common Council of Jersey City, last evening, a petition was received from D.S. SINCLAIR and others, setting forth the inconvenience experienced for the lack of access to the terminus of the Central Railroad of New-Jersey, except by way of New-York, and asking to have Hudson-street opened to the depot in the bay. The petition was referred to the Committee on Streets. A resolution was adopted providing for the payment of $500 per annum to each of the engineers of the steam fire-engines; also, appropriating the sum of $350 for furnishing the house of Hose Company No. 3. Alderman QUAIFE offered the following, which was adopted:

abstract: Old Families of the
snippet: Old Families of the
lead_paragraph: -- Those who happen to be familiar with the names of the prominent families of the Southern States, find the perusal of the frequently published lists of "Pardons asked for" and "Pardons granted" very instructive. In these lists are found not only the notable rebel Generals who acquired position during the late war, not only those men who were distinguished in political life in other days as members of Congress, State Governors, and so forth, but also the less known, though more powerful, representatives of the great leading families of society in nearly every Southern State -- families possessed of great landed properties, having great revenues, and with a social power and general influence for greater than were ever exercised by any other special class in any other part of this country. We see in great number the names of the ancient and proud Virginia families, who have inherited the soil of the Old Dominion ever since its first settlement by Englishmen. We see the names of the great lords of South Carolina, many of whom have never figured prominently either in politics or war, but who, nevertheless, had the influence as well as the wealth of lords. From other of the old States, as Georgia and North Carolina, we also see the names of the chief families; and from the newer States, bordering on the Gulf and on the Mississippi, the masters of the soil are found to turn up; and as they appear, many reminiscences of their history are recalled by those who have known of them in other days.
headline: {'main': 'THE OLD FAMILIES OF THE SOUTH', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE OLD FAMILIES OF THE SOUTH', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Military Services and Political Offices
snippet: Military Services and Political Offices
lead_paragraph: One of the things we earnestly hope will not be done in future political campaigns in which Generals are the candidates for public office, is the showing by one party that the candidate of the opposing party acted as a fool, a coward, or a charlatan during the war. There is not an officer of any grade who has not his enemies; and however great and valuable a soldier's services to the country may have been, there are men who always stand ready to slander him by imputations the most shameless; and the officer must have had a career remarkable indeed who has not done something or left something undone, who has not uttered some phrase while awake or mumbled some words while asleep, upon which malignancy could base a falsehood sufficiently plausible to find believers, and especially during a heated political campaign.
headline: {'main': 'Military Services and Political Offices.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Military Services and Political Offices.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Glencoe, Mo.; Andrews, Daniel, Terrible Confession
snippet: Glencoe, Mo.; Andrews, Daniel, Terrible Confession
lead_paragraph: DANIEL ANDREWS, Postmaster at Glencoe, Mo., was recently arrested for robbing a neighbor, and committed suicide in prison. Before doing so he wrote a confession, which stated, among other things, that he murdered a returned Californian, eight or ten years ago, for the purpose of securing his money, which amounted to about ten thousand dollars; that he had the murdered man buried at his own expense, many of the neighbors attending the funeral, and giving him credit for charity to the dead. He also informs his friends that since his appointment as Postmaster he had robbed the mails in search of money in many instances, and that he never lost an opportunity to appropriate letters intrusted to him with the information that their contents were valuable. The most shocking statement in the confession is, that he had been the means of killing two of his own children, and that he had meditated the murder of his wife, procuring a gun and loading it for that purpose only a few days before the date of the confession.
headline: {'main': 'A TERRIBLE CONFESSION.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A TERRIBLE CONFESSION.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: UNPROFITABLE CUSTOMERS. -- Two young men, WM.R. SEITZER and AARON CONOVER, from Little York, Huntington County, N.J., yesterday visited the saloon of W.H. MCLEAN, in the Central Park, corner Seventy-second-street and Fifth-avenue, They seemed to take great delight in annoying the proprietor with scurrilous observations respecting the quantity, quality and price of the refreshments furnished. After paying their bill and leaving, a lady seated at another table notified the proprietor that each of the young scamps had supplied himself with silver forks from their own and other table near them. They were followed by the proprietor, who returned with one fork given to him by CONOVER, who acknowledgement that he had taken it, but expressed great sorrow for his act. SEITZER denied having any forks, or knowing anything about them. They were then allowed to leave. Upon retailing to the saloon, the proprietor repeated what had been done, and what SEITZER said. The lady assured him that SEITZER had one or more of the forks in his breast pocket. Mr. MCLEAN returned in pursuit, accompanied by one of the Central Park Palace, and arrested both of the men, and their way back to the saloon, SEITZER said that the remaining forks were taken by other members of their party, who had taken their refreshments and left the saloon before he and CONOVER did, and if they would allow him to follow them he could get the forks and would immediately come back with them, and bring the rest of the company with him. He was allowed to leave, and in ten minutes returned with three of the stolen forks, which he said were given to him by the rest of the company. He was charged with having had the forks all the time in his own possession; but he denied it and said that the boys were on a rampage, and if the proprietor allowed him, he would bring back every man of his company who had been in the saloon, and they would acknowledge their offence and settle with him for his trouble. With this assurance the proprietor allowed SEITZER and CONOVER to depart in pursuit of their companions. As might have been expected they did not return. They claimed this to be the first time they ever visited the City of New-York. They certainly made a dis[???]table debut.

abstract: MEETING OF THE MARCUS L. WARD CLUB OF HOBOKEN. -- A meeting of the Marcus L. Ward Club of Hoboken was held last evening at Germania Hall, and was attended by some of the most prominent citizens of the city. The President, Mr. B.H. BALDWIN, occupied the chair, and Mr. ALBERT BOGERT acted as Secretary. Dr. GEMERT, of the German National Union Club, was elected Corresponding Secretary, and a motion adopted inviting the members of the National Club of Hoboken to attend and take part in the proceedings of this club. It was announced that Dr. MYER had accepted an invitation to stump the State amongst the Germans for MARCUS L. WARD. After the transaction of other business, the club adjourned to Wednesday evening next, when arrangements will be made for a grand mass meeting.

abstract: The Board of Education held their first Autumn meeting last meeting, at their hall in Canal-street, President MCLEAN in the chair. A communication was received from City Superintendent S.S. RANDALL, suggesting certain modifications in the rules governing evening schools, and a committee was instructed to make inquiry concerning the expediency of discontinuiug the detailed reports of the board's proceedings, which are printed in the Leader and Transcript at a cost of fifteen cents a line in each journal, or probably about $200 for each session of the board.

RANDALL, suggesting certain modifications in the rules governing evening schools, and a committee was instructed to make inquiry concerning the expediency of discontinuiug the detailed reports of the board's proceedings, which are printed in the Leader and Transcript at a cost of fifteen cents a line in each journal, or probably about $200 for each session of the board.

abstract: Camden vs. Keystone
snippet: Camden vs. Keystone
lead_paragraph: CAMDEN VS. KEYSTONE. -- The contest between these clubs on Tuesday, at Philadelphia, affords another striking illustration of the singular contrasts this season has afforded in base ball matches. The week previous the Empire Club defeated the Camdens by a score of 41 to 11, and yet the Keystone Club beat the Empires by a score of 45 to 15, and now the Camdens turn round and defeat the Keystones by a score of 45 to 20, which they did on Tuesday, and what is more, the Keystones had a stronger nine than in their match with the Empires. It shows how very uncertain a game base ball is. On Saturday the Camdens play their return match with the Athletics, and the contest bids fair to be a close one. The game will be played at 3 P.M. on the Athletic grounds, corner of Fifteenth-street and Columbia-avenue, Philadelphia. We give the score of this match below:

abstract: State Agency; Col. Collyer's Report
snippet: State Agency; Col. Collyer's Report
lead_paragraph: JOHN (his X mark) MULLIGAN and JOHN (his X mark) FAGAN, Mackerelville youths of 19 and 21 years respectively, both cart-drivers, were taken into custody on Monday night by Policemen MICHEL YAGER and BARNEY ENGERMAN, and yesterday morning Mr. ANTHONY SPRINGMAN, of No. 41 Sheriff-street, appeared against the prisoners and made affidavit that they had attempted to rob him. Mr. SPRINGMAN's affidavit recites that on Monday night he was walking in First-avenue with Mr. LAMPERT GRIEF, of No. 275 Avenue A, and when near Eighteenth-street FAGAN and MULLIGAN approached and the latter attempted to strike the deponent, who sprang back and thus avoided the blow, but fell into the hands of FAGAN, who seized him by the coat and strove to snatch his watch. After a struggle with the ruffians he released himself from their grasp, and he and Mr. GRIEF ran into a saloon near by, but were pursued by the robbers, and might have been robbed but for the interference of the landlord, who drove the fellows from his house and alarmed the Eighteenth Precinct Police, who captured MULLIGAN and FAGAN as above. Justice DODGE required each of the prisoners to find $1,500 bail, and in default committed them to answer at the Court of General Sessions.

abstract: Democrats, the, and New Issues
snippet: Democrats, the, and New Issues
lead_paragraph: The Democratic organs inform us that their party will ride no dead horses; will fight with no spent weapons; will turn their backs upon past issues, and go into its coming campaigns on great, living interests. They parade this intention as if it were something very meritorious -- a piece of self-abnegation that ought to be worth to the party a good many thousand votes. It is hardly worth while to smile at this Falstaffian assumption of magnanimity -- this cheap virtue of dropping all scandalous bygones, for the public good.

abstract: London Times (Cor.) on Hostility to England
snippet: London Times (Cor.) on Hostility to England
lead_paragraph: The new correspondent of the London Times writes to that journal, that the predominant feeling in the United States toward England, is one of hostility,--and he sets forth, at length, and with clearness and force, some of the causes to which this feeling is due. Prominent among them, -- indeed paramount in influence, -- is the course pursued toward us during our civil war. The Times devotes an editorial to showing that there is, in all this, no cause for war, -- and that it would be a folly and a crime to plunge the two nations into war for any such reason.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. The season opened at this establishment last night under the most brilliant auspices, Mr. CLARKE'S reception was a perfect ovation, and so significant in its enthusiasm as to prevent him for a considerable time from proceeding with the business of the stage.
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- The season opened at this establishment last night under the most brilliant auspices, Mr. CLARKE'S reception was a perfect ovation, and so significant in its enthusiasm as to prevent him for a considerable time from proceeding with the business of the stage. When we were permitted, from the fervor of his reception, to calmly judge the merits of his performance, we have simply to say, what we have had so often occasion to state, that as Major De Boots he evoked, from the rising to the falling of the curtain, incessant bursts of laughter; and that he seemed, catching inspiration from the triumph of his reception, to have imparted to his personation oven more vim and force than usual. It was a matter of general regret that that charming young actress, Miss ROSE EYTINGE, was prevented by sudden indisposition from appearing in the role of Mrs. Swansdown. Miss ALICE GREY, a stranger to our boards, who in consequence undertook the part at a few moments' notice, filled it very creditably. Of the new appearances, we can congratulate the management on securing in Mr. W.S. ANDREWS, (a young United States officer,) one who can at least talk and walk as a gentleman, and not exhibit himself, as is general in such characters, as a fantoccini figure. The same bill will be repeated to-night, and, we presume, for many nights to come.

abstract: DESCENT OF A BALLOON. -- Last evening, about 6 o'clock, a balloon containing two or three men passed over Cypress Hills Cemetery, close to the ground and apparently with the intention of landing beyond the boundaries of the grave-yard. The men in the basket used their grappling irons very vigorously, and soon made fast to the earth, landing a little beyond the Cemetery, and as far as known in a safe and sound condition. The balloon is supposed to be that of Prof. LOWE, which started from Central Park, New-York.

abstract: Matters were better arranged at the pension-office, in the Custom-house building, yesterday, although, at best, the arrangements for paying the numerous applicants for pensions are not what they should be. Roundsman CONNOR, of the First Precinct, and three patrolmen, have been detailed to keep the crowd in order, and permit each person to come up in turn. Yesterday the number of applicants was quite as great as on the opening day, but the business was transacted with more promptness, although a still greater celerity might readily be introduced.

abstract: Jaudon vs. Gray; Stockholders' Notice
snippet: Jaudon vs. Gray; Stockholders' Notice
lead_paragraph: Bainbridge Jaudon et al vs. Morgan Gray. -- The plaintiffs in this action are stock brokers in this city. They brought the action against the defendant to recover an amount of money growing out of certain stock transactions under the following circumstances: On the 21st of March, 1864, defendant deposited with plaintiffs $2,500, and directed them to purchase and carry for him 200 shares Erie Railway stock, which order plaintiffs executed for $125 3/4 a share. Shortly afterward defendant left town, and did not return till the 25th April following. In the meantime the stock had fallen to 108. On the 16th of April, and during the absence of the defendant, plaintiffs sent a written notice to defendant, addressed to him at his place of business in this city. In this notice defendant was called on for a further margin, and he was furthermore informed, that if he failed to furnish the funds required, plaintiffs would sell out his stock. Not hearing from him within a reasonable time, the plaintiffs sold out his stock at the Brokers' Board. When defendant returned, he at once repudiated the sale, and demanded the stock, which the plaintiffs refused to deliver. The complaint of plaintiffs further demanded the amount of money lost in making the sale above referred to.

abstract: Currency the, and Clearing-house System
snippet: Currency the, and Clearing-house System
lead_paragraph: One of the Opposition papers continues exceedingly anxious to disturb the National Currency system through some sort of Clearing House legislation. It is difficult to know what this paper or the few discontented spirits in the New-York Clearing House would be at, if not malicious mischief. As however they profess higher motives, there can be no objection to reminding the public that, on the merits of their proposition, they have been once voted down in all the Clearing Houses of the three cities. In New-York, with the aid of some six or eight of the old local banks, which are suffered to remain in the Clearing House after voting against accepting the National System, and by excluding about the same number of original National Banks, they were able to muster a respectable minority. But the proposition was nevertheless promptly tabled here; -- almost unanimously tabled in Philadelphia, and quite unanimously silenced in Boston. We may add by the way that three of the local Presidents in New-York, the open and declared enemies of the National System, now and from the start, were on the Committee to prepare this proposition for legislating outside the Act of Congress and through their own Clearing House, in place of appealing to Congress to remedy the defects of what they call the redemption features of the act.
headline: {'main': 'The National Currency.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The National Currency.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Wright, Brig.-Gen. George, U. S. Vols
snippet: Wright, Brig.-Gen. George, U. S. Vols
lead_paragraph: The death of Brig.-Gen. GEORGE WRIGHT, of the United States Volunteers, drowned on the 30th of July last, on the steamship Brother Jonathan, off the coast of Southern Oregon, deserves some more extended notice of his life and character than has yet appeared. He was a native of Norwich, Vt., born in 1803, and was, therefore, about sixty-two years of age. He graduated at West Point in 1822, and had previously graduated at Capt. PARTRIDGE's Military School at Norwich. He was commissioned Second Lieutenant in the Third Infantry, when first appointed into the army; was Adjutant from 1831 to 1836; was appointed Captain of Eighth Infantry July 7, 1838; was breveted a Major for good conduct in the Florida War, March 15, 1842; Lieutenant-Colonel for gallantry at Contreras and Cherubusco, Aug. 20, and Colonel for Molino del Rey, Sept. 8, 1847, where he was wounded; became Major of the Fourth Infantry Jan 1, 1848; Lieutenant-Colonel Feb. 3, 1855, and Colonel of the Ninth Infantry March 3, 1855. He performed important services in the Indian wars in Oregon and Washington Territories in 1856 and 1858. He was made Brigadier-General of Volunteers Sept. 28, 1861; was at one time Commander of the District of Oregon, and afterward Commanding-General of the Department of the Pacific. On the arrival of Gen. MCDOWELL at San Francisco, in June, 1864, he was placed in command of the District of California, with his headquarters at Sacramento. At the date of his death, he was en route to Fort Vancouver, W.T., to assume command of the new Department of the Columbia. It had just been created, embracing the State of Oregon and the Territories of Washington and Idaho.
