abstract: Soon after the persons accused of robbing the St. Albans banks and killing some of the citizens were discharged by Judge COURSOL, of Montreal, the Canadian Government ordered an investigation into the conduct of the Judge to be made by Mr. TORRANCE, a member of the Montreal bar of some ability and high personal character.
lead_paragraph: Soon after the persons accused of robbing the St. Albans banks and killing some of the citizens were discharged by Judge COURSOL, of Montreal, the Canadian Government ordered an investigation into the conduct of the Judge to be made by Mr. TORRANCE, a member of the Montreal bar of some ability and high personal character. The report of Mr. TORRANCE has just been published. He exonerates Judge COURSOL and Mr. LAMOTHE, the Chief of Police, by whose instrumentality the recovered money had so hastily been transferred to the friends of the prisoners from the imputation of corrupt and improper motives. He, however, holds that Judge COURSOL should be indicted for malfeasance in office in not reporting to the government. Judge COURSOL, in a correspondence with Mr. TORRANCE, defends his course by saying that he acted as judge, and not as justice of the peace, and was not bound to report to the government. In support of this position, the telegraph from the Attorney-General in reply to one from Judge COURSOL asking for instructions, is quoted, and is to the following effect: "As you are a judge, use your own discretion." No action has yet been taken on the suggestion of Mr. TORRANCE.

abstract: Perhaps the greatest trotting match which has taken place for a lengthened period, will come off at "The Fashion Course" to day, the weather being fine and the travel in good condition. The fame of the contraband General Butler and the pet of Long Island, Dexter, are alike patent to the trotting public. Their merits have been so often discussed, and have become so much a matter of fireside gossip, that at this late day it would be absurd to enter into a lengthened disquisition on the probabilities of the pending contest. All trotting men know what Butler has been and is -- as also that Dexter is de facto the coming horse of the present season. The records of the trotting turf of the current season show that Butler has been far from his former self. We care not to inquire too curiously why he has been out of condition, but we do know that never horse was stripped in more superb fettle than "the contraband" now is -- thanks to the watchful care which has been bestowed upon him for two months past. Dexter is equally in splendid fix, and there, can be no doubt but that with the confidence displayed on either side and the vast amount of money involved in the decision, but that the coming race will be one of the most keenly contested that has been witnessed for years. The conditions of the race are that both horses have the option of going as they please. Butler will of course accept his best gait, viz: under the saddle, whilst it is a received opinion that Dexter will be trotted in harness, with HIRAM WOODRUFF in the sulky. There will undoubtedly be lively times at the Fashion Course to-day.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the greatest trotting match which has taken place for a lengthened period, will come off at "The Fashion Course" to day, the weather being fine and the travel in good condition. The fame of the contraband General Butler and the pet of Long Island, Dexter, are alike patent to the trotting public. Their merits have been so often discussed, and have become so much a matter of fireside gossip, that at this late day it would be absurd to enter into a lengthened disquisition on the probabilities of the pending contest. All trotting men know what Butler has been and is -- as also that Dexter is de facto the coming horse of the present season. The records of the trotting turf of the current season show that Butler has been far from his former self. We care not to inquire too curiously why he has been out of condition, but we do know that never horse was stripped in more superb fettle than "the contraband" now is -- thanks to the watchful care which has been bestowed upon him for two months past. Dexter is equally in splendid fix, and there, can be no doubt but that with the confidence displayed on either side and the vast amount of money involved in the decision, but that the coming race will be one of the most keenly contested that has been witnessed for years. The conditions of the race are that both horses have the option of going as they please. Butler will of course accept his best gait, viz: under the saddle, whilst it is a received opinion that Dexter will be trotted in harness, with HIRAM WOODRUFF in the sulky. There will undoubtedly be lively times at the Fashion Course to-day.

abstract: For about two months past, a number of the members of this veteran corps have been busily at work recruiting for a militia regiment. So far their progress has been not only encouraging, but such as to make them perfectly certain of success. Company after company has been organized, till now seven companies are nearly full, and on Monday evening next, six of them are to mustered and inspected.

abstract: IRVING HALL. -- Mr. BATEMAN's attractive and important series of concerts will begin at this establishment on Monday evening. The presence of Mme. PAREPA -- one of the best singers we have heard in this city for many years -- insures their success in a musical point of view. Two other artists will, however, be introduced to the public -- Mr. DANNREUTHER, a Cincinnatian, and Herr CARL ROSA, from Hamburg. Both these gentlemen have been spoken of in terms of unusual eulogium, and much is necessarily expected at their hands.

lead_paragraph: Among the passengers by the Scotia were Sir MORTON PETO, Hon. ARTHUR KINNAIRD and son, and Mr. JAMES MCHENRY, of London. Mr. MCHENRY, if not the projector of the Great Atlantic Railway, is the gentleman under whose enterprising and efficient management it has been prosecuted to completion. Sir MORTON, also most enterprising, has invested largely in that and other improvements. These gentlemen go far West, via the Pennsylvania oil wells, visiting Cincinnati, St. Louis, Chicago, &c., &c., all of which is new to Sir MORTON and Mr. KINNAIRD.

abstract: Camden and Amboy; Collision; Nine Injured
snippet: Camden and Amboy; Collision; Nine Injured
lead_paragraph: About 8 o'clock yesterday morning a collision occurred between two trains on the Camden and Amboy Railroad, near Hightstown, which was very near being of a most serious character, but was fortunately unattended with loss of life. Our informant, who was himself considerably cut and bruised, states that the 6 o'clock Philadelphia passenger train reached Hightstown about 8 o'clock, and had not long left the station when the whistle of a train approaching round the curve was heard. The engineer of the passenger train signaled to brake up, and reversed the engine, and then, after waiting long enough to see the danger into which he had brought his passengers, jumped off, accompanied by the firemen. Their example was followed by the engineer and firemen of the freight train. Fortunately both trains were proceeding at a low rate of speed or the consequences would have been fearful. As it was, nearly every passenger in the Philadelphia train was thrown from his seat, men, women and children being piled in heaps on the floors of the cars. Intense excitement prevailed, many of the ladies and children being almost wild with terror, and those who were being smothered by the persons lying above them shrieking to their friends for help.

abstract: Officers
snippet: Officers
lead_paragraph: The annual convention of Wool manufacturers was held on Wednesday, in Philadelphia. Mr. JOSEPH L. HAYES, of Boston, Secretary of the association, read, an address upon the origin and progress of the woolen manufactures of the world. In the United States, he said that there had been a great increase in the num- ber of mills. By the census of 1860, there were in the country 3,319 sets of machinery. The association had received answers giving 4,073 sets, and 608 mills yet to be heard from. The returns of the internal revenue for 1864 show that scoured wool to the value of $,121,868,250 had paid a tax. During 1862, 1863 and 1864, over 200,000,000 pounds of wool had been used for the manufacture of cloth for army use alone.

abstract: Democratic State Convention--Copperhead Elements Repudiated
snippet: Democratic State Convention--Copperhead Elements Repudiated
lead_paragraph: The Democratic party of this State met yesterday at Albany and, after due deliberation and with great unanimity, surrendered, horse, foot and dragoons, to the Unionists and Republicans. The rebellion may now be deemed completely ended. LEE's surrender was not more absolute, nor more beneficial to the country. The political millenium is clearly close at hand. When the Democracy rejoice in the triumph of a war they have steadily opposed -- commend a policy they have resisted, and pledge support to men they have denounced, vilified and tried to defeat, there is little room left for party strife. The contest must be substantially over.
headline: {'main': 'The Democratic Convention Dissolving Views.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Democratic Convention Dissolving Views.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The regular monthly meeting of the Chamber of Commerce was held yesterday. It was resolved to appoint a committee of five to draw up a recommendation to Congress, to permit ten per cent. of the duties on foreign goods to be paid in legaltender notes. A committee was appointed to invite Mr. JOHN BRIGHT, M.P., to visit this country, and the Chamber then adjourned.

abstract: Census of Southern States necessary
snippet: Census of Southern States necessary
lead_paragraph: It will be exceedingly important to have a census of the Southern States at as early a day as possible. This is apparent on many considerations. How far the war, which has had its full course, has diminished the gross population -- what ages have suffered most from its ravages -- how far the natural increase of population has been affected by it -- in what sections of country the decimation of the white population has been most severely felt -- and what sections have increased in population as places of refuge from the scourge -- are all matters of practical account, to be learned or partially learned by an early census-taking. Reliable data by which to measure the practical working of emancipation would also be obtained. No general emigration from the North has yet taken place, nor any general stampede from the South. But some important shiftings of population must soon follow. If in 1870 some county of Virginia should be found depopulated of blacks, it would be important to know whether this was the effect wholly or partly of the war, or did not begin until peace was restored. Many of the emancipated settlers will then be found in the Sea Islands in South Carolina. But we shall wish to know whether they have grown more numerous or less so with the cessation of war, as well as how emancipation has affected the race in special localities.
headline: {'main': 'A Census of the Southern States.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Census of the Southern States.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There are two hundred and fifty thousand freedmen in Louisiana. The census of 1860 gave a slave population of about three hundred thousand. This number has been reduced by various causes. abstract: THE ROOMS OF THE YOUNG MEN's CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION. -- The rooms of the Young Men's Christian Association of Brooklyn, located on the corner of Fulton-avenue and Gallatin-place, were opened lasl evening. An immense audience was present. Mr. WM. EDSALL, the president, occupied the chair, and addresses were made by Rev. H.W. BEECHER, Rev. THEO. L. CUYLER, and others. There was also vocal and instrumental music -- the piano being furnished by Messrs. SAWYER & THOMPSON. The rooms are elegantly fitted up and capable of accommodating not only the association, but others who desire to attend their meetings.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latent and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Strenuous efforts are about being made by some of our ship-owners to again obtain possession of the ships which they sold and transferred to foreign flags during the war.
lead_paragraph: Strenuous efforts are about being made by some of our ship-owners to again obtain possession of the ships which they sold and transferred to foreign flags during the war. It must be borne in mind that by these sales and transfers we lost over a thousand vessels of all classes, which represented over a half million of tons. At the present time a majority of these vessels are engaged in transporting freights which by rights should be carried under our own flag, and consequently we are losing a large annual revenue. Besides in a national point of view, the pride we feel in the matter, we are suffering the mortification of having our work done by other people, and in the vessels which once were our own property.

abstract: Fashion Course. Gen, Butler vs. Dexter, trot for $5,000; Beatty, Mrs., of New-York; Poisons herself and child
snippet: Fashion Course. Gen, Butler vs. Dexter, trot for $5,000; Beatty, Mrs., of New-York; Poisons herself and child
lead_paragraph: The manager of the track had perfected all necessary arrangements for the occasion. The trains, special and ordinary, were, for a wonder, run on time, and no complaint was made of a dereliction of duty either on the part of the railroad employes or the management of the track. A large force of the Metropolitan Police was present, and the utmost order and decorum prevailed throughout. It is pleasant to record facts so much to the credit of the management, for in by-gone years the contrary was the rule rather than the exception. But racing and trotting have within the past year or two taken a new start; and henceforth we anticipate seeing nothing but well-ordered and well-managed meetings, which condition the public mind and feeling will inevitably regulate.

abstract: OCEAN YACHT RACE. An ocean race is to come off on the 11th between the Fleetwing, owned by Mr. GEORGE A. OSGOOD, and the Henrietta, owned by Mr. JAMES G. BENNETT, Jr., two of the largest yachts in the United States. It will be the first ocean race this side of the Atlantic.
lead_paragraph: OCEAN YACHT RACE. -- An ocean race is to come off on the 11th between the Fleetwing, owned by Mr. GEORGE A. OSGOOD, and the Henrietta, owned by Mr. JAMES G. BENNETT, Jr., two of the largest yachts in the United States. It will be the first ocean race this side of the Atlantic. The yachts are to start at noon of the 11th, from the lightship, off Sandy Hook, and sail to and around the light off Cape May, and back to the starting-point. This match is to be sailed by the regulations of the New-York Yacht Club, with the exception that no difference of tonnage is to be allowed, and that one or two topsails can be used in heavy weather, if they be required. Immediately after this race another is to be run on the 15th inst. between the Restless, a very fast schooner yacht, and the Henrietta, from Sands' Point to New-London. Other ocean races are in contemplation.

abstract: The, and State Rights
snippet: The, and State Rights
lead_paragraph: We are among those who believe that the general government has no constitutional right to prescribe the qualifications of voters in the several States, and on that ground have sustained without hesitation the course of President JOHNSON in leaving the question of negro suffrage to the absolute discretion of each State. The Democrats readily enough accept this principle, so far as it bears upon the black man; but down in Maryland, at least, they take it in a very different spirit when it applies to the white. The new constitution of Maryland prescribes a stringent oath of loyalty to be taken by every voter, and also authorizes the Legislature to provide for the disfranchisement of all disloyal persons. This exercise of the sovereign power of the State over the electoral qualifications, has given the Copperheads of the State intense dissatisfaction. They asseverate that it is not only intrinsically despotic, but that it is a violation of that clause of the Constitution of the United States, which insures to each State a republican form of government. At length Mr. THOMAS ANDERSON, one of the disfranchised, has resolved to seek his remedy. He first makes a formal demand that his name shall be registered as a legal and qualified voter, without taking the oath required by law. His language is:

abstract: N. Y.--Manhattan Soap Factory Boiler, Stone-st.; 3 Killed
snippet: N. Y.--Manhattan Soap Factory Boiler, Stone-st.; 3 Killed
lead_paragraph: At about 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, a steamboiler on the fourth floor of No. 52 Stone-street, in the works of the Manhattan Soap Company, exploded, and WILLIAM WATSON, the engineer, and JOHN BITTNER, a German laborer, were instantly killed, and THOMAS HAYES was mortally wounded. At the time of the accident four men were at work on the fourth floor, and two of them escaped uninjured. The front wall of the building was blown to the opposite side of the street, and hero BITTNER was buried under a mass of brick and mortar. He was taken thence to the New-York Hospital by a detachment of the First Ward Police, under Capt. WARLOW, but before reaching that institution he expired, and his body was taken to the New-street Police Station, whither also was taken the body of WILLIAM WATSON, the engineer.

abstract: The trial now going on in Washington has a marked national importance. It is not so much the wretched creature, WIRZ, who is on trial, as it is the temper and spirit of the authorities of the late rebel government.
lead_paragraph: The trial now going on in Washington has a marked national importance. It is not so much the wretched creature, WIRZ, who is on trial, as it is the temper and spirit of the authorities of the late rebel government. They are charged with having starved and tortured thousands upon thousands of Union prisoners who had fallen into their Lands, -- or having, intentionally and systematically, deprived them of shelter and of food, -- of having withheld from them all care during sicknees, -- of hunting them like wild beasts, of killing and maiming them for the most trifling offences, -- in a word, of conduct toward them which should brand them forever with the scorn and contempt of the civilized world. These allegations have been denied -- not so loudly or distinctly by the Confederates themselves, as by their allies and sympathizers abroad. When the present correspondent of the London Times recently sent to that journal a statement of these alleged offences, it was received with indignant incredulity. The charges were branded as false and slanderous, and it was boldly asserted, on the other side, that rebel prisoners met treatment equally severe at the hands of the Government of the United States.

lead_paragraph: THE UNITED STATES CIRCUIT COURT. -- This court met in the new court-house at noon yesterday, His Honor Judge BENEDICT, presiding. The Grand Jury, for the term, was impanneled, and a charge delivered, in which they were instructed in relation to the enforcement of the Internal Revenue Law, holding that the taxes were unequally assessed in some cases, and that the officers did not execute the law in the spirit in which it was intended. In regard to the Navy-yard frauds and thefts. His Honor contended that the law should be enforced, as stealing from the government was equally as reprehensible as stealing from private individuals. After the charge the jury retired to their labors.

abstract: B lestrini's Projected Line, New-York to Paris
snippet: B lestrini's Projected Line, New-York to Paris
lead_paragraph: It is very gratifying to learn that an enterprising Frenchamn, M. ALBERTO BILESTRINI, has undertaken, on his own risk and responsibility, to connect together the three continents of Europe, Africa and America -- including the greater portion of the islands of the North Atlantic -- by telegraph. The last European mail brought us some particulars of the route selected, M. BILESTEINI is to start from Paris, of course; thence to Lisbon and Cape St. Vincent, overland From Cape St. Vincent a submarine line is to be laid to the Canary Islands; from the latter another submarine stretch is to take in Cape Verd -- with stations at St. Louis (Senegal) and Goree, on the African mainland. From Cape Verd, the line is to stretch out in as direct a course as may be to Cape St. Roque, the eastmost point of Brazil. From St. Roque a landline along the coast is to connect with Cayenne; then a succession of submarine and overland wires through the Antilles is to complete the chain of communication at New-Orleans. It is impossible to judge with perfect accuracy of the length of this proposed route; but we take it to be little short of half the girth of the world -- if New-York is to be included is the circuit. Looking to the latitudes alone, it will be seen that Monteur BILESTEINI travels southward over fifty-three degrees before he reaches this continent at all, and coming back to New-York from Cape St. Roque he strides over forty-four degrees more. Make allowance for the longitudes covered by his line, and he will be found to have traveled considerably over ten thousand miles.
headline: {'main': 'From New-York to Paris by Telegraph.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'From New-York to Paris by Telegraph.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Yesterday morning's TIMES contained an account of the death of a widow of the name of BETTS, at No. 335 East Eighth-street; and it is there said that ...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning's TIMES contained an account of the death of a widow of the name of BETTS, at No. 335 East Eighth-street; and it is there said that the neighbors regarded the case as one of poisoning. The woman, who represented herself to be the widow of a soldier who had fallen in battle, hired apartments, a fortnight ago, on the fourth floor of the tenement house No. 335 East Eighth-street, and having moved in her scanty furniture, was scarcely seen again by her neighbors; but at 1 o'clock on Thursday afternoon, Mrs. MARY ANN MURPHY, one of the neighbors, observed that Mrs. BETTS' door had been locked on the inside, and the key left in the lock. It then occurred to Mrs. MURPHY that Mrs. BETTS had not been seen by any one since Wednesday morning last; therefore, suspecting something wrong, she notified Mr. WILLIAM E. BRINKERHOFF, the agent for the house, and he burst the door, and found Mrs. BETTS dead in her bed, with her dead child, a girl of eight months, lying by her side. Mrs. BETTS was about 25 years of age. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday, and the jury, after listening to the testimony of several witnesses, found a verdict of "death from starvation," mainly basing their finding upon the testimony of the Coroner's deputy, which was as follows:

abstract: Labor Organization, Forcible Progress of
snippet: Labor Organization, Forcible Progress of
lead_paragraph: No one who knows anything of human nature or negro nature ever expected that the entire mass of the Southern blacks would resume their operations with the "shovel and the hoe" on the morning after the day on which they learned that they were no longer slaves but freemen. It was quite sure that some of them would go off for a while on a frolic; others would take a long rest after a life of weary toil; others would fall prone, as did the man of Tarsus when struck by the heavenly light; some would desire to change their pursuit or location; and the more so that now for the first time in their lives was it possible for them to do so. In short, taking into account the character of the blacks and the character of slavery, the influence of the war and the influence of freedom, it might have been expected that the entire labor system of the South would be thoroughly deranged for some years.

abstract: PRESENTATION TO CAPT. GROGAN, OF "THE QUEEN." -- Yesterday, Capt. GROGAN, of the new steamer The Queen, belonging to the National Steamship Company, was the recipient of a splendid set of plate, valued at $500, consisting of salver, pitcher and goblets, presented to him by the cabin passengers of the vessel on her late voyage from Liverpool. The presentation speech was made by Mr. RINGGOLD, and was happily responded to by Capt. GROGAN. After partaking of a splendid collation, and drinking the healths of President JOHNSON and Her Britannic Majesty with all the honors, the party spent the afternoon in social converse, and did not separate until quite a late hour. The Queen, on this, her first voyage, brought the enormous number of 1,425 passengers in the steerage.

abstract: It seems the report we  had that a white man in Georgia had sawed off both the legs of a negro to prevent his running away, is not true.
lead_paragraph: It seems the report we had that a white man in Georgia had sawed off both the legs of a negro to prevent his running away, is not true. The person accused of the deed (who is a doctor) has sent as a letter exposing the falsity of the published statement. The authorities in North Carolina have also explicitly denied the innumerable reports which have been sent North that negroes were being hung and shot and stabbed wholesale in that State. In short, most of the tales which come for a while fast and numberless, from the South, about unparalleled and fiendish cruelty to black men, have been proven false.

abstract: Albany Democrats, the New Professions of; Brains and Backbone of the Party Made the Rebellion; Boasts of Past Glories--N. Y. State Convention
snippet: Albany Democrats, the New Professions of; Brains and Backbone of the Party Made the Rebellion; Boasts of Past Glories--N. Y. State Convention
lead_paragraph: Men who mean reform don't boast over past follies. The fellow who should quit his wild oats with a hurrah would get credit for nothing but impudence. The Democratic party of this State wish to have it understood that they are trying to make a now character. They have just begun their political year with what would have been some very good resolutions, but for a silly boast in the beginning. It is declared that "the past history of the Democratic party is to be found in the proudest records of the country, and that it ready to meet the great questions of the future with the patriotism, fidelity to principle, and practical wisdom, that have characterized its long and auspicious identification with the history of the nation." It is impossible to reconcile such language with any sincerity in the promises which follow.

snippet: Columbus, Ohio; Oliver and Hartup Executed; Page, Ex-Gov. John, of New-Hampshire; Deery and Fox, American Championship; Match at Rochester; East Taunton, Mass., Old Colony Works Boiler; 1 Killed; Mexico to California, >amp;c., grant to C. J. Arnou...
lead_paragraph: The Costa Rica (with $938,000 in gold) brings Panama news to the 31st ult. The city had been kept in constant excitement on account of the revolutionary movements going on in the interior, but which appear to result in nothing. The present government may be overthrown, but there is little likelihood of any outbreak in the city. The contending parties have about three hundred men each under arms; but both appear afraid to fight. A good deal of excitement has been occasioned by the government here appropriating a couple of American vessels for transportation purposes. The vessels were sold by the United States Consul, who furnished them with the documents requisite, as the purchasers thought to navigate on this coast and under which they have been sailing for nearly two years. It now appears they had no right to these documents, and their owners can claim no protection either from the Consul or Admiral. From Central America the only important item is that BARRIOS, the Ex-President of Salvador, was being tried by a council of war, and would, in all probability, be shot, notwithstanding, when Nicaragua delivered him up, it was on an express understanding by treaty, that his life would be spared. From Chili there is nothing of interest. Business is dull and arrivals few. The revolution in Peru still progresses, and the rebel fleet had entered Callao, where they were awaiting a reply from President PEZEZ to their ultimatum, before attacking the town. Still, it is not certain that the revolution will succeed.

abstract: Journal of Commerce on Currency and the Clearing-house; Currency and Journal of Commerce
snippet: Journal of Commerce on Currency and the Clearing-house; Currency and Journal of Commerce
lead_paragraph: "The present arrangement is one of very great inconvenience, and the troubles arising from it are daily increasing. For instance the regular customers of the Corn Exchange Bank deposited with it, the other day, drafts on the Sub Treasury to the amount of about eight hundred thousand dollars, drawing against them most of the amount, which was paid out, the checks going into other banks to be redeemed in legal tenders through the Clearing-house the next morning. The Corn Exchange Bank presented the drafts at the Treasury, and was paid in National Bank Notes. How shall it turn these into legal tenders to meet the checks of its customers at the Clearing-house next morning? This is the problem." -- Journal of Commerce.

abstract: THE MURDER AT EASTON, PENN. -- PETER WELLER, the man who was arrested in Jersey City a few days since, on a charge of having murdered a man named JOHN STEEN, at Easton, Penn., was taken to that city on Wednesday by Officer MANNING, of the Jersey City Police, and committed for trial. It appears that on the 26th alt. WELLER, was convicted for stealing from the person, and was placed under bail to await sentence. Some time during the day the prisoner and STEEN had a difficulty, resulting from gambling, but the parties separated without coming to violence: but afterward WELLER made threats against STEEN's life. In the evening he visited a place in the outskirts of the town, where STEEN was staying, and renewed the quarrel, when a man named HUTMAN struck STEEN in the face, and at the same time WELLER rushed upon him. The man's skull was fractured and a billy, supposed to belong to the prisoner, was found in the vicinity after the occurrence. WELLER is well known to the police and bears an unenviable reputation. Not long since, he stabbed a man named LEWIS seven times, inflicting severe but not fatal wounds.

abstract: on Reconstruction
snippet: on Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: Hon. E. CARNES, a citizen of influence and position in Georgia, has published in a letter, dated Augusta, Aug. 25, his views concerning the course which the people of the South ought to adopt for the future welfare of the country and for their own good. Whatever may be thought of the right or wrong of the recent rebellion, no one, he says, can justly doubt that the great body of the Southern people believed they were right in the course they pursued; and they certainly fought for their convictions with a valor and self-sacrifice never surpassed in the records of the race. They failed, and thereby become justly and properly subject to the demands and exactions of the victorious party. "The Government of the United States, according to the law of nations," he says, "has acquired the right to refuse to us a continuance of such political organization in the State as has shown itself hostile to the conqueror, and has aided the war, and so much of our constitution and laws as contravenes the fun damental policy of the conqueror."
headline: {'main': 'SOUTHERN SENTIMENT.; Indications of Southern Opinion on Reconstruction.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'SOUTHERN SENTIMENT.; Indications of Southern Opinion on Reconstruction.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Ketchum, Twelve Indictments presented
snippet: Ketchum, Twelve Indictments presented
lead_paragraph: More than three full weeks have elapsed since the solid men of Wall-street wore thrown into a state of intense excitement by the disclosure of the extensive forgeries which had been perpetrated by the junior member of one of our wealthiest banking-houses--that of MORRIS KETCHUM & SON. As it generally happens in such cases, the excitement reached its climax and had begun to decline before the facts of the case were set forth in extenso; and even prior to the discovery and apprehension of the guilty party, the KETCHUM gold-check operations were only mentioned occasionally. Yet a thing of such magnitude, and somewhat novel in itself, is not entirely erased from the memory in so short a space of time. Many persons have been waiting patiently, and almost silently, to see how the matter would terminate, and whether the prisoner would ever be arraigned for his wrong-doing, while others have been theorizing as to the ultimatum, and more ready to stake large sums on their own conjectures. The opinions which have been expressed have been as various as they were numerous, and have ranged through all degrees of improbability.

abstract: New-York, Moonlight Excursion
snippet: New-York, Moonlight Excursion
lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening a goodly gathering of rare good fellows, fine singers and gentlemen all, accompanied by a no less goodly assemblage of ladies, singers and melodists likewise, met by appointment on the dock foot of Morton-street, occupied by the Havre line of steamships, and from the dock aforesaid the party embarked on the spacious pleasure barge lying securely moored at the pier. There were some three hundred people present, and the party was both fashionable and brilliant. The object of the gathering was simply a moonlight excursion of the famous and no less talented Mendelssohn Union, of this city.

abstract: Wall-street is troubled be  cause the general public, who, for a time, and in the aggregate to a vast extent, dabbled in stocks and gold, have lately withdrawn almost entirely from financial speculation.
lead_paragraph: Wall-street is troubled because the general public, who, for a time, and in the aggregate to a vast extent, dabbled in stocks and gold, have lately withdrawn almost entirely from financial speculation. This withdrawal is owing, in a measure, to the great revival of legitimate trade and commerce, which has called into the channels of business a large amount of the capital which formerly went into the street, and which has given larger and surer and more satisfactory returns than are found even by those who are lucky in speculation. The frauds in the street have frightened away many outsiders. The abolition of the Evening Exchange has also had a good effect in the same way. The small fluctuations for some time part in gold (in which article many of the outsiders rebelled) had also discouraged those who were hungry for heavy and quick profits.

lead_paragraph: THE MYSTERIOUS MURDER AT THE "HUNDRED STEPS." -- Coroner HANLEY, of Hudson City, held an inquest last evening upon the body of the unknown man, dressed in the garb of a sailor, who was found on Friday lying in a clump of briars, about twenty fee from the foot of the "hundred steps" leading ue Bergen Hill to Washington Village. The jury, upon visiting the spot, found a handkerchief, supposed to have belonged to deceased, lying on the ground near the steps, and from thence they discovered traces where the body had been dragged and thrown under thp briars, where it was entirely concealed from view, and was only discovered in consequence of the intolerable stench that arose from the decaying remains, and which led to an investigation of the cause. Upon removing the body, the head and legs separated from the trunk, and the body was so badly decomposed that it was impossible to ascertain in what manner death was caused. A wallet was found in the stocking of deceased, which contained a paper dated at the Philadelphia Navy-yard, August 8, giving him leave of absence for ten days, and requiring him to report, at the expiration of that time, on board the Princeton, at the same place; but the name of the deceased is obliterated. Coroner HANLEY made diligent inquiry, but was unable to obtain any clue in reference to deceased. The jury, from the circumstance of the case, rendered a verdict that the unknown man came to his death at the hands of some person or persons unknown.

abstract: -- A report on the Mont Cenis Railway by Mr. BRUNLEES, C.E., just issued, gives a detail of the successful locomotive experiments already made, and a general review of the prospects of the undertaking. The estimate of £320,000 is still considered sufficient for the railway and rolling stock, including 9 1/2 miles of covered way to protect the line from snow and avalanche runs, the total length being 48 miles, and it is calculated that after the concessions shall have been obtained the whele work may be completed in little more than a year. It is pointed out that although the positive time for the duration of the concession will be only seven years, it will really operate until the completion of the great tunnel, which it is believed cannot, even under the most favorable circumstances, be effected in less than ten or twelve years. In conclusion, it is mentioned that the decision of the French and Italian Governments on the concession may be expected to be given next mouth. The French Council of State is about to disperse for the season, but that government has been asked to treat the Mont Cenis concession as a matter of urgency, and to appoint a special commission for the business, so as to avoid the inconvenience of further delay.

abstract: A NEW PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH. The congregation which for many years have worshiped at the corner of Grand and Crosby streets, under Rev. Dr. THOMPSON, having some time since sold that property, and purchased ground for the site of a new edifice on Thirty-fourth-street, near Broadway, broke ground on Thursday last with appropriate ceremonies. The Building Committee and their architect, ...
lead_paragraph: A NEW PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH. -- The congregation which for many years have worshiped at the corner of Grand and Crosby streets, under Rev. Dr. THOMPSON, having some time since sold that property, and purchased ground for the site of a new edifice on Thirty-fourth-street, near Broadway, broke ground on Thursday last with appropriate ceremonies. The Building Committee and their architect, Mr. JARDINE, with several other gentlemen, met on the premises at 3 P.M., when Rev. Dr. THOMPSON initiated the work of excavation by removing with his own hands the first shovel-full of earth. The edifice will be a splendid gothic structure of Belville sandstone, and will cost when completed about $80,000.

abstract: Obstacles to Resumption
snippet: Obstacles to Resumption
lead_paragraph: The revenue of the General Government is directly dependent on the prosperity of the American people; and this prosperity may be said to depend, in no small degree, on the abundance of money in circulation. While the currency of any country is expanding in amount, commerce and manufactures are active, their prosperity reacting on agriculture and labor everywhere. On the other hand, with currency contraction, there follow the opposite effects, namely: the prospect of lower prices, an unwillingness to give orders, whether to manufacturers or merchants, except to supply immediate and pressing wants. Speculators who had been operating for a rise on borrowed capital are forced to realize when their notes fall due, and markets at once begin to fall. Labor also sympathizes with the general movement downward, and is obliged to accept a low rate of remuneration, with the compensating advantage, however, that, if its income be nominally less, its outlays are correspondingly reduced.

abstract: On Thursday, a complaint was entered against Policeman ROBERT W. DE GRUSHEA, of No. 100 Allen-street, and under Justice SHANDLEY's warrant, he was taken into custody, and required to give $1,000 bail for his appearance for further examination. This was given by Mr. HENRY, of Grand-street and the Bowery, confectioner, and DE GRUSHEA was released from restraint until 9 o'clock yesterday morning, when Mrs. DE GRUSHEA and her niece, MARY LOUISA CROFUT, an interesting miss of fourteen, appeared to make formal affidavit. It appears that on the 1st inst., Mrs. DE GRUSHEA, being absent in the country, and having left her niece to keep house for her husband, DE GRUSHEA, who is a detailed officer, and is not required to patrol the streets at night, went home and made such overtures to Miss CROFUT as he might have addressed to an unchaste female of the street. The girl having repulsed him, DE GRUSHEA, it is alleged, resorted to brute force; and there being no person in the house to whom she could appeal for defence, she was compelled, under a threat, to seal her lips. She maintained silence, however, only until the return of Mrs. DE GRUSHEA, and then disclosed the wrong that had been done her. The husband confronted his wife boldly, and attempted to treat the girl's story lightly as a fiction; but Mrs. DE GRUSHEA summoned a physician, and his test corroborated the story. Whereupon Miss CROFUT and Mrs. DE GURSHEA preferred complaint as above. The accused officer is a man of 55 years, and Mrs. DE G. is his second wife. The injured girl is grand-daughter of one of the most respectable officers of the Metropolitan Police force. A further examination is to be made on Monday, the 18th instant.

abstract: Haytian Frigate Geffrard, at N. Y.
snippet: Haytian Frigate Geffrard, at N. Y.
lead_paragraph: This steamer, which is manned by a colored crew, left Port-au-Prince on the 22d ult., arriving at this city on Thursday morning. She now lies off the Battery. The Geffrard was built at Bordeaux about six years ago, and is used by the Haytian Republic for special government service. She is a schooner-rigged side-wheel steamer, 150 tons burden, measuring 120 feet in length, 13 feet breadth of beam, and 16feet depth of hold. Her engines and machinery were built by PENN & SON, at Greenwich, England. They are of forty horse-power. Her average speed on the voyage was eight miles an hour; but after she undergoes an overhauling on the dry dock, the officers predict that she will attain a much greater rate of speed. Her armament consists of two four-pounders, smooth boare, and she carries a crew of fifty-four men, including the officers.

abstract: Reconstruction of
snippet: Reconstruction of
lead_paragraph: There is a community whose peaceful lives, passed as they are along the coasts of Virginia, have been spared the terrors and suffering of our four years' war. While the whole continent has been rocked by the storms of battle, this race have suffered no anxieties, have been free from the ravages of the raider, nay, have prospered amidst the adversities of others. A quiet race, without thought or care. The delight of those among whose society they happened to fall, they have never been ambitious. Holding places of honor at rich men's posts, vanity and vexation of spirit have never been their unhappy lot. The cherished companions of politicians they have, oh wisdom rare! been dumb as -- themselves. But alas for them now that the temple of Janus is shut, for they will be opened once more. Their days of peace are over that others may be content. Henceforth they are at war -- war with the knife. Their country will be invaded, and made desolate, and all the sentiment of which they are capable -- and does not lyric history record the story of one of them who was in love -- will receive new illustrations as the spectacle of mere shells, once their happy homes, tell the story of their going down.

abstract: Bangs, Mr., and his Oath of Allegiance
snippet: Bangs, Mr., and his Oath of Allegiance
lead_paragraph: -- The statement of a Washington paper that Major-Gen. HOOKER is to be married on the 12th inst. is incorrect. His engagement for that day is to attend the New-York State Fair at Utica. The newspaper gossips are no more authorized to fix the General's wedding-day than they are to estimate the income of the lady who accepts his hand -- both of which have been rudely done to the annoyance of the parties most interested.

abstract: Mr. JAMES G. BELKNAP, of No. 8 Gold-street, appeared before Justice DODGE yesterday, and made a deposition reciting that on the 31st of October, 1863, one double-case gold watch, of the value of $150, was stolen from his waistcoat pocket, while he was in the midst of a crowd at the Cooper Institute, while Gov. SEYMOUR was speaking to the multitude, and that he suspects that the watch was then stolen by one JOHN TIERNEY, keeper of a den in the Eighth Ward. TIERNEY having been taken into custody by Policeman EDWARD BYRNES, that officer testified that on the night of the 8th instant he searched the prisoner at the Wooster-street Police-station, and found on his person three gold watches, one watch-chain, two gold rings set with diamonds, set of pearl and garnet sleeve-buttons, etc., all of which he delivered to Mr. MANUEL A. WHITE, Assistant Property Clerk at Police Headquarters; and Mr. WHITE, believing the watches to have been stolen, and finding on one of them the name of the maker, Mr. A.C. BENEDICT, of No. 28 Bowery, sent thither, and the timekeeper was identified as one that had been sold to Mr. BELKNAP. TIERNEY is to be formally examined on Wednesday, the 13th instant, at 10 o'clock A.M., and Mr. BELKNAP, after the lapse of two years, recovers a watch that was stolen by a gang of thieves that went up to hear Gov. abstract: Mr. AUGUSTUS F. DOW, a widely known and highly esteemed merchant of this city, died of bilious fever on Thursday last, Sept. 7, in Fayetteville, Onondago County, N.Y., in the fifty-second year of his age. Mr. Dow was a native of Connecticut and started in merchantile life in Hartford. About twenty years' ago he removed to this city. During the past twelve years ...
lead_paragraph: Mr. AUGUSTUS F. DOW, a widely known and highly esteemed merchant of this city, died of bilious fever on Thursday last, Sept. 7, in Fayetteville, Onondago County, N.Y., in the fifty-second year of his age. Mr. Dow was a native of Connecticut and started in merchantile life in Hartford. About twenty years' ago he removed to this city. During the past twelve years he has been at the head of the Wall-street commission house of DOW, YOUNG & CO. He had been an active member of the Republican party from its organization. He was nominated for Congress, in the Sixth District in this city, in 1858, but retired in favor of Hon. GEORGE BRIGGS. He was an ardent friend of the public school system of the city, and served as a School Commissioner in the Ninth Ward for one or two terms. In commercial circles he was a very popular man, winning the good opinion of all with whom he came in contact, by his industry and uprightness in business affairs. Socially he stood high, as a man of fine talents and generous nature. The funeral will take place from his late residence at Peekskill, on Monday, the 11th instant, at 1 P.M. Hudson River Railroad train leaves Thirty-eighth street at 11 A.M.

abstract: -- The Missouri Republican is in receipt of a letter from Iowa Point, Kansas, which gives details of a murder committed in Oregon, Holt County, Missouri, a few days ago. It appears that THOMAS WILSON, an industrious, well-behaved man, and a weaver by trade, had worked at the woolen mills of WATSON & SONS, in Oregon, for five years or more, frequently visiting his wife, meantime, who lived at Iowa Point, six miles distant. She was violent and vicious in temper, but during his visits would conduct herself with some forbearance until she got possession of all the money he had made. She would then beat and maltreat him until he returned to work. At last the citizens of Iowa Point compelled her, on account of her general scandalous course of life, to leave the place, and she retired to Oregon. Here she renewed her assaults upon her husband, and at last, with the aid of another woman who was a companion of her dissolute life, she beat him until his leg and skull were fractured, and he died of his wounds. Mrs. WILSON has been indicted for murder in the first degree and sent to jail to await trial. Her confederate in crime fled the town and has not yet been arrested.

abstract: There is a rough justice to be found even among savages; it cannot be dignified with the name of law, in the full sense of the word, but may merit the title bestowed upon it by EDMUND BURKE, "the liberty of will." By it the savage, standing promptly forward in his own defence, by force or stratagem protects his property and his personal rights. By it ...
lead_paragraph: There is a rough justice to be found even among savages; it cannot be dignified with the name of law, in the full sense of the word, but may merit the title bestowed upon it by EDMUND BURKE, "the liberty of will." By it the savage, standing promptly forward in his own defence, by force or stratagem protects his property and his personal rights. By it the stronger or craftier man, and the braver or more politic tribe, succeed in oppressing, subjugating or destroying those families or races which surround them. It is a development of power which would naturally be acquired by those who study the habits and practices of perhaps the larger portion of the animal creation. The African is not to be ruthlessly condemned because he sometimes follows and emulates the ferocity of the lion in his dealings with mankind, nor the pliant and feeble Asiatic, who, often in his own defence, copies and improves upon the cunning and malignity of the cobra of the jungles of the Ganges.
headline: {'main': 'The Regeneration of Law.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Regeneration of Law.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Wright's Oil Regions of Pennsylvania
snippet: Wright's Oil Regions of Pennsylvania
lead_paragraph: A new book on the newest of themes. Our petroleum literature is not very voluminous, and still less valuable. We do not call to mind any recent publication of real value on the subject, except the articles of Prof. EVANS, of Marietta, and the crude jumble of "Derrick and Drill." We are not speaking of foreign productions, or we should necessarily include the speculations of STERRY HUNT, and the careful chemical examinations of certain Swiss and German savans. At all events, petroleum in its glory, enthroned in Venango County, monarch of markets and exchanges, mystery of mysteries, has waited for a historian. Yes, and still waits; for Mr. WRIGHT's book, while incomparably the best that has appeared, does not pretend to do full justice to its vast subject. The coming book cannot yet be written, because the time is not ripe.
headline: {'main': 'NEW BOOKS.; THE OIL REGIONS OF PENNSYLVANIA , Showing Where Petroleum is Found: How it is Obtained, and at what Cost; with Hints for Whom it may Concern. By WILLIAM WRIGHT. abstract: On Thursday last, Mr. EDWARD SMITH, an employe of the Seventh Avenue Railroad Company, was kicked in the pit of the stomach while grooming a horse in the company's stables. He was taken to his abode, at No. 231 West Thirty-fifth-street, and a physician attended him; but his injuries proved mortal, and he died yesterday morning. He was a native of Ireland, aged 58 years.

abstract: It is settled at last. A British army officer, Capt. W.A. BAKER, of the Royal Bombay Engineers, has settled an often-disputed date the year in which the world will come to an end. In a work just published in England, entitled "The Day and the Hour; or, Notes on Prophecy: a Sketch of the Future, extracted from the Bible," he imparts a considerable amount of information. The day of judgment, he ...
lead_paragraph: It is settled at last. A British army officer, Capt. W.A. BAKER, of the Royal Bombay Engineers, has settled an often-disputed date -- the year in which the world will come to an end. In a work just published in England, entitled "The Day and the Hour; or, Notes on Prophecy: a Sketch of the Future, extracted from the Bible," he imparts a considerable amount of information. The day of judgment, he tells us, is fixed for Sept. 20, 1878; the hour, sunset; the Translation of the Saints having previously taken place, at 1 o'clock in the morning on the 25th of January, 1875. He says: "The last twelve hundred and sixty days of this life will be the most miserable that the world has ever seen. Previous to their commencement there will be war in heaven, Michael and his angels fighting against the Dragon and his angels, who will be driven down into the earth, when a loud voice exclaims, 'Woe to the inhabitants of the earth and the sea! for the devil is come down unto you, having great wrath, because he knoweth that he hath but a short time.' Then will the Dragon give his power and his seat and great authority to Antichrist, who will open his mouth in blasphemy against God, to blaspheme His name and His tabernacle, and them that dwell in Heaven; he will make war upon the saints and overcome them, and all they that dwel upon the earth shall worship him, whose names are not written in the Book of Life of the Lamb slain from the foundation of the world."

abstract: -- We have always tried to mitigate the jealousy of New-York and the envy of her greatness, which are entertained by other cities that consider themselves our rivals, such as Philadelphia and Boston. We see no reason why they should be jealous of us. The opportunities of greatness are before each of them. We do nothing to prevent their achieving it. It is unlikely that any one of them will ever supplant us as the great financial and commercial centre of the continent. But there are other matters in which they can surpass us if they will be wise, and take advantage of their chances. Mr. MCMICHAEL, of Philadelphia, thus spoke on the subject at a meeting in that city last week:

abstract: A Story About
snippet: A Story About
lead_paragraph: -- We find the following in the Rochester (N.Y.) Union: "A book will probably appear within a short time, giving the facts in the history of Dr. KANE, the Arctic navigator, which have hitherto been shrouded in mystery. It is true that he was for years engaged to Miss MARGARETTA FOX, one of the young ladies who first presented the phenomena of 'spirit-rapping.' Dr. KANE fell in love with the young girl while she was sitting as a public medium in Philadelphia, in 1852, when she was 15 years of age. With her mother's consent, he removed her from all association with the spiritualists, and placed her in a private school near Philadelphia, to remain during his absence in the Arctic regions. On his return, in 1855, they were to have been married; but the opposition of Dr. KANE's family was such that Miss FOX released him from his engagement. He loved her, however, too well to live without her; and in April, 1856, the engagement was renewed, with the understanding that it should be kept secret till the publication of Dr. KANE's great work should realise an independence for him. In October, 1856, his physicians having ordered Dr. KANE to England, he was secretly married to Miss FOX, and made his will, leaving five thousand dollars to her in private trust to his brother. His last letter was addressed to her. This legacy was not paid, and some injurious reports having been raised, Mrs. KANE's legal advisers urged a suit for dower as the widow, and the publication of a memoir. One was prepared, embodying one hundred and thirty-four of Dr. KANE's letters, and Mr. CARLETON had it in press, when the publication and suit were both stopped by a compromise with the brothers and executor of Dr. KANE; they agreeing to pay the lady the interest of the money left her, and a sum down to repay her expenses, provided she would discontinue the suit in the Orphan Court, Philadelphia, and would seal up the letters, with the MS. memoir, and place them in the hands of a trustee, who would surrender them to the KANE family at her death. A bond was signed by the KANES in 1862, for the observance of the terms they agreed to; Mrs. KANE being permitted to reclaim her letters, &c., in the event of their failure to pay the quarterly installment of interest. This agreement was violated by their refusal to pay -- first, the sum promised for her expenses, then the quarterly installments, and in June last Mrs. KANE reclaimed her letters of the trustee. She is now at liberty to publish the volume which is to establish her fair fame, and to show the world a singular example of faithful love, enduring through unkindness and calumny. The death of Mrs. FOX, Mrs. KANE's mother, has retarded the publication, but it will doubtless appear in good time."
headline: {'main': 'A STORY ABOUT DR. KANE.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A STORY ABOUT DR. KANE.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- SUIT FOR THE RECOVERY OF $6,500 LOST IN PULASKI, TENN. -- The Greencastle (N.H.) Press contains the following: "The goods and effects and real estate of JAMES FOLSOM, jeweler and silversmith, of this place, have been attached within the last few days by an attachment process issued by the Circuit Court for the United States for the District of Indiana, at the suit of Dr. JOSEPH C. ROBERTS, of Tennessee, and said FOLSOM has been arrested and taken to Tennessee, by requisition from the Governor of that State, on a criminal charge. The many improbable stories in circulation concerning these matters induce us to give publicity to the following versions: Dr. ROBERTS alleges that about January, 1864, on the streets of Pulaski, Tenn., he dropped from his pocket-book $6,500 in greenbacks, to wit: six one thousand dollar bills and one five hundred dollar bill. That war was then being waged in Tennessee, making communication with the North very difficult. That all diligent search for said money at the time was fruitless, and that a published reward of $1,000 failed to elicit any information concerning it. That many months afterward a negro man in New-Hampshire made declarations to this effect: That he resided with JAMES FOLSOM at or near Pulaski, in January, 1864, and found upon the streets of that place $6,500 in greenbacks, of the denominations stated above. That he handed the same for safekeeping to Mr. FOLSOM. That on hearing of the $1,000 reward he desired to return the money to ROBERTS, but was dissauded from so doing by FOLSOM, who persuaded him to go North, representing that as a negro he would there enjoy greater social and political privileges, and proposing that they should there share said money equally, and urging the advantages to the negro of the half of $6,500 over said sum of reward. That he was thus enticed by FOLSOM to accompany him to New-Hampshire, and that when they got there FOLSOM faced on the negro, denied all about the money, and refused to give him any part thereof. Whereupon the negro tells. And this, Dr. ROBERTS avers, is the first clue to his missing money. The Doctor further alleges that he has since learned of additional evidence, corroborating the negro's statement fully, and making a clear case against FOLSOM. Hence the attachment proceedings, coupled with a civil action to recover said sum of money. By the criminal code of Tennessee the obtaining and appropriating money under such circumstances is a well-defined crime, punishable by imprisonment. Hence the arrest of FOLSOM under the requisition of the Governor of Tennessee.
lead_paragraph: -- SUIT FOR THE RECOVERY OF $6,500 LOST IN PULASKI, TENN. -- The Greencastle (N.H.) Press contains the following: "The goods and effects and real estate of JAMES FOLSOM, jeweler and silversmith, of this place, have been attached within the last few days by an attachment process issued by the Circuit Court for the United States for the District of Indiana, at the suit of Dr. JOSEPH C. ROBERTS, of Tennessee, and said FOLSOM has been arrested and taken to Tennessee, by requisition from the Governor of that State, on a criminal charge. The many improbable stories in circulation concerning these matters induce us to give publicity to the following versions: Dr. ROBERTS alleges that about January, 1864, on the streets of Pulaski, Tenn., he dropped from his pocket-book $6,500 in greenbacks, to wit: six one thousand dollar bills and one five hundred dollar bill. That war was then being waged in Tennessee, making communication with the North very difficult. That all diligent search for said money at the time was fruitless, and that a published reward of $1,000 failed to elicit any information concerning it. That many months afterward a negro man in New-Hampshire made declarations to this effect: That he resided with JAMES FOLSOM at or near Pulaski, in January, 1864, and found upon the streets of that place $6,500 in greenbacks, of the denominations stated above. That he handed the same for safekeeping to Mr. FOLSOM. That on hearing of the $1,000 reward he desired to return the money to ROBERTS, but was dissauded from so doing by FOLSOM, who persuaded him to go North, representing that as a negro he would there enjoy greater social and political privileges, and proposing that they should there share said money equally, and urging the advantages to the negro of the half of $6,500 over said sum of reward. That he was thus enticed by FOLSOM to accompany him to New-Hampshire, and that when they got there FOLSOM faced on the negro, denied all about the money, and refused to give him any part thereof. Whereupon the negro tells. And this, Dr. ROBERTS avers, is the first clue to his missing money. The Doctor further alleges that he has since learned of additional evidence, corroborating the negro's statement fully, and making a clear case against FOLSOM. Hence the attachment proceedings, coupled with a civil action to recover said sum of money. By the criminal code of Tennessee the obtaining and appropriating money under such circumstances is a well-defined crime, punishable by imprisonment. Hence the arrest of FOLSOM under the requisition of the Governor of Tennessee.

abstract: BARBARITY. -- The Panama Star of the 31st of August gives an account of a series of terrible cruelties upon a sailor of the American schooner Gen. Harney, who was arrested and placed in jail as a witness to prove that the Harney had brought rebel troops from Buenaventura and landed them near Panama. The Star says: "The authorities being unable to get any statement to that effect by their means from the prisoner, put him on the rack, in order to force false evidence from him against the vessel and her owner. The man says he was suspended by the heels, and his legs pulled apart until he thought he should be torn in two, but he still maintained the truth that no troops were brought up on the vessel. In this way he was tortured until his tormentors feared they had carried their brutality too far, and he was released from his fearful position. During the torture the man retained his senses, and stoutly defended the innocence of the Captain and owner of the vessel, but on being set at liberty he fell senseless on the ground."

In this way he was tortured until his tormentors feared they had carried their brutality too far, and he was released from his fearful position. During the torture the man retained his senses, and stoutly defended the innocence of the Captain and owner of the vessel, but on being set at liberty he fell senseless on the ground."

abstract: The most exigent taste can be accommodated to-night in the way of amusement. With the exception of Wallack's all the principal theatres are open, and Irving Hall, one of the most agreeable places of resort in the metropolis, also extends its allurements to the seeker after pleasure.
lead_paragraph: The most exigent taste can be accommodated to-night in the way of amusement. With the exception of Wallack's all the principal theatres are open, and Irving Hall, one of the most agreeable places of resort in the metropolis, also extends its allurements to the seeker after pleasure. The Academy of Music, too, with HERMANN, the most admirable of conjurors, enters once more on the field of competition. Low[???] down town we find at Dodworth's a "prize frog show" -- an exhibition so ludicrous in its nature, that every one will naturally drop in to see what it is about, and to hear Mr. CAHILL's lecture which will, we are sure, be thoroughly entertaining.

abstract: Wool Manufacturers' Convention on War with England
snippet: Wool Manufacturers' Convention on War with England
lead_paragraph: The wool manufacturers of the United States would seem to be an extremely belligerent body of men. They held a convention in Philadelphia the other day, and at its close were entertained by a "magnificent banquet," at which a large number of more or less "distinguished orators" gave free scope to their eloquence. Some of the speakers had a little to say about wool, but more of them had much to say about war -- not the last war, nor any war which has yet been waged, but about a possible war of the future, which we had supposed all good men wished to avoid and no wise man desired to talk about. In short, it would seem that from some unaccountable cause or other, the wool-manufacturers are not averse to fighting England at short notice, while some of them would as lief take a tilt with "all creation." We do not precisely understand why they, or at least those who spoke at their banquet, should break out at this moment; but from every part of the banquetting-board there were eruptions of warlike wrath. It is a remarkable fact, however, that there was only one distinguished General of the Union army present; and that that officer (Major-General BURNSIDE) raised, amid the din, his voice for peace -- for general, universal, permanent, honorable peace. Perhaps it was the first speaker of the occasion who struck the belligerent key-note in a reference to the "baleful domination of that insolent power which, during the last four years, has preyed upon our commerce, outraged our feelings, and given aid and comfort to our enemies." The "father of the feast," who uttered this, was followed by Mr. HAYES, of Boston, the Secretary of the National Wool-Manufacturers' Association, who made the threat direct, and made it loud. He cried out: "We have overcome our home enemies by our matchless system of small arms; and, if it should become necessary to teach the Nemean lion across the water the might of our republican institutions, I have little doubt that it can be done by the same means." [Great applause.] Senator WILSON, of Massachusetts, pronounced himself opposed to talking of war with France or England; but Mr. CAMERON, formerly Secretary of War, who followed him, quickly declared: "I don't believe with Mr. WILSON precisely. I believe in peace or war -- in anything that is good for my country -- and I will go to war with England much more readily than I ever did with rebels, who were my own countrymen." [Enthusiastic applause.] Judge KELLY "did not want war;" "but," exclaimed he, in a burst of bunkum, "let the lion of England shield herself under the wide wings of the eagle of Austria, and dally with the lily of France, and bring to assist them the flags of the world, and we will turn loose the fleet that is gathered in the back creek of League Island, and we will lick them all. [Three cheers for League Island.] Yes, gentlemen, let me say in parenthesis that League Island is now the naval station for the iron-clads of the nation, and that, without a dissenting vote, because, in looking over our vast coast, the Secretary of the Navy could find no other deep fresh water shelter for those floating bulwarks of the nation." [Applause.] The same chaste speaker also defiantly proclaimed: "I flout the Stars and Stripes against the banners of the world." [Sensation.]

abstract: Dow, Mr. Augustus F.
snippet: Dow, Mr. Augustus F.
lead_paragraph: Mr. AUGUSTUS F. DOW, a widely known and highly esteemed merchant of this city, died of bilious fever on Thursday last, Sept. 7, in Fayetteville, Onondago County, N.Y., in the fifty-second year of his age. Mr. Dow was a native of Connecticut and started in mercantile life in Hartford. About twenty years' ago he removed to this city. During the past twelve years he has been at the head of the Wall-street commission house of Dow, Young & Co. He had been an active member of the Republican party from its organization. He was nominated for Congress, in the Sixth District in this city, in 1858, but retired in favor of Hon. GEORGE BRIGGS. He was an ardent friend of the public school system of the city, and served as a School Commissioner in the Ninth Ward for one or two terms. In commercial circles he was a very popular man, winning the good opinion of all with whom he came in contact, by his industry and uprightness in business affairs. Socially he stood high, as a man of fine talents and generous nature. The funeral will take place from his late residence at Peekskill, to-day, at 1 P.M. Hudson River Railroad train leaves Thirty-eighth street at 11 A.M.

abstract: Nation, the Weekly
snippet: Nation, the Weekly
lead_paragraph: The Nation, a weekly journal whose publication we have already announced, continues to increase in interest and value. It is the most resolute and promising of the many attempts that have been make to establish a strong and influential weekly in this city, and it bids fair, according to present indications, to hold and to fill a position here quite equivalent to that held by the Examiner, Spectator and other weekly journals in England. It is large, each number containing thirty-two large quarto pages, and is made up with care and attention to details. The original writing, which constitutes by far the largest portion of its contents, is able, scholarly and indicative of thought. It abounds in opinions, with some of which we do not agree, and which are always urged with peremptory confidence and sometimes with rather ill-temper; but they are always pressed by argument and not by mere assertion. The paper evinces thought and careful consideration in every department. Its interest would doubtless be very considerably enhanced, at least for a very large class of readers, if the writers of its articles were designated; but this is an open question, and the Nation is not without very authoritative precedents for the course it has adopted. Complaints are sometimes made of its being a little heavy; but this, as a general rule, is the fault of readers quite as much as of what they read. Serious discussions of serious topics cannot always have the vivacity of sketchy gossip -- and we can afford now and then to be required to think, it we have something worth thinking about.

abstract: On Thursday last, Mr. EDWARD SMITH, an employe of the Seventh Avenue Railroad Company, was kicked in the pit of the stomach while grooming a horse in the company's stables. He was taken to his abode, at No. 231 West Thirty-fifth-street, and a physician attended him; but his injuries proved mortal, and he died on Saturday morning. He was a native of Ireland, aged 58 years.

abstract: To-morrow the second fall meeting of the Hudson County Association commences on their new race course near Hoboken. Judging from the ample programme of sport, which will be found advertised in another column, the managers are justified in anticipating a brilliantly successful meeting. There are four consecutive days' racing, on each of which three races will be run. On the first day there is a two-year old race, a dash of half a mile, for which nine highly bred two-year olds are entered, including Ulrica and Satinstone, both winners at the recent Saratoga meeting. Also a mile-heat race, and a four-mile dash. On the second day, (Wednesday,) we are presented with a hurdle race, over two miles and eight hurdles, for which four horses are entered, including the two famous Canadian cracks, Minnie Cradock and Zigzag; a two-mile heat race, and a quarter-mile dash. On the third day there are two-mile dash race, a three-mile heat race and a selling race for decision. On Friday, the fourth day after, two dash races, at two and a quarter miles, and one and a quarter miles, we have that most attractive and intensely interesting of all events, a genuine "Steeple Chase," with its leaps over hedges, ditches, water, walls, &c., over a distance of two and a half miles. Recently introduced on the American turf, steeple chasing has proved so attractive, affording such unalloyed gratification to the spectators, that it is certain to become a permanent and a principal feature at our race meetings. For this race, four first-class horses have already entered. The number of horses already arrived is very large, and several stables from the immediate neighborhood are expected to-day. A capital week's racing may be looked for.
lead_paragraph: To-morrow the second fall meeting of the Hudson County Association commences on their new race course near Hoboken. abstract: By the Hibernia at Father Point, we have news from Londonderry to Sept. 1 -- five days later than by the Scotta. The directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Company have ordered a new cable to be forthwith commenced. JUDAH P. BENJAMIN, the late Confederate Secretary of State, had reached England in the West India mail steamer. The steamer came near being burned just after leaving St. Thomas. The Times is urging the Queen to quit her retirement and assume the duties of her station. Junketing with the French fleet at Portsmouth was going on nicely. The cattle disease is still prevalent; harvest weather is tolerably good. The continental news is pointless, except that there had been a ministerial crisis in Portugal, the BANDIERA cabinet having resigned, and the king calling upon the Duke of SALTOVA to form a new cabinet. News from Shanghai to July 29, makes no mention of the fall of Pekin.

abstract: -- Among the news from Europe this morning we have the report that the Atlantic Telegraph Company have formally resolved upon manufacturing a new cable -- by which it is probably meant to begin their enterprise de novo, instead of attempting to mend the broken line. They have doubtless learned, from the experiment made, that their wire and its coating were less perfect than they had been led to suppose. But for the flaws in the lost cable, no hauling in would have been necessary, and ten to one there would have been no break. It seems to be wise to begin the work again from the beginning.
lead_paragraph: -- Among the news from Europe this morning we have the report that the Atlantic Telegraph Company have formally resolved upon manufacturing a new cable -- by which it is probably meant to begin their enterprise de novo, instead of attempting to mend the broken line. They have doubtless learned, from the experiment made, that their wire and its coating were less perfect than they had been led to suppose. But for the flaws in the lost cable, no hauling in would have been necessary, and ten to one there would have been no break. It seems to be wise to begin the work again from the beginning.

abstract: On Thursday, a complaint was entered against Policeman ROBERT W. DE GRUSHEA, of No. 100 Allen-street, and under Justice SHANDLEY's warrant, he was taken into custody, and required to give $1,000 bail for his appearance for further examination. This was given by Mr. HENRY, of Grand-street and the Bowery, confectioner, and DE GRUSHEA was released from restraint until 9 o'clock on Saturday morning, when Mrs. DE GRUSHEA and her niece, MARY LOUISA CROFUT, an interesting miss of fourteen, appeared to make formal affidavit. It appears that on the 1st inst., Mrs. DE GRUSHEA, being absent in the country, and having left her niece to keep house for her husband, DE GRUSHEA, who is a detailed officer, and is not required to patrol the streets at night, went home and made such overtures to Miss CROFUT as he might have addressed to an unchaste female of the street. The girl having repulsed him, DE GRUSHEA, it is alleged, resorted to brute force; and there being no person in the house to whom she could appeal for defence, she was compelled, under a threat, to seal her lips. She maintained silence, however, only until the return of Mrs. DE GRUSHEA, and then disclosed the wrong that had been done her. The husband confronted his wife boldly, and attempted to treat the girl's story lightly as a fiction; but Mrs. DE GRUSHEA summoned a physician, and his test corroborated the story. Whereupon Miss CROFUT and Mrs. DE GURSHEA preferred complaint as above. The accused officer is a man of 55 years, and Mrs. DE G. is his second wife. The injured girl is grand-daughter of one of the most respectable officers of the Metropolitan Police force. A further examination is to be made on Monday, the 18th instant.

abstract: Steamer Seine had arrived at Southampton, having amongst her passengers Mr. BENJAMIN, Ex-Confederate Secretary of state. The Seine took fire when about fifty miles out from St. Thomas and put back with all speed. After considerable difficulty the fire was subdued and the ship proceeded on her course. She had nearly $1,700,000 in specie.

abstract: Williamsburgh; Eleventh-street, Mr. Kaylor's
snippet: Williamsburgh; Eleventh-street, Mr. Kaylor's
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF A DESPERATE MAN. -- About 4 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, Officer THOMSON, of the Fortyseventh Precinct, heard cries of murder issuing from No. 12 Greenpoint-avenue, and he immediately entered the place to ascertain the cause. As he was about to enter the room whence the sounds emanated, a female called out to him, "Look out, officer, he has got a knife!" The officer had not long to deliberate on what to do in the emergency, as a powerful-looking man made at him with a formidable knife, sharpened on both sides, with which he attempted his life, but fortunately only succeeded in cutting his pantaloons. Officer THOMPSON, however, by the judicious use of the club, brought him to his senses and disarmed him, and succeeded in taking him to the station-house. The man proved to be HENRY WILLIAMS, formerly owner of a liquor store in the same building, The cries of murder originated from his wife, whom he was assaulting at the time, and the officer found her bleeding from the effects of the assault. The character of the woman is notoriously bad.
