abstract: Vance vs. Johnson. Purchase Money of Slave
snippet: Vance vs. Johnson. Purchase Money of Slave
lead_paragraph: last week, an interesting case was tried. The executors of D.R. VANCE sued JAMES M. JOHNSON on a note given for the purchase of a slave at the time when slavery existed, the said note falling due before the abolition of the institution in Tennessee. The defendant pleaded a failure of consideration. But it was decided, says the Shelbyville Union, that as the executors could have made a title to the slave at the time the note was due, the defendant is not released from his liability to pay the debt, he not offering to pay it before slavery was abolished. The note was papable in good paper currency of the country, and money itself. The jury rendered a verdict against the defendant for the amount of the note and interest, less twenty per cent., it being proved that the best paper currency was twenty per cent, discount.

abstract: Detective CORWIN arrested WM. L. MAYHEW, on Friday night, on the charge of obtaining money under false pretences. His mode of operations was to call on some business firm, and representing his name to be the same as that of the party he came in contact with, generally ingratiated himself into their favor, when he would order some work to be done. He thus called on a number of carpenters, masons, gas-fitters, ,....
lead_paragraph: Detective CORWIN arrested WM. L. MAYHEW, on Friday night, on the charge of obtaining money under false pretences. His mode of operations was to call on some business firm, and representing his name to be the same as that of the party he came in contact with, generally ingratiated himself into their favor, when he would order some work to be done. He thus called on a number of carpenters, masons, gas-fitters, &c., and offering them a big job, usually some distance from the city, nearly always succeeded in borrowing sufficient money to pay his fare home, having suddenly discovered that be had spent every cent for articles purchased that day. Sometimes he got as much as $10 and other times as low as $1. On Friday he obtained $5 from FELIX GALLAGHER, of No. 9 Wyckoff-street, in this way. The same evening he called at the gas-fitting establishment of Mr. PARSONS, in Myrtle-avenue, on a similal errand, where he was identified and arrested. The accused acknowledged to the officer that he had been engaged in the business for about one year. He was well dressed, and from appearances seemed to have succeeded very well in the enterprise. He was arraigned before Justice CORNWELL on Saturday, and waiving examination was committed to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: Mr. JAMES G. BELKNAP, of No. 8 Gold-street, appeared before Justice DODGE on Saturday, and made a deposition reciting that on the 31st of October, 1863, one double-case gold watch, of the value of $150, was stolen from his waistcoat pocket, while he was in the midst of a crowd at the Cooper Institute, while Gov. SEYMOUR was speaking to the multitude, and that he suspects that the watch was then stolen by one JOHN TIERNEY, keeper of a den in the Eighth Ward. TIERNEY having been taken into custody by Policeman EDWARD BYRNES, that officer testified that on the night of the 8th instant he searched the prisoner at the Wooster-street Police-station, and found on his person three gold watches, one watch-chain, two gold rings set with diamonds, set of pearl and garnet sleeve-buttons, etc., all of which he delivered to Mr. MANUEL A. WHITE, Assistant Property Clerk at Police Headquarters; and Mr. WHITE, believing the watches to have been stolen, and finding on one of them the name of the maker, Mr. A.C. BENEDICT, of No. 28 Bowery, sent thither, and the timekeeper was identified as one that had been sold to Mr. BELKNAP. TIERNEY is to be formally examined on Wednesday, the 13th instant, at 10 o'clock A.M., and Mr. BELKNAP, after the lapse of two years, recovers a watch that was stolen by a gang of thieves that went up to hear Gov. SEYMOUR. lead_paragraph: Mr. JAMES G. BELKNAP, of No. 8 Gold-street, appeared before Justice DODGE on Saturday, and made a deposition reciting that on the 31st of October, 1863, one double-case gold watch, of the value of $150, was stolen from his waistcoat pocket, while he was in the midst of a crowd at the Cooper Institute, while Gov. SEYMOUR was speaking to the multitude, and that he suspects that the watch was then stolen by one JOHN TIERNEY, keeper of a den in the Eighth Ward. TIERNEY having been taken into custody by Policeman EDWARD BYRNES, that officer testified that on the night of the 8th instant he searched the prisoner at the Wooster-street Police-station, and found on his person three gold watches, one watch-chain, two gold rings set with diamonds, set of pearl and garnet sleeve-buttons, etc., all of which he delivered to Mr. MANUEL A. WHITE, Assistant Property Clerk at Police Headquarters; and Mr. WHITE, believing the watches to have been stolen, and finding on one of them the name of the maker, Mr. A.C. BENEDICT, of No. 28 Bowery, sent thither, and the timekeeper was identified as one that had been sold to Mr. BELKNAP. TIERNEY is to be formally examined on Wednesday, the 13th instant, at 10 o'clock A.M., and Mr. BELKNAP, after the lapse of two years, recovers a watch that was stolen by a gang of thieves that went up to hear Gov. SEYMOUR. abstract: -- We understand that Collector KING is quietly studying the condition of affairs in the Custom-house with a view to effecting such reforms as may seem to be required. He intends at once to break up the expensive and cumbrous system of carting, invented by his predecessor, by which the whole city was divided into districts, and the profits of carting shared by superintendents who generally sold their districts for a bonus and per centage. The sale of badges, from which several thousand dollars were realized by somebody, will, of course, be stopped at once. We have no doubt that a rigid and careful inquiry will discover a good many abuses, quite as flagrant and as ripe for reform as this.

abstract: Institute; 36th Annual Fair
snippet: Institute; 36th Annual Fair
lead_paragraph: In years gone by no organization occupied a more prominent position among us than the American Institute. To its annual fair at Castle Garden, inventors, manufacturers, artisans of every name, farmers and cunning craftsmen looked for instruction, edification and an opportunity for display, each in his line. The blight of war fell upon this, as upon other deserving public organizations, and during the past four years when pruning hooks were turned to swords, but little attention was paid to the action of the society or its exhibitions. Things now are changed and it is deemed a proper time by the managers of the Institute to revive the ancient interest and to place the annual fair where of right it belongs in the van of metropolitan exhibitions.

abstract: Shreveport, La., Great Part of Town Destroyed; Brown University Necrology; Letter to Gen. Grant on Slavery
snippet: Shreveport, La., Great Part of Town Destroyed; Brown University Necrology; Letter to Gen. Grant on Slavery
lead_paragraph: The necrology of Brown University for the year 1865 shows that 25 graduates have deceased, of whom 8 were clergymen, 11 lawyers, 1 a teacher, and 2 engaged in commercial pursuits. Of those reprepresenting the legal profession, Hon. ROBERT PITMAN was best known to the public. He was appointed as early as 1820 United States District-Attorney for Rhode Island, which office he filled until 1824, when President MONROE elevated him to the bench of the United States District Court for the same territory. He remained in this position until the day of his death. Of the clergymen, Rev. SAMUEL B. SWAIM, D.D., had been, as Theological Professor in Granville College, and Secretary of the American Home Missionary Society most prominently before the public.

abstract: Passaic Falls, N. J.; Dead Body Found, Shot; Bergen Hill, N. J.; Sailor's Body Found
snippet: Passaic Falls, N. J.; Dead Body Found, Shot; Bergen Hill, N. J.; Sailor's Body Found
lead_paragraph: THE MYSTERIOUS MURDER AT THE "HUNDRED STEPS." -- Coroner HANLEY, of Hudson City, held an inquest on Saturday upon the body of the unknown man, dressed in the garb of a sailor, who was found on Friday lying in a clump of briars, about twenty feet from the foot of the "hundred steps" leading up Bergen Hill to Washington Village. The jury, upon visiting the spot, found a handkerchief, supposed to have belonged to deceased, lying on the ground near the steps, and from thence they discovered traces where the body had been dragged and thrown under the briars, where it was entirely concealed from view, and was only discovered in consequence of the intolerable stench that arose from the decaying remains, and which led to an investigation of the cause. Upon removing the body, the head and legs separated from the trunk, and the body was so badly decomposed that it was impossible to ascertain in what manner death was caused. A wallet was found in the stocking of deceased, which contained a paper dated at the Philadelphia Navy-yard, August 8, giving him leave of absence for ten days, and requiring him to report, at the expiration of that time, on board the Princeton, at the same place; but the name of the deceased is obliterated. Coroner HANLEY made diligent inquiry, but was unable to obtain any clue in reference to deceased. The jury, from the circumstance of the case, rendered a verdict that the unknown man came to his death at the hands of some person or persons unknown.

abstract: Wirz trial taken on Saturday went directly to inculpate the rebel officials of the War Department at Richmond. An ex-Confederate Military Inspector, Col. CHANDLER, was on the stand; a copy of a report he made on the condition of the Andersonville prison was laid before the court; and his sworn testimony, given therewith, presents the most...
lead_paragraph: -- The evidence in the Wirz trial taken on Saturday went directly to inculpate the rebel officials of the War Department at Richmond. An ex-Confederate Military Inspector, Col. CHANDLER, was on the stand; a copy of a report he made on the condition of the Andersonville prison was laid before the court; and his sworn testimony, given therewith, presents the most conclusive proofs that the starving of our prisoners was a deliberate scheme, which had the assent of the highest Confederate authorities. While the late WINDER and WIRZ were the active and eager agents in the infliction of the unparalleled tortures which our men endured, it is clear beyond all doubt, from Col. CHANDLER's testimony, that the superiors of WINDER and WIRZ gave their fullest sanction to the hellish devices practiced at Andersonville. On the 5th of August, 1864, CHANDLER reported to Richmond, respecting the prison-pen, that it was "a place the horrors of which it is difficult to describe, and which is a disgrace to civilization." So horror-struck was this Confederate officer with what he saw within the stockade, that he went so far as to plead, in his report, with the Richmond War Department for the removal of WINDER and for the appointment of someone who "does not advocate in cold blood the propriety of leaving them (the prisoners) in their present condition until their number has been sufficiently reduced by death to make the present arrangements suffice for their accommodation." Not only was this report of CHANDLER's laid before the rebel Secretary of War and his Assistant but CHANDLER went himself personally to the rebel War-office to urge that it should be taken up and acted on. What was the result of this double appeal? WINDER, the hell-hound of Anderson-ville, was promoted to the post of "Commissary-General of Prisoners" for the whole Confederacy!
headline: {'main': 'THE WIRZ TRIAL.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE WIRZ TRIAL.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A NEW PRESBYTERIAN CHURCH. -- The congregation which for many years have worshiped at the corner of Grand and Crosby streets, under Rev. Dr. THOMPSON, having some time since sold that property, and purchased ground for the site of a new edifice on Thirty-fourth-street, near Broadway, broke ground on Thursday last with appropriate ceremonies. The Building Committee and their architect, Mr. JARDINE, with several other gentlemen, met on the premises at 3 P.M., when Rev. Dr. THOMPSON initiated the work of excavation by removing with his own hands the first shovel-full of earth. The edifice will be a splendid gothic structure of Belville sandstone, and will cost when completed about $80,000.

abstract: The action of the Democratic Convention at Albany is the boldest party manoeuvre ever known in this country.
lead_paragraph: The action of the Democratic Convention at Albany is the boldest party manoeuvre ever known in this country. If LEE, instead of surrendering to GRANT, had raised the Stars and Stripes, sworn his troops to support the Constitution of the United States, and marched on Richmond, he would have done precisely what DEAN RICHMOND did at Albany. It would have been, in LEE's case, a splendid display of desperate strategy, and nothing could have prevented its success but GRANT's possible incredulity as to the good faith of this pretended conversion. The political movement at Albany may encounter a similar obstacle.

abstract: City and County, and Assorting House Scheme
snippet: City and County, and Assorting House Scheme
lead_paragraph: An old Bank Officer said to us after the failure of the Assorting House scheme some weeks ago, that he believed that if every city bank were left to mind its own business in reference to the use of greenbacks and National Currency, it would be best for all parties, and especially so for the public convenience. But the scheme is to be tried again at a meeting of the Associated Banks -- including the old local banks who refuse to have anything to do with the National system, except to embarrass its steady working by their votes in the Clearing House -- to be held on Wednesday, 13th inst. Several of the opponents of the scheme have courteously yielded their consent to this meeting, but without abating one jot of their unwillingness to prescribe National Country Bank Notes, or meaning to tolerate the assorting process if attempted. It is taken for granted, though the fact may not turn out so, that the conference will be so far public as to authorize a report of the vote by ayes and noes on the subject, that the seven or eight hundred interior National Banks that keep their accounts in New-York, may understand who really are the promoters of this scheme, and how many of them are rightly entitled to direct the management of a system with which they are in open and declared hostility. Eight of the original National City Banks are not in the association, and will not be consulted at all, although the scheme, if really designed to be general and practical, more nearly concerns them and the two hundred or more Country Nationals that keep their accounts with them, than the same number of local banks that are still suffered to act upon national questions at the Clearing House.

abstract: Bay, Dr. William, of Albany
snippet: Bay, Dr. William, of Albany
lead_paragraph: Dr. WILLIAM BAY, of Albany, died, at the advanced ago of 92, on Thursday last. Dr. BAY was actively employed in his profession more than sixty years; and for more than half a century in Albany, where, also, he was born. When fifty years of his professional life closed, the event was marked by a highly interesting manifestation of popular respect. His friends and professional brethren invited him to a banquet, which was numerously attended, and proved how universally Dr. BAY was esteemed by his follow-citizens, how highly he was estimated by the medical profession, and how truly he was loved by his patients.

abstract: American Association for the Advancement of Science
snippet: American Association for the Advancement of Science
lead_paragraph: Now that so many popular scientific and philanthropic associations which existed in the days before the war, but which ceased their activity during its progress, are being revived, we should like to know why some effort is not being made for the resumption of the meetings of the "American Association for the Advancement of Science." This body of savans used formerly to hold an annual session in one or other of the great cities or lesser towns of the Union -- one year in some Western city, another year in a Southern city, or an Eastern city, or in a city of the Central States. It had a very large membership of the learned men of the country, among whom were those of the highest distinction, as AGASSIZ, PIERCE, GOULD, GIBBES, the brothers ROGERS, the brothers WHITNEY, the brothers LECONTE, and others. At the last meeting, held at Newport, before the breaking out of the war, there were representatives from the scientific men of almost every State of the Union. The next session was appointed to be held (if we remember aright) in Memphis; but before the time for the meeting had arrived, Tennessee had seceded, and the war was raging.
headline: {'main': 'The American Association for the Advancement of Science.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The American Association for the Advancement of Science.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Werner, Mrs. E., Beaten to Death by J. Metz
snippet: Werner, Mrs. E., Beaten to Death by J. Metz
lead_paragraph: Some time ago Mr. EDWIN S. BARRETT, of Wall-street, agent for Ex-Governor JOSEPH A. GILMORE, of New-Hampshire, entered complaint at the Halls of Justice against Mr. CHARLES J. ANTHONY, of Worcester, Mass., alleging that that person had persuaded him to invest $15,000 of Ex-Governor GILMORE's money in the stock of the Mooseland Gold Company, under a representation that the Mooseland mines, which are or ought to be in Nova Scotia, yield or ought to yield a clear surplus of $500 a day. Charging that this showing was utterly false, Mr. BARRETT accused Mr. ANTHONY of obtaining money by false pretence, and to answer this charge Justice DOWLING held the latter to bail in $15,000, to appear at 9 o'clock on the morning of the 11th inst.; but at 10 o'clock neither the complainant nor his counsel had appeared, and on motion of Mr. JOHN SEDGWICK, counsel for the defence, Justice DOWLING canceled the defendant's bail-bond, and dismissed the complaint.

abstract: Sewerage, Law and System of
snippet: Sewerage, Law and System of
lead_paragraph: A law was passed at the last session of the Legislature, giving to the Croton Aqueduct Board of New-York "power to devise and frame a plan of sewerage and drainage of the whole of said city," and enacting that the board should lay out the city into as many sewerage districts as they might deem necessary; should make maps or plans of the location, course, size and grade of each sewer and drain proposed for each of the districts, and of the alterations and improvements required in existing sewers, and draw up a complete plan for the proposed sewerage. The board were at the same time authorized to employ such engineers, surveyors and other persons, and to take and acquire such lands, in accordance with the laws, as would be necessary in the prosecution of the work.

abstract: That uneasy and garrulous Southron, Mr. HENRY S. FOOTE, having got back to Tennessee, by special favor of the President, is again garrulous in the newspapers. Those who remember his aspirations in the United States Senate, some ten or fifteen years ago, may be glad to hear the pitch of his pipe at the present hour.
lead_paragraph: That uneasy and garrulous Southron, Mr. HENRY S. FOOTE, having got back to Tennessee, by special favor of the President, is again garrulous in the newspapers. Those who remember his aspirations in the United States Senate, some ten or fifteen years ago, may be glad to hear the pitch of his pipe at the present hour. It is thus: "I prefer to end our troubles at once by granting the right of suffrage (to the freedmen.) Whatever plausible objections may be presented to this measure, for one, I prefer it to the longer continuance of the present distressing condition of affairs. I desire the early disbanding of the armies now occupying Southern territory. I desire the speedy and perfect restoration of civil authority everywhere. I desire the immediate representation of all the States of the South in the National Legislature; and having good reason to believe that these benefits will not be accorded to us until African suffrage is consented to, I am prepared to make the experiment at once."

abstract: Freemasons and Politics and the War; Speech on Reconstruction
snippet: Freemasons and Politics and the War; Speech on Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: We published in the TIMES, day before yesterday, a full report of a speech made by Hon. THADDEUS STEVENS on the 6th inst., at Lancaster, Penn., on the subject of reconstruction. The position held by Mr. STEVENS in Congress, and his known ability and political experience, give special interest to his views upon the most important question now before the country. The war is over; the rebellion is ended, and the sovereign authority of the National Government is reestablished over every foot of the national domain. In what way shall we make this victory most beneficial to the country? How shall we treat the great body of the people lately in rebellion? Shall we remand them and their affairs to the great fundamental principle of self-government, or shall we assert over them the extreme rights of conquerors, imposing upon them such laws as we please, and holding their lives, their property, their civil rights and their political powers subject, wholly and exclusively, to our will and pleasure?
headline: {'main': 'Restoration vs. Extermination Views of Hon. Thad. Stevens.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Restoration vs. Extermination Views of Hon. Thad. Stevens.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A NEW BAPTIST CHURCH. The dedication of the Fifty-third-street Baptist Church, near Seventhavenue, took place on Sunday. The sermon in the morning was preached by Rev. J.W. HOLMAN, Several appropriate hymns were executed in fine style by the choir at various times during the service.
lead_paragraph: A NEW BAPTIST CHURCH. -- The dedication of the Fifty-third-street Baptist Church, near Seventhavenue, took place on Sunday. The sermon in the morning was preached by Rev. J.W. HOLMAN, Several appropriate hymns were executed in fine style by the choir at various times during the service. A collection was taken up to aid in the completion of the church. The basement of the building in which the dedication was held, is the only part as yet completed, and is 65 by 80 feet. It will cost four thousand dollars to finish the church. Rev. J.L. HODGE preached in the afternoon, and Rev. R.J.W. BUCKLAND in the evening.

abstract: -- We observe that one of the Southern papers, in retaliation we suppose for publications in the North showing the demoralized condition of Southern society, is collating from all sources the vast mass of criminal and immoral news regarding New-York. It makes, of course, a frightful exhibit; and the Southern people who read it, and know nothing further of New-York, may well come to the conclusion that society here is utterly putrid. There is no doubt, however, that it gives as accurate an idea of the condition of things in this city, as much of the Southern news printed here gives of the condition of things in the South. If it were to be taken as a fair statement of the general life, or the average moral condition of New-York, we should quite agree with a country exchange, that the "question of reconstruction should be indefinitely postponed, and the entire nation should be agitated until an universal public sentiment stimulates an universal activity to rescue New-York from the abyss on the edge of which it insanely indulges in its carnival of transgression, and into which it must soon be hurled by the inevitable laws of retribution." Neither the South nor the North is as bad as those imagine who only know of the bad things in either.

abstract: Suffrage in Connecticut; Advocates Negro Suffrage
snippet: Suffrage in Connecticut; Advocates Negro Suffrage
lead_paragraph: -A popular vote is to be taken in Connecticut on the first Monday in October, on an amendment to the consitution, by which the word "while" is to be stricken out from that clause prescribing the qualifications of electors. The amendment was passed almost unanimously by the last Legislature for submission to the people. Its object is to place all men, black and white, upon the same footing, so far a the right of voting is concerned.

abstract: The fourth day's sale (yesterday's) went off with decidedly more liveliness than that of any previous day. Indeed, the sale is evidently and decidedly successful. About a third more buyers are present than have usually attended the sales, and the rates commanded by standard books and meritorious light literature are unexpectedly high.
lead_paragraph: The fourth day's sale (yesterday's) went off with decidedly more liveliness than that of any previous day. Indeed, the sale is evidently and decidedly successful. About a third more buyers are present than have usually attended the sales, and the rates commanded by standard books and meritorious light literature are unexpectedly high. This is, in part, at least, owing to the conviction felt by the trade that prices are now settled pretty nearly where they must remain for many months, and to the consequent filling up somewhat resolutely of their standard stock, exhausted by four years of cautious low trading. The demand for books grows livelier, moreover, among the community now that the war is over. As an example of the firmness of the transactions of this sale, it may be mentioned that sales continue at least as spirited as they were on the first day, notwithstanding that during the intermediate five days the price of book-paper has risen four or five cents a pound. Something of this prosperity is due to the presence of buyers from Richmond, Charleston, New-Orleans, Galveston and other Southern and Southwestern points; but their purchases are not so large as to materially color the aspect of the business.

abstract: THE BATEMAN CONCERTS. New-York is by no means a favorable place for miscellaneous concerts. The business has been overdone, and we have passed to a condition where nothing short of the best will suffice.
lead_paragraph: THE BATEMAN CONCERTS. -- New-York is by no means a favorable place for miscellaneous concerts. The business has been overdone, and we have passed to a condition where nothing short of the best will suffice. Mr. BATEMAN, whose entertainments commenced last evening, at Irving Hall, has prudently recognized this fact, and comes to us with a company of unquestionable excellence. He adds to it the local power of an orchestra, and leaves nothing in freshness or strength to be desired. We trust sincerely that his venture may prove successful. Without treading on the higher ground of the Philharmonic Society, or the symphonic soirees of THEODORE THOMOS, he provides a neutral programme of great merit -- one, in fact, which must appeal more directly to the public taste than either of those furnished by the institutions just named. Of Mr. BATEMAN it is almost unnecessary to speak. He has been before the public for a full quarter of a century, and his family have carried the name honorably and triumphantly through Europe. Miss KATE BATEMAN has been for many months iu England, and her return to America will be an occasion of public demonstration. Her success on the other side has been ample and satisfactory. Few artists have received so warm an approval, so persistent a regard from the English press. Mr. BATEMAN appears before us now as a concert giver, and comes with an entirely fresh batch of artists, engaged, it seems to us, judiciously, and with every project of winning more than an average success.

abstract: -- Counterfeit fifty-cent bills are "thick as hops" -- in fact, in this city, a great deal thicker. They are not difficult of detection; but most folks are so careless in the handling and passage of currency bills, that they have found a very wide circulation. What we should like to hear of is the detection and punishment of some of the counterfeiters of this and other government notes. What is being done in this line? What is being done to make counterfeiting dangerous, and to prevent its enormous extension, to the great loss of the government? Where are the government detectives?

abstract: Statistics, History, Laws, Commissioners, >amp;c.
snippet: Statistics, History, Laws, Commissioners, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Organized charity and incorporated benevolence are very different matters from individual almsgiving and spontaneous assistance to those in distress. It is one thing to give a passing beggar a dime, and quite another to provide dimes and homes for tens of thousands of needy people. Of all cities in this country -- of all places in the world, in fact -- New-York is at present, as it has been at any time during the last ten years, the field par excellence for the operations of an enlarged and catholic spirit of genuine charity. The gateway of the vast Western prairies is the Castle Garden portal; the entrance to the boundless resources of the continent is the sliding-door at the Battery. Through these come monthly thousands upon thousands of boned and sinewed men and women, anxious for employment, flushed with the hope of fortune and independence, spurred on to exertion by the recollection of past miseries and the memory of dear ones yet suffering in the hovels they have left behind. How are they to be met, how provided for, how kept from pauperism and consequent distress, how taught the road to success, how put into the path of honorable labor, how kept from the rolls of the almshouse, how compelled to look out for themselves, and thus made trustworthy, desirable citizens of the commonwealth? These and other like questions have for years occupied the attention of the practical minds among us, and with the emergency came the relief. This relief is found in the organization known as the

abstract: -- There is, no doubt, good cause for some of the complaints of the dirty condition of the city railroad cars, and of their being infested with obnoxious vermin. The stuffed seats give shelter and encouragement to these vermin, beside absorbing and circulating the noxious exhalations from the bodies of the myriad passengers who daily crowd each car. Many people are terrified to ride on some of the lines. The adoption of open cane-bottomed seats, instead of cushions, would prevent many of the evils complained of.

abstract: -- It will be seen by a reference to our European summary that LAWLEY, the veracious Southern correspondent of the London Times, has come to the rescue in behalf of the late Confederate authorities, against the plain, honest statements of the Times' new representative here. LAWLEY. evidently thinks that the public have forgotten how he lied and lied in the interest of these same Confederate authorities for nearly three years. But the public have not forgotten. And what he says now will be taken with all the allowance which ought to be made for such a witness. Even judging LAWLEY, however, by his own admissions, he proves a great deal too much for the good of his Confederate friends. He admits that DAVIS and LEE were surrounded by men who counseled unmentionable projects of warfare, and that the chiefs of the Confederacy resisted these counsels. But what about WINDER? The authorities at Richmond knew all about his scheme of retaliatory warfare at Andersonville. Col. CHANDLER, the rebel inspector, told them about that scheme in his report; and went to Richmond expressly to represent that WINDER was pursuing a course of treatment toward the Union prisoners that was "a disgrace to civilization." What answer came to that report and to CHANDLER's personal protest? The answer came under the sign manual of JEFFERSON DAVIS in the shape of a commission appointing WINDER to the post of Commissary-General of prisoners for the entire Confederacy! LAWLEY had better deal with that fact when he writes again.
lead_paragraph: -- It will be seen by a reference to our European summary that LAWLEY, the veracious Southern correspondent of the London Times, has come to the rescue in behalf of the late Confederate authorities, against the plain, honest statements of the Times' new representative here. And what he says now will be taken with all the allowance which ought to be made for such a witness. Even judging LAWLEY, however, by his own admissions, he proves a great deal too much for the good of his Confederate friends. He admits that DAVIS and LEE were surrounded by men who counseled unmentionable projects of warfare, and that the chiefs of the Confederacy resisted these counsels. But what about WINDER? The authorities at Richmond knew all about his scheme of retaliatory warfare at Andersonville. Col. CHANDLER, the rebel inspector, told them about that scheme in his report; and went to Richmond expressly to represent that WINDER was pursuing a course of treatment toward the Union prisoners that was "a disgrace to civilization." What answer came to that report and to CHANDLER's personal protest? The answer came under the sign manual of JEFFERSON DAVIS in the shape of a commission appointing WINDER to the post of Commissary-General of prisoners for the entire Confederacy! abstract: Somebody, adding to his name "P.G.M. and P.G.H.P., of Kentucky, "sends to one of the editors of THE TIMES a long printed letter, asking for a convocation of incumbent officers of Grand Lodges and Chapters in the United States, to be held at Louisville next month, to smooth out, by the mild spirit of Masonry, all the wrinkles made in the temper of our people, North and South, during the past five years.
lead_paragraph: Somebody, adding to his name "P.G.M. and P.G.H.P., of Kentucky, "sends to one of the editors of THE TIMES a long printed letter, asking for a convocation of incumbent officers of Grand Lodges and Chapters in the United States, to be held at Louisville next month, to smooth out, by the mild spirit of Masonry, all the wrinkles made in the temper of our people, North and South, during the past five years. He means well, does this P.G., &c., we doubt not; but his zeal is froward. Masons, as masons, have nothing to do with political pacification; and it would have been well if some high lights in the order had remembered this -- for instance, ALBERT PIKE, of Arkansas, whose burly and commanding presence we last saw in the star-gemmed chamber of the Lodge of Perfection in Broadway, clad in the cabalistic costume of the highest known degree of the Scottish rites. The Apostle's command, to be subject to the higher powers and pay deference to political rulers without seeking to direct them, was not more binding upon those whom he addressed, than are the similar commands of all Masonic law and tradition -- that, as an order, the members of the fraternity are required to yield peacefully to the established rule, and by no official act to meddle with government. Had they done so in the South, where nearly all the elite of the ruling classes are prominent masons, they might have much retarded, if not prevented the great rebellion; had they respected the still-preserved masonic insignia of WASHINGTON and LAFAYETTE, they would have looked in vain for a PIKE and a BRAGG, and a hundred others, to raise their hands against "the powers that be." And now that it is over, we fancy that the lesson of experience will not strongly favor the coddling of erratic brethren who have alike outraged the non-political and fraternal laws of the order.

abstract: William Burton informed Assistant District-Attorney Bedford that he was laboring under the conviction of having committed a crime, in that he had enlisted in the United States service at Yonkers, received the bounty, and was discharged on account of physical disability; subsequently he reenlisted at Staten Island, when, in order to get the bounty, $600, he swore that he had never been in the service. Being so conscience-stricken that he could get neither sleep nor rest he disclosed the facts.

abstract: South, False Reports of Cruelties to
snippet: South, False Reports of Cruelties to
lead_paragraph: It is only a few days since we were enabled to contradict, on the best authority, the story which had been widely published, and we suppose widely credited, in the North, that a certain Georgia doctor had sawed off the legs of a negro to prevent his running away. We now find in the Alabama papers explicit contradictions of other able fictions which have lately been sent from the South to this section of the country -- such as, that a general slaughter of negroes was in progress in Alabama, which, in the words of the original narrator, "would make you sick of life," -- that "one hundred and thirty-three dead negroes had been found in the woods," -that "five Africans were seen floating in the river," -- that "two men (white of course) were seen to pull a negro down across a log and cut his head off with an axe," -- that "black women and children were killed and then boxed up and thrown into the river," etc., etc. It seems that all these horrific tales are false. We never supposed them to be true. But we suppose somebody must have believed them, or at least expected others to believe them, else they would never have been sent. The authority given for them in the Chicago papers was that of a Teacher of Colored Schools, whose veracity was said to be vouched for by the Secretary of the Northwestern Freedmen's Aid Commission.

abstract: Cunao vs. Perazzo; Gold Dust Robbery Case
snippet: Cunao vs. Perazzo; Gold Dust Robbery Case
lead_paragraph: Edward Cunao vs. Peter Perazzo. -- Plaintiff, who is a returned Californian, claims to have brought home a large amount of gold dust and twenty-dollar gold pieces; went to the boarding-house of the defendant, his countryman, and there, according to his own account, was persuaded by Mr. Perazzo that it was unsafe to take his money to the Five Points, where he was about to go, and to leave it in his charge. Shortly after doing this the defendant having gone out, his wife raised the cry of "thieves," and on entering his room the box in which the money was placed was found broken open and all the valuables removed. The plaintaiff has sued the defendant and procured his arrest for the fraudulent conversion of the gold. The defendant now moves to vacate the order of arrest on affidavits showing his own absence at the time of the robbery and his long residence and good character in this city.

abstract: Coroner FARREL, of Jersey City, held an inquest yesterday on the body of a young man named EDWARD GAVIN, a hand on the barge Wm. Baxter, who fell overboard the day previous at the Oil Inspection Dock, foot of North Third-street, and was drowned. Deceased was in the act of throwing a line ashore, when the boat struck the dock with such force that he was knocked overboard and was drowned before he could be rescused. A verdict of accidental drowning was rendered. Deceased was a single man and resided at Green Point, Long Island, where his remains were conveyed for interment.

abstract: Yesterday was one of social entertainment and pleasure at Jones' Wood for our returned veterans. Under the management of Col. J.B. HERMAN, of the Soldiers' Protective and Employment society, a grand congratulatory pic-nic, to further the laudable purpose of securing peaceful employment to our discharged soldiers and sailors, this gathering among the defenders of the Union was instituted.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was one of social entertainment and pleasure at Jones' Wood for our returned veterans. Under the management of Col. J.B. HERMAN, of the Soldiers' Protective and Employment society, a grand congratulatory pic-nic, to further the laudable purpose of securing peaceful employment to our discharged soldiers and sailors, this gathering among the defenders of the Union was instituted. The day, although cloudy, interfered less with the amusements than might have been expected. The sons of mars with their belles, tripped as lightly to the Music as though they had been all their lives votaries to the art of Terpsichore. Nothing interfered, save a few drops of cooling rain, to mar the pleasure of the day, and we doubt if a more respectable and well-behaved audience ever visited Jones' Wood.

abstract: Reconstruction in
snippet: Reconstruction in
lead_paragraph: The South Carolina Convention, the delegates to which were elected on the 4th inst, is to meet to-day. Its doings will excite a peculiar interest in the North, for the reason that South Carolina was the original seed-bed of the heresy of secession, and its people have been longer and more virulently alienated from the National Government than those of any other State. It is certain enough that we have a new growth there of some sort. But what? Wheat or tares?

lead_paragraph: yesterday morning on board the bark Frank Levett, at Pier No. 10 North River, and both were almost instantly killed. The victims were CHARLES WILLIAMS, first mate, a Nova-Scotian, of 22 years, and EDWARD FREDERICK, second mate, also a native of Nova-Scotia, aged 35 years. They had been sent aloft to strip the foretopmast, and while they were taking the rigging from the mast-head the stick broke, and both men fell to the deck. The first mate died instantly, having received a compound fracture of the skull, and had the bones of both arms and one thigh broken; but the second mate was alive when Capt.HORTON reached the spot, a few minutes subsequent to the accident. lead_paragraph: War's triumphs are ended; those of Peace are now in order. The American Institute, one of the oldest and most efficient of our country's promoters in the lines of art, invention and agriculture, is among the first of our peaceful institutions to take up the dropped thread of progress, resuming with zeal its warp and woof of enterprise and research. abstract: Hoboken Fall Races--First Day
snippet: Hoboken Fall Races--First Day
lead_paragraph: The opening of the Hudson County Association Fall Meeting, yesterday, was most auspicious; a large and select assemblage, comprising a great number of ladies, being present to witness and enjoy the sport. The racing was of the highest order; the contests being close and exciting, and the judgement of the knowing ones fairly upset by the unexpected results. The track was in fine order, and the arrangements for the preservation of order and comfort of the spectators, were perfect in every particular. There was a strong police force in attendance, while the exclusion of the light-fingered gentry from the course was efficiently accomplished by Detectives BENNETT and WILSON. Although the lowering clouds threatened rain, and prevented many from going who purposed doing so, yet it kept fair and favorable throughout the day.

abstract: About 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon two small boys, named WM. MORROW and MATTHEW FALLON, were run over by a heavy double-wagon, which was driven at a furious rate, in Exchange-place, Jersey City. The wheel passed over the chest of the boy MORROW, injuring him very severely. The lads received medical attendance, and were then conveyed to their homes in Sussex-street. The driver, LOUIS WEEDMEYER, was arrested by Officer MCWILLIAMS, and was held for examination.

abstract: Registry Law, The Complaints Against
snippet: Registry Law, The Complaints Against
lead_paragraph: An outery is made against the Amended Registry Law, which is to be applied, for the first time, at the coming election. The absolute requirement of a registration before the day of election, and the appointment of the Inspectors of Election by the Police Board, are the special grievances. The one is denounced as an unconstitutional abridgment of the right of suffrage; the other as a tyrannical interference by a board neither created by nor responsible to the people of this city.

abstract: -- A special meeting of the Jersey City Common Council was held last evening, for the purpose of electing various city officers. All the members were present except Alderman DECKER. The board first proceeded to the election of a City Printer, JOHN H. LYON (Dem.,) and D.S. GREGORY, Jr., (Union,) being nominated. Nine ballots were had, without resulting in a choice, when further balloting was dispensed with. The board then proceeded to the election of a Street Commissioner, for which there were several candidates, the principal ones being JOHN VAN REIPER and WM. MURRAY. After four ballots, without a choice, the board adjourned.

abstract: Saratoga Railroad; Collision Near Moreau Station
snippet: Saratoga Railroad; Collision Near Moreau Station
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, the 9th inst., a collision took place on the Saratoga Railroad, some two miles south of Moreau Station, between two freight trains. It appears that the two trains were proceeding along close together, the first one having a passenger-car attached. The leading train was going at a very slow rate of speed, while the hindmost one was coming at a rapid pace. The result of the collision was a complete smash.

abstract: On the evening of May 21, Mr. WILLIAM WHEATLEY'S wardrobe, in the property-room of Niblo's Theatre, was destroyed by fire of incendiary origin, and as circumstances pointed directly to JAMES McDONOUGH, an employe who had been dismissed from the theatre, he was apprehended and held for examination by Fire-Marshal BAKER.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of May 21, Mr. WILLIAM WHEATLEY'S wardrobe, in the property-room of Niblo's Theatre, was destroyed by fire of incendiary origin, and as circumstances pointed directly to JAMES McDONOUGH, an employe who had been dismissed from the theatre, he was apprehended and held for examination by Fire-Marshal BAKER. The hearing was resumed yesterday morning, and Mr. JOHN DONNELLY, of Washington City, testified that Mr. MCDONOUGH was at his house in the Federal city on the 18th of May, and tarried there until the 2d of June, when he left Washington with a government mule train. MCDONOUGH sister also was put on the stand, and she made oath that she went with him to the cars in Jersey City on the 17th of May, and saw him depart for Washington; and that, moreover, he wrote thence on the 19th of May to CATHERINE HAYES, and the letter which he then wrote was produced in court, properly postmarked "Washington, May 19, 1865." Justice DOWLING, holding that an alibi had been clearly established, dismissed the complaint, and next turned his attention to

abstract: Independence and Lord Bury's Plan
snippet: Independence and Lord Bury's Plan
lead_paragraph: -- The evidences have neither been scant nor doubttul since the scheme of a British American Confederation was first broached that the British Government, in urging the prosecution of that seheme, as it has done, was simply paying the way for casting the Colonies adritt in the least offensive manner possible. In advance of Confederation, the Home authorities have authorized the institution of a Confederate Council for the regulation of such international questions as the Reciprocity Treaty. This new executive authority is evidently intended to supply the place of a Foreign Office for the whole of British America; and its creation is the most advanced and the most practical step yet taken toward terminating the colonial connection.

abstract: -- This was a motion to strike out the defendant's answer as false and frivolous. The action was upon a draft dated June 16, 1865, at one day's eight, drawn by the defendant upon Messrs. Stowell, Chamberlain & Co., to the order of the plaintiff for $1,750, but which was protested for non-acceptance. The defendant set up that the draft was owned by the Ascot Gold Mining Association, and was given by the defendant for the purchase of two shares and a half in the association, upon which he had previously paid $2,005, and that he had been induced by the plaintiff and others to purchase that share, upon the representation that they were to pay $180,000 for the land of the company, whereas they had paid less than $50,000, which fact the defendant alleged he had discovered the day the draft was given. It appeared, however, and the defendant did not deny it, that the defendant was a corporator and trustee of the Ascot Gold and Mining Company, and had taken an active part in its organization, and had attended the meeting of the trustees, after his answer was put and voted, until then, and had never offered to resign, and that he had never made any complaint that he had been defrauded until he put in his answer; and also, that before he paid the last installment of $1,750 upon his share in the Association, he had personally examined the lands of the Company, and expressed himself satisfied with them, and then subscribed for an additional share; and that when the draft in suit had been protested, he had frequently promised to pay it. The plaintiff stated in his affidavit positively that be owned the draft, and had discounted it for defendant, who had assured him it would be promptly met, and in this statement he was confirmed by Mr. Chambers, the Secretary of the Company, who also stated that the Company had no interest in the draft. The plaintiff, and the other persons alleged by the defendant to have made fraudulent statements to him, also swore positively they never had made any such statements. The court took the papers and reserved its decision.

abstract: The latest advices from Hayti, through official sources, state that though the revolutionists have held out longer than was expected, they must submit before long. The rebellion has been prolonged at Cape Haytien, because President JEFFRARD, by investing the town, hoped to weary out the rebel garrison, without inflicting upon the citizens the horrors of a bombardment. But the President has now decided to take more determined measures, and bring matters to a close.

abstract: Reply to Deputation of Southerners on his Intentions; Reply to Richm'd Deputation on Visit
snippet: Reply to Deputation of Southerners on his Intentions; Reply to Richm'd Deputation on Visit
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON'S reply to the deputation of Southerners, which we published in full yesterday morning, gives a very clear indication of the spirit and temper which he brings to the task of reconstruction. It is a spirit of kindness, of magnanimity, of paramount devotion to the public good. Personally, inspite of the jeers and hatred with which the South greeted his adhesion to the Union cause, with a full recollection of the obloquy and Buffering he has endured at the hands of the Southern people, he has no revenges to gratify, no resentments to indulge. He longs only to restore the old relations of amity between the different States and sections of the country, and to secure the highest welfare of the people everywhere. He charges upon the South all the responsibility of the rebellion, -- telling them that they made the issue, -- but recognizing the frankness, sincerity and good faith with which they accept their defeat, and inviting, cordially and hopefully, their aid in whatever the new condition of affairs may require. He disclaims all wish to deal harshly with the Southern people, and cautions them against being alarmed or disturbed by the hostile speeches that may be made.

abstract: Algonquin; Engineers of and Winooski Working
snippet: Algonquin; Engineers of and Winooski Working
lead_paragraph: At about 7 o'clock on Monday evening the fires in the Algonquin's furnaces were lighted, and before 9 o'clock the wheels were revolving in fine style. It is fair to say that the Algonquin can get up steam in a very few minutes, owing to a peculiarity of her boilers and the arrangement of the heating surface. Mr. DICKERSON was present, and through the entire night he gave his personal attention to the working of the engine, and it was not until the grey morn announced the approach of day, that he relinquished his charge, and turning it over to a subordinate, sought his home and couch. The engine was kept running at a moderate speed from the time it was started, and its workings noted with a nicety and regularity.
headline: {'main': 'THE RACE AT THE DOCK.; The Engines of the Algonquin and Winooski at Work No Formal Trial Made as Yet.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE RACE AT THE DOCK.; The Engines of the Algonquin and Winooski at Work No Formal Trial Made as Yet.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- A NARROW ESCAPE FROM A TERRIBLE EXPLOSION. -- At the special meeting of the Jersey City Common Council last evening, a communication was received from Mr. RIDDLE, General Superintendent of the Erie Railway Company, setting forth that there is a barge anchored south of the Pavonia Ferry in the Hudson River, loaded with seven hundred tons of gunpowder, belonging to and kept in store by DUPONT; that on Friday night last another barge, in close proximity to the one thus loaded with powder, caught fire, and but for the watchfulness of some persons on a schooner, the fire would have communicated to the barge in which the powder was stored; that in case of an explosion of the powder, there would have been imminent danger that the buildings and boats of the Erie Railway Company would have been damaged, if not destroyed. Mr. RIDDLE therefore requested of the board that the Marshal of the city, or some other proper officer, be requested to take such steps as may be deemed necessary to remove the said vessel to some point or place where, in case of an explosion, life and property would not be in danger. The meeting having been called for a special purpose, no action could be taken further than to direct the City Clerk to send the communication to the Mayor, who is clothed with all necessary power in such matters.
lead_paragraph: -- A NARROW ESCAPE FROM A TERRIBLE EXPLOSION. -- At the special meeting of the Jersey City Common Council last evening, a communication was received from Mr. RIDDLE, General Superintendent of the Erie Railway Company, setting forth that there is a barge anchored south of the Pavonia Ferry in the Hudson River, loaded with seven hundred tons of gunpowder, belonging to and kept in store by DUPONT; that on Friday night last another barge, in close proximity to the one thus loaded with powder, caught fire, and but for the watchfulness of some persons on a schooner, the fire would have communicated to the barge in which the powder was stored; that in case of an explosion of the powder, there would have been imminent danger that the buildings and boats of the Erie Railway Company would have been damaged, if not destroyed. Mr. RIDDLE therefore requested of the board that the Marshal of the city, or some other proper officer, be requested to take such steps as may be deemed necessary to remove the said vessel to some point or place where, in case of an explosion, life and property would not be in danger. The meeting having been called for a special purpose, no action could be taken further than to direct the City Clerk to send the communication to the Mayor, who is clothed with all necessary power in such matters.

abstract: -- A discharged seaman, named TIMOTHY QUINN, residing at No. 57 Watt-street, New-York, having made the acquaintance of JOHN LOWE, who resides at the corner of Nassau-street and Hudson-avenue, was invited to his house last night. They had taken several drinks, and QUINN, some time thereafter, as alleged, found himself in the street, with nothing on but a pair of pantaloons. His pocket-book, containing $9 and a United States Certificate for $800, were missing. The pocket-book, empty, was found on LOWE's premises. LOWE was arrested and committed by Judge CORNWELL, to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: LAURA MILLS, the wife of FRANKLIN MILLS, employed as engineer in the Eagle Building, near the foot of Fulton-street, came to her death in a mysterious manner, about 1 o'clock on Tuesday morning. The deceased and husband occupied the upper part of the building. They were refugees from the South, and had been living in the building for three or four months only. It appears that on Monday night Mr. MILLS returned from some place of amusement, and, according to his own statement, found his wife ill. Having taken some laudanum to relieve her pains, she fell against a trunk, and injured herself. Mr. MILLS then went for Dr. J.D. JOHNSON, who soon after arrived, and on examination found the woman in a dying condition, but exhibiting no symptoms of having taken poison. She was suffering great pain in the side, and the doctor administered hartshorn for the purpose of reviving her, which had the desired effect. She was then questioned as to the cause of her injuries, and stated distinctly that her husband had struck her with a bottle, which she pointed out on the mantel-piece. The physician believing that, under the circumstances, further assistance was required, sent for Dr. FARLEY, who arrived some time thereafter. The latter asked the same questions, and the woman being informed of her condition, made the same answers. The physicians then requested MILLS to go for Father KEEGAN, but instead of going himself woke up a man at a neighboring hotel and induced him to go. The woman died soon after. MILLS' statement is to the effect that his wife was afflicted with heart disease, and in order to relieve her she sometimes took opium and laudanum; that she had been very affectionate, and that they had lived happily together. A small laudanum bottle, which was empty, was found. In accordance with the views of Coroner BARRETT, it could not contain enough to kill any one who was addicted to the use of opium. The deceased was a native of Matanzas, Cuba, 38 years of age. They had lived in the South during the war, and escaped to the national lines some time last Winter. MILLS then came on to New-York for employment. He is an excellent engineer, and sober and attentive to his business. He was taken into custody by Capt. JACOBS, of the Forty-second Precinct Police, and locked up, to await the result of the Coroner's investigation. A postmortem examination will be made this morning at 8 o'clock, and the inquest will be commenced about one hour thereafter, when all the facts in the case will be developed.

abstract: We have advices up to a late period from the Indian Council at Fort Smith. On the 8th inst. Judge COOLEY read an address to the Indians, which was responded to by the Cherokees to the effect that they had no power to treat, but would refer any proposition the government would make to their National Council.
lead_paragraph: We have advices up to a late period from the Indian Council at Fort Smith. On the 8th inst. Judge COOLEY read an address to the Indians, which was responded to by the Cherokees to the effect that they had no power to treat, but would refer any proposition the government would make to their National Council. Responses from other tribes of a similar character were made. On Saturday, the council was taken up in reading the stipulations to be imposed by the government upon all treaties in the Southwest. The stipulations propose a grand consolidation of all Indian tribes into one nation, the territory of which shall be the present Indian Territory, and such other as the government may decide upon. The tribes now living in Kansas are to be removed South, and the Southwestern tribes are expected to compel the Indians of the plains to observe the treaties. The Indians say they understand they were called to meet the late rebel tribes, and renew friendly relations with them, and not to make new treaties, which they say they are unwilling and unauthorized to do. On Monday replies were made to the propositions presented them on Saturday. All spoke favorably of the policy of the government, and appear anxious to renew friendly relations with it. Many of them promise their aid in bringing the hostile Indians of the plains to terms.

abstract: A very active controversy is going on among the newspapers of Chicago, involving the ethics of journalism. One of the leading papers, it is alleged, is in the habit of publishing editorial articles upon matters of private interest for pay. The other journals denounce the practice, but have not succeeded in ...
lead_paragraph: -- A very active controversy is going on among the newspapers of Chicago, involving the ethics of journalism. One of the leading papers, it is alleged, is in the habit of publishing editorial articles upon matters of private interest for pay. The other journals denounce the practice, but have not succeeded in extracting an admission or denial from the alleged culprit. The practice, we presume, is not wholly un-unknown outside of Chicago; but we believe it is generally confined to those journals whose editorial opinions are not deemed of any special importance, or whose general business fails to pay expenses.

abstract: -- At the conclusion of a ball at Grosse's Garden, Grand-street, E.D., yesterday morning, a woodhouse in the rear of the place was fired. Mr. GROSS says he saw some men in the woodhouse previous to the discovery of the fire. When the engines arrived there was some slight disturbance among the firemen, two of whom, WILLIAM DOYLE, of Hose No. 10, and JOHN MULLIN, were arrested by the police of the Forty-sixth Precinct. When taken before Judge WALTER yesterday, Officer DIPPLE stated that when he attempted to arrest DOYLE he was knocked down with a blow from a trumpet, and FREDERICK CASTINE, of Hose No. 8, testified that he was knocked down by DOYLE. The Judge fined DOYLE $15, and MULLIN $5. The fire was extinguished with trifling loss.

abstract: New-Orleans Trade Review of September, '64, to September, '65
snippet: New-Orleans Trade Review of September, '64, to September, '65
lead_paragraph: The year that has since elapsed has been marked by events the commercial and industrial significance of which is hardly surpassed by their political importance. The Confederate armies, melting away under the combined influences of disease and desertion, were finally compelled to surrender to the Federal forces, and, the contest having been abandoned, the States of the Confederacy are about resuming their former relations to the United States Government. Thus peace is virtually restored, but whether or not it will realize its anticipated benefits to our commercial and industrial classes depends in a great degree on the final settlement of the relations between labor and capital, in connection with the culture of our chief Southern staples. In our remarks on this subject we propose to consider it free from all political bias, and with a single view to our trade and industry, and in order to show what we have lost by the war and recovered since its termination, we commence by a comparison of our principal receipts from the interior during the post year, with those of 1859-60 and 1863-64, as exhibited in the following table:

abstract: For a long time past, it has been considered dangerous to go to pic-nics and on excursions down the bay in steamers; the excursionists, if not robbed of their money, were likely to be beaten by rowdies. The best efforts of the authorities cannot stop it -- all they can do is to abate the evil. People, when they go to pic-nics now, anticipate that their pockets will be picked, either going to the pic-nic, at it, or coming from it, and therefore scatter their money through the various pockets in their clothing, so that if one pocket is cleaned out, they need not go begging among their friends for money to carry them home. Three "professionals," all under the age of twenty-five, very well dressed and likely to deceive, who gave the names of Augustus King, Edward Smith and Thomas Hurdy, pleaded not guilty to an assault on an unknown woman, with intent to steal as pickpockets. Detective Philip Farley said he was up to the excursion of the Caledonia Club, at Jones' Wood, last Thursday. The three prisoners, whom he knew by sight, came there. King got alongside of a woman with a baby, and tried to get his hand in her pocket. He did get his hand in, and the other two assisted. The three he followed for half an hour and saw them in conversation. When King put his hand in the woman's pocket one of the prisoners covered King's movements, and the other engaged her in conversation. The prisoner, Smith, tried his hand at cross-examining the officer, but he only strengthened the case for the prosecution. The officer said he knew all three by sight. Smith said he had only been from Philadelphia a few days, and had never been arrested before.

abstract: Report on Satisfactory Progress of Reconstruction
snippet: Report on Satisfactory Progress of Reconstruction
lead_paragraph: -- Gen. MEADE, it is said, has made a satisfactory report to the government of the reviving sense of political and social duty throughout the Southern section of his department. The report in question is to be made the basis for a reduction of the national army at several points in Virginia and North and South Carolina. For the time it is of great consequence to the white, not less than the black population of the South, that there should be military jurisdiction over disputed cases between the emancipated slaves and their late masters. But the authority of these special courts, if Gen. MEADE correctly estimates the sentiment of the resident population, will not require the support of any large force. And there seems to be on all hands an accumulation of evidence showing the existence of a disposition on the part of employers and employed to make the best of their new relationship. Herein, therefore, lies the main argument and justification for the Executive method of reconstruction. The return of the late insurgents to duty has to be met, as the President proposes to meet it, by extending confidence to them. How much is implied in the word confidence the honest citizens of the South now begin to discover, as they set about finding their way back into the Union.

abstract: writing from Rockport, after alluding to the ancient building known as the " Garrison House," with its legends of witches and Indians, says: "The Nutford family, consisting of a brother and sister, have for seventy years resided on, and never left Cape Ann.
lead_paragraph: writing from Rockport, after alluding to the ancient building known as the " Garrison House," with its legends of witches and Indians, says: "The Nutford family, consisting of a brother and sister, have for seventy years resided on, and never left Cape Ann. They have never seen railroad cars, although the whistle of the locomotive can almost be heard at their door. They are intelligent, and have many visitors during the Summer. Undoubtedly, the writer adds, they have enjoyed life better than many who enter the busy cares of the world. They are true conservatives, of the strictest school. -- Boston Transcript.

abstract: Algonquin and Winooski Trial, The
snippet: Algonquin and Winooski Trial, The
lead_paragraph: The public is becoming utterly disgusted with the conduct of the Navy Department in the trial of the new steamer Algonquin. It is impossible to resist the conviction that, for some reason or other, the department, under Mr. ISHERWOOD's direction, is determined to prevent the fair trial to which Mr. FORBES and the public are alike entitled. The direct issue is presented in a correspondence between Admiral GREGORY and Mr. FORBES, published in another column. The Admiral informs Mr. FORBES that the vessels are ready for the trial, and asks him if he has any objections to the mode, proposed, -- very coolly assuring him, at the same time, that the trial will proceed in spite of his objections, which will be considered afterward! Mr. FORBES very naturally objects to being thus executed and then tried.

abstract: SURGEON.--The London News of the Week contains a singular statement respecting the late Dr. BARRY, who must be well remembered by many of our readers, as holding the place of Inspector of Hospitals in this city, a few years ago.
lead_paragraph: SURGEON. -- The London News of the Week contains a singular statement respecting the late Dr. BARRY, who must be well remembered by many of our readers, as holding the place of Inspector of Hospitals in this city, a few years ago. The statement appears to be taken from some military journal, though of that we are not informed, and it is to the effect that Dr. BARRY died recently in Corfu, where he had determined to remain, after the island was surrendered to the Greeks; and that after his death it was discovered that he was a woman, and had been a mother. Those of our readers who remember him (or her) will doubtless be reminded that his appearance was by no means masculine. But how a woman could have obtained admission to the schools, and then to the army, is not explained. -- Montreal Gazette.

abstract: Speech at Union Meeting, Newark, N. J.
snippet: Speech at Union Meeting, Newark, N. J.
lead_paragraph: There was a large and exceedingly enthusiastic meeting of unionists at Library Hall, in Newark, on Wednesday night. The hall being much too small to accommodate the crowd in attendance, they adjourned to the open air, where for two or three hours a vast throng listened to stirring and patriotic addresses from distinguished speakers. The first speaker was Col. BEMENTE, of Tennessee -- a Union man all through, standing six feet in his boots. After him came the brave Gen. KILPATRICK, the substance of whose speech we make room for:

abstract: Enterprise vs. Eckford at Brooklyn; New-York vs. Boston, at Bedford
snippet: Enterprise vs. Eckford at Brooklyn; New-York vs. Boston, at Bedford
lead_paragraph: A very interesting and well-played game took place on the Capitoline grounds, Brooklyn, yesterday, the contestants being the first nines of the above clubs, the match being the return game between the two clubs. Both had good teams on the ground, though both were short their regular nine. The game opened favorably for the Eckfords by a score of 3 to 0, but afterwards the Enterprise boys recovered their lost ground creditably, the score standing 5 to 5 at the close of the fourth innings. Afterwards the Eckfords again took the lead in advance, and gradually increased their score until the totals stood 26 to 17, those being the figures when the Enterprise went into their last innings. By plucky, up-hill play the Bedford boys managed to pull up their score to 25, but before they could get the tie run in, the game ended. It was very exciting in the last innings. Though defeated, the Enterprise earned a victory. A feature of the match was the excellent decisions of the umpire. We have not seen him do better this season. We append the score:

abstract: ing down a school-house is about as low down in rascality as dirty fellows can fathom. We are sorry to say that some very mean rascals burned down the freedmen's school at Decherd the other day.
lead_paragraph: ing down a school-house is about as low down in rascality as dirty fellows can fathom. We are sorry to say that some very mean rascals burned down the freedmen's school at Decherd the other day. The fellows who perpetrated the act deserve to be kicked out of civilized society. As they will be required to rebuild the school-house, and will have colored troops sent there by the bureau forthwith to prevent any further interference with the humble and laudable efforts of a poor people to educate and improve themselves, they will find out that laying schoolhouses in ashes is a very unprofitable sort of amusement to indulge in.

abstract: Building Wagons in New-York
snippet: Building Wagons in New-York
lead_paragraph: that the Fenian Society is largely engaged in wagon manufacture up town. The vehicles already built are marked as the property of the Order, and they have very much the appearance of the conveyances which go to make up an army train. It is quite possible, however, that they may be merely covered carriages, to be used for pic-nic excursions. On this supposition the enterprise of the brotherhood resolves itself into a very harmless pastime, and no diplomatic complications need grow out of it. So much the better for the peace of the world. A few more pic-nics at Jones' Wood will hurt nobody; and a procession of canvas-covered wagons will be a novel feature in the demonstration.

abstract: Manhattan vs. Paterson, at Hoboken
snippet: Manhattan vs. Paterson, at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: The return match between the Manhattan and Paterson Cricket Clubs was played at the Hoboken Cricket Grounds on Tuesday, the 12th inst. The weather was extremely sultry and oppressive, but notwithstanding the heat there was a good day's sport. The fielding on both sides was excellent, there being but few opportunities lost. Play commenced at 11 A.M., and the stumps were drawn at 6:15 P.M. As there was not time to finish the game, the match was decided by the first innings. Patterson winning by 22 runs. The first match was also won by Paterson.

abstract: Second swarm of on Staten Island
snippet: Second swarm of on Staten Island
lead_paragraph: BEES. -- Mr. QUINBY, as well as all other apiarians among our readers who have made bee keeping a specialty, will be interested in learning that a swarm issued yesterday (Sept. 13) on Staten Island. It was a "second swarm." The owner was not on hand, and the bees left for parts unknown. In about one hour they returned and lodged on a tree, about ten feet from the parent hive, where they remained till nightfall when the owner appeared and hived them. We believe neither Messrs. LANGSTROTH nor QUINBY record so unusual an occurrence in their works. This swarm was half the size of the first Staten Island is devoid of a fair supply of honey. Bees near the shore have as yet deposited no honey in the boxes for market or family use. It is said that gentlemen there have actually to smother bees to get the honey. For general information, will Mr. QUINBY please tell us what is to be done with this late swarm?

snippet: Destitution in; the Two Races, >amp;c. Charleston News
lead_paragraph: The Charleston News of a recent date, gives a clear statement of the immense losses which South Carolina has sustained from the rebellion, and closes it by saying that the seven hundred thousand inhabitants of that State are now probably the poorest in the world. It says they have no right to complain of this; they brought it upon themselves. It is accepted by them as the inevitable penalty of failure in a cause upon which they had staked everything.

abstract: Algonquin; Trial Continued at Dock
snippet: Algonquin; Trial Continued at Dock
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday night the Algonquin and Winooski pulled away at the dock without damage to anything except the pile of coal on the pier. Some time during the night-watches the rings on the Algonquin's piston became loosened and the cylinder gave out a grunting noise. The Winooski's apparatus for taking indicator cards gave out, but beside these two unimportant things nothing of interest occurred to change the dull monotony of the quiet contest. The Algonquin averaged 60 pounds of steam while the Winooski carried about 25 pounds. Both engines are reported to have worked well.

abstract: ALLEGED BIGAMY AND ADULTERY. -- A woman named MINA SCHULTZ was taken before Justice POPE, of Hoboken, yesterday, on a charge of bigamy. PETER SCHULTZ, of New-York, made affidavit that he was married to the accused in 1842, and that they lived together as man and wife until May, 1863, when she left him, and in January, 1865, married AUGUST SCHMIDT. The latter named was also arrested on a charge of adultery. TIM; prisoners were held to bail in $500 each to appear for trial.

abstract: Prof. LOWE and his nuinorous corps of assistants are still busy in enabling adventurous visitors to mount the air and take a bird's-eye view of New-York and its surroundings from cloud-land. Our readers can have no adequate conception of the Empire City until they gaze upon its streets and clustering mass of buildings from the aerial car of Prof. LOWE's War Balloon. The scene spread out before the eye of the spectator cannot be easily described and cover forgotten by those fortunate and brave enough to ascend with the Professor. The price of the ticket is insignificant compared with the pleasure and profit gained by an ascension.

abstract: Dr. Marshall's Mission
snippet: Dr. Marshall's Mission
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. MARSHALL, of Vicksburgh, Miss., is in this city upon an errand of mercy, which appeals strongly to the sympathies of the benevolent. He seeks aid for the crippled, sick, ragged and destitute Confederate soldiers, whom the close of the war left at points remote from their homes, which they have now no means of reaching. They are scattered at various points throughout the Southern States, many at railway stations to which the government has furnished transportation, many in hospitals, and many literally in the streets of Southern towns. Their friends are penniless and powerless, and unless they are relieved by Northern charity, there is every prospect of their having survived the war only to die of starvation.
headline: {'main': 'A Benevolent Mission.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Benevolent Mission.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Hoboken Races--Second Day
snippet: Hoboken Races--Second Day
lead_paragraph: We know not why it is that the Hoboken track, in its immediate vicinity to New-York, should not be more fully and liberally patronised than it is; but the fact is patent to the public that whilst the Long Island tracks have affluent support -- and Paterson either Spring or Fall attracts crowds -- a track so immediately adjacent to New-York that it appertains to that locality, seems inevitably destined to play a second part in the racing programme of the season. The why and the wherefore of this racing contrariety it is not for us to deal with in detail; all that liberal management can do in preparing an affluent programme has been done by the powers that be in Hoboken -- their purses have been liberally opened, and all their arrangements have been correspondingly so; and yet, from some cause beyond the ken or ordinary sporting foresight, the Secaucus meeting has not been as fully or as well attended as it should have been -- not as fully, because New-York has not done its duty in the premises; not so well as we should have anticipated, because those who graced the grand stands at the Paterson Spring meeting, and again at Saratoga, were absent. We missed the display of ladies, who give brightness and bloom to a race course, and in place thereof we had gentlemen with whips suggestive of buggies. Nevertheless and notwithstanding, as the lawyers say, the second day of the meeting was a great improvement on the first. The attendance exhibited an evident increase, owing perhaps to the attraction of the hurdle race; and had the association made their announcements as public as they should have done, it would have been still larger. The sports of the day commenced with --
