abstract: National Prosperity, the Reality of
snippet: National Prosperity, the Reality of
lead_paragraph: We do not consider the present material prosperity of the country to be either fictitious or temporary. It is perfectly healthy in character, and has a broad and profound basis -- that basis being the actual products of the land and the industry of the people. Moreover, it is not an exceptional prosperity in our history; but it is in the regular line of the ordinary, though truly extraordinary, development of this nation for the last half century.

abstract: U. S. vs. Feldman. Tobbacco Stamp Forgery
snippet: U. S. vs. Feldman. Tobbacco Stamp Forgery
lead_paragraph: United States vs. Joseph Feldman. -- The defendant was arrested some time since, on a charge of selling internal revenue cigar stamps, with intent to defraud the government. These stamps are furnished by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue to Inspectors of Internal Revenue, for tobacco and cigar manufactures, and these officers are alone empowered to affix these stamps to boxes containing cigars or packages of tobacco. At the time of affixing, the Inspector is by law required to indorse his name on the date of his inspection.

abstract: The steamship Eagle, from Havana Sept. 9, arrived at this port yesterday. We are indebted to the Purser for customary favors. Latest advices state that Spain has evacuated San Domingo.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Eagle, from Havana Sept. 9, arrived at this port yesterday. We are indebted to the Purser for customary favors. Latest advices state that Spain has evacuated San Domingo. The revolution which broke out there last month, in which CABRAL was named "Protector," is all over, and the Dominicans hope soon to reconstruct their country. In papers of the 6th appears a singular official announcement from the office of the Secretary of the Royal Audencia, or Supreme Court, that for the space of fifteen days proposals will be admitted from persons of color for the position of executioner -- that office being vacant -- and the lucky recipient, if a free negro, will have a salary of $90 per month, and the usual hangman's fees; if a slave obtains the office, ho must produce his master's permission, and receives only half the wages and is lodged at the jail. KIRBY SMITH is still in Matanzas, rather broken in health.

abstract: At police trials, yesterday, Commissioners ACTON and MCMURRY tried eighty-nine policemen on charges as various as the names of the defendants. Commissioner BERGEN did not attend.
lead_paragraph: At police trials, yesterday, Commissioners ACTON and MCMURRY tried eighty-nine policemen on charges as various as the names of the defendants. Commissioner BERGEN did not attend. Mr. JOHN MCKEON appeared as counsel for a young gentleman whom Policeman CHARLES WEINHOLD had arrested, supposing him to have been intoxicated and asleep at the threshold of a dwelling in Lafayette-place, and the young man's relatives swore that on the evening of the arrest he had been at home to within fifteen minutes of the time of the arrest. On the contrary, other persons swore positively that they had seen the young man drunk in the streets some time prior to the arrest. The evidence shows it to be a curious case of mistaken identity.

abstract: Shall it be Distrusted
snippet: Shall it be Distrusted
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON, in his late speech to the great Southern delegation, expressed his belief that "the South would be true to her ancient instincts of frankness and manly honor," and that "when its faith was pledged, every pledge and promise will be fully carried out." This was no idle blandishment on his part. It was an utterance of an earnest conviction, upon which he has shaped and is still shaping his practical policy of reconstruction. This trust manifested itself at the very outset, in a marked degree, in the Amnesty Proclamation, relieving the great mass of the Southern people from the penalties of treason on taking the oath of fidelity to the constitution and to the laws and proclamation which had been made with reference to the emancipation of slaves -- and then in the Reconstruction Proclamations, which allowed them to elect conventions, and to vote, on their own election laws, for all officers necessary to accomplish a reorganization of their State Governments, and for representatives in Congress. The same spirit has governed President JOHNSON in all of his subsequent dealings with the South. A memorable exhibition of it has just been seen in his abrogation of the order of Gen. SLOCUM, which set aside Gov. SHARKEY's proclamation calling on the people of Mississippi to organize military forces in each county for the suppression and prevention of all public disturbance. In the dispatch sustaining Gov. SHARKEY in this matter, he used these words: "The people must be trusted with their government; and, if trusted, my opinion is that they will act in good faith."
headline: {'main': 'Shall the South be Distrusted?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Shall the South be Distrusted?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: FIRE AND DESTRUCTION OF LIVE STOCK AT BOWRONVILLE. -- On Tuesday night the barn of Mr. R.S. SPURGE, Howard-avenue, near Jefferson-street, was fired by incendiaries and entirely consumed. A valuable five-year-old stallion and a milch cow were lost in the conflagration. The stallion was valued at $1,500, and the barn and stock at about $1,000. A few months since the residence of Mr. SPURGE was also fired and destroyed near the same place.

abstract: Hamill, Rev. P.; In Railway Car
snippet: Hamill, Rev. P.; In Railway Car
lead_paragraph: Mr. PETER HAMILL, a Catholic priest, and a resident of Newburyport, Mass., was brought to Bellevue Hospital, yesterday, suffering from incised wounds in his throat of a very serious character. It appears that HAMILL took passage on the train at Boston, and had with him four trunks, which were checked through to this city. It was observed that he acted oddly, but no special notice was taken of him. He went into the forward car and sat in the seat next to the front one; and during much of the time supported his head with one of his hands. It does not appear that he spoke to any person on the way; and when he cut his throat, he made no noise intended to cause any disturbance. There were fourteen or fifteen passengers in the car.

abstract: The United States vs. Capt. Anderson.--The examination into the case of the Captain of the Villafranca was set down for yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Capt. Anderson. -- The examination into the case of the Captain of the Villafranca was set down for yesterday morning. At the appointed hour a large number of passengers made their appearance and literally besieged the United States court-house. A few minutes after, the Captain appeared, and his welcome was anything but complimentary. He, however, passed on, regardless of the looks of his late passengers, to the commissioner's office. On the case being called on, the counsel for the Captain asked for an adjournment till Monday next, for the purpose of procuring his witnesses. The application was granted.

abstract: 105 Fulton-st., Carpenter Shop, $1,000
snippet: 105 Fulton-st., Carpenter Shop, $1,000
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN FULTON-STREET. -- Between 7 and 8 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered in Mr. W. VANDEWATER'S carpenter's shop, on the fifth floor of No. 105 Fulton-street. The flames were soon extinguished, with slight damage by fire. Mr. W. SCHLINGLOFF'S paper-box manufactory, on the third and fourth floors; the office of Mr. CORNELIUS MATTHEWS' New-Yorker, on the second floor, and Mr. JOHN MCMURRAY's Empire Wire Works, on the first floor, were damaged by water. The entire loss, by both fire and water, is roughly estimated at $1,009. The building, which is owned by Mr. C.E. DOWNING, was damaged slightly. A strong force of policemen, from the lower Wards, who were on the ground in season, preserved strict order.

abstract: We learn from a reliable source that the vestry of this church have purchased, a' a site for the new edifice about to be erected, the northwest corner of Fifty-third-street, fronting on the Fifth-avenue, and a few rods below St. Luke's Hospital. The dimensions of the plot are 100 feet on the avenue by 235 feet on Fifty-third-street. Upon this ample ground the vestry intend to build a church and rectory. It is supposed, from the well-known preference of Dr. MORGAN, that UPJOHN & CO. will be employed as architects, and this fact is a sufficient assurance that the new building will be worthy of the parish, and of the magnificent site which has been selected.

This latter subscription, like that of Mr. S.V. ROSE, of Cleveland, Ohio, was forwarded by mail.

Roberts, $50; S. Weir Roosevelt, $20; Wilson G. Hunt, $25; John H. Swift, $10; Thomas A. Vyse, $15; John H. Earle, $5; F.F. Thompson, of Lounenberg, Canandaigua Co., N.Y., $25. This latter subscription, like that of Mr. S.V. ROSE, of Cleveland, Ohio, was forwarded by mail.

abstract: At a late hour on Wednesday afternoon the Algonquin ceased working her engine, by some it was said, on account of her feed pumps giving out, while others said she had collapsed two tubes in the boilers. We believe both of these statements are true. At any rate she stopped. The Winooski, however, run on as usual, carrying about 20 pounds of steam, and making on the average 12 revolutions per minute, and burning her allowance of 1,600 pounds of coal per hour.
lead_paragraph: At a late hour on Wednesday afternoon the Algonquin ceased working her engine, by some it was said, on account of her feed pumps giving out, while others said she had collapsed two tubes in the boilers. abstract: UNKNOWN MAN FOUND DROWNED. -- The body of an unknown man was yesterday morning found floating in the river foot of North Third-street, Eastern District. The deceased was about fifty years of age, five feet six inches high, and was dressed in a blue frock coat, light pants and vest, white shirt and undershirt, white cotton drawers, and the boots had been footed. On a finger of the left hand was a plain gold ring. The body had evidently been but a short time in the water. Coroner BARRETT held an inquest, but nothing could be ascertained in relation to the deceased, and the body was sent to the dead-house for identification.
lead_paragraph: UNKNOWN MAN FOUND DROWNED. -- The body of an unknown man was yesterday morning found floating in the river foot of North Third-street, Eastern District. The deceased was about fifty years of age, five feet six inches high, and was dressed in a blue frock coat, light pants and vest, white shirt and undershirt, white cotton drawers, and the boots had been footed. On a finger of the left hand was a plain gold ring. The body had evidently been but a short time in the water. Coroner BARRETT held an inquest, but nothing could be ascertained in relation to the deceased, and the body was sent to the dead-house for identification.

abstract: Count WALEWSKI tendered his resignation as a Senator, and it was accepted.  The Emperor had received M. MON, the new Spanish Ambassador. He said he attached great value to seeing France and Spain advancing together, and the French Government would always be found ready to strenghten the bonds and unite the two countries.

abstract: EDWARD B. KETCHUM and HENRY B. JENKINS were arraigned yesterday before the Court of General Sessions, the first for forgery and the latter for embezzlement and grand larceny. They both pleaded not guilty. Their trials were set down for the first Monday in the October Term.

abstract: The Quebec correspondent of the Montreal Gazette writes under date of Sept 12: "Colorado JEWETT arrived to-day en route for Europe, per steamer Peruvian, having as a valet a mulatto lately in the service of Ex-President DAVIS. Mr. JEWETT says there is no peace in the American Republic yet, and that a great patriotic party is required to compose the difficulties between North and South. Mr. BEVERLEY TUCKER and GEO. N. SANDERS, two well known Confederates, arrived to-day. Gen. BRECKINRIDGE, after proceeding to Toronto, will, it is said, take up his residence at Montreal."

abstract: Exiles in Mexico and Canada
snippet: Exiles in Mexico and Canada
lead_paragraph: -- Quite a number of notable rebel officers and leaders have taken up their quarters for the time being in Canada and in Mexico. BRECKINRIDGE, after his adventurous flight from Florida to Halifax, via the West Indies, has just joined the Southern colony, which leads a wretched existence in Canada. Our correspondent in the City of Mexico writes that in that city there are, at present, about forty rebel officers of different grades; and we should judge that there are as many more in other of the cities of the Mexican Empire.

abstract: Between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning SENECA STEVENS and JOHN THOMSON, of No. 85 Varick-street, quarrelled over their cups in a drinking saloon in the Bowery, corner of Fifth-street, and STEVENS fired upon THOMSON, inflicting painful wounds in his cheeks and tongue, through which the bullet passed. STEVENS fled at once, and being pursued by THOMSON, he turned to fire again, when Policeman PITCAIRN, of the Fifteenth Precinct, opportunely arrived and took him in custody. STEVENS was required to find $1,500 bail to answer, before the Court of General Sessions, a charge of felonious assault. The only other noteworthy complaint before this court yesterday, was that of CHARLES ELLIS, a soldier, who FELL ASLEEP AMONG THE EIGHTH WARD THIEVES, at about 2 o'clock yesterday morning, having seated himself in Howard-street, while on his way to the Soldiers' Rest, Howard-street and Mercer. The complaint was against THOMAS MULLIGAN, of Troy, a Broadway statue, whom Officer DUNHAM had caught in the act of searching the soldier's pockets. On the way to the Wooster-street Police-station MULLIGAN escaped from the officer, but was recaptured and thrust into a cell. Subsequently the officer had business in the cell, and MULLIGAN fell upon him and beat him brutally, and it was not until othor policemen had reached the spot and clubbed the prisoner that he submitted. Justice LEDWITH, declining to accept bail for this prisoner, committed him for trial.

abstract: A SHREWD COUNTERFEITING DODGE. -- On Wednesday evening an attempt was made to pass a counterfeit $50 greenback at LILL's drug-store, corner of Newark-avenue and Coles-street, Jersey City, but the character of the bill being detected, a policeman was quietly sent for, and soon after arrived. In the meantime the fellow managed to get away, leaving in his stead an accomplice dressed exactly in the same style, who had substituted himself for the other unobserved. As no charge could be made against him, he was allowed to depart.

abstract: Fashions for September, from Le ???oll
snippet: Fashions for September, from Le ???oll
lead_paragraph: The weather has been so very changeable lately that it has been a task of some difficulty to decide what toilettes are most suitable; but, as our leaders of fashion are either traveling or preparing to do so, the materials made up for them have been what are called "etoffes de demi-saison," such as mohair, poil do chevre, alpaca, linos, foulard, silk poplinottes, and even poplins. Tulle, tarlatane, gaze de Chambery, grenadine, and the muslin and other light materials are kept for indoor and evening toilettes; but, of course, should the weather become warmer, we may hope for their reappearance out of doors.

abstract: The convention  which our government is now holding with the Indian tribes of the great Western plains, seems already to have had a good effect. We have had no "Indian outrages" reported of late, and the telegraph line is working from the Missouri River to California. At the latest dates, no representatives from the wild tribes had made their appearance; but the civilized delegates agree to bring the savages to fair terms.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. The subscription for Mr. MARETZEK'S coming season of Italian opera opened yesterday, and the sale, we are happy to say, was unusually large. Although this result was not wholly unexpected, it is still gratifying in view of the fact, that the unexpected temperature of the Fall season has enabled the fashionable world to prolong its stay in the country.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The subscription for Mr. MARETZEK's coming season of Italian opera opened yesterday, and the sale, we are happy to say, was unusually large. Although this result was not wholly unexpected, it is still gratifying in view of the fact, that the unexpected temperature of the Fall season has enabled the fashionable world to prolong its stay in the country. The same cause has probably detained our country visitors in the city. Of the two we are disposed to think that the latter have the best of it. The ardent attentions of the sun are not to be wholly escaped, but they may be accepted more cheerfully in the solitudes of our still deserted avenues, rather than in the dusty and choking lanes of the country. It is a singular fact, that notwithstanding the almost unbearable heat, every place of amusement now open to the public is literally crowded. We doubt not that the same good fortune will be enjoyed by Mr. MARETZEK. When the drama succeeds, the opera can generally manage to take care of itself. It may be added, too, that while the promise of the theatrical future does not hold forth any particular novelty, either in the way of actors or pieces, the musical world will, undoubtedly, be stirred to its centre by the production of MEYERBEER's "Africaine," and by the debuts of several now singers.

abstract: Allen, Phillip; Attempted at Brooklyn
snippet: Allen, Phillip; Attempted at Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, near 2 o'clock, Mr. PHILIPALLEN, a young man about 32 years of age, attempted to commit suicide by cutting his throat with a razor, at his residence, No. 163 Gold-street, Brooklyn. It appears that Mr. ALLEN has been laboring under temporary derangement of mind for several days past, and on Wednesday evening went home in such a state of excitement as to cause the most serious apprehensions on the part of the inmates of the house. Upon the family retiring for the night, one of the members, a youth, resolved to watch ALLEN's movements, and to that intent lay down upon his bed with his clothes on, when he soon fell asleep. He was awakened in an hour or so by a noise in his room, when the first object that met his view was the figure of a man standing by his bedside with his hands to his throat, apparently trying to button his shirt-collar. This was the suspected madman. He remained in this position a few moments, when some idea seemed to strike him, and he left the room. The youth was not tardy in following, and he proceeded down stairs and awakened his mother. Shortly afterward ALLEN came down and passed out into the street, where he remained some time, and then returned to his room. Soon after a noise was heard in the room, occasioned by the fall of a lamp, and in a few moments more heavy breathing was heard to proceed from the apartment, and it was believed that ALLEN was in a dying condition. The door was tried, but found to be locked, and no other response could be gained to the repeated knocks for admission save the loud respirations of the sufferer. Mr. HALL, a friend of ALLEN's, living near by, was then called in, and he proceeded to break in the door, when he found the unfortunate man standing in the middle of the room, with a deep gash in his throat, and the bright blade of a razor glittering in his right hand. Previous to the arrival of Mr. HALL, however, and after he had cut his throat, ALLEN came out of his room, walked down stairs through the hall, down to the basement, then up again to his room, locking the door behind him. Mr. HALL spoke to him, but obtained no answer, save some energetic gesticulations, which were taken for threats of violence. Not caring to deal single-handed with a man in this state of mind, Mr. HALL closed the door and proceeded to call the police and summon medical assistance. In a few minutes three or four metropolitans arrived, proceeded to Mr. ALLEN's room, disarmed him and brought him down into the hall naked and bleeding, as painful and frightful a spectacle as any one might wish to look upon. After considerable delay in groping about the unlighted streets of Brooklyn, a carriage was obtained, and the injured man conveyed to the Brooklyn Hospital, where he now lies suffering greatly from his wound, but with some hope of recovery. No reason is given for this rash attempt upon his life, by Mr. ALLEN. He bears a most excellent character, is well connected, and in the employ of his brother, a wealthy ship chandler, doing business in South-street, New-York.

abstract: The steamship Asia arrived yesterday at Hallfax, with two days later intelligence from Europe. The directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable Company have unanimously accepted the offer of the Telegraph Construction Company to manufacture and lay down a new cable and complete the present one so as to have two perfect cables between Ireland and Newfoundland next Summer.
lead_paragraph: The steamship Asia arrived yesterday at Hallfax, with two days later intelligence from Europe. The directors of the Atlantic Telegraph Cable Company have unanimously accepted the offer of the Telegraph Construction Company to manufacture and lay down a new cable and complete the present one so as to have two perfect cables between Ireland and Newfoundland next Summer. The manufacture of the new cable has commenced. Capt. JAMES ANDERSON has accepted an offer from the Telegraph Construction Company to command the Great Eastern for five years in laying cables. In consequence of the spread of Fenianism the number of regiments in the South of Ireland is to be increased. The report that Mr. BRIGHT is to visit America on official invitation is pronounced to be without foundation. The fetes at Portsmouth in honor of the French fleet progressed in the most splendid manner, and concluded on the 1st inst. The weather throughout was exceedingly fine, and everything passed off in the most happy manner. Banquets, reviews, balls and illuminations followed one after another, and all were alike brilliant and successful. The political intelligence brought by the Asia is of little importance. In France Count WALEWSKI tendered his resignation as a Senator, and it was accepted. In Portugal a new Cabinet has been formed under the Presidency of Visocunt DE CASTRO.

abstract: Since the Grand Jury, just one week ago today, brought in the twelve indictments against EDWARD B. KETCHUM, the room in which the Court of General Sessions is held has been daily filled to its utmost capacity, while the vigilant and efficient officers who guard the entrance have, from necessity, had to deny admission to many persons desirous of witnessing the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: Since the Grand Jury, just one week ago today, brought in the twelve indictments against EDWARD B. KETCHUM, the room in which the Court of General Sessions is held has been daily filled to its utmost capacity, while the vigilant and efficient officers who guard the entrance have, from necessity, had to deny admission to many persons desirous of witnessing the proceedings. That the prisoner would be arraigned early in the week was hardly to be expected; yet, as the precise time, if known, was not disclosed, continual attendance became necessary in order to see him when brought up. During the progress of the session, yesterday, it was intimated that before the adjournment, he would be brought to the bar to plead to the indictments found against him. As the business of the day progressed and the usual time for adjournment drew near, learned and prominent members of the bar appeared in the hall near the door, occasionally looking in and then immediately receding, evidently awaiting the critical moment. A full complement of distinguished criminal lawyers were in attendance during the entire session. After the Grand Jury had made their weekly visit to the court, and with the customary formalities had transferred a ponderous bundle of legal documents to the presiding officer, the door most remote from the bar opened and about a dozen men quietly entered and proceeded to the end of the prisoners' dock, remained a very short time, and then retired to the District-Attorney's office. Among their number were the prisoners KETCHUM and JENKINS, the former's counsel, Ex-Judge ALLEN and Mr. MORRIS KETCHUM.

abstract: Record of the; Extraordinary Heat
snippet: Record of the; Extraordinary Heat
lead_paragraph: -- Certain philosophers have advanced the idea that our little planet is gradually narrowing its orbit and will ultimately drop into the flery body of the sun and disappear like a snow-ball in Mount Vesuvius. The past fortnight has furnished reasonable evidence of the correctness of this theory, with the alarming addition that the circle is narrowing with fearful rapidity. No thermometrical record is extant that will at all compare with that so far noted down for this month. Suffering mortals, behold the figures:

abstract: Boston vs. St. George, at Hoboken
snippet: Boston vs. St. George, at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: The grand match between these clubs was commenced at Hoboken, on the St. George Cricket Ground, yesterday, at noon, and the weather being fine, and a grand prospect of seeing some good cricket, quite a large number of cricketers went over to see the match. The St. George eleven included GIBBES this time, and though not their strongest team, was good enough to test the merits of the Boston Club pretty well. The Bostonians were reinforced by two good players, and presented an excellent eleven for the contest. The ground was in fine condition, and everything was favorable for the sport. The Bostonians won the toss, and sent in EATON and HAMMOND to the bat, against the bowling of GIBBES and HARRY WRIGHT. For some time the wickets were creditably defended, HAMMOND especially showing in good form. SULLIVAN, too, did well while in, but the balance of the eleven found WRIGHT's bowling altogether too effective for run-getting, and in a little over an hour the eleven had been disposed of for 34 runs, of which 7 were extras, SULLIVAN and HAMMOND's scores of 9 each being the only average scores of the innings. WRIGHT's bowling score shows the excellence of his delivery on this occasion; 61 balls, 5 runs, 13 maidens and 6 wickets is an analysis seldom reached in this country. GIBBES was not so successful, 22 runs for 3 wickets being his score. The fielding was very good, POMEROY's long fielding, and good catches by MUMFORD and WRIGHT, being praiseworthy.

abstract: Synagogue of Cong. Bnai Jeshurun Consecrated
snippet: Synagogue of Cong. Bnai Jeshurun Consecrated
lead_paragraph: The new and beautiful synagogue of the Congregation Bnai Jeshurun, the oldest but one in this city, was yesterday consecrated, according to the Jewish custom. This congregation is the wealthiest and most influential of the Israelitish faith in our community, and the members, while chiefly of American birth, nevertheless represent well-nigh every nation on the Eastern continent. Owing to the grandeur of the service, and the belief that many more than the edifice could contain would present themselves, tickets of admission were issued, and none save those thus supplied could find admittance. Upward of a thousand applied, only to be refused, and the favored ones were besought to sell their tickets or use their influence to procure others. The arrangements of the committee being fully carried out, precisely at the appointed hour, 2 1/2 o'clock, the exercises commenced.

abstract: and suite paid a visit to his Honor, the Mayor, yesterday. The interview was a very pleasant one. The Mayor welcomed his distinguished visitors to the city and assured them of the friendly feeling entertained by our citizens toward the representatives of France, our earliest ally. The party consisted of Le Baron DE DIDELOT, Rear Admiral, commanding the rear Imperial Naval Division. M. DE VERNEUIL, Capitaine de Frigate, Chief of Staff, and M. BASSET, Lieut. de Vaisseaux and Aid de Camp. They were introduced by M. LOUIS BOOG, Acting Consul-General of France. After viewing the pictures in the Governor's Room, the Admiral invited the Mayor to pay a visit to his flagship, the frigate Themis, now lying in the harbor, and the invitation was cordially accepted by His Honor.

abstract: Camden and Amboy; Collision at Princeton; Soldier killed
snippet: Camden and Amboy; Collision at Princeton; Soldier killed
lead_paragraph: An accident occurred on the Camden and Amboy branch road, at Princeton, at 2 o'clock yesterday morning, between the train krown as the Adams Express Washington fast freight line, coming from Washington, and the train running from Kensington at midnight. The former runs on slow time, and although on the new double track, had to run off on a turn-out at Princeton, to allow the express to pass, when hearing the latter coming, the conductor of the former sent a man back with a red light, but owing to a dense fog which was prevailing the engineer of the express train was unable to see the light in season to prevent the two trains coming together. The Adams Express train, not having previously succeeded in getting on to the turn-out, the concussion forced the real platform of the mail car of the express train, on to the front platform of the next car, which contained twenty passengers, breaking it up very badly, and yet wonderful to relate, only one person was killed, a soldier, named FREDERICK CLINCH, of the One Hundred and Fifty-eighth New-York Volunteers; nobody else injured even to the slightest extent.

abstract: N. Y.; Jones, Alderman, Singular Conduct in a Pickpocket Case
snippet: N. Y.; Jones, Alderman, Singular Conduct in a Pickpocket Case
lead_paragraph: On Monday afternoon a lady of the highest respectability entered a Madison-avenue stage, near the corner of Eleventh-street, and after paying her fare retained her portemounaie in her hand. At Bleecker-street a man got into the stage, seated himself next to the lady, and after paying his own fare attempted to seize the portemonnaie in the lady's hand, declaring that it was his and that the lady had taken it from his pocket. A gentleman sitting opposite the lady interfered and informed the man that he could not have the pocket-book unless he was able to obtain it by force, as he should protect the lady and her property. The fellow then said he would have both parties arrested, and stopping the stage, he got out, procured the services of a policeman, and had the lady and gentlemen arrested as pickpockets. They were taken to police headquarters and thence to the Tombs Police Court, where Alderman JONES was sitting in the absence of Justice HOGAN. The man here renewed his charge against the parties arrested, giving his name as THOS. WELSH, of New-Brighton, S.I. Alderman JONES said the lady must prove her respectability. This she informed him could be easily done by sending to the office of her husband, in Wall-street. One of the court messengers was accordingly sent thither, and in the mean time the lady and her friend were invited to take seats in the examination-room. In about twenty minutes afterward Aldermen JONES entered the room and informed them that the charge was withdrawn, and that they were at liberty to depart. Shortly afterward the lady's friends arrived, only to find the scoundrel who had preferred the charge beyond their reach. The pocket-book was, of course, returned to the lady, its rightful owner.

abstract: Punishment called for
snippet: Punishment called for
lead_paragraph: We made inquiry on Tuesday why we never heard of the detection and arrest of some of the numerous counterfeiters who are destroying faith in our currency by the circulation of bad bills of different denominations. We suppose an answer was furnished to our inquiry by the Associated Press dispatch of yesterday, which mentioned the recent arrest of several counterfeiters, and ended by declaring that "arrests are continually being made all over the country."

abstract: Unreasonable Opposition to
snippet: Unreasonable Opposition to
lead_paragraph: Just now, when so much is being said about sanitary matters, crowded tenements, cleanliness and education of the masses, it will, doubtless, surprise many of our readers to be informed that there exists, among what is considered an intelligent and respectable class of our foreign population, a spirit of opposition to educational measures of reform. The schools for the very poorest class have been located where the population is most dense, and where, owing to the crowded condition of the ward schools, and the want of care exercised over them by their parents, groups of boys and girls were to be seen idling their time away in the alley-ways, streets and lowest places in the neighborhood. Industrial schools were first established, and different agencies have readily cooperated in this work, but the largest number have been created by and through the Children's Aid Society of this city. That any instrumentality calculated to do so much good, alleviate so much distress, and prevent the growth of so many evils, should meet with opposition, particularly from those who consider themselves the protectors and teachers of the class for whom they were especially devised, is most surprising. Those who have given any time and attention to this subject, know that the design of these schools is not to interfere in any way with the religious training of the children who attend them, nor in any way to prejudice or influence their minds for or against any one system of religion. They combine within themselves all the elements of a reformatory education which are by many felt to be so necessary at the present time. The teachers engaged in them are ladies of refinement and education, and while all the rudiments of a good common-school education are taught, no less attention is given to cleanliness of person and dress. Habits of industry are also taught in the best practical way, by causing the scholars to make up the garments which are afterward given them as a reward for steady attendance and attention to their studies. A feeling of self-respect and decent pride is developed, which of itself is the surest safeguard to virtue. No child can, for any length of time, be a regular attendant upon such a school without entertaining feelings of disgust for the miserable underground cellars and foul tenements from whence they come.

abstract: As is natural, with age the interest increases at the exhibition of the American Institute. There are many hundreds of curious and interesting articles there, many scores of senseless advertisements, many exemplifications of individual vanities; but despite all these, as yet the fair cannot be called a success. It should not have opened until Monday next, by which time the machinery will all be up, the steam will be turned on, and the ponderous wheels and wondrous intricacies of combination will smoothly and easily perform their task.

abstract: Election Returns, Partial
snippet: Election Returns, Partial
lead_paragraph: The Kennebec Journal this morning contains official returns from 264 towns, comprising more than three-fourths of the vote of the State. CONY has in these towns 40,775, and HOWARD 22,135. Last year in the same towns the vote stood as fellows: CONY 47,713, and HOWARD 33,046. CONY's majority thus far is 18,640 against 14,667 in 1864. It will probably exceed 20,000 when all the returns are in. The total vote of the State will fall short of 85,000.

The barkeeper of the American Hotel, which nearly adjoins the Eagle office,...
lead_paragraph: THE RECENT ALLEGED WIFE MURDER. -- Coroner BARRETT continued the investigation yesterday afternoon, into the circumstances attending the death of Mrs. LAURA MILLS, the wife of FRANKLIN MILLS, residing at No. 32 Fulton-street. The evidence showed that the husband came home about 11 o'clock on Monday night, instead of 1 o'clock as stated by himself. The barkeeper of the American Hotel, which nearly adjoins the Eagle office, (where the parties resided) testifies that he heard screams and other evidences of agony on the night in question. Other witnesses testified to circumstances not at all favorable to the accused, but as the physican who made the post-mortem examination was not present, the case was adjourned until this day at noon. MILLS is meantime held in custody to await the result of the in vestigation.

abstract: At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning Policeman MILLER, of the Twenty-second Precinct, attempted to arrest one JAMES RILEY for disorderly conduct in Eleventh-avenue, near Forty-seventh-street, when the ruffian drew a revolver and discharged it at the officer, but, happily, missed him. Officer MILLER sprang upon the fellow and overpowered him, and on searching him at the Forty-seventh-street Police-station, found in his pockets a powder-flask, two bullets, a knife, and a pistol. Justice KELLY committed the fellow to prison in default of the moderate bail of $500 to appear for trial at the Court of General Sessions.

abstract: Speech--the North and South
snippet: Speech--the North and South
lead_paragraph: There are a great many Southerners in this city trying to make arrangements for a resumption of business. As a general thing, their conduct is manly, frank and sensible, -- calculated to win the confidence and respect of every generous and just community. Nine in every ten of them have been utterly ruined by the rebellion. Most of them cast their fortunes into the struggle for a cause which they believed to be right, but which they see and acknowledge to have been fatally and finally defeated. They have lost position, influence, property, children, friends -- everything which makes life desirable. Under such circumstances, weak men sink down into abject despair, or drag out the rest of their lives in the sale obscurity of foreign lands. The defeated Southerners meet their calamity in a more manly style. They show in their defeat, as they did in their struggle, -- courage, desperate tenacity of purpose, and that high-spirited readiness to meet all the responsibilities of their conduct, which never fails to command the respect of the world.

abstract: Strange Conduct in Police Case
snippet: Strange Conduct in Police Case
lead_paragraph: Our Police Justices have never been distinguished for clearness of judgment, or for a particularly fearless discharge of their duties; but in the following case which came up lately at the Tombs Police Court, the acting magistrate appears to have been utterly befogged, permitting a scoundrel to escape, while his innocent victim was made to suffer what to a refined and delicate woman was worse than any punishment that could be devised. It appears that on Monday afternoon a fellow got into a Madison-avenue stage and made a bold attempt to rob a lady passenger by seizing the pocketbook which she held in her hand, and declaring that it was his property. His attempt at robbery was frustrated by a gentleman in the stage, and the fellow then, doubtless actuated by a feeling of revenge, sprang out of the stage, called a policeman, and gave both the parties into custody on a charge of picking his pocket. The three were taken before Alderman JONES, at the Tombs Police Court, and there the prosecutor renewed his charge. Alderman JONES said this was one of numerous similar cases, and that it would be necessary for the lady to bring witnesses as to her character. The lady said that this could be easily done, and requested that a messenger might be dispatched for her husband. During the absence of the messenger the lady and her friend, who had been requested to take a seat in a private room, were informed that the charge had been withdrawn. The lady's husband arrived shortly afterward, but of course only to find the scoundrel who had attempted to rob his wife beyond his reach. Now, it certainly appears that in acting as he did Alderman JONES showed a strange want of sense, or something worse. Of course he could not know that the lady was a person of respectability merely by her appearance, and he was undoubtedly right in holding her to answer the charge. But he was entirely wrong in permitting the prosecutor to withdraw the charge and leave the court without giving the lady an opportunity of vindicating her character. No reason was assigned by Aldermen JONES for the charge being withdrawn. If the prosecutor withdrew it, under the excuse that he had made a mistake, it was then the duty of Alderman JONES to bring him into the lady's presence and compel him to apologise to her for what had occurred. How could the astute magistrate suppose that if the pocket-book rightfully belonged to the prosecutor that he would withdraw his claims to it? For what possible reason could ho allow the case to be terminated in this manner? The ownership of the pocket-book might have been determined, it would seem, in a very few moments by calling on the claimant to describe its contents. Of course he could not have done so, and that would have been proof positive that it was not his property. No attempt, however, is made by Alderman JONES to sift the case; a scoundrel is allowed to escape with impunity, while a respectable lady is dragged through the street, arraigned as a pickpocket, and then informed that it is all a mistake.

abstract: JULIA MCDONNELL, a child of three years, was run over, on Wednesday, near her parents' abode, by an ice-cart which was driven by MICHAEL RYAN. She was immediately taken to her home, at No. 225 West Seventeenth-street, and the Sixteenth Precinct Police apprehended the driver. The child lingered until yesterday morning, when Coroner WILDEY held an inquest, and the jury finding that the occurrence was accidental, RYAN was released from restraint.

abstract: Fire Department--Open Sessions Required
snippet: Fire Department--Open Sessions Required
lead_paragraph: -- The Board of Metropolitan Fire Commissioners some time ago resolved to hold open sessions, free to the press and the public, and the act was hailed as a step in the right direction. It would appear, however, from subsequent movements of the Commissioners, that these "open sessions" are so only in name. The hour of opening the tri-weekly meetings is 3 P.M.; but delays are frequent, and the board hold protracted consultations in their private room, and as soon as seated in session the business appearing before them is seemingly cut and dried, being disposed of in a marvelously rapid manner, without any discussion or debate, thus perpetuating all the evils the proposed open meetings were to avoid. Public discussion by an official board, wielding the power and patronage such as is commanded by the Fire Commissioners, is the only safety the public have that such power and patronage is not abused. We trust that the Fire Commissioners will reform this matter.
headline: {'main': 'THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE FIRE DEPARTMENT.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. McMichael on future of; Immense Activity of
snippet: Mr. McMichael on future of; Immense Activity of
lead_paragraph: We publish this morning an interesting account of the commercial activity by which the opening of the Fall season in this city has been thus far marked. It seems to be wholly without precedent. Contrary to the fears and expectations of very many persons, our merchants are selling goods of all kinds in quanties and values far beyond those of any other season. It was universally understood, of course, that as the South had been swept bare of everything conducive to comfort, and had been for four years excluded from markets of all kinds, they would need large quantities of goods in every department to supply their immediate necessities. But it was also assumed that they bad no money, and that as immense quantities of their cotton had been burned or otherwise wasted, during the war, they would have no means of paying for goods to any considerable extent.
headline: {'main': 'Our Fall Trade Immense Activity.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Fall Trade Immense Activity.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: on Mississippi and Repudiation
snippet: on Mississippi and Repudiation
lead_paragraph: -- Mr. SUMNER is afraid that if the Representatives of Mississippi are admitted to Congress, they will vote for repudiation of the National debt. In other days, Mr. SUMNER used to attribute the origin of repudiation and all other Southern knaveries to the fell spirit of slavery. Now that Mississippi, by the almost unanimous vote of a State Convention composed of her ablest representatives, has agreed to the eternal and total abolishment of slavery, we do not see that there is any likelihood of a new engenderment of repudiation. The cause being gone, how can the effect appear?

abstract: Cartage and Lighterage Monopoly Abolished
snippet: Cartage and Lighterage Monopoly Abolished
lead_paragraph: The monopoly system of cartage and lighterage of bonded goods has been abolished by Collector KING. Henceforth all licensed cartmen and lightermen, who shall file bonds with the Collector for the faithful performance of duty, are to be employed by the inspectors, so long as they fulfill the obligations, which are to some extent of the nature of a trust; for they have charge of vast amounts of property to cart to various parts of the city, or lighter from on board vessels in the harbor.

abstract: THE ALLEGED WIFE MURDER. -- The investigation into the cause of the death of Mrs. LAURA MILLS, wife of FRANCIS MILLS, was concluded before Coroner BARRETT and jury yesterday afternoon. The following is the verdict of the jury: "That said LAURA MILLS came to her death by hemorrhage, caused by rupture of a blood vessel in the abdominal cavity -- said rupture being the result of injuries inflicted by her husband, FRANCIS MILLS, on the morning of the 12th inst., at their residence in the Eagle Buildings, Fulton-street." In answer to the usual questions, the prisoner stated that he was 39 years of age, born in the County of Down, Ireland, and a machinist and engineer by profession. He said that he owned a house and some and in Columbia, S.C. The prisoner was then removed to the County Jail, to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: The flying artillery of this puissant potentate have been out in full force, and under cover of the night (their usual mode of warfare) made a furious attack on the City of Gotham. The battle lasted from sunset to sunrise; the facades and breastworks of the citadel were soon surmounted by the treacherous miners; and though numbers were left dead in the intrenchments, yet such is the impetuosity of this tribe it seemed only to increase their vigor and number as if in revenge of their slaughtered comrades. Each warrior when driven back, nothing daunted, would sound his bugle up to the very gates, wheel round and make a fresh attack with most tantalizing pertinacity. And though their unceasing din was the precursor of approach, yet the most unprotected points of attack were so ingeniously selected that these guerrilla hands seldom failed of victory. The great desire of these cannibals is to drink the blood of their victims and aim at the vital part, and though most of the besieged were caught napping, yet they made a most determined resistance. But our infantry suffered the most severely, as they appear to have been peculiarly marked out by the invaders. The air thick with envenomed darts, it could not be expected that the fair sex should escape unscathed: and though the intruders were politely told

abstract: the Contempt Earned by
snippet: the Contempt Earned by
lead_paragraph: -- The most degrading work of the rebellion was that which was assigned to the agents who represented the Confederacy abroad. The special duty of these missionaries was to malign their country, to declare its government at once a despotism and a failure, to profess faith in and admiration for monarchical institutions, and generally to abase themselves in the dust as Americans, in the vain and hopeless task of procuring foreign intervention. There were comparatively few citizens of the United States, either South or North, at all adapted by natural instinct or by training, to perform such functions. There must have been something revolting to high-minded Americans -- call them Confederates or not -- in the very thought of cringing and crawling, and begging and praying for aid which, if it could have been purchased at all, was only procurable at the cost of traditional character, honor, self-respect and independence. SLIDELL and SANDERS, TUCKER and MASON, may have been no more active enemies of the government than those who had the courage to take up arms and fight against it at home. But in the prosecution of their special tasks, they have earned an infamous renown which will attach to no other class of the late insurgents. To-day they are, in part, earning the reward of their labors, in the contempt and scorn of those to whose evil disposition toward the United States they were so prone in pandering. Their punishment to-day is greater than any penalty which the law provides.

lead_paragraph: -- In another column we publish a reply by Judge HOLT to the calumnious assault recently made upon him by MONTGOMERY BLAIR. It seems, to those familiar with the history of the past four years, somewhat strange that Judge HOLT should deem it worth his while to vindicate his loyalty against anybody's accusations. But it will be conceded that he makes clean work of it in the letter referred to.

abstract: N. Y.; Wall-st., $50,000 Stolen from Banker's Counter
snippet: N. Y.; Wall-st., $50,000 Stolen from Banker's Counter
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday afternoon, a clerk in the employ of E. BLISS, of No. 10 Pine-street, banker, having been to Broad-street to get $100,000 in United States Bonds, entered Mr. BLISS' banking-house, and laid them, in two packages, on the cashier's counter. His attention and that of the cashier having been momentarily diverted, a thief who had followed the clerk seized one of the packages and made his escape. The stolen bonds were as follows: Ten registered 5-20s, of $1,000 each, issued under the Act of Congress of Feb. 25, 1862, to the First National Bank of Iowa City, Nos. 20,461, 20,462, 20,463, 20,464, 20,465, 20,469, 20,470, 20,471, 20,472, 20,473. A registered bond issued under the act of July 17, 1861, to B.C. THAYER, for $1,000 -- No. 10,141. Two 7-30 coupon bonds of August of $1,000 each -- Nos. 39,106, 39,107. One coupon bond of 1881, $500 -- No. 16,600. Coupon bonds, sixes of 1881, issued to BLISS, WILLIAMS & CO., E. BLISS, and SAMUEL C. THOMPSON; 7-30s and a $1,000 debt certificate -- Nos. of which will be forthcoming -- in all $36,500. Payment on all these bonds has been stopped, and Mr. BLISS now offers a reward of $20,000 for their recovery.

abstract: -- Counterfeit one-dollar legal tender notes are in circulation in various parts of the city. The specimens we have seen are poorly executed. The paper is bad, the color is a much lighter green than the genuine bill, and the engraving is indifferent. The police can have little difficulty in discovering some of the circulating agencies. The national currency bills promise to defy imitation better than any class of bank notes yet in circulation. It should be remembered, however, that the temptation to counterfeiting was never so great as it is now, from the variety and immensity of the national issues. It is alarming to find that imitations of some of the higher denominations of United States bonds have been executed with a skill which almost defies detection except by experts. Clearly, our police have work before them which demands increased and incessant vigilance, if the whole country is not to be flooded with a spurious currency. It is important that the people generally should awake to this conviction before it is too late.

abstract: Revolution Achieved at Home and Abroad by the War
snippet: Revolution Achieved at Home and Abroad by the War
lead_paragraph: The influence of the late war upon this nation will be as enduring as the existence of the nation itself. Like the Revolution of 1776, it signalized an era in our history -- an era in which old things passed away and all things became new. The uprooting of slavery was even a greater event than the uprooting of the old royal authority; the emancipation of the country from its influence had a deeper effect than the emancipation of our forefathers from colonial vassalage. Slavery was not merely a baleful political power -- it was a malignant social and moral force, and in fact was or attempted to be dominant in every sphere of national activity -- in church and State, in society and commerce, in school and college, in diplomacy and in the administration of justice, in the North and the South. It would not merely regulate laws and customs relating to itself; but it desired to regulate all laws and customs. It would not only legislate for Carolina and Alabama, but for Kansas and California. In throwing off its trammels, the North is freed as well as the South, the Church as well as the State, education as well as business. The national organism is freer in every muscle and every movement; we think and breathe freer, see clearer, and are stronger. Were the extirpation of the foul ulcer of slavery the only thing the war had effected, it would still have done that which must forever influence the destiny of America. But the formative power of the war itself upon the national character, the formative power of the great and noble ideas underlying the war, the demonstration of the adaptability of free republican institutions to all the exigencies of national life which has been furnished by the war, are of no less importance. Time only can develop the bearings of all these things; but we already know for a certainty that they were too profound not to be permanent.
headline: {'main': 'Our Revolution at Home and in Europe.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Our Revolution at Home and in Europe.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: the, carried on the war
snippet: the, carried on the war
lead_paragraph: There is unquestionably some little extravagance on the part of many in their estimates of the civil and military celebrities of this war. It is not true that any man was indispensable to its success, as WASHINGTON and FRANKLIN were indispensable to the success of the Revolution. The honor of carrying this terrible conflict through to its consummation is due to the PEOPLE alone. This is a truth which must never be lost sight of, or slurred over, in extolling even our bravest and best. That the American people have been educated by civil self-government up to the mental and moral capacity of carrying such an unprecedented contest to such an unprecedented triumph is the finishing proof of the superiority of republican government To attribute the success of this war to any man, or any set of men, is to deprive our institutions of their crowning glory.
headline: {'main': 'No Laudation at the Expense of the People Our Triumph One of Republican Principle.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'No Laudation at the Expense of the People Our Triumph One of Republican Principle.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Southern Purchasers North, >amp;c.
snippet: Southern Purchasers North, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The merchants of New-York have never enjoyed such an active and prosperous Fall trade as that which they are now transacting with their customers, who represent all sections of the country, from Maine to Texas, and from Minnesota to Florida. The season may be said to have commenced early in August. During the intervening weeks, the demand for goods has been unprecedentedly brisk, and the chief difficulty of our wholesale houses has been to provide adequate supplies with sufficient promptness to satisfy the urgent wants of buyers. Our manufacturing establishments have not been able to keep pace with the requirements of the trade. The New-England mills have run far behind the demands of their patrons. Very many of them have contracted to supply goods, the production of which cannot be completed before the early months of the coming year. Several of them are refusing to take any further orders, for the present. The supplies of the leading articles in market have been nearly exhausted. Yet the demand continues vigorous, and gives no evidence of an early falling off. All through the twenty-four hours of each business day, the working force of all our first-class houses finds unceasing employment in selling, assorting, packing, marking and shipping the supplies demanded by the exigencies of trade in all the commercial centres of the country.

abstract: PARADE OF THE ONE HUNDRED AND SIXTY-FIFTH REGIMENT. -- The One Hundred and Sixty-fifth New-York Volunteers, Second Duryee's Zouaves, will parade to-day at 3 o'clock P.M. They will be escorted by the Fifty-fifth Regiment National Guard, Col. LEGAL commanding. The line of march will be from the Battery up Broadway to the City Hall, there to be reviewed by the city authorities; thence up Broadway to Fourteenth-street; down Fourteenth-street to Fifth-avenue; up Fifth-avenue to Thirty-fourth-street, and thence to the arsenal, Thirty-fifth-street and Seventh-avenue.

abstract: Hoboken Races--Last Day
snippet: Hoboken Races--Last Day
lead_paragraph: It ever managers have occasion to bestow their orisons on the gentleman known as "the Clerk of the Weather," the powers that be of Hoboken owe him a debt of gratitude which they can never repay, for their meeting has been gotten through in the midst of uninterrupted sunshine, for Old Sol has persisted in exhibiting himself in a blaze of glory throughout. A little less sun and a little more air would have been more agreeable, for, with the thermometer on the verge of 90 throughout the week, and not a solitary breath of air coming off those dismal marshes, where bullrushes and mosquitos most do flourish, the man proper, however eager for and intent on sport, is inevitably inclined to "wilt," as a large majority of the patrons of the Hoboken races have done during the four days' festivities which terminated yesterday.

abstract: The Toronto Leader of Thursday says: "At an early hour yesterday morning the distinguished Southern General, JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE, arrived in this city from Montreal, by the Grand Trunk Railway, accompanied by Col. AENHAM, Major HELME and Col. J. WILSON. They put up at the Queen's Hotel, where they were visited yesterday by a large number of friends and sympathizers. They are expected to be present at the billiard matinee this afternoon, invitations having been sent to them by Messrs. RILEY and MAY. We believe Gen. BRECKINRIDGE and party proceed shortly to St. Catharines."

abstract: This afternoon Prof. LOWE intends making what may be termed an auction balloon ascension. In other words, the Professor will hold an impromptu auction, at which he will dispose of three tickets to the highest bidder, who will be permitted to enter the car of the war balloon, and in company with the Professor, make an unattached ascension. A number of  comic ascensions will also take place, during which elephants, porpoises, and other queer things will take an aerial flight to the sides.

abstract: To those Kentuckians who petition Gen. PALMER for relief from the burden of a "population that will not labor, but simply exist as a nuisance," he says there is but one course which can relieve them, and whereby they can have this cooperation, viz.: To assure the colored people of their freedom, abondon the scheme of expelling them from the State, and gain or regain their confidence.

abstract: Taxes; Supervisors' Estimate
snippet: Taxes; Supervisors' Estimate
lead_paragraph: -- From the report of the Committee on Annual Taxes submitted yesterday to the Board of Supervisors, it appears that the total amount required to be raised for city and county purposes for the present year is $18,076,099 01, and that the total amount of taxable property in the city and county is $608,827,855; consequently, a tax of nearly three per cent. will have to be levied this year. Thus the burden of taxation increases from year to year, no one appearing to know why or wherefore. The city is not better governed than it was years ago; the increase of population during the past five years is, according to the census, inconsiderable; our streets are just as dirty, and just as badly lighted as ever, and yet our taxes are increasing in such ratio that our citizens begin to think the time is not far distant when they will have to abandon their property to the tax collector.
headline: {'main': 'OUR TAXES.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'OUR TAXES.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Some years ago a gentleman died. His widow inherited his property and collected the insurance on his life, and very soon enlarged, repaired, and fitted up her residence in quite luxurious style. A friend calling, expressed some little surprise that she had made these nice arrangements so soon after the decease of Mr. _____. "Why shouldn't I do it?" replied the practical "relic." "My husband, good man as he was, is enjoying a glorious mansion in the skies, and of course he wishes me to be as comfortable as possible on earth." Who says that woman's faith was not shown by her works. -- Boston Transcript.

abstract: The Greenport, L.I., Watchman says: At about 9 A.M. of Sunday last the schooner Catherine Willcor, of Lubec. Me., was proceeding down the Sound, and while becalmed abreast of that port, about eight miles off shore, the captain and a young man, seventeen years of age, named PETER JOHNSON, belonging at Robinston, Me., formerly a soldier, and who was now working his passage home, stripped off their clothing and jumped overboard for a swim.
lead_paragraph: The Greenport, L.I., Watchman says: At about 9 A.M. of Sunday last the schooner Catherine Willcor, of Lubec, Me., was proceeding down the Sound, and while becalmed abreast of that port, about eight miles off shore, the captain and a young man, seventeen years of age, named PETER JOHNSON, belonging at Robinston, Me., formerly a soldier, and who was now working his passage home, stripped off their clothing and jumped overboard for a swim. JOHNSON swam a few rods from the vessel, to pick up a small piece of wood, and while returning a huge shark, judged to have been fourteen or fifteen feet long, darted toward him, and seized him about the middle, and instantly disappeared with him, dragging him down, as he says, about thirty feet deep. He struggled and fought with the ravenous monster, fearfully lacerating his right arm in the effort. He finally succeeded in grasping the shark by the head, and by gouging one of his eyes, at the same time dealing him powerful blows about the head, he succeeded in wresting himself free, he then swam to the schooner pursued by the monster, but being a man of remarkable physical strength and pluck, he finally succeeded in driving him off, and got on board of the schooner, pulling himself up by the fore-topsail clue-line which hung overboard, but not until the terrible teeth had left their mark in many a gastly wound on his abdomen, groins, thigh and leg, so that he was one mass of gore. The mate and one of the crew took him in the yawl boat and rowed to the shore, landing at Bokum, whence he was conveyed in a wagon to the resilience of Dr. SKINNER, who, with Doctors BRYANT and KENDALL, sewed up and dressed his wounds, the operation lasting nearly an hour, during which time he was kept under the influence of chloroform. There were some thirty-four distinct wounds on his person. The abdomen and groin of the right side was tearfully mangled, the flesh being torn off and left hanging by the skin only, nothing but the thin lining membrane of the abdomen preventing the entrails from gushing out, the femoral vessels were laid bare, and the nerves completely reposed. On the left side of the abdomen was another wound similar in character but less extensive, the right thigh was very badly torn and gashed. Nothing but his indomitable courage and physical vigor enabled him to escape alive. The case attracts attention because of the fact that the shark must have been of the species known as "man-eater," which are common in low latitudes, but are rarely seen in shoal water. The common shovel-nose shark of our waters seldom, if ever, attack mankind. JOHNSON is still living, and although in a very precarious situation, there is yet some hope of his ultimate recovery.

abstract: -- A grimly ludicrous incident of the cholera epidemic at Constantinople, now happily diminishing, is furnished by the Levant Herald: "One of the dead-carts was proceeding with its ghastly load to the cemetery at Chichli, when at a short distance beyond Pancaldi, the driver and his assistant perceived a Croat lying, as it seemed, dead by the roadside. They stopped the cart, and, after a very hasty look at the body, thought the right thing was to give it burial, and so bundled it into the cart and proceeded on their way. On arriving at the cemetery the contents of the vehicle were, as usual, shot into the waiting pit. The shaking en route and this rough awakener roused the Croat from what proved to be only a drunken trance, and before the hasty filling in of the pit had proceeded beyond a few shovelsful, he scrambled to his feet. The surprise of the cartmen and grave-diggers may be imagined; but, whether from pure diablerie or some more vivacious impulse, the story goes that they insisted on burying him, dead or alive. The sobered savage, however, finally managed to climb out of the trench, and, vigorously stoned by his would-be inhumers, fled across the country toward Maslak as fast as fear and a perfectly healthy pair of legs could carry him."
lead_paragraph: -- A grimly ludicrous incident of the cholera epidemic at Constantinople, now happily diminishing, is furnished by the Levant Herald: "One of the dead-carts was proceeding with its ghastly load to the cemetery at Chichli, when at a short distance beyond Pancaldi, the driver and his assistant perceived a Croat lying, as it seemed, dead by the roadside. They stopped the cart, and, after a very hasty look at the body, thought the right thing was to give it burial, and so bundled it into the cart and proceeded on their way. On arriving at the cemetery the contents of the vehicle were, as usual, shot into the waiting pit. The shaking en route and this rough awakener roused the Croat from what proved to be only a drunken trance, and before the hasty filling in of the pit had proceeded beyond a few shovelsful, he scrambled to his feet. The surprise of the cartmen and grave-diggers may be imagined; but, whether from pure diablerie or some more vivacious impulse, the story goes that they insisted on burying him, dead or alive. The sobered savage, however, finally managed to climb out of the trench, and, vigorously stoned by his would-be inhumers, fled across the country toward Maslak as fast as fear and a perfectly healthy pair of legs could carry him."

abstract: The failure of the apple crop scorns to be general this year. The quantity produced in Kentucky will be very small. A Mr. CUTTER, near Culbertson's Station, Kenton County, last year sold 2,500 barrels. This year he will only have about 500 barrels. The Nova-Seotia papers say the fruit of that Province will be very light this year. Many orchards in Annapolis Valley, Md., from which a hundred barrels of apples have been annually gathered, will not yield twenty barrels this year.

abstract: Tait, Bishop, and Church of St. Michael; Clerical Bickerings
snippet: Tait, Bishop, and Church of St. Michael; Clerical Bickerings
lead_paragraph: The London Daily News narrates, in a recent number, a singular difficulty, or rather series of difficulties, which occurred at the dedication of the Church of St. Michael and All Angels in that city. We are informed that the first cause of offence to the officiating Bishop, Dr. TAFT, was the appearance of the altar, which was decorated with four handsome bouquets, which latter he desired should be removed. Again, on the entrance of the priests of the church, who were habited in surplices with richly embroidered stoles, he is reported to have said, quietly but sternly: "The clergy of my diocese must appear in the ceremonial of to-day in the simple dress of clergymen of England." No attention being paid to this, Dr. TAIT repeated, "I must ask you to take off those ribands, gentlemen;" which request was then speedily complied with. On the stone reredos behind the communion table there was a rough sketch, in charcoal, of the crucifixion, with two figures of the saints. This also was highly objectionable, and the Bishop desired that it should be obliterated. As the operation could not be well performed at that time, the incumbent, (Rev. Mr. LYFORD,) signed a memorandum to the effect that it should certainly be erased, on which the Bishop proceeded with the ceremony of dedication.

abstract: There is scarcely a more pressing necessity experienced by humanity than that of mental occupation. The brain must be found work, which is at once its aliment and its safety. As in the bodily system, the unsupplied stomach preys upon itself, so in the system of the mind, idleness means corrosion and utter destruction.
lead_paragraph: There is scarcely a more pressing necessity experienced by humanity than that of mental occupation. The brain must be found work, which is at once its aliment and its safety. As in the bodily system, the unsupplied stomach preys upon itself, so in the system of the mind, idleness means corrosion and utter destruction. Not that the action of thought and will ceases, but it becomes diseased, misdirected and evil; and anything which contributes to the supply of food for the mind is as truly beneficent in its aims and results, as any scheme conceived and executed by the noblest philanthropist of our race.

abstract: -- Wyassup Lake, of North Stonington, was originally a natural pond of twenty-five or thirty acres, and contained an island of two or three acres, which was frequently visited by the residents of the vicinity. A short time ago, however, the Wyassup Reservoir Company raised this lake seventeen feet, causing its waters to cover an area of about one hundred and seventeen acres. As the waters rose, the island rose with them, and thus it remains. The soil is spongy, and as the visitor treads upon its springing surface he feels a little insecure, but soon finds himself as safe as on the solid land. It is a curious incident, and rather too much for the philosophers of Eastern Connecticut. They cannot account for it. -- Hartford Post.
lead_paragraph: -- Wyassup Lake, of North Stonington, was originally a natural pond of twenty-five or thirty acres, and contained an island of two or three acres, which was frequently visited by the residents of the vicinity. A short time ago, however, the Wyassup Reservoir Company raised this lake seventeen feet, causing its waters to cover an area of about one hundred and seventeen acres. As the waters rose, the island rose with them, and thus it remains. The soil is spongy, and as the visitor treads upon its springing surface he feels a little insecure, but soon finds himself as safe as on the solid land. It is a curious incident, and rather too much for the philosophers of Eastern Connecticut. They cannot account for it. -- Hartford Post.

abstract: The obsequies of Rev. PETER HAMILL, the unfortunate Catholic priest who, while laboring under insanity, inflicted wounds on his throat from the effects of which he died, on Friday, at Bellevue Hospital, were observed at St. Stephen's Church, in Twenty-eighth-street, yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: The obsequies of Rev. PETER HAMILL, the unfortunate Catholic priest who, while laboring under insanity, inflicted wounds on his throat from the effects of which he died, on Friday, at Bellevue Hospital, were observed at St. Stephen's Church, in Twenty-eighth-street, yesterday morning. A solemn requiem mass was offered up for the repose of his soul at 9:30 o'clock. The celebrant on the occasion was Rev. HENRY LYNDON, of Newburyport, Mass., where the deceased was ministering at the time of his death, assisted by Rev. JAS. QUINN, of St. Stephen's Church, as deacon, and Rev. LOUIS GAMBOSVILLE, of the same parish, as sub-deacon. The ceremonial of the mass was most solemn and imposing. The music was furnished by Prof. WM. BERGE, who presided at the organ, and singers selected from the old choir of St. Francis Xavier's and from the present choir of St. Stephen's Churches. The mass sung was CHERUBINI's requiem, a most solemnly plaintive and appropriate composition, which was faultlessly rendered. Quite a large congregation was present during the ceremony.

abstract: Shipyards (Private) of Great Britain
snippet: Shipyards (Private) of Great Britain
lead_paragraph: In giving, some time since, an account of the dockyards of Great Britain and comparing them with our own, we alluded to the private ship and machinery building establishments of England as superior to any in the world. We now propose to describe a few of the more complete of these works, and to glance at the amount of perfected workmanship they can produce yearly, and shall confine ourselves to the iron ship building works, as almost none but iron ships are now built for the British navy, and but few wooden vessels of large size for the merchant marine. The private iron ship building works of England are of three classes. 1. Those that manufacture within one inclosure every part of a ship, including armor plates for iron-clads. 2. Those that manufacture steam machinery for ships. 3. Those that confine themselves to rolling armor plates and every kind of rolled work.

abstract: -- A short time since, two brothers, aged respectively thirteen and seven, sons of a poor man named CAIN, obtained the use of a small boat, in which they went on a voyage of discovery from Mission-street wharf. While within the shelter of the shore, the little navigators glided over the smooth surface of the bay, as young life glides down the great tide of time, without impediment. After a while the usual evening breeze sprang up, and the little fellows were exhilarated at the pleasure of flying before the wind, till want of skill in the management of their craft caused it to upset, when, the instant before happy children, as the alloy of their pleasure, had to struggle for life. The larger boy, with the courage and nerve of a full-hearted man, seized his little brother with one hand, and with the other held on to the capsized boat, and thus they were radidly drifted out upon the milled billows of the bay. The little boy lost his courage -- he was but a child, and complained of cold -- the waters chilled him. His noble brother held him closer to his bosom to warm him with the fire of courage and fraternal love that blazed within -- even in those perilous circumstances. For nearly three hours they drifted on and on in the cold, cold water -- the elder boy holding the younger one in his arms till he died of the effects, of cold and fear, and he held his icy corpse in his embrace for hours, till the steamer Merrimac, which happened to be passing, saw the boat and made toward it, when the boy's joy at being rescued from certain death caused him to relax his grasp of the body of his dearly loved brother, when it sunk as a stone beneath the water. -- San Francisco Flag.
lead_paragraph: -- A short time since, two brothers, aged respectively thirteen and seven, sons of a poor man named CAIN, obtained the use of a small boat, in which they went on a voyage of discovery from Mission-street wharf. While within the shelter of the shore, the little navigators glided over the smooth surface of the bay, as young life glides down the great tide of time, without impediment. After a while the usual evening breeze sprang up, and the little fellows were exhilarated at the pleasure of flying before the wind, till want of skill in the management of their craft caused it to upset, when, the instant before happy children, as the alloy of their pleasure, had to struggle for life. The larger boy, with the courage and nerve of a full-hearted man, seized his little brother with one hand, and with the other held on to the capsized boat, and thus they were radidly drifted out upon the milled billows of the bay. The little boy lost his courage -- he was but a child, and complained of cold -- the waters chilled him. His noble brother held him closer to his bosom to warm him with the fire of courage and fraternal love that blazed within -- even in those perilous circumstances. For nearly three hours they drifted on and on in the cold, cold water -- the elder boy holding the younger one in his arms till he died of the effects, of cold and fear, and he held his icy corpse in his embrace for hours, till the steamer Merrimac, which happened to be passing, saw the boat and made toward it, when the boy's joy at being rescued from certain death caused him to relax his grasp of the body of his dearly loved brother, when it sunk as a stone beneath the water. -- San Francisco Flag.

abstract: Report of Aid by Am. Union Commission; Report of Richmond Agent
snippet: Report of Aid by Am. Union Commission; Report of Richmond Agent
lead_paragraph: The American Union Commission continues active in its work of regeneration and assistance at the South. From the following report of the Richmond Agent, which has just been received at the parent office, in this city, much of interest can be gathered by our readers. It is evident that the commission is doing a great work, and one to which the government and particularly the War Department, is lending every assistance possible.

abstract: Complaint having been made recently, by emigrants who had been charged from $3 to $5 a day [???]retched board which is given by the emigrant boarding-house-keepers in Greenwich and Washington streets, below Cortlandt, Capt. BRACKETT has resolved, Mayor GUNTHER assenting, to compell these publicans to comply with the provisions of the law, first in taking out license, and secondly in conspicuously posting their rates in their respective houses, printed in five spoken languages. Capt. BRACKETT will notify these offenders to-day, and give them one week's grace, after which time he will enforce the law and strive to collect $50 fine from every delinquent.
