abstract: MYSTERIOUS SOUNDS IN A CHURCH -- INVESTIGATION BY THE POLICE. -- Considerable excitement has arisen in Jersey City in consequence of groans, yells and unearthly sounds said to emanate from a church in the upper part of Jersey City for some nights past. The first known of these mysterious sounds was some ten days since, when the pastor had occasion to return to the church after evening services to procure some manuscript which he had forgotten, and had occasion to make use of. The edifice had been closed for the night, and was in total darkness. On entering he lit a match to guide him along the aisle, and when approaching the altar at the rear, his attention was attracted by a low moaning sound, which gradually increased and at the same time drew nearer to him. To this he at first paid but little heed, presuming it to be the antics of mischievous boys; but presently the sounds changed to seemingly unearthly yells, shrieks and groans, from innumerable invisible beings clustering around in close proximity to his person, until finally his feelings were so wrought upon that he felt impelled to leave the building with all possible haste. The above are substantially the facts of the case as stated by the pastor of the church to Chief of Police MCMANNUS, after reports were beginning to be circulated in the neighborhood that the church was haunted, and requesting that the matter might be kept as quiet as possible, believing that in a few days at furthest he would be able to unravel the mystery, and satisfactorily explain the cause of the sounds. Since that time the church edifice has been thoroughly examined, inside and out, but without unraveling the mystery, and meantime these dismal and unearthly yells and cries are heard almost every night. A couple of nights since, Chief of Police MCMANNUS, accompanied by Aid DOYLE and Detective E.L. MCWILLIAMS, determined to pay a visit to the reported haunted church. They accordingly procured the keys and entered the edifice shortly after midnight. Taking their position in the centre of the church, in total darkness, they had remained there but a short time when they heard a low moaning sound, apparently proceeding from the vicinity of the pulpit, which gradually grew louder and came nearer until it finally culminated around their heads into howls, yells, groans, &c., and then gradually died away as it came. After a few moments of perfect silence, Chief MCMANNUS drew from his pocket a revolver, loaded with blank cartridge, and fired one charge, when almost instantly the edifice seemed filled with thousands of infuriated demons, making the most hideous noises and apparently bent on tearing them to pieces. The officers describe having experienced a very peculiar sensation in the head, and finally the noises became so hideous and unearthly that they made a hasty retreat, apparently pursued by the infuriated demons to the door, which they closed and locked. The officers then crossed the street to the opposite walk, and remained there until daylight, but heard no further sounds, and made no discoveries which would tend to explain the mystery. The people residing in the immediate neighborhood claim to have been disturbed at all hours of the night by these demoniac sounds, and a number of them have determined to leave the neighborhood.

abstract: -- A remarkable circumstance occurred near Allegan, Mich., on the 31st ult. A Mr. TYLER was plowing around his bees. When the distance between had increased to several rods, two bees were observed flying spitefully around the heads of the horses. While brushing these off, their numbers began to increase until they came, as described by an eye-witness, in clouds. It was now impossible to remove the team, which was pitching and rubbing furiously. His wife, who usually attends their swarming, came to his assistance, and was stung so [???]ly that r covery was thought doubtful. The whole forty [???] [???] [???] [???]ted upon the horses, which were [???]ed instantly.

abstract: Valuation of Life and Limb Suggested
snippet: Valuation of Life and Limb Suggested
lead_paragraph: The public loudly demand that a stop be put to the slaughters by rail which daily darken our pages, and bring merited disgrace upon the country. One of the wisest of ancient legislators declared that that country was best governed in which a wrong done to the meanest citizen was considered and treated as an injury to the community of which he was a unit. People cannot and will not afford to purchase even the facilities of rapid transit by rail, at the frightful cost of half a score killed, and considerably more than that number wounded, per day. By comparison with other countries, the tale is found to be infinitely too large, and wholly unjustifiable. In the elaborate report of the violent deaths which have taken place through negligence or accident on steamboats and railroads, which was published in this paper last week, it was computed that the number of people killed on railroads in this State alone amounted to 285 during the past year, against twenty for the same period of time in Great Britain. This statement proves conclusively that guilt lies somewhere in the general conduct of our railroads; and there is no hope left of securing even a comparative degree of safety for the traveling public, but by fearlessly exposing and punishing it.

abstract: -- While the Secretaries were counting the votes last evening for delegates to the State Convention from Ward Eleven, Mr. PHILBRICK, Superintendent of our public schools, took occasion to introduce the grandson of LAFAYETTE, who has recently come to this country, and who was present last evening for the purpose of becoming acquainted with the manner in which our preliminary political meetings are conducted. Though but little acquainted with our language, he uttered some eloquent remarks in relation to the recent rebellion in this country, and said the struggle was not only for free principles in America, but in the Empire of France. His speech, though short and much broken, was warmly applauded. -- Boston Traveler, Sept. 12.
lead_paragraph: -- While the Secretaries were counting the votes last evening for delegates to the State Convention from Ward Eleven, Mr. PHILBRICK, Superintendent of our public schools, took occasion to introduce the grandson of LAFAYETTE, who has recently come to this country, and who was present last evening for the purpose of becoming acquainted with the manner in which our preliminary political meetings are conducted. abstract: Substitutes for
snippet: Substitutes for
lead_paragraph: There are fears that the price of coal will be extremely high in this city during the coming Winter, as it was last Winter. The use of this article, and, we suppose, its price, might be greatly reduced, were those contrivances for cooking and for heating rooms by means of petroleum, kerosene, gas, or any of the burning fluids or oils brought into as general use as they might be. There are stoves, little and larger, of various patents and various orders of merit, now in the market, in which the above-named substances and others are burned; and they, or at least some of them, can be made to serve all the uses of ordinary stoves, and at a much more economical rate than coal stoves or fires. Even now they are much used in small families, and by persons who board themselves, and by all sorts of folks, for all sorts of purposes. If they are used this coming Winter by one-half of those who would find it profitable and convenient to use them, the profits of the coal speculators will be less, and so, too, will be the sufferings of the poor.

abstract: Books Forthcoming
snippet: Books Forthcoming
lead_paragraph: The inactivity of Summer is now fairly over, and the Fall season finds the publisher and book-trade generally fully engaged in the energetic prosecution of business. Both in its own special results to contributors and purchasers, and as a barometer to the state of the market, the New-York Trade Sale, just concluded, was unusually important. The wide section of the country unrepresented at such gatherings for the last three or four years, is again in the field, in the persons of its traders, and an unaccustomed liveliness and spirit was clearly shown in consequence. The great extent of the demand for books, however, is a cause that there are fewer novelties produced than in times of comparative depression. It is impossible for publishers to manufacture their books, already known to the public, fast enough to supply the demand, and there is consequently loss inducement to bring out new ones. School books and educational literature of a staple character take the lead in this general rush. Many whole States are absolutely bare of this kind of stock, and must be supplied at once, in addition to the steadily growing home demand. The sales of many well established school books may now be counted by millions, and with a constantly increasing future demand still in prospect. So occupied are publishers with supplying their own issues, that the new and extraordinary call for war books has necessarily fallen into other hands. This has given the canvassing, or agency business, a vast development, and the quantities of large and expensive books disposed of in this manner is something surprising, and can hardly be specified without danger of exaggeration. The rewards of literary labor are beginning to increase in the same proportion, and altogether it may be said the commerce of literature shares, fully in the general prosperity of the country.

abstract: Rebel Loan; Holders and their Meeting
snippet: Rebel Loan; Holders and their Meeting
lead_paragraph: By the City of Boston we have four days later news from Europe. Financial affairs in the United States seem to occupy the most prominent place in the news. The holders of Confederate bonds had held a solemn meeting, at which it was gravely argued by the chief speaker, that inasmuch as the Federal States had conquered the Confederate States, the dominant power was in duty bound to pay the rebel debt, and the speaker explained that a certain English Vice-Chancellor had so decided. But the argument does not seem to have had the intended effect; on the contrary, the rebel loan declined one per cent. the next day. A more successful operation is likely to result (to those in the secret) from the invention of a story, said to come from New-York, that it had been officially stated that the United States would be compelled in every short time to negotiate a new loan. This "news" will be news indeed at Washington. The American cotton trade at Liverpool is rapidly reviving. A half-dozen of Fenian leaders, near Dundalk, have been committed for trial without benefit of bail, Sir WM. HAMILTON, Astronomer Royal at Dublin, is dead. Mr. JOHN BRIGHT's home organ says there is no truth in the rumors that he is about to visit America. The English wheat crop is reported to be in bad order. The cattle plague continues; among other remarkable facts, the entire destruction of the fine herd of cows belonging to Miss BURDETT COUTTS. The cholera excitement is nearly over, the season being so far advanced that its spread northward is daily growing more improbable. NAPOLEON and EUGENE are going to visit the King and Queen of Spain at San Sebastian. JOSEPH BONAPARTE, Prince of Musignano, is dead. EULENBURG, the murderer of Prince ALFRED's cook, has been allowed to join his regiment. The King of Prussia was to have an interview with the Queen VICTORIA on the 6th, at Darmstadt Large numbers of fugitive Dano-Schleswigians have arrived at Copenhagen. Official notice was given that the present government of the Duchies would cease on the 14th, and the government for Holstein would [???] Kiel. The Basuto was in South [???] was going on vigorously, and great atrocities are committed. The English Consul, Capt. CAMERON, who has been so long held in confinement by the Emperor of Abyssinia, has been released. An extensive conflagration had swept over Stamboul, destroying about 2,500 houses and causing great distress.

abstract: Financial Croakers never content; Debt and Financial Croakers
snippet: Financial Croakers never content; Debt and Financial Croakers
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of the Treasury is constantly overwhelmed by newspaper and private financial suggestions for bettering the Currency, which has not increased; for raising new loans, which are not wanted; for bringing down the price of Gold, which, through nearly three months of extraordinary demand to pay Customs, has not advanced, although the stock in Bank has fallen from $20,400,000 down to $13,775,000 since the middle of July; and for taking care of his National Bank Note Currency in New-York, where it would be difficult to scrape together three millions of dollars out of the one hundred and eighty millions now in circulation, without including the Notes of the City Banks themselves. Even these are nearly all in the country, so that our largest Banks, in point of Country Bank balances, pay out Greenbacks almost exclusively. One of the largest had only $35,000 National Currency on Saturday, as against $3,700,000 Greenbacks, and another $15,000 as against $3,500,000 Greenbacks.

abstract: The Bostonians closed their week's play on Saturday with a victory, the only one they obtained in the four games played; the result of the second eleven match being the success of the Boston eleven by a score of 135 to 125. The closing part of the match was quite interesting, the Bostonians barely having time to lead the score of their adversaries. Only one inning on each side was played.

abstract: Prospects; the Mobile Tribune on
snippet: Prospects; the Mobile Tribune on
lead_paragraph: The Mobile Tribune discusses approvingly the proposition made in the TIMES for a convention of cotton-growers to devise means for fostering and enlarging the cultivation of that staple next season. It says that the cotton-producing soil of the South is fertile as ever -- nay, it is not improbable that the rest it has had for at least three years will give it new vigor for production; and there is a more serious desire now to make a great crop than formerly. The Tribune alleges that there is but one thing necessary to secure a superabundance of cotton next year for domestic use and for export:

abstract: Mr. LOUIS WUST by name, appeared against GEORGE POWERS, a young engraver who dwells at No. 139 East Twenty-second-street. Mr. WUST made affidavit that while he was riding on the front platform of a Third-avenue car, on Tuesday last, a youth who stood by his side pushed him and then leaped from the car, and that subsequent to this transaction he missed his gold watch. POWERS having been taken into custody by Policemen VERMILYEA and HARRIS, of the Eighteenth Ward, Mr. WUST positively identified the prisoner as the person that had probably stolen his watch. The accused listened attentively to the charge, and then carelessly remarked to the Judge that he could prove that on Tuesday last he was under imprisonment in the Tombs, and was not discharged therefrom until Wednesday. This is

abstract: The four-oared race between New-York and Newburgh, will come off on Monday, Sept. 25, upon the Hudson River, at Sing Sing, between the hours of 1 and 3 o'clock. The balance of the $2,000, for which amount the match is made, was put up at the place of deposit on Friday last, when the course, &c., was settled. The boats are to run a five-mile race -- two and a half miles up the river, turning a stake-boat, and return. The judges, referee, &c., are to be chosen the night previous to the race. Both crews are in severe training -- the New-York crew at Pleasant Valley, a few miles up the Hudson, and the Newburgh crew at Cornwall. The latter crew will have a new four-oared boat. The New-Yorkers will row one of the two boats built by CHARLES B. ELLIOTT, which they pulled in Boston on the 4th of July, and against Poughkeepsie on the 18th of July, in both of which races New-York's champion crew won easily. The steamboat D.R. Martin will make an excursion up the Hudson on the day of the race, and accompany the boats over the course.

lead_paragraph: CASUALTIES. -- On Saturday afternoon a portion of a wall, at the intersection of Franklin and Church streets, fell in and buried one of the workmen, JOHN GARRITY, who was excavating, under the wall. GARRITY was taken to his abode, in Avenue C, near Twelfth-street, and it was there ascertained that both of his legs had been broken.....THOMAS DALLY, of Lewis-street, stevedore, who was employed discharging cotton from the steamer Western Metropolis, on Saturday afternoon, fell into the lower hold, and sustained a fracture of the skull. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital . . . . . ADOLPH CROWELL, of No. 55 Avenue C, a lad of thirteen years, was taken to the New-York Hospital, having fallen through a scuttle in Messrs. JAMES WILDE & CO.'s warehouse, at No. 55 White street . . . . . THOMAS NEILAN, a lad of seven years, was run over and severely injured, on Saturday evening, by a stage, at the intersection of Broadway and Duane-street. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital . . . . . Mr. JOHN PFEIFFER, of No. 319 East Twelfth-street, having been knocked down by the tongue of a stage, in Broadway, was run over by a lager-beer wagon owned by Mr. GEORGE B. HARSEN, of No. 309 West Forty-second-street, and driven by FRANCIS SEIFERT, of No. 229 West Forty-fourth-street Mr. PFEIFFER was taken to Bellevue Hospital . . . . On Saturday afternoon one of the Harlem Railroad freight cars ran over and killed a horse in Centre-street owned and driven by Mr. OWEN CARROLL, of Brooklyn. Mr. CARROLL was thrown from his wagon, and slightly bruised . . . . ANDREW VEGO, of No. 158 Orchard-street, was knocked down and severely injured, at the intersection of Broadway and Twelfth-street, by a barouche, which was driven by S.N. PRIESTLEY, of No. 15 Spruce-street . . . . Mrs. BRIDGET MALOY, having accidentally fallen from a third-story window at No. 50 Orchard-street, was taken to Bellevue Hospital, where it was found that her collar-bone had been fractured.

abstract: At the managers' meeting, held day before yesterday, in the Bible Rooms, Rev. Dr. ARMITAGE, President, occupied the chair. A letter was read from Rev. Dr. TAYLOR, Secretary of the Southern Missionary Board, asking the Union to assist in printing and circulating the Scriptures in China. Dr. MASON writes on behalf of Karen Scripture distribution, and begs the Uuion to renew its labors for the nations in India ...
lead_paragraph: At the managers' meeting, held day before yesterday, in the Bible Rooms, Rev. Dr. ARMITAGE, President, occupied the chair. A letter was read from Rev. Dr. TAYLOR, Secretary of the Southern Missionary Board, asking the Union to assist in printing and circulating the Scriptures in China. Dr. MASON writes on behalf of Karen Scripture distribution, and begs the Uuion to renew its labors for the nations in India, who are anxious to possess the work of God. Rev. J.H. CHANDLER, of Siam, is anxious for another appropriation of $1,000 for the Siamese Scriptures. Rev. T.A. REID, missionary among the Yoruba tribes of Africa, was present, and laid before the board the New Testament translated, and now being circulated among that people. His statements are full of interest; he has won the confidence of the natives; and king and peasant alike implore him to return. The Treasurer's statement shows a large increase of receipts over last year. The prospects are encouraging for an unusually interesting anniversary, which will be held in New-York, Wednesday and Thursday, Oct. 25 and 26. A large and varied correspondence was laid before the managers, in reference to the distribution of the revised New Testament among the freedmen. The letters received are full of incidents, showing the condition and wants of the freedmen, their aptitude for learning, and their earnest desire for copies of the revised New Testament The openings for Scripture circulation are numerous; the opportunities for benefiting the souls of millions are very great. The Bible Union can now send forth the Word of The Lord to an unlimited extent; and all that its friends can do, before the anniversary, must be done at once.

abstract: LAYING A CORNER-STONE. -- The ceremony of laying the corner-stone of the new St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church, took place yesterday afternoon, corner of Grand and Van Vorst streets, Jersey City, in the presence of a vast assembly. The crowd evidently could not be the people of one congregation, for it seemed they had congregated from the neighboring churches. The procession started from St. Peter's Church, and was led by a cross bearer, on either side of whom was an acolyte bearing tall candlesticks and candles. These were followed by a train of altar-boys dressed in red cassocks, white surplices, and decorated with crimson sashes. The clergy, dressed in the usual costume employed in their functions, followed, the Right Rev. Bishop of Newark, JAMES ROSEVELT BAYLEY, D.D., in the rear; a deacon and sub-deacon accompanied him, wearing flowered silk vestments, called delmantics. Two small boys -- a mitre and crosier bearer -- followed these ministers. Temperance and other societies, with bands of music and gay banners, formed lines occupying in close column several blocks around the new edifice. The societies formed in open line and allowed the clergy to pass through and ascend a flight of steps on the first floor of the new edifice. The prelate commenced the religious ceremony by the blessing of a large cross erected in the place intended for the altar. He returned to the west end or front of the edifice to bless the corner-stone, the clergy meantime chanting several psalms. Instead of the usual papers in sealed bottles, it was tiles, or delf tablets, which were placed within the cavity of the cornerstone. The memoranda were in Latin, and read to this effect: "This stone of the Church of St Peter's was laid Sept. 17, 1865, by the Most Rev. J.B. BAYLEY -- ANDREW JOHNSON being President of the United States; JOEL PARKER, Governor of New-Jersey, and ORESTES CLEVELAND being the Prefect of the city -- in presence of a large assembly of the faithful. God be praised." On the second tablet was: "Dedicated (this building understood) to God, the Great Omnipotent -- PIUS IX. being (Supreme Pontiff, and $#8224;JOHN Archbishop of New-York; J.B. BAYLEY, Bishop of Newark, and J. KELLY, A.D. 1865 -- A.M.D.G." On the third tablet was the names of the architect, P.E. KEELEY; mason, THOS. KELLY; carpenter, P.E. REED; trustees, * * and JOHN MCBRIDE. J. GARAGTHY, W.N. HENRATTI. The exercises closed by a discourse from the Rev. E. MCGLYNN, D.D. A collection was taken up, and apparently a liberal sum was contributed on the occasion toward the expenses of the building. The church is 142 feet in length, by 70 feet in width to the transept. In this latter part which is cruciform, and termed the transept, the width is ninety-four feet. It is being built of brick, trimmed with a light-colored freestone, from the Belleville quarries. It will be very lofty, having clere story and aisles. There is a high basement, for a chapel and free school. The tower and spire will be 120 feet high. The cost of the building, it is said, will not exceed $45,000. The edifice will be inclosed before winter, and will be completed some time during next season.

abstract: The Vienna papers publish a decree of the Minister of Justice to the Procurator-General, relative to the course to be pursued toward the press. The Minister recommends the exercise of the law against really serious offences of the press, but a careful avoidance of all measures which might raise a suspicion that the prosecution was of a partisan character. Apart from all prejudiced opinion, the government, says the Minister, will gratefully accept all well-founded criticisms of their acts.

abstract: OPERA IN BROOKLYN. -- Of all queer places in the world Brooklyn takes the lead. Within the recollection of any ten-year-old child it was considered by all good people there to be a sin to visit the opera-house; now it is considered quite the reverse. Then, a manager was deemed a fool if he but thought of going there; now, he would be an undoubted fool if he should decline to give a regular season there. The public spirit of a few wealthy men has provided Brooklyn with one of the handsomest, certainly the most comfortable opera-house in the city. This has been leased by MARETZEK, who proposes and announces to give nine performances as "the first series," and quite likely as many more in a second series. Mr. E.J. LOWBER, fomerly of the Restaurant Sanitaire, is entitled to the credit of securing a successful season last year, and to his able management the matter is again referred. Subscription books are now open, the price being $30 for two seats nine nights, and when two hundred subscribers have pledged themselves to the undertaking, the privilege of seats will be drawn for, the old Provost Marshal's wheel having kindly consented to revolve on the occasion."
lead_paragraph: OPERA IN BROOKLYN. -- Of all queer places in the world Brooklyn takes the lead. Within the recollection of any ten-year-old child it was considered by all good people there to be a sin to visit the opera-house; now it is considered quite the reverse. Then, a manager was deemed a fool if he but thought of going there; now, he would be an undoubted fool if he should decline to give a regular season there. The public spirit of a few wealthy men has provided Brooklyn with one of the handsomest, certainly the most comfortable opera-house in the city. This has been leased by MARETZEK, who proposes and announces to give nine performances as "the first series," and quite likely as many more in a second series. Mr. E.J. LOWBER, fomerly of the Restaurant Sanitaire, is entitled to the credit of securing a successful season last year, and to his able management the matter is again referred. Subscription books are now open, the price being $30 for two seats nine nights, and when two hundred subscribers have pledged themselves to the undertaking, the privilege of seats will be drawn for, the old Provost Marshal's wheel having kindly consented to revolve on the occasion."

abstract: Between 12 and 1 o'clock Saturday morning Mrs. MARY LADDING, who was momentarily insane, leaped from a second-story window at No. 145 Worthstreet, and sustained a compound fracture of the skull, from which she died three hours subsequently. She was a native of Ireland, 68 years of age....JOHN MACDONALD, who sustained painful injuries from falling from a wagon on the 31st ult., died at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: Between 12 and 1 o'clock Saturday morning Mrs. MARY LADDING, who was momentarily insane, leaped from a second-story window at No. 145 Worth-street, and sustained a compound fracture of the skull, from which she died three hours subsequently. She was a native of Ireland, 68 years of age....JOHN MACDONALD, who sustained painful injuries from falling from a wagon on the 31st ult., died at St. Luke's Hospital yesterday morning. He was a native of Ireland, 32 years of age. The Coroner's Jury found a verdict of "death from injuries accidentally received"....On Friday evening the Fifth Ward police found the body of an unknown woman, of about 40 years of age, floating in the dock at Pier No. 35 North River. The woman was attired in spotted calico s[???]k, black petticoats, slippers and white stockings. The hair is brown. The body had been about four days in the water.

abstract: Securities in Europe and Reuter's Telegrams; Reuter's Partisan Telegrams on American Affairs
snippet: Securities in Europe and Reuter's Telegrams; Reuter's Partisan Telegrams on American Affairs
lead_paragraph: We have learned to regard "Reuter's Tele- grams" in the English papers with as much suspicion as we used to look upon "Philadelphia Dispatches" during the war. "Reuter's" American news has always been utterly unreliable, and as unfriendly as possible to the Union. While the rebellion was in progress, REUTER gave to the European public, through his dispatches in the journals, all the pro-rebel falsehoods and all the secession fictions that his agents could procure for him; and now that the war is over, REUTER lends himself to European speculators to injure American credit abroad, by the publication of all adverse rumors he can gather in regard to the condition and prospects of our national finances.

abstract: -The prospectus of a new Transatlantic Steamship Company is announced in our advices from London this morning. The line is to be composed of fast and capacious passenger and freight steamers, to run between Southampton and New-York. The company propose to raise a capital of £800,000 sterling, in shares of £50 sterling, and half the amount is said to have been already subscribed. They look to the carrying of American supplies of provisions for the London market as one great source of their prospective profit. Is it not about time that we began to think in earnest of at least one American line among the score of foreign companies, now reaping the credit and the material profits of this vast commerce?

abstract: Morris' Infantry Tactics, 7th edition
snippet: Morris' Infantry Tactics, 7th edition
lead_paragraph: The seventh edition of Gen. MORRIS' Infantry Tactics, carefully revised and corrected by the author, is in readiness for the press, and will soon be published by D. VAN NOSTRAND, Broadway. This work, resulting from the experience of our troops in the field, contains the flank movements which have superseded those of the old school; and the formations of columns in mass by successive movements instead of by the complicated and fatiguing methods derived from European systems. By rejecting useless and absolete evolutions and unnecessary details, Gen. MORRIS has given us a purely practical work, which greatly increases the efficiency of infantry, and is easily acquired. Some twenty State Adjutant-Generals have given their opinions of this system and greatly prefer it to all others for State troops on account of its simplicity, and the short time required by its use to prepare troops for the field. The work is also strongly recommended as one resulting from our campaigns, and better suited to the wants of our service than the system still under government patronage, by Gens. Thomas, Meade, Foster, Warren, Humphries, Couch, Pleasonton, Dix, Hartsuff, Peck, Stoneman, Emory, Sickles, Butler, Carr, Lockwood, Stahel, Hazen, Johnson, Wilcox, Ferrero, Lanman, Cook, Meredith, Sturges, Fisk, Sweeny, Fry, Pitcher, Prall, and many other distinguished tacticians, whose brilliant careers stamp them as the highest authority. The Duke of CAMBRIDGE, Commander-in-chief of the British forces, is personally examining this system of tactics in order to make himself acquainted with its merits and suitableness for his troops.

abstract: Hamill, Rev. Peter; Verdict; Funeral Ceremonies
snippet: Hamill, Rev. Peter; Verdict; Funeral Ceremonies
lead_paragraph: The obsequies of Rev. PETER HAMILL, the unfortunate Catholic priest who, while laboring under insanity, inflicted wounds on his throat from, the effects of which he died, on Friday, at Bellevue Hospital, were observed at St. Stephen's Church, in Twenty-eighth-street, on Saturday morning. A solemn requiem mass was offered up for the repose of his soul at 9:30 o'clock. The celebrant on the occasion was Rev. HENRY LYNDON, of Newburyport, Mass., where the deceased was ministering at the time of his death, assisted by Rev. JAS. QUINN, of St. Stephen's Church, as deacon, and Rev. Louis GAMBOSVILLE, of the same parish, as sub-deacon. The ceremonial of the mass was most solemn and imposing. The music was furnished by Prof. WM. BERGE, who presided at the organ, and singers selected from the old choir of St. Francis Xavier's and from the present choir of St. Stephen's Churches. The mass sung was CHERUBINI's requiem, a most solemnly plaintive and appropriate composition, which was faultlessly rendered. Quite a large congregation was present during the ceremony.

abstract: HIGHWAY ROBBERY. -- JOHN TARNEY, residing at No. 222 Tillary-street, was attacked in Navy-street on Saturday night by two men, and robbed of $7 50. Officer WILMARTH, of the Forty-fourth Police Precinct, pursued the assailants and succeeded in arresting one of them, named JAMES MCGINNEY. The accused is charged by the police with being one of a gang who frequent the city parks and of robbing any one whom he may deem it safe to attack. He was held for a hearing.

abstract: Fenians, Arrests of in Ireland
snippet: Fenians, Arrests of in Ireland
lead_paragraph: -- Five members of the Fenian brotherhood, to-day's European budget informs us, have been caught, near the town of Dundalk, in Ireland, indulging in their little evening pastime, and have been ruthlessly lodged in jail without benefit of bail. Devotion to the Fenian cause in Ireland, it will thus be seen, involves somewhat more risk than it does here. Our Fenian friends in New-York may drill themselves from morning till night, and from night till morning without the slightest interference on the part of the police, or anybody else. And when they get tired of drilling, they may go to Jones Wood and recuperate. That is the difference between Fenian life at Dundalk and Fenian life in New-York. Under the circumstances we should be disposed, were we a Fenian, to remain in New-York.

abstract: We have the intelligence to-day from Europe that the cholera is making unexpected progress at Marseilles, half the daily deaths being attributed to the pestilence. We are fortunate beyond our deserts in having escaped a visitation during the hot season just closed. Shall we be any better prepared for the terrible visitor next year? Surely we have had timely warning.

abstract: MYSTERIOUS SOUNDS IN A CHURCH -- INVESTIGATION BY POLICE. -- Considerable excitement has arisen in Jersey City in consequence of grams, yells and unearthly sounds said to emanate from a church in the upper part of Jersey City for some nights past. The first known of these mysterious sounds was some ten days since, when the pastor had occasion to return to the church after evening services to procure some manuscript which he had forgotten, and had occasion to make use of. The edifice had been closed for the night, and was in total darkness. On entering he lit a match to guide him along the aisle, and when approaching the altar at the roar, his attention was attracted by a low meaning sound, which gradually increased and at the same time drew nearer to him. To tide he at first paid but little heed, presuming it to be the antics of mischievous boys; but presently the sounds changed to seemingly unearthly yells, shrieks and groans, from innumerable invisible beings clustering around in close proximity to his person, until finally his feelings were so wrought upon that he felt impelled to leave the building with all possible haste. The above are substantially the facts of the case as stated by the pastor of the church to Chief of Police MCMANNUS, after reports were beginning to be circulated in the neighborhood that the church was haunted, and requesting that the matter might be kept as quiet as possible, believing that in a few days at furthest he would be able to unravel the mystery, and satisfactorily explain the cause of the sounds. Since that time the church edifice has been thoroughly examined, inside and out, but without unraveling the mystery, and meantime these dismal and unearthly yells and cries are heard almost every night. A couple of nights since, Chief of Police MCMANNUS, accompanied by Aid DOYLE and Detective E.L. MCWILLIAMS, determined to pay a visit to the reported haunted church. They accordingly procured the keys and entered the edifice shortly after midnight. Taking their position in the centre of the church, in total darkness, they had remained there but a short time when they heard a low moaning sound, apparently proceeding from the vicinity of the pulpit, which gradually grew louder and came nearer until it finally culminated around their heads into howls, yells, groans, &c., and then gradually died away as it came. After a few moments of perfect silence, Chief MCMANNUS drew from his pocket a revolver, loaded with blank cartridge, and fired one charge, when almost instantly the edifice seemed filled with thousands of infuriated demons, making the most hideous noises and apparently bent on tearing them to pieces. The officers describe having experienced a very peculiar sensation in the head, and finally the noises became so hideous and unearthly that they made a hasty retreat, apparently pursued by the infuriated demons to the door, which they closed and locked. The officers then crossed the street to the opposite walk, and remained there until daylight, but heard no further sounds, and made no discoveries which would tend to explain the mystery. The people residing in the immediate neighborhood claim to have been disturbed at all hours of the night by these demoniac sounds, and a number of them have determined to leave the neighborhood.

abstract: Churches, Reconstruction in the
snippet: Churches, Reconstruction in the
lead_paragraph: The national organizations of the churches were the first to split. It seems now as if they would be the last to unite again. Not one of the four largest denominations, which dissolved North and South before the rebellion, have yet made the first movement toward a new junction. Nor, indeed, is there the least sign yet of such a disposition, unless it be among the newspapers of the Old-School Presbyterians. A certain vague yearning for a reconciliation manifests itself there, but it shapes itself into no propositions, nor ever makes the attempt. The organs of the New-School Presbyterians, the Methodists and the Baptists, Northern and Southern, advert to the subject only to make it manifest that they disagree as much as ever.

lead_paragraph: is seldom written of prisoners who enter the portals of the East Side Court; but on Saturday such commitment was ordered in the case of WILLIAM JOST, a Bowery statue, who had snatched a wallet, containing $108, from the hands of Mr. EDWARD GRIFFITH, of NO. 834 Broadway, while that gentleman was payivg for refreshments in a Bowery saloon, near Grand-street. Having laid hands on Mr. GRIFFITH;s wallet, the thief fled to the street, but was pursued and captured by Policeman WILSON, of the Eighteenth Ward, who happened to pass the saloon at the moment of the robbery. The thief tossed the wallet into a gutter while he was flying from the officer; but it was recovered and restored to Mr. GRIFFITH. abstract: By the British steamer we have this morning a very amusing report of a meeting of Confederate bondholders in London. These sagacious and far-sighted capitalists have come to the conclusion that it is time for them "to inquire into the circumstances under which the loan was contracted." We should think it was quite time to inquire. It has been usual for lenders of money to make such inquiries a ...
lead_paragraph: By the British steamer we have this morning a very amusing report of a meeting of Confederate bondholders in London. These sagacious and far-sighted capitalists have come to the conclusion that it is time for them "to inquire into the circumstances under which the loan was contracted." We should think it was quite time to inquire. It has been usual for lenders of money to make such inquiries a little earlier -- if anything; but that is a matter of taste with which we have no right to interfere. We are a little more concerned in another proposition advanced at the meeting in question. It seems that one of the bondholders -- a Mr. CHAMBERLAIN -- has just been advised by one of Her Majesty's Counsel, learned in the law, that the "Federal Government" is liable for the whole Confederate debt! "morally and internationally liable!" The London Star, commenting on the proceedings of the meeting generally, says:

abstract: Two thousand two hundred inhabitants of Schleswig arrived at Copenhagen on the 2d of September. abstract: DROWNED WHILE FISHING. -- Yesterday afternoon, while several boys were fishing in Newtown Creek, near Penny Bridge, one of them, about 14 years of age, fell into the creek and was drowned, his companions being unable to rescue him. The body, however, was recovered last evening. The name of the boy could not be ascertained last night.

abstract: We have Cape news to July 28. The Basuto war was proceeding with great vigor, and the whole course of affairs up to then, was strongly in favor of the Free State Vechtkop. The stronghold of the Busheli and Basute chiefs had been captured, 60 Basutos were killed and 400 to 500 sheep, 425 cattle, and 150 horses captured. Mogata Town, another Basuto stronghold, had also been taken and about 1,000 huts burnt. The county of Molihami has been seized, and proclaimed a Free State territory.

lead_paragraph: Complaint having been made recently, by emigrants who had been charged from $3 to $5 a day or the wretched board which is given by the emigrant boarding-house-keepers in Greenwich and Washington streets, below Cortlandt, Capt. BRACKETT has resolved, Mayor GUNTHER assenting, to compell these publicans to comply with the provisions of the law, first in taking out license, and secondly in conspicuously posting their rates in their respective houses, printed in five spoken languages. Capt. BRACKETT will notify these offenders to-day, and give them one week's grace, after which time he will enforce the law and strive to collect $50 fine from every delinquent.

lead_paragraph: -- The State of Louisiana had, before the war, an endowed collegiate institution, under the style and title of the State Seminary of Learning and Military Academy of Louisiana, located near Alexandria, on Red River. It owes its origin to neither State nor individuals, but to the liberality of the General Government, as its often quoted inscription testified; and it is the very institution of which Major-Gen. W.T. SHERMAN was the first Superintendent.

abstract: The members of Mr. MARETZEK's company are beginning to congregate in force. The new artists have arrived, and the greatest activity prevails in the vicinity of Fourteenth-street. It will be possible to acknowledge that one is in town after Monday next. The fashionable season opens with the Academy and the millinery stores on that day. The effect, indeed, on the fancy goods trade by this institution can hardly be exaggerated. There is scarcely a store in Broadway that is not directly benefited by the existence of Italian opera, and amongst these people all is bustle and preparation. From the vendor of bouquets to the importer of Cashmere shawls, every one is on the alert. So essential is the opera to a large class of tradesmen -- that class which supplies the elegancies of life -- that we have often wondered they did not amongst themselves subscribe for another opera-house just to keep the ball moving in the dull periods of the year.

The effect, indeed, on the fancy goods trade by this institution can hardly be exaggerated. There is scarcely a store in Broadway that is not directly benefited by the existence of Italian opera, and amongst these people all is bustle and preparation. From the vendor of bouquets to the importer of Cashmere shawls, every one is on the alert. So essential is the opera to a large class of tradesmen -- that class which supplies the elegancies of life -- that we have often wondered they did not amongst themselves subscribe for another opera-house just to keep the ball moving in the dull periods of the year.

abstract: Brooklyn Navy-Yard; Wages Question in
snippet: Brooklyn Navy-Yard; Wages Question in
lead_paragraph: For several days past the atmosphere at the Brooklyn Navy-yard has been very hazy, trouble has been brewing, and at last it has come to a head. As is well known, the government has need at all times of a great many mechanics; experience has demonstrated the fact that it is better to have good men to whom the highest wages are paid, than classes of men who can be compensated by a sliding scale of rates. Consequently some time since an act was passed by Congress making it incumbent on commandants of yards to employ none but first-rate hands, to whom such wages should be paid as were the current compensation to men of like occupation in the immediate vicinity.

abstract: Community of Action among; Example of in Reconstruction Followed by Other States
snippet: Community of Action among; Example of in Reconstruction Followed by Other States
lead_paragraph: We have news to-day, by way of New-Orleans, from the Alabama State Convention. The resolutions introduced before that body and partially acted on, indicate the determination of Alabama, to follow in spirit, if also exactly to the letter, the resolutions affirmed in the Mississippi Convention. This involves the repeal of the ordinance of secession, and all the State ordinances consequent upon the same; the full recognition of the abolishment of slavery; the provision by law for the protection of the persons and property of the freedmen of the State, and the appointment of an early day in October for holding a general election of State and Congressional representatives. Although minority reports have been presented on the various resolutions offered to the convention, there is no doubt from the partial action thus far reported that, in all its essential features, the new State Constitution of Alabama will be the counterpart of that adopted last month by Mississippi.

abstract: Anderson, Capt., of the Villafranca; Case of
snippet: Anderson, Capt., of the Villafranca; Case of
lead_paragraph: An examination was commenced yesterday morning before Commissioner OSBORN in the case of Capt. Anderson of the ship Villafranca, charged with cruelty toward his passengers on the voyage from London to this port. Numerous passengers, of whom many were emigrants, were in attendance as witnesses for the prosecution. The case was conducted on the part of the Government by Joseph Bell, Esq., and on that of the defendants by Erastus Benedict, Esq.

abstract: Atlantic and Pacific Steamship Companies Amalgamated
snippet: Atlantic and Pacific Steamship Companies Amalgamated
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, at 2 o'clock,the Atlantic Mail Steamship Company was consolidated with the Pacific Mail Steamship Company, the latter paying $4,500,000 for the ships and appurtenances of the former. This consolidation forms the largest steamship company on this continent, and is destined to wield a most powerful influence on our commercial relations with the world.

abstract: West Indian, with rather a dark complexion, was attacked near the corner of Plymouth and Jay streets, on Sunday evening, by some Irish women, who mistook him for a negro. Mr. WILLIAMS, who is a sailor, was in company with the lady with whom he boards, at No. 343 Water-street, New-York, and her two children. He escaped from the infuriated women, who thought he was abducting white children, but was protected by Sergt. CROWE, of the Forty-second Precinct Police, who conducted him to the ferry, and he returned home safety.

abstract: CELEBRATION OF THE BIRTHDAY OF FATHER MATTHEW. The forthcoming anniversary of the birth of the great Apostle of Temperance, Rev. THEOBALD MATTHEW, will be duly celebrated by the Father Matthew Total Abstinence Societies on the 10th of October, by a grand procession. Mr. O'CONNELL, a representative from No. 4 Society, has been chosen Grand Marshal.
lead_paragraph: CELEBRATION OF THE BIRTHDAY OF FATHER MATTHEW. -- The forthcoming anniversary of the birth of the great Apostle of Temperance, Rev. THEOBALD MATTHEW, will be duly celebrated by the Father Matthew Total Abstinence Societies on the 10th of October, by a grand procession. Mr. O'CONNELL, a representative from No. 4 Society, has been chosen Grand Marshal. The societies will assemble and form line on East Broadway, thence proceed through Chatham-street to the east gate of the Park, to Broadway, passing in review before His Honor the Mayor, thence to Fourteenth-street, to Eighth-avenue, to Thirty-eighth-street, to Madison-avenue, where the procession will be reviewed by His Grace Archbishop MCCLOSKY, branching to Third-avenue, and marching thence to the Washington statue in Union-square, and be dismissed. In the evening, several of the associations will give balls and lectures in honor of the event.

abstract: At about 7 o'clock yesterday morning, Mr. JOHN GOODRIDGE, of No. 32 Henry-street, found the body of an unknown man floating in the dock at Pier No. 84 East River. He immediately secured the body and notified an officer and later in the day ...
lead_paragraph: At about 7 o'clock yesterday morning, Mr. JOHN GOODRIDGE, of No. 32 Henry-street, found the body of an unknown man floating in the dock at Pier No. 84 East River. He immediately secured the body and notified an officer, and later in the day Coroner GOVER held an inquest over the remains. Drs. JOHN BEACH and CHRISTOPHER WELJIE, having made a post-mortem examination of the body, and found a punctured triangular wound penetrating the scalp, and clots of blood on the surface of the brain under the spot where external marks of violence were visible, rendered their opinion that the unknown died of violence, and the jury found that "the deceased came to his death by violence at the hands of some person or persons unknown." The body is that of a stout man of about 40, attired in a light brown linen coat, white shirt, soldier's blue pantaloons, and Wellington boots. It had been about two days in the water.

lead_paragraph: The managers, exhibitors and subordinates on duty at the Fair of the American Institute are a very show set of geniuses. abstract: The Independence Belge is responsible for the following story: "The events which we are about to relate occurred in a Belgian village near the frontier of France. The hero is a farmer of considerable property, who has been a widower for some years past. Since the death of his wife this farmer, whom we will name M.X., has addicted himself to drinking, and on the evening of the 13th August he returned home in a state of intoxication. On the following day, the morning was already far advanced, and M.X. had not appeared. One of his sons went to the door of his room and knocked, but received no answer. Entering, he saw his father apparently asleep, but found all efforts to awake him fruitless -- M.X. gave no sign of life. Terrified by this, the young man called in his family, a doctor is brought, and all sorts of pains are taken to recover him. He is, however, to all appearance, dead. At the moment of signing the certificate for his burial the doctor hesitates. Certain signs makes him doubt whether his patient is really dead. For forty-eight hours he never quits the bedside of the farmer whom he strives to reanimate, even calling in the help of another physician. They try everything which can be thought of, but all is useless, and the funeral is ordered. M.X. was generally respected, and the neighbors wish to show their kind feeling toward the children -- hence all the village is on foot to carry him to his last home. His orphan children fellow the coffin with sobs and tears. Chief among the mourners in the eldest daughter of the deceased, a young girl of eighteen, who suffers under a heavy affliction -- she is dumb. The sad ceremony goes on until suddenly -- just at the moment when the coffin is about to be lowered into the grave -- a noise is heard, which undoubtedly proceeds from the coffin. The frightened undertakers fled, but the courageous doctor rushes forward, and with the help of some of the bystanders wrenches off the lid, when forth steps M.X. alive and well. At this moment the dumb daughter's emotion is so great that the infirmity which had held her for the last ten years disappears, and with filial love she exclaims, 'Mon pere!' and faints away. This story is related as having been reported by an eye-witness, who is only prevented from giving the names of the persons by reasons of convenance."

abstract: Trade, during the week, has been moderately active. With an unusually light stock of Eastern goods, and the non-arrival of two or three ships over-due, prices of leading staples tend upward. Oils, candles, provisions, case goods, starch, soap, coffee and chemicals have advanced; but the higher prices and unsettled condition of affairs in the East checks speculation.

abstract: Wages Difficulty in
snippet: Wages Difficulty in
lead_paragraph: The mechanics employed at the Brooklyn Navy-yard are in trouble. On the 14th of the month they were notified that their wages were to be reduced -- the caulkers $1 her diem, the sparmakers half a dollar -- the reduction to date from the 1st of the month. Quite naturally, they objected to this march of economy, and while they did not desire us being considered on a strike, they ceased work, and drew up a set of grievances, for the perusal of the Admiral in charge and the information of the Secretary at Washington.

abstract: The expose in another column of the names of subscribers to the British cotton loan in the aid of the late rebellion is curious and instructive. By looking at the sums opposite the names of certain leading members of Parliament, one can almost mark down the percentage of manifested ill-will toward the North, for which these now doleful subscribers are responsible. LINDSAY, LAIRD, SPENCE and GREGORY [???]e names,' in and out of Parliament, not soon to be forgotten. Our namesake, the [???]i-disant Thunderer -- the London Times -- makes a s[???]rry show. Of course, we cannot suppose that consistent, conscientious, high-toned and severely moral journal to have been pecuniarily influenced; and so we merely note that the subscription of £15,000 by Mr. SAMPSON, the money editor, and £10,000 by Mr. [???] ELANE, the managing editor of the Times, are only pledges of confidence in the justice of the Southern cause. In connection with this matter we have an important letter from Secretary SEWARD to Minister ADAMS, in general terms setting forth that the United States has never [???]d never will assume any of the debts contracted by the rebels. It seems that some Vice Chancellor in England has been ruking, in a suit in which the United States was a party, that we are bound to assume and pay the rebel Cotton loan. Mr. SEWARD has directed Mr. ADAMS to repudiate this decision, and, if necessary, to bring the matter to the notice of Earl RUSSELL. The whole matter assumes a high degree of interest, and further developments will be anxiously looked for.

abstract: At Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, before Justice DODGE, Mr. NATHANIEL B. WILSON, Solicitor for the Navy Department, was examined in relation to the allegation of Mr. DAVID M. PORTER, that for $25,000 he could secure MR. WILSON influence, and through such influence, obtain the unconditional release of Mr. HENRY D. STOVER from Fort Lafayette. Mr. PORTER being M. STOVER'S counsel...
lead_paragraph: At Jefferson Market Police Court, yesterday, before Justice DODGE, Mr. NATHANIEL B. WILSON, Solicitor for the Navy Department, was examined in relation to the allegation of Mr. DAVID M. PORTER, that for $25,000 he could secure MR. WILSON influence, and through such influence, obtain the unconditional release of Mr. HENRY D. STOVER from Fort Lafayette. Mr. PORTER being M. STOVER's counsel at the time, Mr. STOVES placed confidence in him, and gave him a part of the required $25,000; but he now alleges that PORTER defrauded him. The case has again been postponed, and is to be resumed at 10 o'clock on Monday morning next.

abstract: New-York Officers in the Navy; Material of War Furnished by
snippet: New-York Officers in the Navy; Material of War Furnished by
lead_paragraph: The Empire State can boast of a glorious record of her participation in the war which now happily exists only as a matter of history, and upon which we look back as a long and horrid dream. None more prompt than she to rush to the rescue of the Union, and none more prodigal in her proffers of men and money; and at all times the General Government had full reliance in her for loyalty and strength. We do not think we overrate her value, her strength and power among her loyal sister States, when we say that but for her devotion to the common cause, the termination of the struggle would have been far different in its every aspect. It is not, however, our purpose at the present writing to go into all the details of what the State of New-York has done since 1861, but to confine our pen more particularly to what she has done for the navy of the United States, both in men, ships and guns. The following tables will give in a condensed form the amount.

abstract: Storer-Porter Case. Solicitor Wilson Examined
snippet: Storer-Porter Case. Solicitor Wilson Examined
lead_paragraph: Solicitor for the Navy Department, was given yesterday, in the private examination chamber at Jofferson Market Police Court, before Justice DODGE, the examination being conducted by Mr. JOHN GRAHAM, counsel for Mr. PORTER. In this case Mr. HENRY D. STOVER seeks to show that while he was incarcerated in Fort Lafayette, his counsel, Mr. DAVID M. PORTER, defrauded him of $25,000 by pretending that for that sum he could secure his release. The testimony of Mr. WILSON was substantially as follows: I reside in Washington; was Assistant District-Attorney from Feb. 1, 1864; am acquainted with David M. Porter; never authorized him to receive any money from Mr. Stover; lived eight years in Washington; was appointed special counsel to the Navy Department by the Secretary of the Navy; saw Mr. Stover for the first time on the 6th of July; cannot say of how many charges Mr. Stover was found guilty; I saw the charges about four months since; Mr. Stover never tried to retain me as his counsel, but his friends did; the first I knew of my name being in the case was in Washington; I went to Stover, and asked the reason why my name was used; did not know whether the government intended to make additional charges; have been books and am making an examination; am thinking of preferring charges, but am not satisfied about Stover's guilt; never told Mr. Porter that charges would be preferred; tried several cases; had my suspicions aroused; suspected all the Navy Agents were acting improperly; also knew that Mr. Stover was the largest contractor; was informed Stover and Henderson were immediately connected; did not think that any open bribes were given. The witness denied that any money or presents, given either directly or indirectly, would have been acceptable as a compensation for what he might have done to procure the release of STOVER, and he d d not receive any compensation from Mr. PORTER. A report was made by witnesses to the Secretary of the Navy as to the case of STOVER, and he (witness) supposed that a note had been sent to Gen. DIX, and in that way he thought the release of STOVER had been effected; did not know of any other agency that had been employed.

abstract: An order was issued by Collector KING, to take effect yesterday, relating to goods sent to public stores and appraised. The practice has hitherto been for the appraisers, after doing their work, to forward the invoices to the Custom-house and Naval Office, where...
lead_paragraph: An order was issued by Collector KING, to take effect yesterday, relating to goods sent to public stores and appraised. The practice has hitherto been for the appraisers, after doing their work, to forward the invoices to the Custom-house and Naval Office, where they were checked at various desks and were then returned to the Appraisers' stores. This caused a delay after the appraisal had been made of from three to ten days, before the importer could gain possession of the goods.

abstract: Music is often but a question of sentiment. A soldier hears sweet strains in the shriek of a bullet, or in the sullen roar of a blazing shell; a sailor finds harmony in the scream of the hurricane, a hunter in the growl of a tiger, a broker in the chink of his coin. But the music most agreeably welcomed yesterday was the wild whistling of the Autumn wind, and the sharp tink of the first drops of equinoctial rain. Looking (rather late in the morning, we confess,) from our skyey balcony, we saw the heavy-leafed ailanthus wrangling with the wild wind, and tossing its green arms in vain contest with the enemy. Heavy masses of pewter-colored clouds wore seemingly settling on the steeple-tops, and a steel-gray color of the invisible atmosphere gave token that at last Summer had departed, (for the present.) The day justified the morning. Gauze-clad citizens were glad to hurry home and drag forth what the moths had left of last season's woolens, and came from dinner wrapped like Esquimaux mummies in a seven-fold shield of warm cloth. Ere night the sullen clouds began to weep, and their cold tears bedewed the dry earth with sorrow for the death of Summer. Night came early, for none could guess the hour of sunset in such a mist of vapors; and then a high, boisterous, purposeless breeze, a wind with no special origin and no particular direction, went wandering and wailing through the dank streets, searching out the exposed points of mortal life, and sending the sharp sting of Winter to victims illy prepared for the frigid monarch's rule. To myriads who have gasped through the late terribly hot season, this sudden change is most grateful; but there are too many who shrink with apprehension at the first breath of the Prost King, and who, in those days of exaggerated prices, look in almost hopeless dismay upon the advent of Winter. Yet there are worn days in store. The traditional equinoctial storm will soon do its utmost; then will come the fair, hazy skies; the long, dreamy days; the genial, warm and mellow evenings, and the voluptuous nights of the glorious Indian Summer; then will the solemn woods put on the lively of decay, and glow like a son of shipwrecked [???] in the magnificient colors peculiar to our country, and the fiery coronels of the maple and the beech, the multi-shaded browns of the oak, and the everlasting green of the pine and the spruce will mingle in that gorgeous picture which annually astonishes and defies the magic of art -- then, indeed, will be Autumn.

abstract: ATTEMPTED WIFE-MURDER -- JEALOUSY THE CAUSE. -- Between 9 and 10 o'clock on Sunday night, as Mrs. ELLEN CURLEY, residing at No. 157 North First-street, E.D., arrived in front of her residence in company with an acquaintance named PETER FARRELL, from a visit to a relative at the corner of Scholes and Lorimer streets, her husband, who had been following them, stealthily came behind her and plunged a knife several times into her back, holding her by the hair, it is stated, with his left hand. The escort of the woman abandoned her at the first demonstration of her assassin husband, and ingloriously ran away, leaving the unfortunate woman to her fate. The husband, thinking, probably, that his bloody work was finished, walked leisurely away to the Forty-sixth Precinct Station-house, and gave himself up to the police. His victim lay on the sidewalk for some time, wel[???]ering in her blood, but was finally removed to her apartments and attended by Dr. DE LONG, who dressed her wounds. She is now in a low condition, in consequence of loss of blood, but the wounds are not necessarily mortal. It seems that Mr. and Mrs. CURLEY were mar[???]ed [???] four years ago, and in the second year of their wedded life much unhappiness r[???] between them, caused principally by the intemperate habits of the [???], and a separation was [???] consequence, the w[???] [???]ing to her parents in Bushwich-avenue. After this, however, they came t live together again, but only for a short time, when another separation was agreed upon, Mrs. CURLEY resolving to support herself by means of her needle. The injured woman is about 22 years of age, and her husband only 24. The excuse he gives for his conduct is, that his wife and FARRELL have been intimate for two years, and that he has been watching them. Mrs. CURLEY states that this is the second time he attempted her life, having laid her forehead open with a knife about nine months since, when she was residing in Smith-street. The prisoner will have a hearing as soon as his victim becomes able to appear before a magistrate.

Mrs. CURLEY states that this is the second time he attempted her life, having laid her forehead open with a knife about nine months since, when she was residing in Smith-street. The prisoner will have a hearing as soon as his victim becomes able to appear before a magistrate.

abstract: Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, flames burst from a window in Messrs. COE  LAWRENCE'S United States Bonded Warehouse on Cherry, Water and East streets, near Grand. The building was one of the largest in the city, having a frontage of two hundred and forty feet on Cherry-street, and about one hundred feet frontage on the river side.
lead_paragraph: Between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, flames burst from a window in Messrs. COE & LAWRENCE's United States Bonded Warehouse on Cherry, Water and East streets, near Grand. The building was one of the largest in the city, having a frontage of two hundred and forty feet on Cherry-street, and about one hundred feet frontage on the river side. A fierce northerly gale prevailed at the time, rapidly sweeping the flames through the building, which was filled with cotton, sugar, hemp, saltpetre, rosin, linseed oil, and a great variety of other merchandise on storage. Fortunately, the wind was "off shore," else the destruction of property must have been enormous. So rapidly did the flames leap from story to story, that 15 minutes subsequent to the discovery the entire edifice was a mass of fire, and before the fireman had limbered their hose the roof and walls of COE's warehouse had fallen, and there was evidence that the adjoining five-story warehouses, which are designated as No. 750 and A, B, C, and D Water-street, and which were occupied by Mr. WILLIAM LAWRENCE, must also fall. Half-an-hour subsequently these five stores were a vast sheet of flame, presenting one of the wildest of imaginable scenes. Fears being entertained that the Judd Oil Works and other establishments in Cherry and neighboring streets must be consumed, and it being manifest that the burning warehouses could not be saved, the firemen bent their energies to the work of confining the fire; and in this they were, happily, successful until about 4 o'clock, when the fire again threatened surrounding property, and Chief-Engineer KINGSLAND sent a telegram for steamer Metropolitan, No. 1, and other down-town fire machinery. These soon reached the spot and went to work with efficiency; but even with all the steam power thus added, the firemen were unable to keep the flames under, and at about 10 o'clock last night the piers on East-street took fire, driving the Fire Department off. A telegram was promptly sent for Harbor Police-boat No. 1, but as she is lying up for repairs, Chief KINGSLAND was compelled to press several ferry-boats into service. The fire was burning in an immense mass of cotton, hemp and resin, at our hour of going to press, and the eastern heavens were illuminated.

abstract: Brace, C. L.; Changes in England in Few Years
snippet: Brace, C. L.; Changes in England in Few Years
lead_paragraph: To a traveler who has not seen England for ten years, it is very plain that great changes have been going on in the nation. The "middle class," almost unconsciously to itself, has been rising continually in power. The manufacturers and merchants have accumulated immense fortunes, many of which have been at once invested in land, thus creating a new kind of land-holding class. The nobility have often been only too glad to connect themselves with these wealthy commoners. But the great changes have arisen from the intense mental activity and unbounded energy of the middle class. In all departments the purely intellectual, the scientific, the reformatory, the works of organization and industry, and the immense range of their financial enterprises, one sees the fruits of this powerful body. And they are growing conscious of their strength. For the first time in associating with Englishmen, have I seen in this visit no toadyism. No commoner had happened on a single occasion to speak incidentally of his friendship or acquaintance with Lord this or Duke that in any different tone from what he would use if speaking of Mr. Smith or Mr. Brown. I see that the middle class circles are often sufficient of themselves, with less social struggling for an intimacy with the aristocracy than used to be the fact.

abstract: Institute Fair
snippet: Institute Fair
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday last the American Institute opened the doors of the old Palace Gardens on Fourteenth-street, and invited the people to an exhibition of American industry. The war being finished, peace has resumed its leadership as of old, directing the onward march of art and science and homelier effort in industrial pursuits, some of the grand results of which are brought before the people only at such times and by such fairs as this. A gallant soldier of the republic inaugurated the exhibition in an eloquent address, fitly complimenting the vigor and brain of the men whose strength and will had been so largely instrumental in bringing the nation through its peril, and then happily urged an immediate return to the channels of olden pursuit and success. A great crowd attended, and for its information and delectation were provided at every point evidences of the skill and handiwork of the people. In one room are clean cut models for ships; in another engines as conspicuous for capacity and power as for simplicity of construction and cheapness; beyond are pianos and other instruments of melody; around the walls hang specimens of photography, the equal of which the world is defied to bring, while countless inventions for the saving of labor and the advancement of our national interests crowd the rooms.

abstract: -- The Fall term of the College opened on Thursday morning. The classes have got well started. The freshmen are getting settled and ready for the time of their persecution, which occurs soon after electioneering is over, and everything appears in a prosperous condition. The Law School is to receive a series of capital lectures this term, BENJAMIN V. ABBOTT, Esq., is now giving a very interesting course, on the subject of "Conveyancing." If the plan at present adopted is continued, the school cannot fall to become the first in the country. -- New-Haven Chronicle.

abstract: "HAUNTED CHURCH" EXCITEMENT. -- The announcement of hideous and unaccountable noises, said to have been heard for a few nights past in one of the up-town places of worship in Jersey City, and which has caused a story to be circulated that the church is haunted, has occasioned considerable excitement not only in Jersey City, but elsewhere. On Sunday night hundreds of men, women and children congregated in the vicinity of the up-town churches, intent upon satisfying a morbid curiosity. About forty persons came over from Hoboken, -- among them a self-constituted committee of church members -- to investigate the mystery. There were also persons present from New-York and other localities, who listened to all sorts of stories told by the knowing ones, and they went away no wiser than they came. A mob of about 200 persons assembled in front of Grace Church, in Erie-street, corner of South Seventh, while services were in progress, and caused much annoyance to the worshippers. Under the fear that a demonstration would be made upon the building, Chief of Police MCMANUS was applied to and dispatched a posse of police, who dispersed the assemblage. The German Catholic Church in South Eighth-street, and the Third Reformed Dutch Church at Hamilton-square, were also surrounded until a late hour, but the parties eventually departed without having their curiosity satisfied. One explanation of the hideous sounds is, that some miserable our has found means of ingress under the flooring of the St. Boniface Church, and there betakes himself at nights, where he devotes a portion of the time in yelping and dismal howls. An old, well-known butcher in the avenue, locates the "ghosts" at Father SENEZ' church, in South Eighth-street, inasmuch as his daughter was out in search of the haunted church, the other night, and relates that in passing the last-named edifice, she saw a ghost or spook standing on the steeple, waving its hand over the spire, and presently the mysterious figure hurled a Belgian paving-stone directly down in front of her face, but, fortunately, not hitting her. Probably the young woman was too much excited at her narrow escape to have thought about securing possession of the Belgian paving-stone, and it is thought that at the time of telling this story the old butcher was troubled with spirits of bourbon in the head.

abstract: United States vs. Tobias E. Echart. -- The defendant in this case was brought before the commissioner charged with having in his possession, withintent to pass the same, $500 in counterfeit Treasury notes. The accused was arrested by a detective of the Treasury Department on a vessel at the foot of Barclay-street, and on being searched the above amount was found, all in counterfeit $1 notes. The examination did not show that there was any intent to pass the bills. The prisoner was held for further examination.

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENT IN A FOUNDRY. Two men named JOHN FRANER and PATRICK MCDONOUGH, employed in ESSLER  Co.'s foundry, foot of Dikemanstreet, South Brooklyn, met with a fatal accident on Monday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: FATAL ACCIDENT IN A FOUNDRY. -- Two men named JOHN FRANER and PATRICK MCDONOUGH, employed in ESSLER & CO.'s foundry, foot of Dikeman-street, South Brooklyn, met with a fatal accident on Monday afternoon. They were, it appears, preparing to cast a bed-plate for a steamship, of about five hundred pounds weight. They carried the molten substance in ladles, the whole weighing some two hundred pounds. While passing along a scaffolding, the plank broke, and the men fell a distance of about five feet. The melted iron fell upon them, and they were so dreadfully injured that they died yesterday. Coroner BARRETT held an inquest on FRANER, and the inquest on the other will be held to-day. Both men leave families.

abstract: European Ambition
snippet: European Ambition
lead_paragraph: EUROPEAN AMBITION. -- Two or three of the Powers of Europe seem to desire exclusive control of the work of governing the entire human family. Besides her vast and populous colonial possessions in different parts of the world, from Australia to Canada, England governs nearly one-fifth of mankind in the East Indies. France has lately extended her power, in Mexico on the one hand and in Cochin China on the other; and there are both British and French statesmen and political writers who are strongly in favor of the extension of the Franco-English or Anglo-French rule over China proper. Russia is forever extending her territories and enlarging the populations under her sway, and is actively intriguing both in Turkey and Persia. The other two of the great European Powers, Austria and Prussia, have no especial aspirations outside of Europe.

abstract: A delegation of sixteen gentlemen, comprising a portion of the Aldermen and city officials of the City of Chicago, arrived in this city yesterday, most of whom are stopping at the St. Nicholas Hotel, which will be their headquarters during their stay. They will remain here until the first of next week, and then proceed to Boston, and from thence to Philadelphia, Baltimore, Washington City and Pittsburgh, arriving home in about a fortnight. They have already visited Detroit, and Toronto, Canada. Aldermen Vance and James, of the latter place, joined the delegation, and will accompany them throughout the remainder of their journeyings. Alderman Peter Shimp, proprietor of the Real Estate Bulletin, at Chicago, is chairman of the committee. The object of the delegation in visiting our Eastern cities is to inspect the modus operandi, &c., of the public and charitable institutions, in order to recommend on their return home such measures for like purposes as their experience will instruct them.

abstract: MAXIMILIAN AND JUAREZ. -- Neither the Emperor of Mexico, MAXIMILIAN, nor the President of Mexico, BENITO JUAREZ, are having very pleasant times. The Emperor is floundering in all sorts of difficulties -- frightful financial difficulties, fearful ecclesiastical difficulties, dreadful military difficulties. There is no end to the young man's troubles; and they so harass his mind, and embarrass his motions, that it is no wonder he is disgusted with his empire, his subjects, and his French masters. The lot of President JUAREZ also has been hard enough since the Austrian adventurer and the French soldiery landed in Mexico. He has been driven from one position to another, from Central to Northern Mexico, from Chihuahua to El Paso del Norte, from which latter point he can at quick notice step into our territory. Through all his own misfortunes and those of his country, President JUAREZ has borne himself most heroically and honorably. He had demonstrated his ability before the foreign invasion, and had proven himself to be one of the few Chief Magistrates of Mexico who combined in himself elements of character that might have enabled him to become the regenerator and saviour of his unhappy country.

abstract: The Algonguin and Winooski are ready in the engine department for trial, but the wheels were not quite prepared yesterday to begin work. They have been altered so that the dip of the wheels will be about twenty-four inches, the paddle-floats being seven inches on the face. The Winooski has one iron float on each wheel, while the Algonquin has two on one and three on the other.
lead_paragraph: The Algonguin and Winooski are ready in the engine department for trial, but the wheels were not quite prepared yesterday to begin work. They have been altered so that the dip of the wheels will be about twenty-four inches, the paddle-floats being seven inches on the face. The Winooski has one iron float on each wheel, while the Algonquin has two on one and three on the other. These are put on to aid the engines over the "centre." Since the workmen began to overhaul the Algonquin they have built a bulkhead abaft and closing in the fire-room, and from the blower now runs a flume through which is driven a strong current of air which passes under the furnaces, acting as a direct blower to the fires. It was the intention when our reporter left the dock yesterday afternoon for the Winooski to fire up during the night and run the engine for the purpose of testing some point unknown to him. Mr. DICKERSON does not state when he will be ready. Report says that he has again protested.
