abstract: South-st., Amer. Rice Mills
snippet: South-st., Amer. Rice Mills
lead_paragraph: Just at midnight last night Mr. THOMAS MCGRATH, of No. 111 South-street, discovered smoke issuing from a window in the third story of the American Rice Mills, at No. 156 South-street. He immediately gave the alarm, and the firemen were promptly brought out; but before they reached the spot the flames had burst from the third, fourth and fifth story windows, and it was clear that the entire structure must be consumed.

abstract: New-Jersey; "Owl Train" Thrown off Track
snippet: New-Jersey; "Owl Train" Thrown off Track
lead_paragraph: JERSEY CITY COMMON COUNCIL. -- A regular meeting of the Jersey City Common Council was held at the City Hall last evening, all the members being present but one. A communication was received from the Morris Canal Company, remonstrating against the opening of Hudson-street from Bergen-street to the Central Railroad depot, situated in the cove 1,700 feet from the shore. The communication sets forth that the contemplated improvement must not only involve a large outlay, but would be impracticable from the fact that a drawbridge would have to be constructed, and that it would necessarily have to be open the greater portion of the time to allow boats to pass out and in. The communication was referred to the Committee on Streets.

abstract: It has long been a matter of discredit to Americans, that having the largest variety and the finest quality of steel-making materials in the world, they have been and still are, to a great extent, dependent for this most useful alloy, upon the furnaces of Sheffield and of Essen. The general adaptedness and the enormous use of steel, are very little understood by the public at large, or in America, by that portion of the public most immediately interested. The popular idea of steel is a hard, brittle substance, produced in small masses, and useful only for cutting instruments. It is, therefore, not less surprising than gratifying to observe in the present fair of the American Institute, steel masses of a ton weight, and rails and axles, steamship machinery and boiler plates forged and rolled directly from ingots of cast-steel. This is the first exhibition of the kind ever seen in the United States, and the first exhibition of American steel of this quality ever made. An inspection of these specimens also corrects the prevailing notion regarding the nature of the material. Under one treatment, steel is fractured like glass by a blow, but is highly elastic and susceptible of a keen edge. We see the results of another treatment in railway axles, bent double while cold, and railway rails twisted while cold, an entire revolution in two feet length. These are the materials that are to solve the problem of railway safety no less than the problem of railway economy.

abstract: Peto, Sir Morton, and Party; Excursion; Faith in our Stability
snippet: Peto, Sir Morton, and Party; Excursion; Faith in our Stability
lead_paragraph: Sir MORTON PETO, Mr. KINNAIRD and their distinguished companions, of whose movements in the West we have a special account to-day, may honestly congratulate themselves when they compare their investments on this side of the Atlantic with those of the melancholy lierd of "sympathizers" in London who are the holders of the rebel cotton loan. It deserves to be remembered to the honor and sagacity of these railway princes, that it was during the very stormiest period of the late conflict that the bulk of the money for the building of the Atlantic and Great Western Road was raised under their auspices in England. It is true that nearly every other industry at the North, as well as that of building railroads, was maintained in a state of activity during all the years of war. It is true that the energy and spirit of our commercial and manufacturing class at no period -- even the darkest of the struggle -- failed them. But it is none the less to the credit of men like Sir MORTON PETO and Mr. KINNARD that, as foreign capitalists and non-residents, they saw throughout the whole of our conflict sufficient reason, amid evil and good reports, to trust in the stability of our institutions, in the financial honor of our business public, and in the permanent and uninterrupted material and social progress of the country. The organs of public sentiment most trusted by the British people -- especially those organs which best reflected the opinions of the financial world of Europe -- were all devoted to daily illustrations of the rapidity and certainty of our downfall as an independent nation. Our credit was assailed in the daily issues of the "leading journal" of Europe as the credit of no other nation had ever before been assailed. Universal bankruptcy, from one end of the United States to the other, was predicted for us with a confidence and assurance which men were not permitted to gainsay. Our "securities" served to give point and pungency to the sneers of the Anglo-Confederate oracles, and were a standing joke at every commercial resort where the SAMPSONS and the SPENCES were accepted as authority. Germany and her small capitalists were held up to the derision of the English world as the credulous dupes of United States borrowing agents. And it was made a special reproach against the late RICHARD COBDEN in the leading columns of the London Times, that he was righteously a victim, financially, to his trust in American stocks.

abstract: Joseph Cassills, grocer, No. 75 Mott-street, was charged with finding the pocket-book of Mary E. Myers on his counter, and abstracting $20 therefrom. Witness said she left her pocket-book on defendant's counter by mistake, after she had made some purchases. She had not been gone over four or five minutes when, recollecting her mistake, she hastened to...
lead_paragraph: Joseph Cassills, grocer, No. 75 Mott-street, was charged with finding the pocket-book of Mary E. Myers on his counter, and abstracting $20 therefrom. Witness said she left her pocket-book on defendant's counter by mistake, after she had made some purchases. She had not been gone over four or five minutes when, recollecting her mistake, she hastened to the store and the pocket-book was gone. The prisoner was asked for it in the presence of two boys, when he denied having it. Upon cross-examination it was found that Cassills denied that it was the pocket-book of witness, as the money she alleged was in it did not correspond with what Cassills saw in it. He asked what was in the pocket-book she left, and the reply was, "Three $10 bills, some Confederate money and some pawn tickets." Cassills then said no such amount of money was in the pocket-book, and it couldn't be hers. James McMahon, one of the boys present at the transaction, said he saw the pocketbook on the counter, and he picked it up and gave it to the defendant, who opened it and took out some stamps and Confederate bills, and complainant came in and asked for her pocket-book. Defendant didn't deny having the pocket-book till she said there was $30 in it, and he said it could not be hers, as there was only $10 in it. He saw Cassills take the money out and count it, and there was only one $10 bill in it, when she insisted that there were three tens.

abstract: About 4:30 o'clock on Saturday afternoon, at Boston, the inflated balloon Star-Spangled Banner suddenly broke through its nettings, and in an instant it was hundreds of feet in the air. When at the height of 1,200 or 1,500 feet, apparently, it seemed to become still for a few seconds, and to remain almost motionless, when suddenly it collapsed, and the fragments came fluttering to the ground. Fortunately, as no car was attached, and no person had ascended with the balloon, no one was injured. The loss is placed at $1,200, exclusive of the gas which escaped.

abstract: ARREST OF THREE SUPPOSED BURGLARS. Between 1 and 2 A.M. yesterday, Officer PETER HUNT, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, observed three suspiciouslooking characters prowling about in the rear of the store of JOHN BALDWIN, No. 241 Grand-street, E.D., and concluding from their conduct that they were up...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF THREE SUPPOSED BURGLARS. -- Between 1 and 2 A.M. yesterday, Officer PETER HUNT, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, observed three suspiciouslooking characters prowling about in the rear of the store of JOHN BALDWIN, No. 241 Grand-street, E.D., and concluding from their conduct that they were up to mischief, he consulted with his side-partner, Officer WALSH, and the three were taken to the station-house. They gave their names as WILLIAM BRADY, JAMES ROBERTSON and HENRY STEPHENS. When searched no burglar's tools were found upon them, but shortly afterward a deck-hand belonging to one of the Division-avenue ferry-boats, went to the station-house with a bundle of skeleton keys, which he found in the boat near where had been previously sitting three men answering the description of those arrested. The prisoners were yesterday taken before Judge DAILEY, who postponed their examination until Thursday next.

abstract: London Times and Rebel Cotton Loan
snippet: London Times and Rebel Cotton Loan
lead_paragraph: On a certain occasion, years ago, the London Times was publicly charged with bribery. It replied in a very powerful leader, that the allegation was an absurdity -- that public confidence was the life of a public journal, and that no man of sense could believe that a newspaper worth its millions would sell its title to public confidence for hundreds or thousands. The answer was accounted good. If wealth lifts an individual above venality, even without the aid of moral principle, there is no reason why it should not have that effect upon a newspaper. The effect, indeed, ought to be all the greater, for a newspaper's business prosperity is peculiarly involved in its good repute.

abstract: The managers of the Ulster County Fair, now being held at Kingston, N.Y., having offered a silver ball as a prize to be contended for by base ball clubs, the Mutual and Active Clubs of this city will contend for the trophy to-morrow afternoon, on the fair grounds.
lead_paragraph: The managers of the Ulster County Fair, now being held at Kingston, N.Y., having offered a silver ball as a prize to be contended for by base ball clubs, the Mutual and Active Clubs of this city will contend for the trophy to-morrow afternoon, on the fair grounds. A first-class game may be expected, as both clubs will take their best men with them. The Actives will introduce HATFIELD for the first time, while the Mutuals will probably play HARRIS in place of THORN. The players and their friends will take the 7:30 train on the Hudson River road to-morrow morning.

abstract: SOLDIERS DRUGGED AND ROBBED. The outlines of a system of atrocious robberies that have recently been perpetrated upon our returning soldiers, are given by Col. GURNSEY, of the Twenty-sixth United States Colored Infantry, as follows: Steamboats are chartered to make excursions in the harbor;...
lead_paragraph: SOLDIERS DRUGGED AND ROBBED. -- The outlines of a system of atrocious robberies that have recently been perpetrated upon our returning soldiers, are given by Col. GURNSEY, of the Twenty-sixth United States Colored Infantry, as follows: Steamboats are chartered to make excursions in the harbor; soldiers who have just been paid off are induced to take passage to the city; when on board they are carried about the harbor and amused, while drugged or stupefying liquors are sold to them, and ruffians sell them spurious jewelry or other worthless articles, and by false representations and sometimes by threats, succeed in robbing them of a large part of their wages. The soldiers are in many cases paid on Hart's Island, from one hundred to four or five hundred dollars each on final settlement, and the gains of the persons who swindle them are proportionally large. There were some very singular occurrences on board the steamboat Massasoil on Monday of last week. Three hundred soldiers of the Twenty-sixth United States Colored Infantry, who embarked at Hart's Island, were not landed, as they desired, but were conveyed to various places in the harbor, were sickened with vile drinks, and thieves operated freely among them. Finally, the commander of the soldiers, Col. GURNSEY, found it necessary to put the Captain of the boat, MCLEAN, under arrest; and, in consequence of this fact, the soldiers were not robbed to the extent, the officers believe, they would otherwise have been. Col. BROWNE, the United States Paymaster, who had paid the colored soldiers $400 each, was on the boat. He had $40,000 government funds in his possession; and information was given to him that some of the ruffians on board were making plans to seize the money. For two hours and a half he held his loaded pistol in his hand, and he was not molested. It was by his advice that Capt. MCLEAN was compelled to place the colored soldiers on shore at Peck-slip. Col. GURNSEY and one of his officers have since been arrected for constructive assault and battery upon the Captain of the boat, and the suit will soon come before the courts. Mr. JACKSON S. SCHULTZ is the bondsman of the officers, and Col. GEORGE BLISS their counsel. The case will come up on Friday morning, before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs.

abstract: The Constitutional Convention of South Carolina met on Wednesday last, delegates from all parts of the State being in attendance. Mr. D.L. WARDLAW was chosen President. Gov. PERRY's message was delivered on Thursday, read and referred to the proper committees. The convention seems to have got readily to work, and yesterday the Governor telegraphed to President JOHNSON that the ordinance of secession had been repealed; that a committee had reported in favor of the entire abolition of slavery; for equalizing representation by population instead of by parishes, as now; for electing Governor and Presidential electors by direct vote of the people, and for viva voce voting in the Legislature. All these measures the Governor assures us will pass. The admission of a delegate irregularly chosen by Northern citizens at Beaufort is noted as a remarkable fact. We print the Governor's message and the first day's proceedings of the convention in other columns.

abstract: On the afternoon of Saturday last, a party of about forty girls from the New-York Juvenile Asylum, at High Bridge, accompanied by the Superintendent and several lady teachers, made an excursion on the Harlem River. The day was delightful; the children full of anticipation, with eyes sparkling with delight...
lead_paragraph: On the afternoon of Saturday last, a party of about forty girls from the New-York Juvenile Asylum, at High Bridge, accompanied by the Superintendent and several lady teachers, made an excursion on the Harlem River. The day was delightful; the children full of anticipation, with eyes sparkling with delight at the beauties and wonders of the way, their sweet voices now and then breaking into song, and many a hearty good wish they won from their fellow-passengers. On nearing the dock at Peck-slip, a benevolent stranger, whose name we did not learn, perhaps remembering the longing of his own childhood, perhaps recalling the winsome pleading of little voices at home, presented $2 to a little fatherless girl, with a request that she would buy fruit for the company.

abstract: Mining Territories, Our
snippet: Mining Territories, Our
lead_paragraph: OUR MINING TERRITORIES. -- We are glad that, now when we have opportunity and spare forces, attention is being turned to making life and industry safe in our outlying territories, such as Arizona. It is perfectly well known that Arizona is rich in silver mines. They were worked by the Spaniards two centuries ago with immense returns, and they have been explored again of late years since the territory came into our possession. But the region has been, and still is, to some extent, dominated by savage Indians. Within the last ten years, the wild Apaches have driven off, very often, parties of American explorers and miners, and large numbers of these adventurous men have lost their lives. But latterly our government has been sending troops there, and posts have now been established at the principal commanding positions in the territory. There are good prospects for the mines and for the miners and settlers of all kinds. Now that the country is so much in need of silver and gold, the industries and interests of our great western territories, where a superabundance of these metals exist, should be well protected by the government.

abstract: PAREPA IN BROOKLYN. -- Last night Mr. BATEMAN's third concert was given at the Academy of Music, before one of the largest and most enthusiastic audiences ever gathered in that exceedingly particular and fastidious city. The programme embraced many of the lady's choicest selections, and as she was in admirable voice and conspicuously jolly mood and temper, she carried the house by storm, and created a furore of enthusiasm, such as the City of Churches has rarely witnessed. The fourth concert will be given on Thursday.

abstract: Ferris Wife Murder, Motion for New Trial
snippet: Ferris Wife Murder, Motion for New Trial
lead_paragraph: Francis Ferris, plaintiff in error, vs. The People of the State of New-York, defendants in error. -- This case was argued at great length yesterday at the General Term, before the above-named Justices. Mr. Wm.H. Anthon represented the prisoner, Ferris, and Mr. A.O. Hall appeared for the people. The facts involved in this case are briefly as follows: At a late hour on the night of Friday, the 9th of September, 1864, Ferris, the prisoner, made an attack on his wife, Rosannah Ferris, at their residence, No. 31 James-street, in this city. The testimony subsequently given all tended to show that the attack was made with an ax; that he struck her several blows on the head, penetrating the skull. The surgeon, who was called in soon after, found that the brains of the unfortunate woman were oozing through the skull, and, owing to the irregular and jagged nature of the orifices, the operator was unable to close the skull until he had cut off large portions of the protruding brain. The wife remained insensible for about two days after the assault, when she expired. On the Coroner's inquest it was shown that both the husband and wife were quarrelsome. Ferris was arrested, indicted, and on the 27th and 28th days of February, and the 1st day of March of the present year, he was tried before Hon. Recorder Hoffman. The jury rendered a verdict of guilty of murder in the first degree, and thereupon the Recorder soon after sentenced him to be hung on the 14th of the ensuing April. This sentence would have been carried into effect on the day specified, but for the fact that prisoner's counsel obtained a stay of proceedings until such time as the matter could be brought before the Supreme Court at General Term on a writ of error, and bill of exceptions to the charge of the magistrate who presided at the trial.

abstract: Registry and Elections, Inspectors of
snippet: Registry and Elections, Inspectors of
lead_paragraph: At the last session of the Legislature a law was passed taking the appointment of Inspectors of Registry and Elections, and Canvassers, out of the hands of the Board of Supervisors and transferring it to the Metropolitan Police Commissioners. At the same time the law was somewhat modified, evidently with the intention of allowing both the leading political parties to be fairly represented, and of obtaining a better class of men to serve as inspectors and canvassers than could be got under the old law. abstract: South-st.,--the losses over $4,000,000
snippet: South-st.,--the losses over $4,000,000
lead_paragraph: The estimates of losses by the disastrous conflagration in Mr. LAWRENCE's warehouses are far higher than those which were published in yesterday morning's TIMES, and it is now thought that the aggregate will exceed $4,000,000. The insurances alone are estimated at $2,200,000, and are distributed among nearly all the insurance offices in the city. The goods on storage belonged to nearly one hundred firms, and consisted of many kinds of merchandise, including cotton, wool, hemp, furs, hides and grain; but there was no saltpetre on storage, as the reporters were incorrectly informed on Monday night. A report was circulated during the earlier stages of the conflagration that a large quantity of combustibles and explosives were on storage in the warehouses, and hearing this, many firemen withdrew; but they subsequently resumed work on being assured that the report was erroneous. One of the buildings was one hundred and fifty feet by two hundred and fifty, and three stories high. The second building was one hundred and fifty feet by two hundred and fifty, and five stories high. These two warehouses were separated by a space of five feet. At the time of the fire the windows of the bonded stores were open, and the flames almost instantly communicated from the free to the bonded stores. Many of the owners had open accounts at these warehouses, and it is not known precisely how much merchandise they had therein at the time of the fire. It will require the labor of two or three accountants a day or two to perfect a list of the owners, losses and insurances. Meantime we publish the following list of insurances as far as they have been ascertained:

abstract: Rebel Loan Holders in England and United States Government
snippet: Rebel Loan Holders in England and United States Government
lead_paragraph: speaking for himself; Mr. SPENCE, Mr. SAMPSON, Dr. DELANE, Lord WHARNCLIFFE, and other holders of the rebel cotton loan, proposes -- as we saw in the report of the late meeting of the London Tavern -- that he and his confederates should prostrate themselves at the feet of President JOHNSON and Mr. SEWARD, and ask that the rebel indebtedness in Great Britain should be assumed by the United States. Very well. But before this is done, will the London Times please to show how all the additional burden of the rebel debt is to be borne by a country which it has so clearly proven to be hopelessly bankrupt? We submit that Mr. GREEN, before flattening himself out in front of the White House, should consult the oracle, and learn what he is actually to gain by that act of self-abasement. Mr. GREEN must remember that Britannia still rules, &c., and that Britons never, never, never, &c.

abstract: EDWARD BAISON was arrested yesterday by Officers HORDELT and MULLEN, of the fourth Precinct, on the complaint of FREDERICK RABITSCHER, of No. 273 Bowery, who alleges that on the 16th instant the accused obtained forty dollars from him on a check on the Continental National bank, alleged to have been drawn by a New-Haven merchant to the order of Messrs. KLETTWIG & CO., of No. 376 Bowery, and indorsed by the latter firm. The complainant subsequently learned that the check was a forgery, and after his arrest, the prisoner acknowledged that he had forged the signatures. Several other persons entered complaints against the accused, alleging that they had been defrauded out of small sums in the same manner. The prisoner is a native of Germany, 34 years of age, and lived at No. 28 Third-street. He pleaded guilty, and Justice LEDWITH committed him, in default of $1,500 bail.

abstract: New-York; Freligh, Janitor of Old Bowery Theatre, fell from roof and killed
snippet: New-York; Freligh, Janitor of Old Bowery Theatre, fell from roof and killed
lead_paragraph: -- An inquest was held yesterday by Coroner COLLIN, at No. 82 Eldridge-street, on the body of ISAAC F. FRELIGH, the janitor at the Old Bowery Theatre, who was killed by accidentally falling from the roof of that building on the top of the Atlantic Garden. Deceased was sitting on the coping of the roof, superintending some repairs which were being executed, and fell backward, falling a distance of fifteen feet. In his descent his bead struck an iron shutter, and he was instantly killed. Deceased was 54 years of age, and a native of New-York. He had held the position of janitor of the Old Bowery Theatre for a number of years.

abstract: Union; Supply Steamer; Officers of
snippet: Union; Supply Steamer; Officers of
lead_paragraph: The Winooski started her fires at 3:30 at o'clock yesterday morning, and at five minutes past 5 o'clock she put her engine in motion, running slowly. At 8 o'clock our reporter visited the ship and found her making eighteen revolutions on thirty pounds of steam, the throttle being three-quarters open and "cutting off" at six-tenths. Mr. ISHERWOOD was on hand early, and expressed his belief that the Winooski would beat the Algonquin a large per centage in the development of power and economy of coal, and in the trial of speed on the Sound, make two or three knots per hour more than her antagonist. A few hours later Mr. DICKERSON expressed himself as much in favor of his vessel as Mr. ISHERWOOD had in favor of his. So both men appear very sanguine of the results.

abstract: Centreville Course Trot. Rogesson's b. c. and Voorhees' b. c.; Fashion Course. First of Fall Purses
snippet: Centreville Course Trot. Rogesson's b. c. and Voorhees' b. c.; Fashion Course. First of Fall Purses
lead_paragraph: The first of the Fashion Course Fall purses comes off at the Fashion Course, Long Island, to-day, viz.: A purse of $1,000, mile heats, best three in five, in harness, for which the dashing chestnut mare Lady Emma, the brown stallion George Wilkes, the golding Dexter, the gray mare Blonde, and the contraband black gelding General Butler, are entered. What the stable selections from the above will be, it is impossible for us at this writing to say; but one thing is certain, viz.: that a most exciting contest will inevitably ensue, and that, perhaps, the previous calculations of the knowing ones of the trotting turf will be set aside in a manner not yet predicated on foregone conclusions. The most affluent arrangements have been made by the manager of the track, in view of the expected concourse of trotting men and the public generally, for full particulars of which we refer our readers to the advertisement which appears in another column. It is beyond a doubt but that the race will be intensely interesting, and the attendance correspondingly large.

abstract: CHARLES WILSON and WILLIAM THOMAS were arrested yesterday, by Officers CROSBY, BROWN and BLACKMAN, on a charge of swindling DANIEL SHEEHAN, a returned soldier, out of $55. The complainant met WILSON at the Hudson River Railroad depot, and the latter asked him to take a drink. SHEEHAN's destination was Lake Champlain, and WILSON said he also was going there, and would be his traveling companion. The men soon became quite intimate, and the soldier was invited to visit a billiard-saloon at the corner of Broadway and Twwenty-ninth-street. After entering the saloon THOMAS presented a bill to WILSON and demanded payment. The latter produced a $500 bill, which THOMAS could not change. SHEEHAN was then appealed to, and WILSON succeeded in borrowing $55 of him. The swindlers then left the saloon, but were subsequently arrested. Justice DODGE committed the accused without bail.
lead_paragraph: CHARLES WILSON and WILLIAM THOMAS were arrested yesterday, by Officers CROSBY, BROWN and BLACKMAN, on a charge of swindling DANIEL SHEEHAN, a returned soldier, out of $55. abstract: Chicago Platform, Party Effrontery of
snippet: Chicago Platform, Party Effrontery of
lead_paragraph: RICHARD BRINSLEY SHERIDAN, picked up from the gutter, and taken before the morning magistrate, was asked his name. "William Wilberforce" was the reply. It is as cool a piece of impudence in the Democratic bummers found in the last rebel ditch, and arraigned before the people, to call themselves the Administration party. As a joke, a specimen of that sort which consist in oddness of contrast, it would have been laughable enough. But these worthies don't in the least mean it as such. They really imagine that they can pass themselves off to the people as ANDREW JOHNSON's special champions.

abstract: London Daily News, Error of on Negro Question
snippet: London Daily News, Error of on Negro Question
lead_paragraph: It will he seen, by a reference to the European news, that our good, steadfast friend, the London Daily News, acting, doubtless, on false reports from this side the Atlantic, has fallen into the serious error of magnifying, to an alarming degree, the dangers arising from the altered relations of capital and labor in the South. That any party here -- counting a bare baker's dozen -- seriously proposes to garrison every county of the South with black regiments, we do not believe; first, because there have been no serious disturbances on the part of the black or the white population of the South since the war closed; and next, because the whole people, North and South, believe in the early reduction of the national army to a point which would make the garrisoning of the South impossible. A few raving fanatics may still shout for subjugation and extermination, as they did all through the war; but they belong to that class which rendered the least service to the nation while the conflict was going on. We regret that so good and so able a journal as the London Daily News should have been led astray on this point, as its services are still needed in the honest cause of disseminating truth respecting this country among the British people.

abstract: The Raleigh Daily Standard of the 16th inst. says: "We are gratified to state that Major-Gen. RUGER has consented, at the request of Gov. HOLDEN, that these persons to whom animals have been leaned by the Quartermaster's Department, for the purpose of getting in their crops, and who are in indigent circumstances and unable to purchase animals, will be permitted to retain them until the first day of November next. Persons, however, who are able to purchase, or who have animals of their own, will be liable to have government animals in their possession called in and sold, whenever such action may be deemed necessary by the department."

abstract: extraordinary commercial and business prosperity at this time, but in Philadelphia, Baltimore and the business centres of the Western States, there is unprecedented activity. Boston, we judge from its papers, has not its proportional share of the new commercial prosperity; but any deficiency in this line is made up by the enormous profits that are accruing to the manufacturing interests of that locality. We believe that in Baltimore and Philadelphia, in Cincinnati, St. Louis, and, indeed, everywhere, business with the South and Southwest is being carried on upon a sound and conservative system -- a large proportion of it cash, and the remainder upon short and safe credits.

abstract: in an Evening journal which circulates some four thousand or five thousand copies daily. The news thus published is then reprinted in the Morning dailies, which circulate some two hundred and fifty thousand copies. The Evening journal naturally presents a complaint, (and has done so every day for twenty odd years,) of the injustice under which it labors. A remedy for this injustice will be found when the public begin to learn that all the intelligence we receive reaches New-York between 3 and 4 o'clock in the afternoon of each day, and is all forestalled by one enterprising firm of publishers, who, as we have said, naturally complain that they are not better appreciated.

abstract: Coal, Wheat, >amp;c.
snippet: Coal, Wheat, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: "Billy," said a benevolent vender of food for stoves, as with cheerful visage he sat down to his matutinal repast, "is it cold?" "Wery cold, father," was the reply. "Is the gutters froze, Billy," rejoined the parent. "Werry hard, father. they is," was the response. "Ah!" sighed the old gentlemen, "put up the coal two pence a pail, Billy. God help the poor!"

abstract: lished three or four most entertaining volumes of military history. They summoned before them nearly all the Generals of the Union army, engaged in nearly all the battles, from the Susquehanna to the Red River, and obtained their testimony as to their own behavior and that of their fellow-officers. Would it not be well for this committee to continue its labors, and summon before it for examination the leading Generals of the late army of the late Southern Confederacy? If the object of the committee's labors was to get at the facts of the various campaigns and furnish material for history and literature for posterity, it would be well that they should carry out this suggestion. There were many points left in the dark; there were many intricate things left unraveled, because we could not get at the facts as to the condition of things on the other side of the lines, and as to the movements, manoeuvres and purposes of the enemy. All these matters can now be reached. The Southern officers would doubtless he very glad to give their testimony. LEE, JOHNSTON, LONGSTREET, EARLY and the others, would promptly obey the summons. We should thus have a more perfect picture of the war, and should be able to award praise or blame to our officers with more justice than heretofore. We have ourselves had some remarkable revelations concerning some of the campaigns from leading Confederate officers; and what we have heard makes us anxious to know more. The way we have suggested is the best way to get the facts.

abstract: The steamship Australasian arrived at this port yesterday, bringing two days, later intelligence from Europe. The Fenian movement appears to cause considerable solicitude in England, and the British Government has taken precautionary measures against a possible uprising. Several gunboats have boon stationed in [???]ntry Bay, to keep a strict watch on that part of the coast. The widow of THOMAS MOORE, the poet, is dead. A marriage is said to have been arranged between a son of VICTOR EMANUEL and a Spanish Princess. This may account for the cordial relations existing between the two courts. The popular feeling in England and France against the Austro-Prussian Convention is very decided. In the Duchies of Schleswig-Holstein evidences of increasing dissatisfaction are constantly appearing. Deplorable accounts are received from Constantinople of the great fire in Stamboul. It is stated that 2,800 buildings were destroyed, and that upwards of 22,000 persons were rendered housless by the disaster. Some accounts even estimate the destruction of buildings at upwards of 12,000. The Medical Commission at Constantinople reports that cholera had almost disappeared.

abstract: Greenleaf et al. vs. Peter R. Mumford. -- A motion was made in this action to compel the Life Insurance and Trust Company to pay over to the plaintiffs the amount of their claim -- which they allege amounts to about $28,000 -- in advance of other creditors, on the ground that they had attached the money in bank before the assignment was made. The case was fully argued some days since, and yesterday the court decided the motion in favor of the plaintiffs.

abstract: Clafley, D., Killed in Riot at Lion Park
snippet: Clafley, D., Killed in Riot at Lion Park
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday evening, subsequent to a pic-nic excursion which the Church of the Annunciation had made to Lion Park, two rival gangs of Bloomingdale outlaws engaged in a fight at the Park Hotel, and WILLIAM and DANIEL CLAFLY, brothers, were stabbed, and the latter was almost instantly killed. The murderers escaped, and WILLIAM CLAFLY was taken to his abode, in Eleventh-avenue, near One Hundred and Eleventh-street, where his wounds were dressed. The corpse of DANIEL CLAFLY was taken to the Thirty-first Precinct Police Station, and several persons who saw the affray were held as witnesses. Coroner GOVER held an inquest last evening.

abstract: that the British Government not only begin to dread a Fenian uprising on Irish soil, but that they have stationed gunboats and men-of-war off the west coast of Ireland -- with the view, as we judge, of looking out for a Fenian armada from the west. We should probably be suspected of putting our neutral friends off their guard, if we said that this naval enterprise is a very ridiculous affair. We happen to know far more of Fenianism here than our cousins do on their side of the water. But the British Government will find informers by the hundred -- who are members of the order -- ready to give them all the information they desire at a small cost. Any gratuitous intelligence, therefore, from this side of the Atlantic, need not be tendered. The British navy wants exercise, and there can be no good reason why it should not take it in Bantry Bay as well as any place else.

abstract: St. George vs. Young America, of Phila.
snippet: St. George vs. Young America, of Phila.
lead_paragraph: One of the most interesting games of cricket we have had this season, and what promises to be the best display of the beauties of the game, takes place to-day on the St. George Cricket Ground, at Hoboken, the occasion being the grand match, "Young America vs. St. George," for the benefit of SAM. WRIGHT and his son HARRY, the two worthy professionals of the St. George Club. The eleven of the Young America Club is composed of American players entirely, and the St George eleven of nine English players and two American. The following are the names of the contestants: St. George -- Messrs. Bainbridge, Earnshaw, Gibbes, Gordon, Kendall, Moore, Robinson, Ratcliff, Tiffany, Torrance and H. Wright. Young America -- Bayard, Bavis, Johns, Large, Morgan G. Newhall, H. Newhall, C. Newhall, D. Newhall, Vernon and R. Wistar. The game will commence at 11 A.M. each day; dinner at 2 P.M., and stumps drawn at 6 P.M.

abstract: At police trials yesterday, before Commissioners ACTON, BERGEN and McMURRAY, the visitors were Ex-Mayor KALABFLEISCH, of Brooklyn,and Supervisor BRIGGS and Alderman RYERS, of this city. The calendar was not large, the number of complaints being barely seventy-eight. Treasurer McMURRAY reported the receipt, thus far, of $449 toward the purchase of a country cottage for the widow and child of the murdered policeman, THOMAS WALKER.

abstract: The market opened Monday morning with 3,540 beeves upon the books, including 510 sold during the closing days of last week. Only 16 came in during Monday night; 1,705 head were sold at Bergen, mostly on Saturday; 170 were taken direct to butchers' stalls, and 874 to the other smaller yards in the city. Some few very choice lots of corn-fed cattle brought this week as high as 19c. lb., but those were superior in quality to any offered at the market last week. Taking an average of the market from its opening to its close, prices for the same grades were not more than 1/2c. lb. higher than last week. There were as usual several lots of poor Canadian stock, consisting of working cattle, thin cows, &c, which went off at a very low figure. The present high rates are calling in everything with hide and horns at all fit for butchering purposes, from all parts of the country. The actual demand is more than equal to the supply; nor does there appear to be, as some suppose, any very great reserve held back by speculators for the purpose of keeping up prices. Especially is this the case with beef cattle. The enormous price of pork at the West has led to a larger consumption of beef than hitherto, and now the demand for this article is taking off the supply as fast as it can be fitted for the market. At the same time we do not deny that speculation has aided in maintaining advanced rates at the meat market, as elsewhere.

abstract: An affray occurred on Tuesday night in a porter-house in the Seventh Ward, during which JAMES GEOGHAN stabbed JOHN KING, of No. 32 Willett-street, in the face and head with a clasp-knife. Officer COLE, of the Seventh Precinct, arrested GEOGHAN, and yesterday Justice SHANDLEY committed him to prison.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The sale of ordinary tickets for the opening night -- Monday, Sept. 25 -- commences to-day at the Academy and the other regular offices. The first opera will be "Faust" -- not "lone" as previously and erroneously announced. GOUNOD's work will be given with an almost entirely new cast. We are glad to say, however, that Miss FELLOGG -- our own admirable prima-donna -- will still be the Margherita, and Signor BELLINI -- one of the grandest baritones now on the operatic stage -- has again kindly volunteered to sustain the secondary role of Valentine.  The remaining characters will be rendered by Miss ADELAIDE PHILLIPS, (our public will be only too happy to give her a hearty return welcome.) Signor IRFRE (the new tenor) and Signor ANTONUCCI, (the new basso.) Mr. MAX MARETZECK presides in the orchestra.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The sale of ordinary tickets for the opening night -- Monday, Sept. 25 -- commences to-day at the Academy and the other regular offices. abstract: the distributing markets on the seaboard, and the rapid inflation of prices.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia papers dwell on the strike in the Scranton coal mining region -- its causes and consequences -- to which latter, we are assured, legitimately belong the falling off in the receipts of coal at the distributing markets on the seaboard, and the rapid inflation of prices. The strike, it is now said, has narrowed itself down to a dispute as to which party shall determine "the rate of wages," -- the mining companies or the miners. Each party contends for an absolute right to dictate terms, and neither is disposed to make the slightest concession. The companies insist on their right to regulate their own affairs to suit their own interests.

abstract: Mission of as Educators of Youth
snippet: Mission of as Educators of Youth
lead_paragraph: our advertising columns, that this is the season in which the educational institutions of the city and country are being reopened. No one who has the charge or supervision of youths of either sex, and who has studied these advertisements in the TIMES for the last few weeks, can have failed to observe how admirably we are supplied with schools, seminaries and colleges, in which every branch of knowledge is taught. It is a noteworthy fact, that of over one hundred seminaries and educational institutions which were advertised in yesterday's issue of this journal, more than a half were under the conduct and control of ladies. In many of these, not merely dancing and music are taught, but the classics and mathematics. Some of them only take girls as pupils, but others take both boys and girls.

abstract: Restoration, the Plan of
snippet: Restoration, the Plan of
lead_paragraph: We suppose President JOHNSON's mind was turned in favor of the particular mode of "reconstruction" which he is carrying out, partly by the fact that it was the mode first adopted by President LINCOLN, and applied by him to the State of Tennessee; partly by the circumstance that, as Provisional Governor of Tennessee, Mr. JOHNSON had an excellent opportunity of testing the practicability and value of the plan; and partly by the fact that no other plan had been suggested to which there were not greater objections than there were to the Tennessee plan.

abstract: Alleged intended Robbery of Soldiers and Paymaster on Board at New-York
snippet: Alleged intended Robbery of Soldiers and Paymaster on Board at New-York
lead_paragraph: On the 11th of September the Twenty-sixth Regiment of colored troops, under command of Col. GURNSEY, took passage on the steamer Massasoit from Hart's Island for the City. A number of pickpockets and other bad characters had, in some way or other, got on board the boat, and on the passage up to the city, the Captain, ALEXANDER MCLEAN, acted so suspiciously in regard to the management of the steamer, that the Paymaster, Col. GEORGE BROWN who had $40,000 in his possession, became alarmed and supposing that MCLEAN was keeping the boat from making her landing, in order to give the thieves on board an opportunity to rob him, he requested Col. GURNSEY to grant him the necessary protection. The Colonel accordingly had MCLEAN arrested, and took possession of the boat. On landing MCLEAN was released and he then had Col. GURNSEY arrested for assault. The case was tried yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions.

abstract: St. George vs. Young America; Conclusion
snippet: St. George vs. Young America; Conclusion
lead_paragraph: The match between these clubs, which was commenced at Hoboken on Wednesday, terminated yesterday afternoon in the success of the young American cricketers, by a total score of 180 to 119. The best total scores of the match, on the part of Young America, were CHAS. NEWHALL's 58, DAVIS's 26, DAN NEWHALL's 19, GEO. NEWHALL's 15, and WATSON's 15. On the part of the St. George, BAMBRIDGE's 38, RALCLIFFE's 15, and EARNSHAW's 13 were the best scores. In bowling, JOHNS' total figures were 192, 39, 25, 7, and but one wide. C. NEWHALL's being 144, 41,16, 5, and two wides. DAN NEWHALL taking three wickets for 25 runs with his slows. On the St. George side, H. WRIGHT's total figures were 246, 71, 26, 10, and one wide. TIFFANY's being 134, 46, 15, 7, and four wides. The following is the score:

abstract: Brace, C. L.; European Social Reforms; Irish Prison System
snippet: Brace, C. L.; European Social Reforms; Irish Prison System
lead_paragraph: Some fifteen years ago, the writer of this, in company with some friends, was making a foot journey over England. In the course of their wanderings, they chanced on some persons enthusiastically interested in a new system of prison treatment, as it had been applied by a certain Capt. MACONOCHIE, on Norfolk Island. The ideas and method struck the whole of them as something wonderful, yet most natural, and as far in advance of any prison system then in use in the world. One of the party, whose name has since become widely known in England and America, Mr. F.L. OLMSTEAD, wrote a brief account of this remarkable system and its principles, in a little work called Walks and Talks of an American Farmer in England. This was, perhaps, the first description of the "mark system" presented in America. The writer of this has also, at various times, urged it in the American Press. But in general, it may be said that the most reasonable and original system for the treatment of convicts, which modern benevolence has invented, was utterly unappreciated in the life of its founder, and that the ideas which Capt. MACONOCHIE planted twenty-five or thirty years ago, and which only brought annoyance, disappointment, and almost heart-break to himself, have just now begun to take root and spring up in what is called the "Irish Prison System."
headline: {'main': 'EUROPEAN SOCIAL REFORMS.; The Irish Prison System.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'EUROPEAN SOCIAL REFORMS.; The Irish Prison System.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Edward Tracey, a laboring man, was charged with assaulting Officer Cornelius Western, of the Eleventh Precinct. Witness said he caught defendant's son attempting to commit a burglary. The thief fled, and took refuge in a large tenement building in which his father resided. The officer was near enough to see the entry way in which the fugitive took refuge, but lost him in the darkness as he groped his way up stairs. On one of the upper floors, where the officer thought the burglar might have entered, he knocked at the door of an innocent German, and roused him up. The German opened the door, with night-cap on, in undress, and with a sickly-looking candle in his hand, and was almost frightened out of his wits when he saw the embodiment of law, if not justice, standing on the sill of his door. When informed that it was supposed that a burglar had taken refuge in his apartments, he said: "Mine herr, mine herr; up, up," and he conducted the officer to the room overhead, where somebody had entered in haste a few moments before. The German and the officer, after getting the door opened, entered together, and the burglar was found in bed undressed. He had made a quick undressing. He asked for time to put his pantaloons on. This was granted; and as soon as had got one leg in he made a dash for the door to get out, but was stopped by the officer. He then got both legs in his pantaloons, mounted a chair and tried to jump through a small window that would have landed him in the hallway. His gymnastic feat was a failure; he only butted his head against the wall. By this time the father of the burglar, Mr. Tracy, who had gone to bed legitimately, had finished dressing himself; and when Officer Western seized his prisoner to take him off, he clasped his arms around the officer's neck and gave him a choking hug. The consequence was the officer had to let go of the son, and as the next best thing he took the father in and charged him with assault and battery. The up-shot of the affair is, that the father is in the son's shoes, serving three months in the penitentiary.

abstract: Union State Convention--Resolutions Compared with Democratic Resolutions
snippet: Union State Convention--Resolutions Compared with Democratic Resolutions
lead_paragraph: It took little time or trouble for the delegates of the Union party to do their business. A few hours were all that were needful to make up a capital ticket for State officers, to appoint an efficient State Committee, and to adopt a series of resolutions, setting forth in the clearest terms the principles upon which the canvass is to be conducted. All were inspired with a devotion to the cause, and the utmost harmony prevailed throughout.

abstract: Eckford vs. Atlantic
snippet: Eckford vs. Atlantic
lead_paragraph: The first match between these clubs since 1863 took place at Bedford yesterday, the result being the success of the Atlantics by a score of 28 to 23. The Eckfords fielding was very loose in the way of wild throws in the fifth innings. The score stood 9 to 3 at the close of the third innings in favor of the Eckfords, but afterward the score was reversed, the Atlantics being 10 ahead on the fifth innings. In the last four innings the Eckfords had the advantage, scoring 13 to 8. The utmost good feeling was shown by the contestants one to the other, and the match proved to be a pleasant reunion. The following is the score:

abstract: Schemmelfennig, Gen., Memorial Ceremony to
snippet: Schemmelfennig, Gen., Memorial Ceremony to
lead_paragraph: In the lecture-room of the Mercantile Library a large audience gathered last evening, to do honor to the memory of the German Gen. SCHEMMELFINNIG, who recently died from disease contracted while in the discharge of active duty in the field. Those present were mainly Germans, a large number being ladies. The proceedings were interesting and impressive in character, and were gotten up under the immediate auspices of the "Unionbund," or German Union League.

abstract: Dr. Lieber's Letter to Sec. Seward; Letter to Sec. Seward on International Arbitration; Dr. Lieber's Letter to, on International Arbitration
snippet: Dr. Lieber's Letter to Sec. Seward; Letter to Sec. Seward on International Arbitration; Dr. Lieber's Letter to, on International Arbitration
lead_paragraph: DEAR SIR: Permit me to address to you in the form of a letter, some remarks on a subject which deserves the attention of every American citizen and every lover of right and progress. You, Sir, at the head of our foreign affairs, influencing and guiding, in a great measure, our highest transactions abroad and at home, will, I respectfully trust, pardon me for sending forth this letter with your name as that of its public recipient, since its topic is international arbitration.

abstract: Fashion Course. Dexter, Gen. Butler.Geo. Wilkes, for $1,000
snippet: Fashion Course. Dexter, Gen. Butler.Geo. Wilkes, for $1,000
lead_paragraph: The first of the two great Fall purses offered by the proprietor of the Fashion Course, came off yesterday, viz.: Mile heats, best three in five, in harness. The entries comprised the stallion George Wilkes, the brown gelding Dexter, the black gelding Gen. Butler, the gray mare Blonde and the chestnut mare Lady Emma. Of these the first three only came to the score, the other two, for obvious reasons, declining to put in an appearance. The probabilities of a great and exciting race, and the certainty that with a clear day and good track something unusual would be on the tapis, induced an unusually large attendance. It seemed a foregone conclusion that something beyond an ordinary trot was on hand, and due preparations were made by the management, represented by Mr. CROCHERON, for doing it full honor. For once in a while we are disposed to award the Flushing Railroad credit for the excellence of their arrangements. The early morning trains were run with due punctuality; the half-past 1 o'clock specially advertised, which so few believed that they refrained from purchasing tickets until it was in the shed, was absolutely a fixed fact, and, strange to say, on time -- a fact which we record to the credit of the company, as their lapses have neither been few or far between, and it is pleasurable to notice anything in the shape of an improvement in the management of this road, which is the great and only outlet of New-Yorkers to the Fashion Course, unless they possess private vehicles. Unblest in this respect, it is really with extreme satisfaction that we record the fact that on this occasion the railroad people fulfilled their promises. For a day or two previously Dexter had been unquestionably the favorite against the field -- the odds settling down on Wednesday evening to 100 to 60 on him. On Thursday morning, prior to a departure for the course, he stood at even against the field. The track was crowded, the patrons of the trotting turf flocking to it by rail and road, many of the latter, owing to the crowded state of the ferries, not being able to put in an appearance until after the first heat was disposed o[???]. Rarely have we seen so unexceptionable an attendance at the Fashion Course. The strictest decorum was maintained, a large force of the Metropolitan Police being present, but as far as their services were required, they might just as well have been in New-York -- the days when roughs and rowdies can rule a race course are past, and henceforth the strong feeling of gentlemanly management, and the observance of strict propriety will be observed -- not only at the Fashion Course, but at every other which bears a time-honored name.

abstract: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- Mr. LESTER WALLACK drew to his establishment last evening one of the most fashionable and critical audiences that could at any period of the season be attracted to a place of amusement. Every one was there, and every one listened to the new play with attention. The name of the play is the "Serf" -- a piece powerful and even painful in its interest, but not we think destined to a phenomenal longevity. Writing hastily after a protracted and late performance we cannot speak of Mr. TAYLOR's production in due terms of criticism. We prefer for the moment to record the success of the artists who took part in it. Mr. E.L. DAVENPORT was received with favor, and justified every hand that was raised in his applause. Miss MADELINE HENRIQUES was in each scene thoroughly admirable, and in the last act touched every one with the true pathos and naturalness of her style. Mr. JOHN GILBERT and Mr. FISHER and Mr. GEORGE HOLLAND -- in a way which we shall hereafter discriminate -- obtained their usual degree of applause. For the rest we need simply say that the drama was placed on the stage in a perfect manner, and that it affords us -- by its singularities -- an opportunity of speaking of it immediately at greater length.

abstract: Institute Fair; Machinery--Fruit
snippet: Institute Fair; Machinery--Fruit
lead_paragraph: All things have an end, and the vexatious delays to which the exhibitors of machinery at the Fair of the American Institute have been subjected, during the past week, are nearly over; indeed, it might almost be said they are ended, for at last the great bulk of the machinery is supplied with power, and the busy hum of wheels resound throughout the place. The fair is now attractive to all classes of people, and the attendance, which hitherto has been large only at night, is now from early morn until the hour of closing remuneratively great.

abstract: Anglo-French Naval Review, the meaning of
snippet: Anglo-French Naval Review, the meaning of
lead_paragraph: The man who can fathom the mysteries of European diplomacy at the present epoch, is wise indeed. Somebody is always getting led by the nose, and somebody is leading; but the trouble is to tell which is which. Of one thing we may be sure, it is very seldom that prononce proboscis of the sagacious master of the Tuileries that is led about.

abstract: The party of English capitalists seem to be supremely delighted with everything in the United States, and are in ecstacies over the West. Their enthusiasm increased as they advanced toward the Mississippi, and when they stood on its banks, and in the noble City of St. Louis, they gave hearty and eloquent utterance to their wonder. It was not merely the bigness of the country -- which English snobs often say is the only thing we can boast of -- but its resources, intrinsic and developed, its agricultural advancement, its commercial activity, its financial thrift -- not merely these things either, but its achievements in arms, and its magnanimity after war -- and not these alone, but its orderly freedom, its educational attainments, and its progressive spirit. It is, of course, comfortable for these gentlemen to be so well pleased with the United States, where they have so large interests involved. They represent, it is believed, not less than forty millions of dollars, invested in American railroad enterprises, and they visit the country to form a judgment as to the profitableness of investing another forty millions. Their chief interest, as we have previously stated, is in the lately completed Atlantic and Great Western road, 750 miles long, from where it leaves the Erie road to where it connects with the Ohio and Mississippi road. Their idea is to make common stock of these three great roads, double-track them all the way from New-York to St. Louis, contract a branch to Louisville and another to Chicago, and ballast the whole so securely that a speed can be secured equal to that in practice upon the best European railways.

abstract: SERIOUS ACCIDENT -- TWO MEN SEVERELY INJURED. -- Yesterday afternoon two men, named GEORGE PETTIGREW and ISAAC MESEROLE, were engaged in painting the gable of a house in Third-street, E.D., when the scaffolding gave way and precipitated both men to the sidewalk, a distance of about fifty feet. Mr. PETTIGREW, who lives in South Seventh-street, between Fourth and Fifth, had a leg and an arm broken. Mr. MESEROLE was severely injured internally. He lives at No. 41 Tenth-street.

abstract: Fort Pulaski, with its frowning parapets lined with the savage dogs of war, is at present a place of considerable interest, containing within its battered, war-begrimed, historic walls, several distinguished prisoners of the late Confederate States. Among the prominent men now confined there are Gov. MAGRATH, of South Carolina; G.A. TRENHOLM, late Secretary of the Treasury of the defunct Confederacy; D.L. YULEE, of Florida; Secretary SEDDON, Judge CAMPBELL, Gen. MERCER, and others.

abstract: New-York Harlem Bridge; Part of carried Away and Persons thrown in Water
snippet: New-York Harlem Bridge; Part of carried Away and Persons thrown in Water
lead_paragraph: PART OF HARLEM BRIDGE CARRIED AWAY. -- A section of Harlem Bridge, about one hundred feet in length, was carried away between 2 and 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, and five men and one woman, who were in two vehicles on the bridge, were thrown into the Harlem River. Clinging to the floating timbers, the party kept above the water until Policemen BATES, MOULD and HALORAN reached the spot and rescued them. The lady, who is a daughter of Mr. EDDY, the actor, was taken to the Westchester side. The horses, also, were saved. The accident occurred from the steam-tug T. Farrell, which had in tow the barge John A. Bergen, being driven by the tide against the bridge while she was passing through the draw.

abstract: Thomas Brady was tried for robbing in the first degree -- in common parlance, garotting. The complainant, James Blackburn, a gentleman residing in Eleventh-street, in this city, testified that on the 10th of this month, about 2 o'clock in the morning he was passing through Nineteenth-street, he was overtaken by the prisoner and another man, who escaped. The two robbers pushed him into an alley-way, and prisoner jumped upon witness, took his pocket-book containing $140, kicked him several times, and both thieves then ran away. Witness having called lustily for help, Officer Gaynor made chase after the men and caught the prisoner in Sixth-avenue about a block from the scene of the occurrence. The testimony of the complainant was given in a very confused manner, but he was corroborated by the police officer and another witness. The jury rendered a verdict of guilty.

abstract: Clafley, at Lion Park, Inquest
snippet: Clafley, at Lion Park, Inquest
lead_paragraph: Coroner GOVER concluded an inquest at the Eighty-sixth-street Police-station on Wednesday evening, over the body of DANIEL CLAFFY, the young man who was murdered on Tuesday evening by a gang from Bloomingdale. From the testimony which was adduced, it appears that on the evening of the 19th, subsequent to a pic-nic which CLAFFY and his brother had attended, a number of inebriated rowdies created a disturbance in the bar-room of the Lion Park Hotel, and were ordered thence by the cashier; and as they declined to go, two policemen were instructed to eject them. Whereupon a free fight ensued, in which chairs, tables and crockery were flung about the room and pistols and knives were used. The fight continued ten minutes or more, and at the conclusion CLAFFY was found to have been mortally wounded. Twenty witnesses have been examined; but nothing was elicited showing by whom the murder was committed. The substance of the affidavits is as follows:

abstract: The "Union Bund," or German Union League, of this city, held an interesting meeting last evening, in the lecture rooms of the Mercantile Library Association. The purpose of the meeting was to pay a proper tribute to the memory of Gen. ALEXANDER SCHIMMEL[???]NNING, who it will be remembered recently died of consumption, contracted during his four years of service. The exercises were of an impressive character, and participated in by a large gathering of our German citizens. Addresses were made by Dr. SCHUTZ, President of the League, Messrs. FREDERICK KAPP and HUGO, WESENDONK, and Gen. S.L. WOODF[???]D. Steps are being taken to provide some suitable provision of the deceased General's family.

abstract: Fall and Winter
snippet: Fall and Winter
lead_paragraph: New-York has wonderful resources, there is no doubt of that, we scarcely noticed a diminution in the tide of wealth, and fashion, which pours its swift current, through its streets, and thoroughfares, and into its merchant palaces, during the just closed war, but now that it is over, now that the sword is turned into a plough-share, and the spears into yard-sticks, we feel the inspiration of a new life, and more abundant vitality, through all its veins, and find everywhere the indications of a new reign of peace, and abundant prosperity.

abstract: On Tuesday last, Mr. RUSSEL DART, of this city, died at Middle Haddam, Conn., whither he had gone on a visit. The deceased was in the 70th year of his age. He was formerly engaged in the dry goods business, and for forty years was a member of the firm of R.A. DART & CO. Mr. DART was highly respected as a business man and as a good citizen. The funeral will take place from his late residence, No. 149 East Fifteenth-street, on Saturday afternoon at 4 o'clock.

abstract: We trust our readers do not hastily pass over the brief reports of this trial. When the full record comes before the world, it will add to history the blackest volume that ever dishonored civilization. We have refrained from extended comment upon the case, preferring to await its termination before saying anything that could even seem like interference. But it is certainly proper to call attention to such of the evidence as implicates the leaders of the rebellion in the awful treatment of our men. Yesterday, it was put on record that Gen. HOWELL COBB, one of the main pillars of the Confederacy, and an intimate friend and counsellor of JEFFERSON DAVIS, made a speech at Andersonville, in March last, where a number of paroled prisoners had a chance to hear him. That the entire tone and spirit of Gen. COBB were in harmony with the action of WINDER and WIRZ, cannot be denied. Pointing to the stockade where our poor boys were huddled together, a mass of skeletons, with no mothers, wives or sisters to kiss away their dying groans, this incarnate Son of Chivalry, Gen. HOWELL COBB, told his own men how much better off they were, and bade them go home, kiss their wives and sweethearts, and find new courage to struggle for success. And then, in full view of fifteen thousand helpless men enduring the pangs of starvation, this brave Gen. HOWELL COBB, in a voice of stentorian power, (doubtless raised so that the prisoners might hear him,) said that he would treat them well, he would feed them well; and -- pointing to the grave-yard where they were thrown like dead dogs by hundreds into shallow pits, he added with demoniac sarcasm: "he would take care of them!" By-and-by the world will be wiser as to the complicity of the leading rebels in the murder of prisoners, and it is barely possible that the London Times may change its estimate of its model gentleman and Christian soldier, the late Gen. J.H. WINDER.

abstract: UNION PRIMARIES. -- Union primary meetings were held in Jersey City last evening for the purpose of electing delegates to the County and Assembly Conventions. The Third Ward meeting was largely attended by the most prominent citizens of the ward. After the election of delegates, stirring speeches were made by ISAAC W. SCUDDER, Esq., Messrs. LEWIS, DICKSON, Gen. RAMSEY and Maj. PANGBORN. Maj. PANGBORN announced that Gen. SWIFT, of Louisiana, and Col. HAWKINS, of Tennessee, will speak at Cooper Hall next Monday evening. Gen. RAMSEY will undoubtedly receive the nomination for Assembly from the Third Ward, and MATTHEW ARMSTRONG, of Bergen, will probably receive the nomination for State Senator.

abstract: Decline in and Future Prospects of
snippet: Decline in and Future Prospects of
lead_paragraph: The large falling off in the emigration from Europe to this country within the last three months, is not very easily accounted for. It is thought that the idea prevailed abroad that the return to the pursuits of civil life of the million able-bodied men who had been in our army would more than supply all the demands of the country for industrial labor, and that the large class of emigrants who come here to seek employment would find it impossible to obtain it. It is also thought that the idea which prevailed to some extent here, and was industriously circulated abroad, that the close of the war would be followed by a grand commercial and financial crash, in which the whole country would be involved in ruin, had considerable effect in deterring intending emigrants from coming over until they saw what shape affairs were really going to take. Other things, such as the assassination of President LINCOLN, are supposed to have had an effect in the same way.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The trial of Capt. WIRZ was continued yesterday. Among the witnesses examined was Dr. HOPKINS, who testified that he was commissioned together with Surgeon WHITE to make a thorough inspection of the prison and hospital, with a view to their improvement. The report of these gentlemen, addressed to Gen. WINDER, was read. It appears from this that the commission found the prison in the most horrible condition, and in accordance with their instructions they made a series of suggestions, which, if carried into effect, would have tended greatly to ameliorate the suffering of our men. But this was never done, though they were all practicable, and would have involved little expense to the rebels. Most of the labor would have been gladly performed by the prisoners. The old, dreadful story was further confirmed by the testimony of other witnesses.

abstract: Kingston Journal on President Buchanan's Reformed Cabinet
snippet: Kingston Journal on President Buchanan's Reformed Cabinet
lead_paragraph: Equally disingenuous, and equally at variance with the record of accepted history, is the following representation of Mr. BLAIR: 'In the interim between the meeting of Congress and the accession of Mr. LINCOLN, the influential men in the Cabinet designated by him, and those playing their last card in BUCHANAN's Cabinet, were busied in intrigues with conspirators who were setting up their power over the Slave States.' We utterly deny any such collusion as is here alleged -- we utterly deny the existence of a state of facts at all justifying Mr. BLAIR's sweeping accusation. The 'interim' referred to covers the events embraced in the period subsequent, as well as previous to the change which everybody knows took place in Mr. BUCHANAN's Cabinet -- a change which threw out COBB, THOMPSON and FLOYD, the master-spirits of treason, and brought in STANTON and DIX, simultaneously with the transfer of HOLT to the War Department.

abstract: His Administration of the War Department
snippet: His Administration of the War Department
lead_paragraph: The Secretary of War is no popularity hunter, and has an invincible repugnance to being lionized. He means that his visit to New-York shall be of the most quiet character; and all the world has learned that what he means he executes. It is absolutely refreshing to see an American of his force and fame moving with so little noise and show -- content with the friendly courtesies of private life.

abstract: Reception in New-York

lead_paragraph: EDWIN M. STANTON, Secretary of War, has been the guest of Senator MORGAN, at his residence, corner of Fifth-avenue and Thirty-seventh-street since Wednesday evening last, and this morning by special conveyance has returned to Washington, when he will resume the duties from which he has been absent exactly a month -- the first known absence since his as- sumption of the office.

abstract: In the Police Courts, yesterday, there were many interesting trials -- the most noteworthy of which we epitomise as follows: Capt. BOWEN G. LORD, of the Sanitary Police, outing under orders from the Metropolitan Police Commissioners, made affidavit against Mr. CHARLES SHERMAN, proprietor of the tenement dwellings Nos. 220 and 222 East Seventeenth-street, reciting that these edifices, which are only 50x45 feet square and five stories (of eight feet each) in height, contain thirty-eight families, embracing 152 persons, and are not only not properly ventilated, but are filthy in the extreme. Capt. LORD further alleges that more than a hundred cases of fever have occurred in these pestilence-breeding, quarters within a twelve-month. Mr. SHERMAN having appeared before Justice DODGE and agreed to cleanse and fumigate his houses and make them habitable, the complaint was dismissed.......Justice LEDWITH committed EDWARD GILMORE, of No. 86 Mulberry-street, shoemaker, for stealing a watch from Mr. ENOS B. MOORE, of No. 131 East Houston-street, while in a Fourth-avenue car.......Before Justice DODGE, Mr. EUGENE EVANS, of No. 106 Third-avenue, preferred complaint against PATRICK GLENNAN and THOMAS KELLY, for felonious assault. In a saloon at no. 34 Oak-street, yesterday morning, GLENNAN stabbed Mr. EVANS in the abdomen, inflicting a fearful gash whence the intestines protruded....CHAS. BURGDORF, AUGUSTA BURGDORF and MARY HOPF were committed by Justice DODGE, for examination by Fire-Marshal BAKER, on a charge alleging that they had set fire to the cabinetmaker's shop on the third story of No. 232 West Thirty-fifth-street BURGDORF had $1,500 insurance in the Peoples' office, and Policeman ADAM MOULIGAN, who arrested the accused, thinks that BURGDORF's entire stock was not worth $500. A remarkable circumstance in this connection is that on Thursday night, evidences of incendiarism having been discovered, Fire-Marshal BAKER was summoned to BURGDORF's place, and he cautioned BURGDORF to desist....Justice SHANDLEY committed LEWIS KRONE, of No. 81 Allen-street, for stabbing Mr. GEORGE HENRY ORB, of No. 151 Ludlow-street, inflicting a serious wound in the face. The assault was committed at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, at the intersection of Grand-street and the Bowery.

A remarkable circumstance in this connection is that on Thursday night, evidences of incendiarism having been discovered, Fire-Marshal BAKER was summoned to BURGDORF's place, and he cautioned BURGDORF to desist....Justice SHANDLEY committed LEWIS KRONE, of No. 81 Allen-street, for stabbing Mr. GEORGE HENRY ORB, of No. 151 Ludlow-street, inflicting a serious wound in the face. The assault was committed at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, at the intersection of Grand-street and the Bowery.

abstract: Spanish Italian Amity; and Spain, Amity Between
snippet: Spanish Italian Amity; and Spain, Amity Between
lead_paragraph: If it is true that the son of VICTOR EMANUEL is about to espouse the daughter of the Queen of Spain, there might seem cause either to fear much for the Italians or to hope much for the Spaniards. The rumored alliance would set a seal upon the diplomatic relations recently established between the two countries, and would go far to heal the hurt which the Re Galantuomo inflicted on his Bourbon cousin of Spain, by consenting to receive at the hands of GARIBALDI the crown rent from his Bourbon cousin of Naples. Since it is rumored that the King has lately shown a tendency to favor the least liberal faction of politics among his subjects, the match might afford some further crumbs of comfort to the patient Reaction which has gone empty so long in Italy. It might be taken as a sign that the revolution, which placed VICTOR EMANUEL at the head of nearly all the Italian States, had accomplished itself, and that generous patriotism was hardening into selfish order. The Pope might look with satisfaction on a union of the family of his erring son with that of most Catholic Spain, and might cordially join with the heirs of FRA DIAVOLO, (to whom VICTOR EMANUEL still pays the pension bestowed on their illustrious ancestor,) in rejoicing over the introduction into Italy of that royal Spanish blood which has always been so favorable to brigandage.
headline: {'main': 'Spanish-Italian Amity.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Spanish-Italian Amity.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Candidates for Governor and Parties in
snippet: Candidates for Governor and Parties in
lead_paragraph: In connection with the fact that two Generals of our army are in nomination for the Gubernatorial chair of Ohio, by the two opposing political parties, we recently reprehended certain party papers of that State for their attempts to distort and blacken the military record of one or other of thoss gentlemen to subserve partisan ends. Since that time two Generals have been nominated by the two parties of this State for the important office of Secretary of State. Both of these political candidates have an honorable record as soldiers, and we trust that in the canvass now opened there will be no attempt on the part of any man to belittle or dispute the services of either. Assaults of this kind will certainly redound to the advantage of the party assailed. In no Republican paper have we seen a word of detraction from Gen. SLOCUM's merits as a true soldier; and we are pleased to say that of the Democratic papers which have reached us since the nomination of Gen. BARLOW, on Wednesday, all have pursued a similar course in his case.
headline: {'main': 'The Candidates and the Parties.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Candidates and the Parties.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Judge Nelson's Decision
snippet: Judge Nelson's Decision
lead_paragraph: Judge NELSON, sitting in the United States Circuit Court, at Cooperstown, recently, as our readers are aware, declined to issue the injunctions which were prayed for by some of our bankers and brokers against the Assessors and Collectors of Internal Revenue, to prevent them from collecting the tax which the Treasury Department claims to be payable upon sales of United States Bonds by these bankers and brokers for their own account. It is not by any means to be understood that this decision arose from any new doubt which had sprung up in the Judge's mind as to the illegality of the tax, for he says again, in his decision, the though the question is not a clear one, his best justment is that the tax cannot be legally imposed. The injunction is refused in accordance with that well-known principle that an injunction "is always refused where there is a remedy at law."

abstract: Military Career of; Military Career of
snippet: Military Career of; Military Career of
lead_paragraph: The military career of Gen. FRANCIS C. BARLOW presents something typical of the character of the ideal American tempered with more modesty and greater reticence. Like GRANT, he learned to command by first learning to obey, and his steps from the study to the ranks, from the ranks to the highest military honors, illustrate the versatility and adaptibility of the American mind. Gen. BARLOW was a hater of slavery, from conviction that liberty was the equal right of all human beings. Educated at Harvard, where he was the honor man of his class, he was known to his fellow-students as the keenest, the most logical and most combative of disputants on the great question which then agitated the country. A course of study for the bar in the office of the late lamented WM. CURTIS NOYES, and a partnership in the practice of law with Col. GEORGE BLISS, brought associations which did not diminish the impression of earlier days, and the commencement of the war found him prepared to maintain the justice of the Northern cause by every personal sacrifice.
