abstract: KINGS COUNTY POLITICS. -- The Regular and National Democratic Senatorial Conventions met yesterday afternoon -- the former to nominate a candidate for the Third Senatorial District. Gen. C.E. PRATT presided; and after calling the roll of delegates, a motion was made to adjourn, which was carried. A committee was appointed to notify the Nationals of their action. The Nationals held a convention to nominate a candidate for the Second Senatorial District. JOHN R. WILDS presided. It being understood that Mr. JOHN C. JACOBS had a majority of the delegation, the members discussed the propriety of going into a nomination or adjourning, when it was announced that Mr. JACOBS would not accept. On tide announcement, the convention adjourned, subject to the call of the chair. The Regular County Convention met at Montague Hall, and adjourned without doing any business. The Nationals also met and nominated JAMES FITZGERALD as Superintendent for the Poor of the Eastern District, and AUGUSTUS PERCIVAL as Superintendent of the Poor for the country towns. GEORGE W. SEAMAN was nominated for JUSTICE of the Sessions, when the convention adjourned.

abstract: Cuba, Negro Slavery in
snippet: Cuba, Negro Slavery in
lead_paragraph: -- On various accounts, negro slavery in Cuba has now a very uncertain tenure. As long as the "institution" existed in this country, and was upheld by our government, the system in Cuba had strong backing up. But now that it has fallen here, it there stands alone, in execrable solitude, on the North American continent. The new power, importance and energy of the Liberal party in Spain, also works against the continuance of slavery in the colonies. The Liberals of Spain, like those of every European country, are strongly opposed to slavery, and would make short work of it had they possession of the government. Even in the Conservative party, the system has many foes; and it is not unlikely that, under the influences now operating throughout the world in favor of emancipation, the measures which have been inaugurated in Spain in favor of gradual abolition, will, before the close of next year, be pushed to their consummation.
headline: {'main': 'SLAVERY IN CUBA.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'SLAVERY IN CUBA.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Emigration, Commissioner Mitchell's Brief on
snippet: Emigration, Commissioner Mitchell's Brief on
lead_paragraph: The question of what shall be done with the negro was one of the most complicated which the war called forth. And among the methods proposed for his benefit, assisted emigration to various tropical regions has been much discussed. In the pamphlet which Mr. MITCHELL has just issued, he furnishes a statement of the action of President LINCOLN and the late Congress in regard to such emigration, and the present condition of the question. Quoting the Act of July, 1862, authorizing the President to make provision for colonizing such of the colored race as were willing to emigrate, Mr. MITCHELL calls attention to the Emancipation Proclamation of September 1862 and January 1863, which he considers contain solemn obligations to carry out the provisions of that act. The commission to Mr. MITCHELL was issued on August 4, 1862, and is still unrevoked. The funds necessary were provided by a clause in the tax law of June 1862, the amount subject to requisition on July 31 of the present year being $205,980. Mr. MITCHELL now says:

abstract: -- An old contributor to these columns writes to ask us to press the claims of condensed milk upon public attention and patronage. We were asked, moreover, the other evening, "whether we had gone out of the milk business yet." Both matters may be disposed of at once. We have not "gone out of" the practice of exposing milk or any other extortion, nor intend to do so. But, for the present, the condensed milk dealers are doing effective service, and the monopolists will find it out. Already the use of condensed milk is exclusive and rapidly increasing. Whether the dealers therein are bringing their commodity forward with sufficient prominence is their affairs; but we find that numerous families use the new article and are delighted with the changes.

abstract: High Freight Rates on Coal
snippet: High Freight Rates on Coal
lead_paragraph: -- A singular policy has been adopted by the Baltimore and Ohio Railway Company in the inauguration and maintenance of freight rates which are injurious to all the great interests lying along its immense extent. The City of New-York consumes some two hundred and twenty-five thousand tons of gas coal, Brooklyn and Williamsburgh sixty thousand, Hoboken and Jersey City twenty-five thousand, or upward of three hundred and ten thousand tons for this city and its suburbs. Owing to the high freight which the Baltimore and Ohio road imposes, it is impossible to bring to market the excellent gas coal lying west of Cheat River. The Cities of New-York, Boston and all those in this section are thus forced to resort to Nova Scotia, Cape Breton and Pictou. The Baltimore and Ohio Railway will move flour and Western freight, which it has to handle, for fifty cents per ton from the Ohio River less than coal, which it simply transports, and other way freight, which has to be transported over two to three hundred miles less of road. It charges this intermediate freight fifty to eighty cents more for not being two to three hundred miles further from its destination.
headline: {'main': 'GAS COAL THE BALTIMORE AND OHIO RAILROAD.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'GAS COAL THE BALTIMORE AND OHIO RAILROAD.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Algonquin; Trial with Winooski Commenced
snippet: Algonquin; Trial with Winooski Commenced
lead_paragraph: Owing to the fact that the wood used for starting the fires had to be passed up from the fire-rooms of the respective vessels yesterday morning to be weighed, it was not until a little over two hours after the time set that the fires were lit From 7 o'clock until the moment the match was applied, the scene on the dock, as well as on board of the vessels, was of the liveliest interest Mr. DICKERSON, Chief-Engineers DANBY, KELLOGG, SPRAGUE and PHYTHIAN were on hand early, and enjoyed themselves in spinning yarns while the wood was being passed up and weighed. Sixteen wheelbarrow loads made up the hour's allowance of coal, which was wheeled on board of each vessel. Shortly after 9 o'clock the firemen began to "wood up" and prepare for the contest. Before starting, the engineers of each vessel were served with a copy at the following document, emanating from the Board of Experts:

abstract: ALMOST A RIOT -- ATTACK UPON A PIC-NIC PARTY OF COLORED FOLKS. -- About 8 o'clock last night, as a party of colored folks reached Eleventh-street, E.D., on their way to the ferry, from a pic-nic at Leffert's Park, they were set upon by a gang of white folks, and an indiscriminate row was the result. Sticks and stones wore freely used and bloody heads became numerous. When the fight was at its height the police of the Forty-fifth Precinct made their appearance and arrested several of those engaged. One of the arrested negroes says his party were marching along in an orderly manner, preceded by fife and drum, when he heard some one shout out "Kill the niggers -- kill the niggers," and then a shower of stones was poured into them. A white man who was caught throwing stones, on the contrary states that the negroes were the first to commence the row. It was not ascertained whether any one had been mortally injured. The following parties were locked up last night, and will have hearing before Judge DAILEY this morning: Anthony Jones, Wm. Mitchell, W. Laflin, Geo. Harris, Francis Satters and Isaac White, all colored, and Michael Furphy, white.

abstract: On the Democratic Platform
snippet: On the Democratic Platform
lead_paragraph: The Republican platform is thus shown by an eminent member of the party to be as dishonest as a bank check, circulating in the mercantile community, not drawn against any funds. It is a fraudulent trick to keep up the credit of a concern consciously bankrupt, which does not disclose its real situation.

lead_paragraph: On Thursday, the Mutual and Active Clubs, of this city, played a game of base ball on the fair ground at Kingston, for a silver ball, presented by the Agricultural Society of Ulster County. After an exciting contest, the trophy was won by the Mutuals, by a score of 26 to 20. On the same day the Knickerbocker Club of Albany, contested with the Resolute Club, of Brooklyn, for a similar prize, which was won by the Albanians in a well-contested game of ten innings, by a score of 13 to 12.

abstract: Jacob, Dury???a, Sloop, Sunk by Collision in Long Island Sound
snippet: Jacob, Dury???a, Sloop, Sunk by Collision in Long Island Sound
lead_paragraph: Off Matinicock Point, at about daybreak yesterday morning, the propeller Occanus, of the New-York and Providence line, came into collision with the sloop Jacob Duryea, striking nearly amidship, and nearly cutting her in two. The Occanus was instantly barked from the spot, and the sloop, filling with water, began to careen; but before she had filled, Capt. Young, of the Occanus, threw a line to the Duryea, which enabled two of the sloop's male passengers to reach the steamer. Boats were also sent from the Occanus to the wreck, and all but three of the residue of the passengers were saved. The three that perished on board the sloop were. Mrs. SARAH E. DAVIS and her two children, EMMA W. and HATTIE B. DAVIS, infants of 7 and 20 months respectively, who were in the cabin at the time of the collision. Capt. YOUNG tarried by the Duryea until daylight, when the bodies of Mrs. DAVIS and one of the children were recovered, and the wreck was towed into Glen Cove Landing. Thence the Occanus took the bodies and the rescued passengers to this city, and on reaching the Robinson-street pier sent information to Coroner COLLIN.
headline: {'main': 'COLLISION ON LONG ISLAND SOUND.; A Steamboat Runs Down a Coasting Sloop Three Persons Drowned inquest by Coroner Collin.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'COLLISION ON LONG ISLAND SOUND.; A Steamboat Runs Down a Coasting Sloop Three Persons Drowned inquest by Coroner Collin.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: De Vere, Major Murder of; Military Morality
snippet: De Vere, Major Murder of; Military Morality
lead_paragraph: The death of Major DE VERE, Inspector of Field Fortifications, who was deliberately shot by JOHN CURRIE, a sapper, under his command, is reported in the London Times of the 24th ult. It appears that the soldier (a youth of nineteen years of age) who thus murdered his Major took offence at that officer, who had caused to be inflicted on him some punishment of no unusual severity. This occurrence might not be deemed worthy of notice were it not for the statement in the same journal that the number of military murders of this class committed of late seems to call for exceptional treatment at the hands of the British legislature. Indeed, the London Times proposes, if it does not advocate, that cases of this description might, with advantage to the public interest, be taken from under the cognizance of the civil courts and referred to courts martial. But, as courts martial are ticklish subjects to speak of in the ears of the British public, this opinion is very gingerly promulgated.

abstract: London Telegraph on Shoddy in Paris
snippet: London Telegraph on Shoddy in Paris
lead_paragraph: Shoddy is here at last; and the mouth of Paris waters and the ears of Paris tingle at the sight and sound of its well-filled pockets. I have just returned from half-an-hour's lounge in the court-yard of the Hotel, SHODDY's headquarters. Behold him in his magnificance as he reclines gracefully upon two chairs, one arm thrown over the back of a third, his boot heel resting, at an elevation considerably higher than his head, upon the rim of one of the wooden tubs that contain the fan-like palmiers. He is smoking his seventh cigar, while he waits the return of his wife and daughters from their drive -- be it recorded en passant that female Shoddy never walks -- and here they come! Fat, sallow and long past forty, the matron Shoddy sits bolt upright, for if she reclined the world would lose half her attractions, and while seeing she drives to be seen. She has diamonds in her ears; she has pearls around her neck; and a Niagara of pearls flowing over her mountainous bosom. She has heavy bracelets on her arms, rings epon her fingers, and would have bells upon her toes if the prejudices of society were not against such a fashion. The Shoddy maidens are as refulgent as their mother. The whole courtyard as they enter brightens up as with a sudden burst of sunbeams, and as they descend, which they do somewhat heavily, from the carriage, there is a prolonged metallic rattle, as though they wore, which in great part they do, chain armour over their clothes. Shoddy himself, cigar in mouth -- it is never out except to eat, drink, or spit -- iounges over to them, consults his watch, a costly affair, a size or so smaller than the hotel clock above his head, and hinting that it is luncheon time, states his intention of "putting himself outside of something right off." The ladies replying, through their noses, that they have no "objecshuns," the whole party shine and rattle up the steps, and are soon engaged in "taking stock" -- the phrase is Shoddy -- of a light and elegant repast, consisting of Strasbourg pie, pickled salmon, lobster salad, cucumber, and cheese, washed down by two bottles of Cliquot, and concluded with what the ladies denominate a "freshener up," and the gentlemen a "corpse reviver!" This glorious vision had scarcely vanished from my view, when my attention was called, by their very high voices, to a meeting of shoddy ladies who were waiting, as they termed it, "to be hauled up to their rooms by the diving bell." They were yellower in every way than the party I have just mentioned, as brassy and more bilious, keeping up a high-pressure conversation in voices pitched to the keynote of a railway whistle. Forced to become a listener, I was favored in less than five minutes with much domestic information, which, wiser than they, I shall keep to myrelf, merely recording the fact that Jane, the daughter of one of the ladies, was at that moment "fixing herself up" for a drive in the Bois, and that STEPHEN had gone out with his father "to liquor." Do I exaggerate? Certainly not. Paris, as I have before said, is flooded by les mouveaux riches of the New World -- men who more than realise BEN JOHNSON's cynical conception, and are Face, Subtle, and Epicure Mammon combined. -- Paris Correspondent of the London Daily Telegraph.

abstract: Steamship New-York, Tinklepaugh, Aspinwall Sept. 16, with mdse. and passengers to D.B. Allen. Sept. 16, at 8:24 P.M., signalized steamship Ocean Queen. Arrived at Sandy Hook Sept. 23, at 7:44 A.M., making the trip in 6 days 30 minutes, the quickest passage ever made between Aspinwall and New-York. The shortest voyage ever made before between the ports was by the Baltic, in 6 days and 21 hours to the Hook, which the New-York beats by 9 hours and 30 minutes, proving herself one of the fastest vessels afloat.

abstract: The five-hour test was completeed shortly after 3 o'clock on Friday afternoon, and at 4 o'clock the fires were hauled from the furnaces of both vessels; twelve hundred pounds of wood were served out with which to start new fires, and all the coal and ashes in the fire-rooms was hoisted out and weighed. At 4:22...
lead_paragraph: The five-hour test was completeed shortly after 3 o'clock on Friday afternoon, and at 4 o'clock the fires were hauled from the furnaces of both vessels; twelve hundred pounds of wood were served out with which to start new fires, and all the coal and ashes in the fire-rooms was hoisted out and weighed. At 4:22 P.M. the Algonquin lighted her fires, the steam gauge indicating a pressure of twenty-one and five-tenths pounds of steam. At 4:47, steam being at sixty-eight pounds, the engine was started. At 6:03 the spring in the indicator wheel broke.

abstract: the scene wherein a new version of Enoch Arden has been enacted. A Mr. G., four years since, left home to share the fortunes of Gen. PRICE, leaving at home a worthy and estimable wife burdened with the care and support of two children. Time rolled on; the hard-working mother heard nothing from her husband, till, growing weak and faint beneath the burdens of life, her heart yielded to the sympathy of a neighbor, Mr. TURNER, who kindly aided her children, and bestowed pity and love upon the fair supposed widow. The female heart could not resist the combined force of sympathy, charity and love, and the Mrs. G. became Mrs. TURNER. Life with its ceaseless changes rolled on, endearing the new husband in the affections of the erst-while lonely and forgotten woman, and added fresh olive buds to her peaceful home circle. We must, however, hasten to the conclusion. Yesterday the "original" Mr. G., the veritable first husband, entered the domicile of the happy Mr. and Mrs. TURNER. His body bore tokens of his bravery, and his face was deeply graved with his trials and hardships. After the first surprise was over the three calmly seated themselves to consider the anomalous position of the parties toward each other. Each of the men urged his affection for the lady, and each declared he sought but her happiness, and was willing to abide her decision to go or stay; and after this full exposition of their sentiments the two men started down the street, leaving the lady of their desire to make her decision uninfluenced by either. When the two returned, the lady announced that she had chosen to cling to her last love, and that she could never look upon her former husband with aught but feelings of friendship and esteem. Mr. G., though evidently disappointed, acquisced, only claiming his children as blood of his blood. This claim could not be controverted, and the father and children quietly and sadly bade adieu to the woman they had known as wife and mother and departed for the South. -- St. Louis Republican

abstract: A visit was made on Friday night by Sergeant LE FERTS, of the Fourth District Police Court, with details from the various Precincts, on several gambling saloons in Broadway and elsewhere. At No. 818 Broadway fifteen persons were captured, together with a quantity of gambling implements and $1,054 in cash. Yesterday the prisoners were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, but for want of sufficient evidence all were discharged with the exception of three. No arrests were made by any of the other squads the gamblers having in some mysterious manner got wind of the movements of the police.
lead_paragraph: A visit was made on Friday night by Sergeant LE FERTS, of the Fourth District Police Court, with details from the various Precincts, on several gambling saloons in Broadway and elsewhere. At No. 818 Broadway fifteen persons were captured, together with a quantity of gambling implements and $1,054 in cash. Yesterday the prisoners were taken before Justice CONNOLLY, but for want of sufficient evidence all were discharged with the exception of three. No arrests were made by any of the other squads the gamblers having in some mysterious manner got wind of the movements of the police.

abstract: Merivault vs. S. S. McDonald; collision
snippet: Merivault vs. S. S. McDonald; collision
lead_paragraph: Henry de Mericault vs. The Steamboat McDonald. -- This was a case of collision. The libel was filed by the libelant as master of the French war steamer Tisiphone, to recover the damages occasioned to her by being run into by a barge in tow of the McDonald, on the 25th of November, 1863. The libel alleged that the Tisiphone was lying at anchor in the East River, where she had a perfect right to be, and was negligently run into by the barge in tow of the McDonald. The answer denied that the Tisiphone was anchored where she had a right to be, and alleged that, on the contrary, she was "moored contrary to the regulations of the port, in an improper and unsafe place, and in the track of vessels, where she was not compelled to be and had no right to be." It also claimed that the libelant had no right to bring the action, but this objection was waived on the trial.

abstract: ABATEMENT OF THE CHOLERA IN THE EAST. The United States Consul-General at Constan-  tinople, under date of August 23d, reports to the State Department a sensible abatement in the cholera since his last dispatch. The number of deaths on the 21st was one hundred and forty-three, while heretofore it exceeded two thousand in a single day.

abstract: THE LATE FIRE IN CHERRY-STREET. On the day after the fire in Con's warehouses in Cherry-Street occurred, a committee of the Peard of Underwriters waited on the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners and  requested them to make some arrangements for put  ting more apparatus to work to extinguish the fire which was then smouldering among the ruins.
lead_paragraph: THE LATE FIRE IN CHERRY-STREET. -- On the day after the fire in CO[???]'s warehouses in Cherry-street occurred, a committee of the Board of Underwriters waited on the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners and requested them to make some arrangements for put ting more apparatus to work to extinguish the fire which was then smouldering among the ruins. The committee were told that twelve, steam-engines were out of repair and use at that time. On the following night three more engines broke down, making fifteen useless engines in all. No relief could therefore be given. The committee applied for the police-boat, and that was out of order. They then went to Brooklyn, and the Union Ferry Company, through Hon. CYRUS P. SMITH, President, promply sent two of their steam ferry-boats to the dock, which put on eight streams of water. The committee also hired private engines and tug-boats to work by the day, paying from $15 per hour to $100 per day. The late heavy losses by fire and the evident inefficiency of the fire apparatus, have rendered both insurers and insured extremely anxious as to the present condition of affairs. They feel that if a very extensive fire were to break out the Fire Department, as it exists at present, would be entirely unable to subdue it.

abstract: The society opened their sessions for the Winter, on Thursday evening, at the residence of Dr. PERINE. The secretary called the society's attention to some interesting correspondence from the Rhode Island Society in relation to their proposed medal of ROGER WILLIAMS, and from Mr. BARBER, a distinguished member of the Royal Academy, and now of Providence, concerning a large bronze medallion of LINCOLN, executed under his superintendence. Letters were also...
lead_paragraph: The society opened their sessions for the Winter, on Thursday evening, at the residence of Dr. PERINE. The secretary called the society's attention to some interesting correspondence from the Rhode Island Society in relation to their proposed medal of ROGER WILLIAMS, and from Mr. BARBER, a distinguished member of the Royal Academy, and now of Providence, concerning a large bronze medallion of LINCOLN, executed under his superintendence. Letters were also read from Gen. BUTLER, relative to his army-medal, and from Secretary STANTON, accompanying an encased copy of the war-medal authorized by Congress. Among other donations were a variety of Indian trophies and war-relics, by W.E. MONTGOMERY, of Norwalk, Conn., late of the Eleventh Cavalry Regiment; a Cuban medal of elegant design, and some valuable curiosities, by Mr. G.W. STREET, of New-York; a singular collection of arrow-heads from an ancient Indian encampment near the shore at Deal, New-Jersey, presented by Mr. Seymour; and a list of nearly one hundred silver and bronze coins and medals, chiefly foreign and rare, from a member of the society. The same member, on behalf of a lady of this city, presented a small vase, dug cut at Chiriqui during the image fever, some years ago. The thanks of the society were unanimously tendered to the various donors. The Lincoln medal committee exhibited a rough cast from the obverse die, which gives great promise, The artist, Mr. SIGEL, expects to have the first installment of medals ready by the middle of October. The dies will cost some eight hundred dollars. Several resident members were proposed, and Dr. JAMES A. LANCASTER, Pennsylvania, was elected a correspondent. After a lively discussion on the proposed medal fund and other matters, the members adjourned.

abstract: THE RECENTLY ATTEMPTED WIFE-MURDER. -- PETER CURLEY, the man who stabbed his wife recently, in a fit of jealousy, with a shoemaker's knife, while she was in company with a friend of her's named PETER FARRELL, was brought up on Saturday before Justice WALTER for a hearing. By advice of his counsel, HENRY A. MOORE, the prisoner waived examination, and gave bonds in $1,000 for his appearance before the Grand Jury. Mr. JOHN MALONE became his bondsman. Mrs. CURLEY wan in court, and appeared to be suffering from her injuries.

abstract: N. Y.; "Rocky Moore" Arrested for Robbery with violence
snippet: N. Y.; "Rocky Moore" Arrested for Robbery with violence
lead_paragraph: were again in trouble yesterday, MATTHEW MOORE, otherwise known as "Rocky" MOORE, one of the East Houston-street crew that are alleged to have been concerned in the murder, last Winter, of HENRY LAZARUS, having been arrested for robbery. According to the affidavits, THOMAS SMITH, of Prince-street, who had been gambling in "Fatty" WELSH'S den, in Broadway, near East Houston-street, on the morning of the 19th inst., went from that place with $1,185 in his pockets, and was accompanied by MATTHEW MOORE to a saloon at the intersection of Greene and Prince streets, where MOORE demanded SMITH's money. SMITH refusing to surrender, MOORE garroted him, and took the $1,185 from him; then, springing toward the door, ho was about to escape, but was seized by SMITH. MOORE now drew his revolver, and, placing its muzzle at SMITH's forehead, threatened to blow SMITH's brains out. SMITH having released MOORE, the latter leisurely walked away, coolly remarking that no one need trouble to arrest him, as he had five hundred politicians to aid him out of the meshes of the law. Notwithstanding this threat, Justice DOWLING issued a warrant, on Friday, and Capt. JOHN JOURDAN took the case in hand. Meantime the case was presented to the Grand Jury, and that body promptly brought in a true bill against MOORE for robbery in the first degree, and a bench-warrant was granted by City Judge RUSSEL. On Friday night Capt. JOURDAN and Sergeant QUINN arrested MOORE, and he was committed to the Tombs prison, yesterday morning, without bail.

abstract: A large meeting of workingmen was held last evening at Metropolitan Hall. No. 95 Sixth-avenue, to discuss the question whether or not eight hours are sufficient for a day's toil. snippet: Ireland, Emigration Statistics from
lead_paragraph: The Cork Examiner states that Mr. ADDISON, the well-known London actor, has had a narrow escape of losing his life. Mr. ADDISON, his daughter, and Mr. SOTHERN, visited the celebrated "blarney stone." Nothing daunted by the discovery that the party performing the kissing operation must of necessity be held by the heels over a parapet some hundred feet from the ground, Mr. ADDISON insisted on Mr. SOTHERN seizing him round the ancles, two guides also holding Mr. SOTHERN. The stone was triumphantly kissed, and Mr. SOTHERN becoming rather tired of the novel position of holding 14 stone by the heels, suddenly called out to the guides to pull away. They did so; but the 14 stone, not anticipating such an energetic hoist without some signal, clung to the iron bar by which the celebrated pebble is supported. The consequence was one of Mr. ADDISON's boots came off, and for a short time he was held in this frightful position by one ancle only. By a great effort, however, he at last succeeded in giving Mr. SOTHERN, his other foot, and he was hauled up. During this scene his daughter was so terrified that she became speechless and sunk to the grass.

abstract: Idealists, a Plea for
snippet: Idealists, a Plea for
lead_paragraph: There is a paper in that excellent periodical, the old Spectator, which gives an account of an entomologist, terminating with his death, which took place in consequence of his having overheated himself in his chase after a butterfly. The Spectator makes merry in giving a list of his effects, which mainly consisted of dried spiders, beetles and other small wares of the same nature. The widow of the philosopher, we presume, was not so well satisfied with the returns they produced. Though, indeed, there are cases where collections of apparently insignificant trifles have netted to their more fortunate recipients very considerable fortunes; one antiquary alone, Mr. THOMAS, who died in London in 1850, having left to his son a cabinet of medals which were sold at auction for over $200,000.

abstract: Emigration to Turkey of Natives
snippet: Emigration to Turkey of Natives
lead_paragraph: tinues unabated. Two thousand Tehechers, with their arms, horses and cattle have been received at Kars by the Turkish authorities, having been conducted thither by Russian officers. The whole of the tribe, numbering some 60,000 souls, will, it is expected, follow the same route, and be dispersed over the district of Mouch, Sirvas and Diarbekir. The Kabardians have also intimated their desire to emigrate, but the Porte has replied to their application that it cannot receive them before next year. Another tribe, the Abases, wish to return to their native mountains, and have requested the Turkish Government to furnish them with vessels for the purpose. They have, however, been informed that they can either proceed to Russia by land or be distributed in the provinces of the interior. The latest arrivals in Turkey make the total number of Circassian emigrants encamped on the Asiatic shore of the Black Sea 172,000.

abstract: The steamer New-York, from Aspinwall Sept. 16, arrived at this port yesterday morning, with interesting news from Central and South Ameica. We learn that the revolt in Panama had been entirelysubdued, the rebel leaders, with most of their forces, having surrendered. Col. ALEXANDER R. McKEE,
lead_paragraph: The steamer New-York, from Aspinwall Sept. 16, arrived at this port yesterday morning, with interesting news from Central and South Ameica. We learn that the revolt in Panama had been entirelysubdued, the rebel leaders, with most of their forces, having surrendered. Col. ALEXANDER R. MCKEE, United States Consul at the port of Panama, died at that place after a severe illness. His remains were accompanied to the Foreign Cemetery by Admiral PEARSON, of the United States Navy, and a large number of his officers, as well as by a corps of marines. From Peru we learn that the prospects of the rebels there are not so bright as by previous accounts, and it is now thought the government will succeed in quelling the insurgents. Meanwhile business remains in a most ruinous condition. In Chili the passage of the law tolerating religious worship of all kinds has, at length, been satisfactorily settled. Government has given notice that it will receive tenders for the long-talked-of scheme of steam communication to England via the Straits. Ex-President BARRIOS has been shot in Salvador, after a short trial before a court-martial, which sentenced him to death as a revolutionist. He was a liberal and intelligent man, and his death excited great indignation throughout Central America.

abstract: Merchants themselves are in a great measure to blame for the large amounts of cotton that are stolen from them while their property is being delivered at the wharf; when subpoenaed to prosecute these dock thieves, they think their time more valuable than the property they have lost, and decline to appear to prosecute, hence the thief, after one or two adjournments of the case, is discharged, to resume his or her nefarious life again. Robberies on the docks have been so frequent of late -- and of this fact none are more cognizant than the judges of this court -- that we have no doubt if merchants and their consignees would agree to prosecute in all cases, the court would assist them as far as lies in their power by instructing the clerk of the court to have such cases called first, and they could then all be disposed of on any morning before 10 o'clock. This would not stop thieving on the docks; but it would tend to check it by making punishment sure to follow the committal of crime. Yesterday morning there were three cases of stealing cotton from the docks. One prisoner had stolen only one pound, worth forty cents. The complainant said he appeared to prosecute, because he saw from the TIMES that the crime was so prevalent, and he believed it his duty to help stop the evil. Another prisoner was charged with stealing fifty pounds of cotton, but the complainant failed to appear to prosecute, although the summons had been left with him personally. Unless there is a unanimous movement made in this matter by cotton dealers themselves, they must expect to suffer.

abstract: Jenkins, the, on the Beach Shooting Case
snippet: Jenkins, the, on the Beach Shooting Case
lead_paragraph: Some days ago we read in an evening paper, with that subdivision of sensation which the arrangement of the different phases of an event under as many different captions, is apt to produce in the reader, an account of the suicide of an unhappy priest who cut his throat on the cars somewhere in Massachusetts. We thought at the time it was perhaps one of the finest pieces of writing, in many respects, which we had ever seen. There was an awful simplicity, and a kind of compressed breathlessness, if we may so speak, in the narration, which we found very admirable; we recall with peculiar distinctness the thrill awakened by the description of the conductor who "took the razor from the maniac, closed it, carried it to the other end of the car, and laid it in a place of safety;" after which, we think, he retired and left the madman to his reflections. In this history, -- for though not philosophized narrative, this account certainly rose above mere report in dignity, -- there was visible a certain repression of language and manner which was also extremely fine: a result as from a powerful and glowing imagination, held in check by the chilling probabilities of the editorial management: the stern, rigid, all-but Dantesque compactness of a Jenkins who knew that his noblest sentiment and most eloquent imagery would have been mercilessly lopped away, and who avoided the humiliation by avoiding the obnoxious splendor of diction and thought. We feel sure that the being who produced the history in question, would have added some general observations on suicide; but the same exigency which forbade him to adorn his tale, would not permit him to point his moral. He was therefore obliged, apparently, to tell his story straight-farwardly, and to stop when he got through; to let the homily which would have followed so naturally, rot in his breast, like the suppressed disquisitions of Sancho Panza.

abstract: The Board of Commissioners of Metropolitan Police, striving to exercise their functions in the spirit and to the letter of the law which empowers them to create the Boards of Officers for our next elections, have selected about two thousand of our best citizens and notified them of their appointment; but the com-...
lead_paragraph: The Board of Commissioners of Metropolitan Police, striving to exercise their functions in the spirit and to the letter of the law which empowers them to create the Boards of Officers for our next elections, have selected about two thousand of our best citizens and notified them of their appointment; but the commissioners are seriously apprehensive of difficulty in securing the services of such persons as it is desirable should take charge of the polls, since more than fifty per centum of the appointees have indicated their utter unwillingness to serve. The commissioners desire to appeal to citizens of known integrity and urge them to serve at the polls; else the grade of character of inspectors and canvassers must be lowered. Hosts of ward politicians are anxious candidates. The commissioners will reject their applications if our best men will volunteer to devote to the public the four or five day which are required for election duty; but if reputable and responsible citizens will persist in evading what is regarded as their plain duty, then, under the law, the commissioners must accept the best men that may offer. So many appointees have declined to serve, the commissioners fear that they may not be able to perfect the Election Boards before the close of next week.

abstract: The Academy of Music opens for the season to-night, with GOUNOD's opera of "Faust." This work has been especially selected for the rentree of Miss CLARA LOUISE KELLOGG and the debuts of Signor IRFRE and Signor ANTONUCCI. It would not, of course, ...
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Music opens for the season to-night, with GOUNOD's opera of "Faust." This work has been especially selected for the rentree of Miss CLARA LOUISE KELLOGG and the debuts of Signor IRFRE and Signor ANTONUCCI. It would not, of course, be in good taste to speak at this moment of the gentlemen, but there can be no impropriety in saying that they have been eminently successful at rehearsal. Every one will be glad to welcome Miss KELLOGG back to the operatic stage. She is the favorite of our public, and as Margherita can hardly be excelled by any artist in the world. Signor BELLINI is the Valentine and Mr. MAX MARETZEK will preside in the orchestra. The house will, of course, be most brilliantly attended.

abstract: Grace, Captain of Steamship Erin; Testimonial to
snippet: Grace, Captain of Steamship Erin; Testimonial to
lead_paragraph: TESTIMONIAL TO CAPT. GRACE, OF THE ERIN. -On the last trip of the steamship Erin, a meeting of the cabin passengers was held, AMBROSE SNOW, Esq., presiding, and O. MCMAHON, Esq., acting as Secretary, at which an address was drawn up and presented to Capt. GRACE, expressive of the passengers' appreciation of his abilities and zeal, and of his noble conduct during the terrific storm through which the ship had passed. Subsequent to the meeting, Mr. L. TOPLITZ, of New-York, said he was authorized to express, on behalf of about 80 Israelites in the cabin and steerage, their sincere thanks to Capt. GRACE for his kind permission to celebrate the ceremonies of their New Year, 5626, on board of said vessel, in a portion thereof allotted to them free from interruption.

abstract: Capital, British, Seeking Investment in the Great West
snippet: Capital, British, Seeking Investment in the Great West
lead_paragraph: The visit to this country of the great English capitalists appears not to have been a mere affair of sentiment or pleasure, so far as concerns the principal purpose they had in view. The public is left in no doubt as to what that purpose was. Sir MORTON PETO, in reply to an address presented to him and his co-travelers, on Friday last, by the citizens of Hamilton, (C.W.,) stated briefly and explicitly, that "the object of our visit to the United States is strictly one of business." And at Toledo, in answer to another influential deputation which waited upon the visitors, Sir MORTON, after expressing his wonder at the extent of the yet undeveloped resources of the West, and his conviction that it required only judicious outlay in railroad construction to make them available, added: "We are prepared to recommend, on our return to England, such an expenditure of capital as will lead to a full and fair and free development of your commerce. That will be our interest."

abstract: On Saturday night a pleasant company of Brooklynites met in the Assembly Rooms at the Academy of Music. The band comprised many of the solid men of the city, many of the snobs, many of the fast youth and a few of the politicians.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday night a pleasant company of Brooklynites met in the Assembly Rooms at the Academy of Music. The band comprised many of the solid men of the city, many of the snobs, many of the fast youth and a few of the politicians. On one side of the long room were placed horses, wooden ones, on which rested a platform for the accommodation of several accurate looking gentlemen, a Provost-Marshal's wheel of fortune, Mr. WEIR, the Janitor, and his son. Precisely at 7 o'clock, when the room was filled with smoke and the benches held about two hundred men and boys, Mr. E.J. LOWBER, of various notorieties, mounted the platform and announced that the meeting was of the subscribers to MARETZEK's forthcoming opera season, that the list of names with the number of seats taken by each ward be read, and that then the lottery for choice of seats would be made. Mr. LOWBER read the names and numbers, after which the one hundred and fifty odd numbers were placed in the Provost-Marshal's wheel. A veteran with a long nose and but little energy (a member of the old Fourteenth,) was deputed to turn the wheel, while Mr. JONES kept the record. Mr. WEIR, Jr., held the schedule of seats, and Mr. LOWBER made out the checks. The wheel turned and the lucky name of GRIMES was recorded as the first chooser. Many bitter jokes were made on the fortunate GRIMES. One person suggested that old GRIMES was dead long ago, another that this was a son of the old and well-known individual whose coat buttoned down before, but despite all this Mr. GRIMES walked up smilingly and selected two of the worst seats in the house with manifest trepidation.

abstract: sells in Texas at 5 cents ???; Assorting Machine of, (Clearing House)
snippet: sells in Texas at 5 cents ???; Assorting Machine of, (Clearing House)
lead_paragraph: A City Bank correspondent suggests that there is neither necessity nor economy in running a hostile assorting machine against the National Banks outside of New-York, as all the commercial centres, West as well as East, named in the Law for Country redemptions, are compelled to redeem their own Notes in New-York. Mr. GALLATIN, we believe, made this point at the first meeting of Bank Officers, as against combining with Boston and Philadelphia for an expensive Assorting House. To seal up their Notes, already convertible into Legal Tender here, or to send home the Notes of the Pennsylvania, New-England and other Country Banks, which these centres redeem for, (except in the adjustment of balances between the three cities,) would be a waste of time and labor and vexatious expense and responsibility. And then, as to the Western redeeming centres, they too, are compelled to keep their own Notes good for Greenbacks in New-York, and outside of these, redeem at their counters or give checks on New-York for the Notes of only 186 Country Banks in their immediate vicinities, out of the whole mass of 1,556 Banks of National Banks' issue in the country.

abstract: FIRES. Between 12 and 1 o'clock on Saturday morning, a fire broke out in the oil refinery of Mr. CHRISTOPHER, corner of Ferris and Sullivan streets. In the attempt to extinguish the flames the watchman, WM. COOPER, was severly burned.
lead_paragraph: FIRES. -- Between 12 and 1 o'clock on Saturday morning, a fire broke out in the oil refinery of Mr. CHRISTOPHER, corner of Ferris and Sullivan streets. In the attempt to extinguish the flames the watchman, WM. COOPER, was severly burned. The loss amounts to about $1,000; no insurance. An alarm of fire on Saturday morning was caused by the bursting of a still in the oil factory of RUSSELL & LIBBEY, in Walcott-street, near Conover. Damage slight. Shortly after 1 o'clock on Sunday morning a fire occurred on the upper floor of PRIME & CO.'s grocery in Fulton-street. Supposed to have been caused by a lighted pipe, carelessly left lying among some papers in the water closet. Damage, $200; insured.

abstract: The machinery department of the fair is now in working order, and will be visited to-day by Gen. HOOKER, who will make a critical examination of all the new inventions, and, it is reported, will on some future evening give a lecture on the articles on exhibition. The floral show begins to-day, and it promises to be very attractive. There are already some remarkable specimens of ferns and rare plants on exhibition, and a very fine specimen of the cocoanut tree, ten feet high. A large collection of orchids or air plants, the flowers of which bear a strong resemblance to the forms of many birds and insects, are already entered for exhibition.

abstract: Emperor, the Private Cabinet of
snippet: Emperor, the Private Cabinet of
lead_paragraph: In the Palace of the Tuileries, or in whatever imperial residence the Emperor of the French may be, he is ever accompanied by what is termed "Le Cabinet de l'Empereur," meaning his Private Secretary or chef a sous chef, and two attaches of the first official -- four huissiers or ushers, and a copyist. These form the Private Cabinet of his Majesty, and the Chief or First Secretary is looked upon as one of the most important personages in France. The well-known Monsieur MOCQUARD filled this post up to last year, the date of his death. The duties of the Chef are varied and numerous. He is generally called upon to prepare all the public speeches made by the Emperor, to look over and arrange in accordance with their importance, the dispatches, letters and petitions addressed to his Majesty, while he is to answer them or give directions to his attaches as to the will of the sovereign in each case. Persons desiring audiences of the Emperor receive their replies from the Chef du Cabinet, and as he is allowed great latitude in deciding whether the applications shall ever reach his imperial master, his own importance is from this very fact vastly increased. Each morning the Chef receives from his subordinates the documents to be presented to the Emperor. He selects from the number such as are to be at ouce answered, and with a scratch of his pen disposes of a petition for pardon, for advancement, relief, &c. Non scrawled over an epistle means that the attache shall make a decided refusal. A curt peremptory "no" is to be addressed to the unlucky person who wrote the petition -- "Desole, mais pas possible" -- (very sorry, but it is not possible,) is understood by the attache to mean that a polite note of regret shall be sent in this case.
headline: {'main': "FRANCE.; The Emperor Napoleon's Private Cabinet.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "FRANCE.; The Emperor Napoleon's Private Cabinet.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Progress of; Alabama Convention, the Action of
snippet: The Progress of; Alabama Convention, the Action of
lead_paragraph: The Alabama Convention has adopted an ordinance forever interdicting slavery, and making it the duty of the Legislature to enact laws for the protection of the freedmen. It is identical with that of Mississippi, and is passed with yet closer approach to unanimity -- the vote being eighty-nine against three. There is little doubt that the vote, yet to be taken, on the report of the committee declaring the secession ordinance null and void, will show a similar preponderance. All the proceedings of the convention thus far denote that it is animated with an excellent spirit. Like that of Mississippi, it is generally composed of old Whigs, who originally were utterly opposed to the secession movement. They belonged to the Union party of 1860, which in all probability, would have defeated the secession ordinance had it been submitted to the people, and which actually did carry more than one-third of the secession convention itself against that measure -- the vote then being sixty-one to thirty-nine. Their present earnestness and good faith cannot be doubted.

abstract: The great four-oared race between the picked oarsmen of Newburgh and New-York will come off upon the Hudson River, at Sing Sing, this afternoon, between the hours of 1 and 3 o'clock. The purse to be rowed for is $2,000, the distance five miles -- two and one-half miles down the river toward New-York and return. The Newburgh crew will consist of the four brothers WARD; the New-York crew is the same as won in Boston and Poughkeepsie, with the exception of JOHN J. ECKERSON and JOHN BLUE, who will row in the place of two of the old crew. The WARDS will pull a row-boat built by STEPHEN ROBERTS, of Harlem. The New-Yorkers will pull in one of CHAS. B. ELLIOTT's shells. The Newburgh crew went to Sing Sing last Wednesday. The New-York crew and boat went up the river on Saturday morning on the steamboat Norwalk. The steamboat Metamora will make an excursion to Sing Sing to-day, to carry parties to witness the race. She will leave Broome-street, East River, at 8 o'clock A.M.; Pier No. 4, North River, at 8:30 o'clock; Christopher-street at 9 o'clock, and Thirteenth-street at 9:30 o'clock, returning to the city at an early hour in the evening.

abstract: Mr. SAMUEL H. JOHNSON, agent of the Sing Sing Prison, telegraphed to Police Headquarters, yesterday, asking him to send a platoon or more policemen to attend the boat race on the Hudson, to-day. President ACTON thought that inasmuch as New-York would probably send a delegation of a thousand thieves, it was certainly her duty to send at least fifty officers to watch them. Accordingly he ordered that that number of officers be detailed, and last evening Inspector CARPENTER sent off, on board Harbor Police Boat No. 1, fifty men, under Capt. THOMAS STEERS, of the Thirteenth Precinct. These officers are prepared for any emergency.

abstract: Algonquin Trial; Five hour test
snippet: Algonquin Trial; Five hour test
lead_paragraph: The five-hour test was completed shortly after 3 o'clock on Friday afternoon, and at 4 o'clock the fires were hauled from the furnaces of both vessels; twelve hundred pounds of wood were served out with which to start new fires, and all the coal and ashes in the fire rooms was hoisted out and weighed. At 4:22 P.M. the Algonquin lighted her fires, the steam gauge indicating a pressure of twenty-one and five-tenths pounds of steam. At 4:47, steam being at sixty-eight pounds, the engine was started. At 6:03 the spring in the indicator wheel broke.

abstract: At an early hour yesterday morning a delegation from the municipal officials of the city of St. Louis arrived at the Astor House. The object of the visit of the party is to view the various municipal institutions of our city, as they have already done those of Philadelphia, and afterward to proceed to Boston for a similar purpose. The party consists of A. Valle, Esq., President of the City Council of St. Louis, and Messrs. F.W. Croenbold, H. Gcheoman, A.G.W. Gordon, J. Cheever, P. Driscoll, D. McAuliff, Charles Borg, Charles Gohoenbeck, A. Pritchard and H.C. Gempp, members of the Council. There are also with the delegation Hon. John Hogan, M.C.; I.J. Homer, City Engineer; Hon. C.C. Simmons, United States Senator; M.G. Rem, Superintendent of City Parks; W.P. Curtis, W.R. Pritchard, Superintendents Water Works, and several representatives of the Western press. Hon. G.W. Dreyen, ex-member of the Council, directs their movements.

abstract: Off Matinicock Point, at about daybreak Saturday morning, the propeller Occanus, of the NewYork and Providence line, came into collision with the sloop Jacob Duryea, striking her nearly amidship, and nearly cutting her in two.
lead_paragraph: Off Matinicock Point, at about daybreak Saturday morning, the propeller Oceanus, of the New-York and Providence line, came into collision with the sloop Jacob Duryea, striking her nearly amidship, and nearly cutting her in two. The Oceanus was instantly backed from the spot, and the sloop, filling with water, began to careen; but before she had filled, Capt. YOUNG, of the Oceanus, threw a line to the Duryea, which enabled two of the sloop's male passengers to reach the steamer. Boats were also sent from the Oceanus to the wreck, and all but three of the residue of the passengers were saved. The three that perished on board the sloop were Mrs. SARAH E. DAVIS and her two children, EMMA W. and HATTIE B. DAVIS, infants of 7 and 20 months respectively, who were in the cabin at the time of the collision. Capt. YOUNG tarried by the Duryea until daylight, when the bodies of Mrs. DAVIS and one of the children were recovered, and the wreck was towed into Glen Cove Landing. Thence the Oceanus took the bodies and the rescued passengers to this city, and on reaching the Robinson-street pier sent information to Coroner COLLIN.

abstract: An eminent, though not prominent, Confederate officer, who served as chief of BEAUREGARD'S staff during the greater part of the war, and who, during the first and later stages of military operations, had unsurpassed opportunities for acquiring knowledge as to the ...
lead_paragraph: An eminent, though not prominent, Confederate officer, who served as chief of BEAUREGARD's staff during the greater part of the war, and who, during the first and later stages of military operations, had unsurpassed opportunities for acquiring knowledge as to the opinions, plans and actions of some of the most notable rebel chieftains, has contributed to Harper's Magazine a review of the part played in affairs by JEFFERSON DAVIS. Gen. JORDAN discusses DAVIS' personal character and peculiarities, his line of conduct while President, his influence on the conduct of the war, his relations with leading Generals, and the effect of his deeds and misdeeds in producing the downfall of the Southern Confederacy. The leading thought of the article is not altogether new; but it is enforced and illustrated by such an array of curious and novel facts and circumstances, by such a mass of evidence known heretofore to but few individuals, South or North, that it must be regarded us a valuable historical aid in comprehending the extraordinary times through which we have just passed.

abstract: Union vs. Active at Hoboken
snippet: Union vs. Active at Hoboken
lead_paragraph: On the 4th of July last the Active Club went to Morrisania to play their first match with the Union Club, and they returned home a defeated party by a score of 25 to 16. On the 19th of August the return match was played on the Active's ground, the Unions this time being the victims. This necessitated a third match, and the home and home game took place on the neutral ground of the St. George Cricket Club, on Saturday last, the result being the signal success of the Actives by a score of 32 to 10. In the two first games the Unions opened play with the lead, but on Saturday the second innings terminated with a lead for the Actives by a score of 19 to 1, the Unions playing very loosely in the field. Afterwards they improved considerably in their play, and but for the heavy score against them in the early part of the match the totals would not have been so different. The match was witnessed by a large crowd of spectators, and in the latter part of it it proved to be quite interesting. We append the score:

abstract: INAUGURAL SERMON OF REV. DR. MATTISON. -- Dr. MATTISON, who has just been appointed to the pastorate of Trinity M.E. Church, Jersey City, preached his inaugural discourse yesterday morning, from Acts x, 29: Therefore came I unto you, without gainsay, as soon as I was sent for; I ask, therefore, for what intent ye have sent for me? His theme was the office and work of the Christian minister, in the discussion of which he was portrayed as a Divine Ambassador, a Religious Teacher, a Spiritual Watchman, an Evangelist, and an Under Shepherd or Pastor; in all of which relations his duties and responsibilities were forcibly presented. The doctor fully indicated his future policy in reference to the church he had come to serve, the youth of the congregation, the pastors and members of other churches, civil rulers and the laws, and the current issues of the times. Discarding the discussion of all merely political issues upon the Sabbath, he claimed it to be both his privilege and his duty, as a minister of Christ, to discuss moral and religious questions just as freely when they become involved in politics, as if they were not thus involved. He should not throw overboard any part of the Gospel of Christ, merely because the politicians had carried it into the political arena. A large audience was in attendance, and the sermon was listened to with marked attention.

abstract: During the fair at Danville, Ky., recently, an [???] occurred between some negro soldiers and the citizens, which for a time created a great deal of excitement. At the amphitheatre, on the fair grounds, four negro soldiers were promenading around among the white people. The marshal, named MOORE, a returned Confederate, went to them and told them to go around and occupy a place amongst the negroes on the premises. Three of the four started willingly, but the fourth grew somewhat stubborn, and was being pushed down stairs by MOORE and another gentleman, when the negro drew his pistol and fired, shooting the gentleman in the breast. The negro got with the other three, and by this time the citizens grew excited, and hunted up the negroes. They found them, and a general fight took place. The negroes emptied their pistols at the citizens, but they were each of them shot, and it is said all were dangerously wounded.

abstract: Fashion Course. Com. Vanderbilt and Toronto, trot for $5,000
snippet: Fashion Course. Com. Vanderbilt and Toronto, trot for $5,000
lead_paragraph: The fourth of the matches for $5,000 each came off at the Fashion Course on Saturday, and created the customary excitement among the immediate patrons of the trotting turf. Saturday is a bad day to attract a crowd, added to which the morning was low ering and threatened rain, hence many who would otherwise have been present deferred their intention, doubtful if the race would come off, consequently the attendance was more select than numerous.

abstract: were again in trouble yesterday, MATTHEW MOORE, otherwise known as "Rocky" MOORE, one of the East Houston-street crew that are alleged to have been concerned in the murder, last Winter, of HENRY LAZARUS, having been arrested for robbery. According to the affidavits, THOMAS SMITH, of Prince-street, who had been gambling in "Fatty" WELSH's den, in Broadway, near East Houston-street, on the morning of the 19th inst., went from that place with $1,185 in his pockets, and was accompanied by MATTHEW MOORE to a saloon at the intersection of Greene and Prince streets, where MOORE demanded SMITH's money. SMITH refusing to surrender, MOORE garroted him, and took the $1,185 from him; then, springing toward the door, he was about to escape, but was seized by SMITH. MOORE now drew his revolver, and, placing its muzzle at SMITH's forehead, threatened to blow SMITH's brains out. SMITH having released MOORE, the latter leisurely walked away, coolly remarking that no one need trouble to arrest him, as he had five hundred politicians to aid him out of the meshes of the law. Notwithstanding this threat, Justice DOWLING issued a warrant, on Friday, and Capt. JOHN JOURDAN took the case in hand. Meantime the case was presented to the Grand Jury, and that body promptly brought in a true bill against MOORE for robbery in the first degree, and a bench-warrant was granted by City Judge RUSSEL. On Friday night Capt. JOURDAN and Sergeant QUINN arrested MOORE, and he was committed to the Tombs prison, on Saturday morning, without bail.....Between 3 and 4 o'clock, on Saturday morning,

snippet: Sermon on Negro Suffrage
lead_paragraph: Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER has renewed his regular ministrations at Plymouth Church, and yesterday availed himself, morning and evening, of the opportunity to instruct his people, and an immense audience of outsiders, in the way they should go, politically and morally, on the great questions of the day; assuming that, sooner or later, the entire people of this country will become participants in the discussion of negro suffrage. Mr. BEECHER, in the morning, preached a powerful sermon, drawn from the story of Christ washing his disciples' feet, thereby inculcating the doctrine that the superior should, by virtue of his superiority, serve the inferior; that the Lord and Master should become the minister or servant, and that thenceforth the law of love, which insists upon the extension of aid and service from the strong to the weak, should be enforced. This example, set by the founder of the Christian religion, is before all his followers, and what was done by him has become the duty of every man.

abstract: Charges of malfeasance in office have been preferred against myself and other City Officials. They were presented to the Governor, who appointed the 26th instant to receive our answers or defense. I would have addressed you in regard to them at an earlier day ...
lead_paragraph: Charges of malfeasance in office have been preferred against myself and other City Officials. They were presented to the Governor, who appointed the 26th instant to receive our answers or defense. I would have addressed you in regard to them at an earlier day, only that a serious illness, which confined me to my house for over two weeks, prevented my giving attention to any except purely official business which imperatively required action. The charges against me emanate from two of my personal and political enemies, who are actuated by a low spirit of revenge. One of them, the editor of the New-York Atlas, adopts this method to redress his private griefs. and has for along time persisted in an abortive at tempt to injure my reputation. The other is an individual who has never forgiven me for making known to the proper authorities his official dereliction. Both these persons are versed in the matter of official misconduct, as the records of the County sufficiently at test. If I looked merely at the character of these accusers I would not notice their attack. But holding an important station, to which I was chosen by the electors of this County, and having a proper regard for public opinion, I deem it proper to make this statement to the community.

abstract: Dismal News From the South
snippet: Dismal News From the South
lead_paragraph: The Mobile Daily News comes to us with a whole column of intelligence devoted to the discouragement of free society everywhere, and more especially in the South. There, it appears, according to this dismal column, free soil has bred such rank growth of free manners that the former slaves are ruling everything; and even the Oberlin theory that a white man, if he behaves himself, is as good as a negro, is rejected by the dominant color. In New-Orleans it seems they fire upon brothers-in-law of old and respected citizens; at Knoxville they shoot white men in the legs; at Jackson they dwell in tents on the borders of the town, and get their communities broken up and scattered by the efficient provost-marshal; employed as troops in Texas, they are hard to be kept from murdering their white officers; at Macon their females get into rows just below editors' offices, and pull each other's wool; and on the plantations near that city, though quite unarmed, they strive to kill the Federal guards placed there to protect the whites; at Savannah, colored damsels, formerly servants in respectable families, marry white Lieutenants in negro regiments; at church fairs in Louisville they pistol one another; while, as we are told elsewhere in the paper, they are mistaken for raccoons in the woods near Eufaula, get blazed away at by hunters, and badly peppered in their arms; nay, they thus cause themselves to be shot under circumstances of which reporters can learn none of the particulars.

abstract: who were arrested by Sergt. WILLIAM H. LEFFERTS, of the Fourth District Police Court, on Friday evening, and against whom ex-Judge STEWART did not appear on Saturday morning, have informed Sergt. LEFFERTS that the proprietors of the five gambling-saloons which were visited by the down-town police, and which were found to have been deserted at the early hour of 11 o'clock, had been previously notified by some person who, probably, forged ex-Judge STEWART's signature, that a raid was contemplated, and could be prevented by the payment of money. The gamesters say that, having gained this information, they "piped" certain police-stations, and on Friday night, when their pickets saw a number of policemen assembling, they promptly notified their employers, and the gambling-rooms were cleared instanter.

abstract: On Sunday afternoon F.G.H. BEHRENDS, a young German of 27 years, committed suicide at No. 169 Eldridge-street, by taking poison. Little is known of the young man beyond the fact that he took lodgings about three weeks ago at the place where he committed suicide, and, not having found employment, had been quite intemperate and misanthropic. Dr. JOHN BEACH made a post-mortem investigation, but was unable to ascertain what poison the suicide had taken.

abstract: The reductions in the expenses of the government during the last four months have been on a gigantic scale. In the naval and military departments, as well as in collateral branches like that of the Provost-Marshal-General, the nation has been relieved of heavy burdens. Military reductions are still going on upon a considerable scale throughout the country, and naval vessels and stock are being disposed of as rapidly as possible. We trust the government will permit no pause in the progress of retrenchment and economy. They have many other applications, beside those already made, which would not be difficult to point out. Not to speak of the actual necessities of the case, not to speak of the moralities involved, the Republican administration and the Republican party can gain immense credit and strength, for the present and the future, by giving to the country the example of an upright and economical administration of public affairs. The Democratic party has always been a party of extravagance, waste and corruption. The administration of President LINCOLN was necessarily one of unprecedented expenditures. But now that that necessity has gone by, the present ruling party has an opportunity of acquiring distinction by the practice of rigid economy, and thus of attaching the people to it by lightening the popular burdens. We trust this opportunity will not be allowed to pass away.

abstract: ASSAULTING A NEW-YORK POLICEMAN. On the 14th inst., Policeman BENJAMIN DEVOY, of the Seventh Precinct, New-York, and who resides at No. 62 Remsen-street, E.D., was crossing to New-York in one of the ferry-boats plying to Grand-street, when he found it necessary to take into custody a passenger named JAMES DORSEY, whose residence is at No. 159 Worthstreet, New-York.
lead_paragraph: ASSAULTING A NEW-YORK POLICEMAN. -- On the 14th inst., Policeman BENJAMIN DEVOY, of the Seventh Precinct, New-York, and who resides at No. 62 Remsen-street, E.D., was crossing to New-York in one of the ferry-boats plying to Grand-street, when he found it necessary to take into custody a passenger named JAMES DORSEY, whose residence is at No. 159 Worth-street, New-York. It seems that a woman employed on the ferry-boat woke up DORSEY, who had been asleep, when he abused her in a virulent manner, and she called upon Officer DEVOY to arrest him. DORSEY then assaulted the officer in a cruel manner, but he was finally taken before Judge MANSFIELD, who decided that he had no jurisdiction, and the prisoner was yesterday taken before Judge DAILEY for trial. The assault having been proven, DORSEY was fined $100 or three months in County Jail.

abstract: FENIANS ON A RAMPAGE. Three young men named MICHAEL DONLIN, JOHN JONES and MARTIN  HENLEY, arrested by Officers RAMSEY and ROSE, were  taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, yesterday morning, charged with having on Sunday evening conducted themselves in a very disorderly manner in one of the Jersey City and Hoboken cars. It was alleged that the prisoners, while intoxicated, entered one of the cars with cigars in their mouths.
lead_paragraph: FENIANS ON A RAMPAGE. -- Three young men named MICHAEL DONLIN, JOHN JONES and MARTIN HENLEY, arrested by Officers RAMSEY and ROSE, were taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, yesterday morning, charged with having on Sunday evening conducted themselves in a very disorderly manner in one of the Jersey City and Hoboken cars. It was alleged that the prisoners, while intoxicated, entered one of the cars with cigars in their mouths. There being some women in the car, the conductor requested them to desist from smoking, which they refused to do, and conducted themselves in a very boisterous manner, using foul and blasphemous language, until the police were called and they were taken to the lock-up. In the cells the ruffians conducted themselves in the most disorderly manner, and announcing themselves as Fenians, threatened that as soon as they should get out, they would raise a mob of brother Fenians and demolish the City Prison. Recorder MARTINDALE required them to pay a fine of $5 each.

abstract: Fenians, the Agitation in Ireland
snippet: Fenians, the Agitation in Ireland
lead_paragraph: in Ireland, according to the advices received last night by the Moravian, continues to excite alarm in England, and the British Government appears to be quietly but promptly taking measures to quell instantly any attempt at open revolt. Little, however, is really known of the numbers or the intentions of the Fenians. The papers are all at sea in regard to the movement, hardly knowing whether to treat it as a ridiculous bugbear, gotten up for mere political effect, or a serious attempt to precipitate the sister island into revolution. The London Times counsels precautionary measures, but professes to regard the whole affair as a piece of wanton agitation, confined to a small portion of the poorer laboring class, and believes it will never come to a genuine revolt. The Daily News, on the other hand, sees trouble ahead, unless the government shall take the earliest opportunity to show its repressive power. It asserts that there is no time to be lost; that the repression must be prompt and complete; and that it would be a mercy to Ireland if every Fenian leader were at once brought to trial.

abstract: Col. SAM'L THOMAS, Assistant Commissioner for Freedmen's Affairs, in an official communication dated Vicksburgh, Sept. 14, while giving his returns for August, says the records in that part of Mississippi are destroyed, and that persons are reluctant to supply the missing information. He states that 115 plantations are leased in Louisiana; 57 of them by whites, and 58 by blacks; also 136 in Mississippi, 113 of them by whites, and 23 by blacks. There are 13,500 acres in 81 plantations in Louisiana and Mississippi leased to blacks, and 52,800 acres in the same States, in 170 plantations, leased to whites. About one-half of the lands leased to whites was abandoned owing to the overflow of the Mississippi. A tremendous pressure is being brought to bear by returned citizens of all classes to get possession of their property. They are constantly writing to the President and the heads of the different bureaus at Washington, filled with all kinds of misrepresentations in order to effect their purposes. The Colonel says no property has been libeled for confiscation, and that he has made no attempt to distribute land in small lots to negroes, as he knew it would meet with strong opposition from all parties. It would require a hero to execute it, and a military force to protect the freedmen during the term of their lease. If, he adds, the militia is organized, as foreshadowed by Gov. SHARKEY's proclamation and indorsed by the President, he has no idea that the freedmen will remain quiet laborers in the cotton fields. They are excited and partially armed. The hope of organizing the labor of the State in such a way that the freedmen will return to the fields and recruit the agricultural wealth of the State as free laborers, seems to vanish with the promulgation of this military order. In conclusion, he says he hears of but little trouble between freedmen and their employers. Nearly all the colored people of the State working on plantations have been contracted with, and employers are anxious to make contracts for the year 1866, for fear labor will be hard to get at the beginning of the season.
lead_paragraph: Col. He states that 115 plantations are leased in Louisiana; 57 of them by whites, and 58 by blacks; also 136 in Mississippi, 113 of them by whites, and 23 by blacks. There are 13,500 acres in 81 plantations in Louisiana and Mississippi leased to blacks, and 52,800 acres in the same States, in 170 plantations, leased to whites. About one-half of the lands leased to whites was abandoned owing to the overflow of the Mississippi. A tremendous pressure is being brought to bear by returned citizens of all classes to get possession of their property. They are constantly writing to the President and the heads of the different bureaus at Washington, filled with all kinds of misrepresentations in order to effect their purposes. The Colonel says no property has been libeled for confiscation, and that he has made no attempt to distribute land in small lots to negroes, as he knew it would meet with strong opposition from all parties. It would require a hero to execute it, and a military force to protect the freedmen during the term of their lease. If, he adds, the militia is organized, as foreshadowed by Gov. SHARKEY's proclamation and indorsed by the President, he has no idea that the freedmen will remain quiet laborers in the cotton fields. They are excited and partially armed. The hope of organizing the labor of the State in such a way that the freedmen will return to the fields and recruit the agricultural wealth of the State as free laborers, seems to vanish with the promulgation of this military order. In conclusion, he says he hears of but little trouble between freedmen and their employers. Nearly all the colored people of the State working on plantations have been contracted with, and employers are anxious to make contracts for the year 1866, for fear labor will be hard to get at the beginning of the season.

abstract: Lamoriciere, the French General
snippet: Lamoriciere, the French General
lead_paragraph: Foreign news, received last night, announces the death of CHRISTOPHE LEON LOUIS JUCHAULT DE LAMORICIERE, the well-known French General. He was of the old Legitimist stock, was educated in the college at Nantes, in the Polytechnic School of Paris, and in the Academy of Military Engineers at Metz, on leaving which (says the American Cyclopaedia) he joined the Algerian army, and entered the corps of Zouaves at the time of its formation (November, 1830.) Placed in 1833 at the head of the office (burean Arabe) organized by Gen. AVIZARD, for the purpose of facilitating the relations with the native population, his intercourse with the Arabs became as useful to him as it was agreeable to them. Depending solely upon the influence of kindness and affability, he carried about his person, in his exploration of the country, no other means of defence than a light cane; hence the name of Bou Aroua, or father of the cane, conferred upon him by the Arabs. He took an active part in the capture of Constantino, the expedition against Mascara, the battle of Isly and many other engagements. He commanded the Zouaves for several years until June, 1840, when he was succeeded by CAVAIGNAC. The celebrity of the Zouaves was chiefly due to the skill which from the beginning LAMORICIERE had brought to bear upon their organization. In November, 1845, on the departure of Gen. BUGEAUD, he became provisional Governor-General of Algeria, but went to France in 1846, in the hope of being able to exert a favorable influence upon the destiny of the African colony, by taking part in the parliamentary discussions on the subject. At first defeated as candidate for one of the arrondissements of Paris, he was elected to the Chamber in October, 1846, as member for St. Calais, Sarthe. Returning to Algeria soon after, he crowned his military career by organizing the expedition against ABDEL-KADER, which finished the war. He was reelected to the Chamber of Deputies in 1847, and when the revolution of Feb., 1848, broke out, exerted himself in favor of the formation of a new administration under LOUIS PHILIPPE, and, as Colonel of the National Guard, went among the people assembled on the Boulevards, in order to allay the public excitement. But he was not listened to, and, after the abdication of LOUIS PHILIPPE, he was slightly wounded while on his way to the Palais Royal, to proclaim the regency of the Duchess of Orleans. He soon recovered however, and on the same evening tendered his allegiance to the provisional government. He took his seat in the Constituent Assembly as a member for Sarthe, and became prominent in the Committee on Military Affairs. During the bloody days of June, 1848, he fought with so much spirit against the insurgents that three horses were killed under him. He officiated as Gen. CAVAIGNAC's Minister of War until Dec., 1848, and was instrumental in introducing various measures for the benefit of Algeria. He strenuously opposed the election of LOUIS NAPOLEON to the Presidency, and even questioned his right to citizenship. Being elected to the Legislative Assembly, he became President of the Constitutional Committee, and opposed the projects of the ultra radical party. In the course of the Hungarian struggle with Austria, he was intrusted with a diplomatic mission to Russia; but on his arrival there the Hungarians had already been crushed by the armed interference of the Czar. On hearing of the overthrow of ODILON BARROT's administration (Oct. 31, 1849) he returned to France, and resumed his seat in the Legislative Assembly. After the coup d'etat of Dec. 2, 1851, he was arrested, and detained in the fortress of Ham until Jan. 9, 1852, when he was permitted to go to Prussia. A letter of his, refusing to recognize the government of LOUIS NAPOLEON, was published in May, 1852. He afterward successively resided in Coblentz, Montz, Wiesbaden and Ems. In April, 1860, having gone to Rome for the purpose, he was appointed by Pope PIUS IX. Commander-in-Chief of the papal troops, but after a brief service retired to private life.
