abstract: Diplomatic Correspondence; Seward's, Secretary, Dispatch on Prioleau Cotton Case
snippet: Diplomatic Correspondence; Seward's, Secretary, Dispatch on Prioleau Cotton Case
lead_paragraph: The bonds on the rebel Cotton Loan declined one per cent., we see, after that famous meeting of Confederate bondholders at the London Tavern, at which was urged so pathetically the bounden duty of the United States, upon international and moral grounds, to assume the Confederate debt. The reason for this fall is stated to be that "the proceedings at the meeting afforded little ground of hope to the bondholders." We suspect that if some one of those parties present, who so cruelly laughed aloud at the idea of the "justice and policy of the Federal Government taking the debt upon itself," could have produced and read to the meeting the dispatch which Mr. SEWARD has written to Mr. ADAMS in reference to the decision of Vice-Chancellor WOOD, the bonds would have fallen considerably more than one per cent. For although the idea of the duty of the United States feeling themselves "internationally and morally bound" to assume the loan was too absurd to be even caught at like a straw by the most desperate of the drowning bondholders, the fact that Mr. PRIOLEAU had by the decree of the Vice-Chancellor been secured against the loss of the 20,000, which he was out of pocket for the Confederacy, and that the bondholders, too, might, by some streak of good luck, be helped in the same way, was a grain, and about the only grain, of comfort which the meeting had. But the hope that any such doctrine, as that on which that decree was based, would ever be accepted by our courts or our government, must have been utterly destroyed by Mr. SEWARD's letter. For he is entirely clear and explicit in his declaration that our government would not accept that doctrine, but claimed the cotton still as theirs, notwithstanding the decision of the Vice-Chancellor. As a matter of precaution it was doubtless well for Mr. SEWARD to send that dispatch to guard against any notion of acquiescence on the part of our government in the doctrines laid down in that decision. For whatever may be the result of the litigation before the English courts, that question involved in it, and many other questions arising out of the rebellion will ultimately have to be settled not by the courts but by the governments themselves. The courts will decide the questions when they are brought up, according to the present views of the respective governments concerning them. Our courts will not hold that the United States are the "successors" of the rebellion, because our government has always maintained, and will, we think, always maintain, in the words of Mr. SEWARD's dispatch that the United States "are now, and during all the time of the rebellion have been, just what they were before the rebellion began, a sovereign State, absolutely entitled to the regulation and control of all property and persons within the United States, subject only to the limitations of their own constitution," and if the English courts hold that we are such successors it is because that view has found favor, as Mr. SEWARD says, "even with the British Government."

abstract: Broadway, Spencer's Glass House--$3,000
snippet: Broadway, Spencer's Glass House--$3,000
lead_paragraph: SHALL A SOLDIER OF THE UNION FILL A PAUPER'S GRAVE? -- An old soldier of the Union, named JOHN ROGERS, who was honorably discharged, on account of sickness, some months before the close of the war, died on Saturday, after a lingering and painful illness, leaving a wife and three children wholly destitute. The widow has no means with which to bury her husband, and unless some benevolent persons step forward and render her the needed assistance her husband must rest in a pauper's grave. Any one who feels stirred to assist this family in burying their husband and father can do so by forwarding a contribution to Mrs. ROGERS, care of the Superintendent of the Working Women's Protective Union, No. 80 White-street.

abstract: Algonquin; Trial of; Cause of Breakdown
snippet: Algonquin; Trial of; Cause of Breakdown
lead_paragraph: Mr. DICKERSON's card in this paper yesterday morning explained the cause of the Algonquin's stoppage. The feed pipe was not of copper, but of cast iron about one-half inch thick, and has the appearance of being a perfect casting. The piece blown out is about seven inches long by three inches wide, and was found lying near the place from whence it came. All that were on board and in the vicinity of the vessel at that time may congratulate themselves upon the fact that it was no worse, and, that it was not some other portion of the machinery. There can be no question but that the high steam carried, and the consequent strain arising from driving a vessel at the dock, tends to use her up, and your reporter has often wondered how she stood it so well. She has had a number of mishaps, all charged to carelessness. If this be the fact, something ought to be done to put more careful people on board, or some time she will go up higher than the Central Park balloon.

abstract: VESSEL SUNK. -- Mr. James M. Clark, Sandy Hook pilot, of the Nettle, No. 20, reports a schooner sunk in 10 fathoms of water, 15 or 20 miles S. by E. from the Highlands. Her foremast is alongside, and the mainmasthead is just out of water. Took from her a part of her gaft-topsail. She lies directly in the way of vessels bound in or out the Hook. About the same time picked up a veseel's yawl and oars. Mr. Clark thinks the vessel was coal-loaded, and that she was run down on Saturday night by one of the many outward bound steamers, and that the crew had been taken on board the steamer and carried South.

ANDREWS advertised that he would give employment at $50 a month and good security to any person that would loan him $200, and Mr. MILLER snapped at the bait and was caught. Having taken Mr. MILLER's money, ANDREWS gave him a certificate of stock in the Matapedea Petroleum Company, and agreed soon to take this stock and give real estate security. Meantime Mr. MILLER was to see him at the New-Haven Railroad station yesterday morning, and the two were to go to Massachusetts, where ANDREWS was to find a situation for his victim. Not finding ANDREWS at the Twenty-sixth-street railway station at the time agreed upon, Mr. MILLER awoke and at once made complaint before Justice DOWLING. abstract: London Times on Shenandoah Pirate
snippet: London Times on Shenandoah Pirate
lead_paragraph: that the Fenians may be successful in raising a powerful rebellion in Ireland, and obtaining the recognition of their belligerent rights on land and sea, appears to have awakened the London Times to a realization of enormities committed against American commerce by the Shenandoah. In a leader, quoted in our summary of European news this morning, it denounces Capt. WADDELL as a pirate, and declares that unless he can clearly show that he had no knowledge of what was known to every one else in the same latitude, he has no claim to mercy. The Times characteristically adds that while England has already done everything required by international law, it would be well, under the circumstances, (that is, circumstances in Ireland,) if British ships of war were instructed to treat the Captain of the Shenandoah as a pirate, and to lend their assistance in putting an end to his wanton and wicked depredations.

abstract: Pres. Johnson's reply to Brazilian Minister; Reply to the Brazilian Minister
snippet: Pres. Johnson's reply to Brazilian Minister; Reply to the Brazilian Minister
lead_paragraph: As the first ship in our new Brazilian line is about starting, to open closer commercial intercourse between Brazil and our own country, the address of the President to the new Brazilian Minister is as fortunate in time as it is felicitous in tone. It manifests much more warmth of feeling than usually marks such state receptions. It evinces clearly that the President attaches peculiar importance to the cultivation of intimate relations with this first of the South American States. His concluding sentence is particularly strong: "If Brazil shall agree with us in this policy we shall hereafter be not only close friends, but practically we shall become firm and fast allies." But this is not the first time that such close relationship with Brazil has been officially suggested. President BUCHANAN's Minister to Brazil, RICHARD K. MEADE, in presenting his credentials, in a memorable speech expressed his hope that the two nations might be brought into the closest alliance. The special motive he assigned, was that the two great slave-holding nations of America needed to combine to resist the anti-slavery pressure of the rest of the world. What is the policy President JOHNSON advances as the basis of this alliance? "Our policy," he says, "is simple and easily to be understood. We wish to promote the progress of civilization in this hemisphere, and for that purpose the development of material resources, the improvement of commerce, and the introduction, as fast as possible, of free intelligent labor into the virgin fields of the continent." Verily, times have changed.

lead_paragraph: FIRES. -- Yesterday afternoon about 5 o'clock, a fire broke out in the stable of Mr. JOHN THOMAS, in the rear of No. 102 Washington-street, from which the flames spread to the adjoining stables of the Coney Island Railroad Company, and to the stable of Mr. LOCKWOOD ABRAHAM. The carpenter shop of DECKER & BUCKLEY next caught, and the flames extended to the stable of HUSTED & CARLL, all of which were totally destroyed. Damage about $3,500. Insured in the Etna Company of Hartford, Conn. The house No. 3 Stewart-street, occupied by EDWARD O'NEIL and ANTHONY JOHNSON, was damaged to the extent of $200. No insurance.

abstract: smoking" on the Bleecker-street and Fulton Ferry cars, there is not and never has been the slightest effort made to enforce the rule. In four rides out of six within the last few days, we have found men smoking (shockingly bad cigars, too,) on the front platform before the open window, so that every particle of the fumes would be driven the entire length of the car. Now, does the company mean to tolerate this, or is it simply neglect on the part of their men? If they approve, let their lying signs be taken down, and persons who do not like smoke will seek other modes of conveyance. If the smoking is not stopped or the signs removed within a week, we shall give the public such further information and advice as the case may demand. As far as we know, there is no such nuisance on any other city line.

abstract: Marshall, Capt. C. H., Proceedings of Public Bodies, Mr. John Jay's Speech
snippet: Marshall, Capt. C. H., Proceedings of Public Bodies, Mr. John Jay's Speech
lead_paragraph: The death of Capt. CHARLES H. MARSHALL has called forth a spontaneous ebullition of sorrow and regret from the various public bodies and institutions with which the deceased was associated. The well-known patriotism and earnest character of Capt. MARSHALL give these manifestations a peculiar interest.

abstract: Pymouth Rock, of Fall River Line; Fire on Board
snippet: Pymouth Rock, of Fall River Line; Fire on Board
lead_paragraph: As the steamer Plymouth Rock of the Fall River line was passing Whitehall-slip on her trip east, last evening, at a quarter past five o'clock, fire was discovered forward of the starboard boiler, and in a short time large volumes of black smoke were seen to ascend, and the boat was headed in for the piers on the East River and stopped. By this time the pumps of the steamer were at work, and the hand pumps were set going with a will seldom equaled. After a detention of eighteen minutes, she proceeded. Not the slightest excitement was shown among the passengers. We saw some ladies sitting aft when the fire commenced who did not leave their seats during the whole time of the burning. The steamers City of New-York and Newport lay close by the Plymouth Rock until all danger was past.
headline: {'main': 'Fire on Board the Steamer Plymouth Rock.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Fire on Board the Steamer Plymouth Rock.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: was preferred by Mr. AUGUSTUS REINBECK against DAVID STEENBERG, alleging that on the 7th of July last he gave STEENBERG $100 worth of jewelry and clothing to sell, and that the goods were sold, but that STEENBERG did not account for them in money, and that subsequently STEENBERG rose early, one morning, and taking $40 from Mr. REINBECK's waistcoat pocket, departed from the room where they had lodged, and was not again seen until he was apprehended, yesterday, by Policeman THEOBALD, of the Thirteenth Ward. The prisoner was committed, in default of $1,000 bail, for trial at the Court of General Sessions.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC -- OPENING OF MR. MARETZEK's SEASON. -- Italian opera has been well described as the most captivating form of the drama. The truthfulness of this definition is found readily in the favor with which every class views so agreeable an institution. Even they who have but little relish for music in itself are captivated with the many accompaniments and surroundings of opera. The ordinary drama has, indeed, borrowed much from its grand cotemporary, and so involuntarily complimented it. There are but few pieces now that do not boast of their new and original music, of their dances and scenery. In melo-drama we have almost reached the recitative. Speaking "through the music" is an ordinary device, and where intonsity is aimed at, prevails in whole scenes. But in Italian opera the senses that best bear refining are appealed to in the most direct way. A fictitious world is created for our pleasure -- a world of poetry, tinted and burnished with the other arts. To penetrate this realm of magic illusion is a privilege that the world has never been slow to acknowledge. Curiously, too, it happens that a practical people generally take most readily to this form of recreation. In New-York opera has become a necessity of every class, and in London it has been found to thrive lustily in the eastern districts, where the bands are horny, and the voices boisterous but honest. When Mr. MARETZEK commences a season, he scarcely considers the subscription list except for the convenience of the habitues. He looks to the amphitheatre, the family circle, the lobbies where "standing room only" is the modest requirement, and there he reads the verdict of the town. He will, we fancy, be satisfied with the one recorded last night. We have rarely seen a more brilliant gathering, or heard applause that was more hearty and encouraging alike to the artists and the manager. The assembly was mainly provincial, and further illustrates our position that the opera is general in its interest and confined to no class.

abstract: Steel Manufacture in America; Boston Advertiser on Ocean Steamship Lines; Ocean Steamship Lines; Action Needed to Establish
snippet: Steel Manufacture in America; Boston Advertiser on Ocean Steamship Lines; Ocean Steamship Lines; Action Needed to Establish
lead_paragraph: and Philadelphia have already moved in the matter of steam communication with Europe, as well as in the establishment of steamship lines to all the chief seaports of the South. Boston is now moving in the same direction. The Directors of the American Steamship Company have felt justified in undertaking to construct the first two steamers of the Boston and Liverpool line. Two steamers have been purchased for the trade between Boston and Havana; and lines to Mobile and to New-Orleans are in operation. We have frequently spoken, since the close of the war, of the importance of the capitalists of this great commercial metropolis taking comprehensive measures for the establishment of American steamship lines, communicating not only with our own ports on the Gulf and the Pacific, but with the ports of Europe, of South America, and of China. Something has already been done in the way of establishing the Brazilian line, and the China line; and we have heard of several hopeful projects for lines to Europe. But nothing has been done, or even projected, compared with what ought at least to be in the way of accomplishment. Capitalists move in this business with a timidity that is certainly very un-American. We should think that if rich men fail of their duty in this matter, the establishment of joint-stock ocean steamship navigation companies, upon a plan in which persons of small means could take stock, might prove successful as well as profitable. A company, for instance, under the supervision of such an experienced man as Capt. MARSHALL, who died last week, would have commanded universal public confidence. It has also been suggested that lines of ocean steamships might be started in connection with and under the auspices of some of our great railroad companies that terminate near the seaboard; and this idea is being carried out in the Baltimore line, we believe.

abstract: Apprenticeship and Albany Trades Convention
snippet: Apprenticeship and Albany Trades Convention
lead_paragraph: MECHANICS. -- We notice that among the questions to be considered at the convention of Trades Societies at Albany is that of regulating the laws of apprenticeship. It is the widespread complaint that, owing to the inefficient system of apprenticeship in this country, the number of good workmen in every branch of the mechanical arts is growing less year by year. Young fellows will go to a shop for a year or so and learn the rudiments of a trade, and then start off for another city where they set themselves up as journeymen. They get employment in consequence of offering to work cheaply, or because of the great demand throughout the country for skilled labor of all grades and kinds, however poorly skilled. Hence we have in the United States such a vast amount of wretched work of every nature, and such vast numbers of wretchedly poor workmen-wretched engineers, wretched carpenters, wretched shoemakers and tailors, wretched printers, wretched members of all the mechanical crafts. Hence, also, really efficient and trained workmen are discredited and damaged, and those who have served a long apprenticeship to a business are put on a level with those who have taken no pains to learn it.

abstract: Cooper vs. Burr; What Constitutes a Gift
snippet: Cooper vs. Burr; What Constitutes a Gift
lead_paragraph: Mary Cooper vs. Melancthon Burr et al. -- This case comes before the General Term on appeal from a judgment entered on a verdict rendered by a jury at the Circuit Court in favor of the plaintiff. In 1830 one Wm. Cooper died, leaving surviving him as heirs-at-law Mary Cooper, a daughter; Mrs. Euphemia J. Barr, Mrs. Howe, Mrs. Ann S. Lyons and Wm. Cooper, all children of one John Cooper, who is a deceased son. The parties above-named are heirs-at-law. A daughter of William Cooper, whose name is Catharine, is also interested in the litigation. The plaintiff, whose real name is Mary Flood, was taken from an asylum when she was about six years old, and brought up and educated by the deceased. This Mary Flood assumed the name of Mary Cooper, her protectress, and by that name she went until the death of the latter, which occurred in August, 1861. After the death of Wm. Cooper, Mary Cooper, after consulting with her relatives as to how she should rid herself of the plaintiff, finally compromised the matter. After her father's death, Mary Cooper resided in Eldridge-street until her decease. During that time she received an annuity of $1,000 from her father's estate, which sum was paid her quarterly by the defendant, after deducting $300 per year for house rent. The amount was always paid in coin, or, by the request of Mary, changed into coin, and this money the latter very carefully secreted in a trundle bed in the house. She practiced this system for many years. At the time of her death, or soon after, there was a large amount of gold coin and jewelry found on the premises.

abstract: A ministerial journal of Berlin says that the payment of indemnity to Austria for the Duchy of Lauenburg will be made for the present from the King of Prussia's privy purse, and that the occupation of Lauenburg will take place without delay. The further settlement of its position toward the Prussian Crown is postponed.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Police--Ought Not to be Employed Out of the City
snippet: Police--Ought Not to be Employed Out of the City
lead_paragraph: the Metropolitan Police had, yesterday, to be sent up the river to Sing Sing, for the protection of the community residing there against a band of New-York thieves, who were expected to witness the boat-race and ply their calling in the town. Several hundred of the lowest ruffians of New-York society are said to have been on hand, and the presence of a strong constabulary force was doubtless required. But the question arises, should New-York be called upon, at her own expense, to furnish protection to outlying towns, on such occasions as this of the Sing Sing boat-race. If these races are of a character to attract hordes of the thieves and vagabonds from the metropolis, there ought to be a special tax levied on those who take part in such sports, to meet all the contingencies of keeping the public peace. Otherwise the community, which is immediately affected by the concourse of lawless characters, should have the power of forbidding such assemblages altogether. It is altogether preposterous that the tax-payers of New-York should be called upon to supply police protection to communities seventy or a hundred miles distant. If the commissioners here are to meet such demands, let them have the power of collecting a special tax to indemnify themselves. The citizens of New-York certainly should not be burdened with such work as this growing out of the Sing Sing boat-race, or any other boat-race.

abstract: The steamship Moravian arrived yesterday off Father Point, with five days later news from Europe. The London Times denounces Capt. WADDELL, of the Shenandoah, as a pirate, and calls upon the British Government to assist in putting an end to his wanton and vindictive depredations. Continued alarm was felt in England at the spread of Fenianism, and some of the papers recommend prompt repressive measures. The channel fleet had been ordered to cruise along the Irish coast. A disturbance had occurred at the seance of the Davenport Brothers in Paris. The brothers were loudly hissed. The police cleared the room and returned the entrance money. One of the spectators discovered their secret. Gen. LAMORICIERE, a distinguished French soldier, is dead. The murder of OLT by the Count EHRENBURGH was being investigated. It is again asserted that France demanded satisfaction for the murder. The political news is unimportant.

abstract: Atlantic,Report and Plans of Directors
snippet: Atlantic,Report and Plans of Directors
lead_paragraph: An extraordinary general meeting of the Atlantic Telegraph Company was held in London on the 14th. The directors presented a report setting forth the results of the late effort, and sanguine expectations for the future deduced therefrom, expressing a determination to press forward with the work, and announcing that they had already entered into a contract for renewed operations. Under this contract the Telegraph Construction Company undertake, for the sum of 500,000 sterling, (that is the mere cost price,) to manufacture and lay down a new cable next year; and if successful, but not otherwise, they are to have in shares and cash and profit of twenty per cent. on this cost. They also undertake, without any further charge whatever, to go to sea with sufficient cable to complete the present broken cable, and use the best endeavors to that end. Carrying out this contract requires that the Atlantic Company should raise a minimum of 250,000 to a maximum of 500,000 sterling in cash, upon which new capital a preferential dividend of twelve per cent. is proposed, with a share in the profits of the dividends to which they are entitled, have been paid on old shares. The report was unanimously adopted, the question of raising capital being left to the final decision of another meeting called for the 12th of October.

abstract: Prophecies of financial crash in 15 years
snippet: Prophecies of financial crash in 15 years
lead_paragraph: -- One of the atrabilious papers, which has always been predicting disasters for the country -- military disasters during the war, and financial disasters ever since its close -- and which is suffering disappointment, owing to the failure of its recent prophecies of ruin, now predicts that we will have a grand financial and commercial crash in fifteen years -- that is to say, in 1880. We are not told in what month the crash will come; but it is quite likely it will come in December, when the thermometer is below zero. If the crash should not have happpened when the end of 1880 has arrived, then the prophets of evil could do as do the millenarians, and show that they simply made a miscalculation of, say, fifteen years, but that the crash will surely happen in 1895, say in the month of July, or in the dog-days. It is in that season that financial crashes usually occur in England, and why should American history not be a transcript of that of England? It shows good sense in the authors of oft-refuted predictions, when they begin to fix the period for the fulfillment of their prophecies a safe distance ahead.
headline: {'main': 'WISE PROPHETS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'WISE PROPHETS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: SEIZURE OF LIBIDINOUS LITERATURE. -- Yesterday morning Detective Officers GILMOR and MCDOUGALL, having been informed that the Town, a Bostonian hebdomadal, which was recently confiscated by our police, had been revived under the title of the Sporting Times, and having learned on what trains and boats the edition for this city might be expected, paid their respects to KINSLEY's and HARNDEN's expresses, and the morning boat from Fall River, and seized five large packages, containing about eight thousand copies of the sheet, addressed to B.W. DUDLEY, of Nos. 21 and 23 Ann-street; THOMAS SISSON, of New-York City, to be called for; JOHN BARRY, of No. 162 Nassau-street; and SAMUEL YATES, of No. 100 Nassau-street. These were taken to Police Headquarters, there to be destroyed. It is reasonable to presume that after paying for the engraving of two or three more captions to his sheet, and losing several more consignments to this city, the enterprising Boston publisher may keep his obscene literature at home.

abstract: The correspondent of the London Times at Biaritz, mentions the discovery of a reported plot against the Emperor, either on the way to San Sebastian or on the return to Bayonne. The parties concerned in it were aliens, including a brother or cousin of ORSINI's. Precautionary measures were taken, and the Queen of Spain insisted on accompanying the Emperor and Empress to the railroad station, notwithstanding it was night, in order that she might share any risk run by her guests.

abstract: Larkin vs. King; alleged detaining of money
snippet: Larkin vs. King; alleged detaining of money
lead_paragraph: Anne Larkins vs. Frederic J. King. -- This case, which has heretofore excited considerable interest, came on yesterday before Justice BARNARD, in the chambers of the Supreme Court. The amount involved is about $63,000. The parties to the litigation are Fred. J. King, a lawyer of the Supreme Court, who is defendant, and one Mrs. Ann Larkins, the plaintiff. Mr. Fogerty represents the plaintiff, and Mr. Walker the defendant King. It is charged, that the lawyer King withholds from the lady above-named the sum of $63,000.

abstract: Cuba, Slavery and Labor in
snippet: Cuba, Slavery and Labor in
lead_paragraph: -- We referred some days ago to the perils that now surround slavery in Cuba, owing to the abolition of the institution in this country, and the growth of the Liberal and Anti-Slavery party in Spain. The latest issue at hand of the London Times discusses the same subject. It declines that "the influence which the abolition of slavery in the United States may exert indirectly upon the existing system in Cuba, has not escaped the attention of the leading merchants of Havana, whose conclusions with respect to it, however, are not discouraging, either as regards the prospects of the colored population or the continued prosperity of the island." The large majority of the Cuban planters look to the adoption of a plan of gradual emancipation, and are confident the result will in no way permanently impair their commercial strength and resources. Their ground for this belief consists in the experience for the last few years of the rapid advance of mechanical as compared with manual labor. Statistics recently published show that in 1846 there were in the island 323,772 slaves, while the production of sugar was 17,729,589 arrobas. In 1862 the slaves numbered 368,550, and the production of sugar reached 41,418,444 arrobas. Thus, while the increase of slaves was less than 14 per cent., the increase of sugar production was more than 130 per cent. The introduction of machinery, new and improved methods of culture, and immigration from China, have been the cause of this change, and they are considered certain to continue in a still increasing ratio to replace slave labor.
headline: {'main': 'CUBAN SLAVERY.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'CUBAN SLAVERY.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The steamship Cuba arrived at Halifax yesterday, with two days' later news from Europe. We also received mails to the 13th by the New-York at this port. The Fenian agitation continued unabated in Ireland. Numerous arrests were made daily, and strict measures were taken to put down with a strong hand any attempt at insurrection. A meeting of the Atlantic Telegraph Company was held in London on the 14th, at which the directors presented a report setting forth the results of the late effort, and sanguine expectations for the future deduced therefrom, expressing a determination to press forward with the work, and announcing that they had already entered into a contract for renewed operations. The report was unanimously adopted, the question of raising capital being left to the final decision of another meeting, called for the lath of October. DONALD MCKAY is said to he negotiating with the British Admiralty in regard to placing torpedoes in the English Channel. A report is current that a plot has been discovered for the assassination of the French Emperor. It is stated that the Italian Government has revived the old project of purchasing Venetia from Austria.

abstract: Suffrage no Party Issue
snippet: Suffrage no Party Issue
lead_paragraph: The political bankrupts of the late rebellion, again turned fortune-hunters, are straining every nerve to make something out of the question of negro suffrage. They insist that it shall be a party test, in spite of the fact that the Union Conventions in all the great States, without exception, have declined to make it such. They will have it that the approaching State elections must be decided on that issue, and that they alone are on the right side of it. The pretence is ridiculous; and but for their hard straits, we would say contemptible.

abstract: -- There is, of course, the greatest interest in financial circles as to what measures will be recommended by Secretary MCCULLOCH to Congress, which meets in two brief months. The financial question will divide the attention with the question of reconstruction; but we judge from what is known of the Secretary's thoroughly practical mind, from the opportunity he has had of testing the value of various schemes, and from the fact that no partisan issues are involved, that it will be much easier to reach a wise decision on the financial than on the political question. It is an admirable characteristic of Secretary MCCULLOCH's administration that his special measures or projects never leak out in advance. Nobody can speculate upon anything that "they know" the Secretary is going to do at any particular time or in any particular crisis. All that anybody "on the street" or anywhere else knows of his policy is that so far as is in his power he will adopt, or will try to have adopted, such measures as will increase the financial strength of the government, improve its credit at home and abroad, and secure the nearest approximation possible between the value of its securities and the universal standard of value, gold. He expressed his views, in general, when he first accepted office, and declared that it would be his constant aim to secure the adoption of such measures as would favor a speedy return to the specie basis. He has been able to do but little in this way as yet, owing to the condition of affairs consequent upon the close of the war, the dissolution of our armies, and the heavy amount of work and of cash involved in the settlement of accounts. But he has now time and opportunity to systematize and perfect his plans, and he has the means at his disposal and in prospect to carry out the most comprehensive measures of financial improvement. The extent of the public debt, and the interest demand, have been ascertained; the estimates, military and civil, for a year of peace can be intelligently made; he can give data as to customs returns, past and probable; and he has been able to judge the permanent value of the internal revenue system, and the amount it will bring to the National Treasury. With those important points clear, with a large surplus of gold in his hands, and with a healthy condition of all the branches of his department, the Secretary of the Treasury will go before Congress in December able to speak with authority, sure to be heard with profound attention, and almost certain to command full support for all his recommendations. On this matter the well-posted Washington correspondent of the Springfield Republican writes:

abstract: In the case of WIRZ, the government has closed, at least temporarily, and yesterday the defence began. In view of the overwhelming evidence of his treatment of our prisoners, it will excite a feeling that we do not choose to characterize, when we read that this man complains, through his counsel, that he is under surveillance in his correspondence and his personal intercourse with his friends. And he complains of his bill of fare -- only full government rations, and "only two cups of milk and two eggs." It is but a week since witnesses swore that starving Union prisoners at Andersonville scraped undigested food from human excrement, and eagerly ate it to keep life in their poor skeletons, while WINDER and WIRZ were buffeting back, with obscene language and blackguard threats, the offers of aid brought to the gates of that hell upon earth by Georgia women. "Only two cups of milk and two eggs!" There were three witnesses called yesterday for the defence -- two priests, Fathers HAMILTON and WHEELAN, and Col. FANNIN, of the First Georgia Regiment. Their evidence was almost entirely negative -- they did not see or hear of the atrocities alleged.
lead_paragraph: In the case of WIRZ, the government has closed, at least temporarily, and yesterday the defence began. In view of the overwhelming evidence of his treatment of our prisoners, it will excite a feeling that we do not choose to characterize, when we read that this man complains, through his counsel, that he is under surveillance in his correspondence and his personal intercourse with his friends. And he complains of his bill of fare -- only full government rations, and "only two cups of milk and two eggs." It is but a week since witnesses swore that starving Union prisoners at Andersonville scraped undigested food from human excrement, and eagerly ate it to keep life in their poor skeletons, while WINDER and WIRZ were buffeting back, with obscene language and blackguard threats, the offers of aid brought to the gates of that hell upon earth by Georgia women. "Only two cups of milk and two eggs!" There were three witnesses called yesterday for the defence -- two priests, Fathers HAMILTON and WHEELAN, and Col. FANNIN, of the First Georgia Regiment. Their evidence was almost entirely negative -- they did not see or hear of the atrocities alleged.

abstract: New-York; Wolfsohn, Dr. Benjamin, Drowned; New-York; Vitty, William P., Policeman, shot dead by fall of pistol
snippet: New-York; Wolfsohn, Dr. Benjamin, Drowned; New-York; Vitty, William P., Policeman, shot dead by fall of pistol
lead_paragraph: On Friday evening last, Dr. BENJAMIN WOLFSOHN, a respectable physician of this city, left his home at No. 236 West Twenty-second-street, and attended a meeting of the Harmonie Club, at No. 141 Eighth-street. He tarried there until after 10 o'clock, and then, taking cheerful leave of his companions, departed, as every one supposed, for his dwelling. But on Saturday morning his son, EDWARD WOLFSOHN, the pianist, having learned that the Doctor had not been home, made inquiry, but was unable to trace him beyond the threshold of the club-room. Dr. WOLFSOHN having been a man of regular and abstenious habits and well-balanced mind, and never having been away from home at night without making his whereabouts known, his family naturally feared that he might have fallen a victim of the Sixteenth Ward banditti while on his way home from the club; they therefore notified Superintendent CARPENTER and the several Captains of police throughout the city, and offered a liberal reward to any person who would give them a clue to the Doctor's whereabouts. Nothing, however, was heard of him until Monday morning, when two boys who were rowing a boat in the North River off Twenty-third-street, discovered the body of a man floating near the Twenty-second-street pier. They secured it with ropes and at once informed the Sixteenth Ward Police, and when the corpse was taken from the river it was found to be that of Dr. WOLFSOHN. The doctor's gold watch, wallet, (containing a considerable amount of money,) his gold spectacles, and other valuables being on his person, of course all idea of foul play was banished from the minds of the spectators and police; but the relatives, unable to take a cool view of the subject, insisted that he had been foully murdered, although they could see no earthly reason for the commission of the deed. They therefore insisted upon a searching inquest; and in compliance with their request, Coroner WILDEY impanneled a jury this morning, and after examining ten witnesses, among whom were many members of the club, with whom the doctor conversed on Friday night, nothing being found that was in any way satisfactory to the family, the Coroner adjourned the investigation one week, to enable the police authorities to search for any evidence that may bear upon the case. The club men testified that on Friday evening Dr. WOLFSOHN conversed with his usual vivacity and betrayed no sign of mental aberration, that he drank nothing intoxicating whatever, and that he departed from the circle shortly after 10 o'clock, apparently rational and cheerful; and it having been shown that when the body was taken from the river, on Monday, everything valuable which he is known to have had in his possession was yet on his person, it seems probable that the Doctor, when he left the stage which he took at the club-room door, busily engaged with his own thoughts, walked in the wrong direction and into the river. This theory is supported by the testimony of the watchmen on two vessels which were moored near the Twenty-third-street pier, who say that at about 11 o'clock on Friday night they heard a splash and shout for aid. Dr. WOLFSOHN was of German nativity, 69 years of age.

abstract: Villafranca Case. Capt. Anderson Committed for Trial
snippet: Villafranca Case. Capt. Anderson Committed for Trial
lead_paragraph: The summing up of the case against Capt. Anderson, master of the Villafranca, was finished yesterday afternoon, Mr. BENEDICT appearing for the Captain, and Mr. Bell for the United States. The Commissioner rendered his decision at once; he held that the Captain had knowledge of the state of things on board, and that he had probable cause to believe him guilty of the offence charged. The Captain was thereupon fully committed for trial, to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: Phillips >amp; Solomon's Photographs from South America
snippet: Phillips >amp; Solomon's Photographs from South America
lead_paragraph: One of the most superb and interesting collections of photographs we have ever seen is the volume with the above title, published by PHILIPS & SOLOMONS, of Washington, and for sale at No. 200 Broadway. It contains one hundred pictures exquisite in quality of tone and finish, and presenting a complete panoramic view of the cities and coast scenery of Peru. We have never seen architectural subjects rendered with greater delicacy of detail and transparency of tone in the shadows, which in such subjects are apt to be heavy and dull. The views of the Chincha Islands give one a clearer idea of the immense guano deposits, and the mode of working them, than could be obtained from the most elaborate description. If any one wishes to visit South America without leaving New-York, he could not do better than spend an hour in turning the leaves of this elegant collection.

abstract: Fire Department; Want of Organization
snippet: Fire Department; Want of Organization
lead_paragraph: -- We do not know that the Fire Commissioners are to blame, but complaints against their delay in effectively reorganizing the department abound on all hands. It is certainly very alarming to find such utter feebleness and lack of organization as marked the firemen's efforts at the great fire last week. The commissioners can hardly fail to appreciate the actual perils of the situation, and they must know that the public look for promptitude and decision at their hands. The interests committed to their keeping will not bear being trifled with, even for an hour. Action, action is what is wanted. If the best men are not available at the outset, take the second best, and see that the force is sufficient, under all contingencies.

abstract: Owners of Indicted for Manslaughter
snippet: Owners of Indicted for Manslaughter
lead_paragraph: -- The Grand Jury of this county have at last taken steps toward the punishment of criminal carelessness and neglect on the part of railway officials and steamboat owners. At the instigation of District-Attorney HALL, DAVID D. SMITH and TUNIS SMITH, proprietors of the steamer Arrow, have been indicted for manslaughter in the fourth degree, in causing the death of MARX E. ERRICSON, through willful and culpable neglect and carelessness in the management of the steamer Arrow, which they owned and controlled.

abstract: Hamilton-avenue, South Brooklyn, is by no means an inviting street. It is devoted to tenement-houses, junk-shops, third-rate porter-houses, old-clothes dealers and vile stenches -- a remarkable fact enough when it is considered that thousands of persons have daily to run the gauntlet of these nuisances on their way to the important ferry at the terminus of the street. There is yet hope, however, of redeeming Hamilton-avenue from its indecency. The first step has been taken by Messrs. SMITH & JEWELL, extensive millers and flour merchants. These gentlemen have recently completed near the lower end of the street an imposing brick building six stories in height, 200 feet in length and 75 in width, extending through to India Wharf, Atlantic Basin, which they have named the "Atlantic Flour Mills," there being also in connection with the main building a grain elevator on the basin, of dimensions about 45 by 25, which, in its capacity for work, rivals anything of the kind in the country. A late visit to the establishment we found quite interesting. On the first floor, besides the neatly-fitted offices and the capacious delivery-room, is the motive power of the mill. This is an engine of about 600 horse-power, which was built by the Cuyahoga Steam Works Company, Cleveland, Ohio, and which operates upon a comparatively new principle, so far as it is adapted to driving a flour mill. The mill has now in operation ten run of burr-stones, and is manufacturing from 700 to 800 barrels of flour daily. There is room, however, for an additional ten run of stones, which are now in process of setting, and when they are at work, the capacity of the mill per diem will reach the enormous aggregate of fifteen hundred barrels. The machinery of the mill for cleaning wheat, bolting, and, in fact, for doing everything required in the process of taking bulk wheat from the boats, manufacturing it into flour of the various grades, packing it into barrels, and delivering it for market, is complete and efficient. In the adaptation of this machinery to milling purposes, many improvements have been made, which are the fruits of the ripe experience of the proprietors and of their fathers before them, after practical milling in this city and in Western New-York for more than fifty years. The storage capacity of the mill is about 100,000 bushels of wheat and 10,000 bushels of flour. The elevator takes bulk wheat into the mill at the rate of 4,000 bushels per hour, and vessels are loaded with flour direct from the mill dock. The principal trade of this establishment is with South America and the West Indies, the climates of which require what is termed "high ground" flour, made from the choicest wheat. The entire appointments of the Atlantic Flour Mills are substantial and excellent. The building was designed by Mr. JEWELL, and constructed under his personal superintendence. He, unhappily, barely lived to see the fruition of his labors. In addition to the Atlantic Flour Mills, the firm owns the Brooklyn City Mills, at Fulton Ferry, and a smaller mill in Westchester County. When all three of these establishments are working to their full capacity, they produce 20,000 barrels of flour daily, requiring 10,000 bushels of wheat in its manufacture.

abstract: was committed by the "sportsmon" who returned to this city on Monday evening, on board the steamboat George Washington, from the Sing Sing boat-race. The boat had about six hundred passengers and was densely crowded; but notwithstanding the discomfort of the voyage, everything passed off merrily until the "sportsmen's" gin had begun to fly into their heads, and then, as the boat neared West Tenth-street pier the fellows picked up a fight with several of the deckhands. The encounter soon became furious and general, and terminated only with the arrival of the boat, when a rush was made for shore, and in the struggle on the gangway FRANK BURNS, of No. 157 Perry-street, and PATRICK MCGINN, of the Eighth Ward, were stabbed in the abdomen. Policeman TERHUNE, of the Ninth Ward, took BURNS to the Charles-street Police-station, and notice of the riot was then sent to Capt. DIXON, of the Twenty-eighth Precinct. The officers of that precinct hurried to the beat, and on information which was given them by Mr. JOHN MURRAY, of No. 663 Washington-street, they apprehended-ARTHUR FISHER and JAMES WASHINGTON, deck-hands employed on the boat. The prisoners were taken to Jefferson Market yesterday morning, and FISHER was committed for trial; but no person appearing against WASHINGTON, he was released from custody....THOS. HASTINGS and JOHN PICKENS were committed to answer for

abstract: Bonn, The Murder of Prince Alfred's Cook at
snippet: Bonn, The Murder of Prince Alfred's Cook at
lead_paragraph: The recent assassination, at Bonn, of Mr. OTT, Prince ALFRED of England's cook, appears likely to assume considerable political importance. The incidents connected with this homicide appeared at the time at length in the public papers, and were substantially as follows: The deceased was quietly walking at evening on one of the public streets of Bonn, when he met, coming in an opposite direction, three officers of the Prussian service, one of whom, without any provocation or insult sufficient to justify even a rebuke, drew his sword and cut down Mr. OTT. The result proved fatal, and investigation showed the murderer to be a Mr. EULENDERG, a son of one of the Cabinet Ministers of Prussia, and holding an advanced military grade. An attempt was made to hush the matter up, ordinarily a very easy undertaking in Prussia, in cases where the culprit belongs to the patrician order and the victim is a member of lower social rank. But exceptional circumstances threw an unexpected difficulty in the way of this contemplated evasion of justice. Poor OTT was, it is true, only a plebeian, which was a good deal against him in those latitudes, and he was only a cook by avocation, which fact did not help him much. But as he happened to be in the service of Prince ALFRED of England, and as a maitre de cuisine once lost is not easily replaced, His Royal Highness naturally demanded justice. But even this unpleasant contretemps, in which light only the military aristocracy was disposed to view it, might have been got over had not another still more powerful influence demanded redress for the murder. Poor OTT was a French citizen, and it seems that the Emperor insists on full justice being done, regardless of the rank of the offender. Up to the present time, however, the disposition to a fair investigation appears to be wanting, for at latest accounts the aristocratic assassin, after arrest and a short nominal detention at the barracks, had been allowed to rejoin his regiment and enjoy the same liberty as his brother officers.

abstract: Williamsburgh; Fifteenth Ward Hotel, Liquors and Watch
snippet: Williamsburgh; Fifteenth Ward Hotel, Liquors and Watch
lead_paragraph: ESCAPE OF CONVICTS FROM BLACRWELL's ISLAND -- ONE OF THEM REPORTED DROWNED. -- Early yesterday morning, Officers MANGUM and HOYT, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, found two men near the ferry foot of Grand-street, with their clothing, which was scant, dripping with water. Believing that they were escaped convicts from Blackwell's Island, the officers took them into custody and locked them up. This belief proved correct. The men -- who gave their names as DANIEL KERSLEY and ANTOINE PERIER -- acknowledged that they had escaped from the island shortly after midnight, and succeeded in swimming to Hunter's Point. They also stated that a man named MAURICE WHITE started with them, but his strength failing him, he was drowned, within a few hundred feet of the Long Island shore. The runaways were returned to the island.

abstract: Ireland, Fenians, Numerous Arrests in Dublin, >amp;c.
snippet: Ireland, Fenians, Numerous Arrests in Dublin, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: On invitation of Lord FENNOY, the Lord Lieutenant of County Cork, a meeting of more than 150 magistrates took place recently in Cork, to consider the security of the public peace, as menaced by Fenian movements. The proceedings were private, but the Cork Examiner says they resulted in the unanimous adoption of a memorial to the government, praying for an immediate increase in the police and military force of the county. The existence of secret organizations, dangerous to the public peace, was generally admitted, and it was supposed that the adoption of the proposed steps would be sufficient to maintain public order.

abstract: drew ANNIE WALTER, of No. 49 Walker-street, into difficulty recently, The young woman, who had taken large quantities of shirts and other garments to make up, dreamed that certain numbers in the Maryland and Delaware lotteries would yield her large pecuniary profit; and having faith in dreams, she pawned four dozen shirts at Mrs. WOOD's place, at the junction of East Broadway and Grand-street, and invested every dollar of the proceeds in one of the little "exchange offices" near by, laying a wager with the proprietor thereof that the number which she selected would be the first drawn. She lost, of course, and then repeated this financial operation with like ill-luck until yesterday, when she was arrested and committed to prison. The Police Property Clerk has eighteen of the shirts awaiting the appearance of claimants....JOSEPH POOL, for

abstract: Officials; Charges Before Gov. Fenton
snippet: Officials; Charges Before Gov. Fenton
lead_paragraph: -- Our city officials accused of certain derelictions in office, appeared yesterday at Albany, to answer to the charges preferred. Little was done beyond the formal reading of documents. There is a strong array of counsel, and of course a great deal of public interest in the matter. Naturally enough, the first point raised is want of constitutional power on the part of the Governor to make the investigation. It is probably beyond the capacity of the human mind to make a constitution or a law so explicit that no one will question its meaning, and, indeed, we have heard so much of "unconstitutionality" within the last ten years that we regularly anticipate that as the first point of defence in any matter, however trivial. Years ago a fellow was convicted of some crime and put in the stocks, while his counsel was searching musty folios to prove that such punishment was "unconstitutional." Hurrying to the court-room with his invincible argument he was hailed by his client who was actually in the wooden purgatory. "I tell you," said the lawyer, "they can't put you in the stocks -- they caan't do it -- it's unconstitutional." "Oh! confound your pother about constitutional; don't you see I am in the stocks?" It is to be hoped that no scruples upon constitutional points will prevent a fair investigation into the grave charges against our city officers. If they are innocent, as we trust they are, a full examination will be the very best proof of their purity that could be desired. Why not have it?

snippet: Eclectic, New-York vs. Americus of Newark
lead_paragraph: Newark was the scene of a very interesting match on Monday, the occasion being the debut of the Eclectic Club of this city, with the well-known Americus boys of Newark. The Eclectics astonished their friends by their good play, and well-deserved the trophy they won. The Americus nine certainly merited a better score. A bountiful repast was spread for their guests at the close of the game, and much good feeling prevailed. We give the score:

abstract: N. Y.--Arrow Explosion; Messrs. Smiths, Owners, Indicted for Manslaughter
snippet: N. Y.--Arrow Explosion; Messrs. Smiths, Owners, Indicted for Manslaughter
lead_paragraph: The Grand Jury have jointly indicted David D. Smith and Tunis Smith, proprietors of the steamboat Arrow, for manslaughter in the fourth degree. The indictment charges that these parties owned, managed and controlled the steamboat Arrow, and that the navigation of said steamer was managed in such a culpably negligent and careless manner as to cause the death of one Mary G. Grierson by scalding, &c. The accused appeared by Gilbert Dean, Esq., their counsel, and, after pleading not guilty to the indictment, gave bail in the sum of $5,000 each to appear next month for trial.

abstract: Calhoun, Steamship, Mutiny and Suicides on Board of
snippet: Calhoun, Steamship, Mutiny and Suicides on Board of
lead_paragraph: The ship Calhoun, PAGE, Liverpool Aug. 18, with merchandise and 365 passengers to SPOFFORD, TILESTON & CO., arrived yesterday. Aug. 14. -- While lying in the river Mersey, CHARLES GRUA, steward, committed suicide by taking poison, and was buried at Liverpool. Sept. 1. -- FREDERICK JARGENSEN committed suicide by jumping overboard. Sept. 19. -- FRANCIS WILLIAMS, second officer, died of brain fever. Sept 21. -- The crew, in a state of mutiny, made a combined attack on the cook of the ship, and during the melee JAMES MALONE, seaman, was shot. Sept. 26 engaged the tug Seth Low to go for naval assistance. She returned at 2 P.M. with U.S. revenue cutter Crawford, Capt. KELLUM, in tow. The captain of the cutter found the ship's crew in a state of mutiny, and two of the officers in state-rooms in the wheel-house over which the crew had guards stationed. He immediately released the imprisoned officers and placed all the crew in irons, and remained by the ship till she arrived up to the city, and had the men put into the hands of the proper authorities.

abstract: Cars, Courtesy in
snippet: Cars, Courtesy in
lead_paragraph: A friend who has to ride up and down a good deal in one of the avenue cars, occasionally offers his place to a lady without one. His mother and sisters being women, our friend cannot bring himself to sit and sec women stand, and cannot help figuring the slight homage he does them as done by another to those ho reveres and loves to honor. He has thus a double pleasure in his acts, and gets an objective sense of its amiability. He is hound to say also that the courtesy is courteously received in nearly all cases, especially by these whose beauty might exempt them from any repayment except through a part of such happiness as they tacitly confer on all the world by being beautiful in it. He has, therefore, expressed to us his belief that it is only middle-aged ugly women who continue to neglect this sort of politeness, and has mentioned as the sole instance in which he has signally thrown away his good nature, that of a scraggy being who scarcely needed his proffered space to sit down in. Pale, of skim-milk effect, and of a blossomless austerity of presence -- the reader knows the type -- the skeleton in crinoline swept into his place with phantom-like silence, and kept it with ghastly insolence and ingratitude.

abstract: Mission held a meeting, on Tuesday evening, in the Baptist Church, Stanton-street. A.R. WETMORE, Esq., Chairman. Several missionaries reported instances of privation among the families of our brave soldiers. The widow of a good German soldier was found industriously toiling on carpet-shoes at thirty cents a dozen, to support herself and children. Some ladies have been, through the missionaries, distributing relief to such worthy cases. Laborers among the Jews, and the immigrants, gave interesting accounts of their work. The chairman referred to the position of the Stanton-street Church, and its relation to the neighborhood, the overflowing population of the Eleventh and Seventeenth Wards, and the value of missionary effort, and the encouragement given to every one to carry the Gospel to the perishing. Among the statistical results, we note 6,792 missionary visits; 300 meetings; 457 persons to church; 276 children to school; 69 temperance pledges, and 66,154 tracts distributed.
lead_paragraph: Mission held a meeting, on Tuesday evening, in the Baptist Church, Stanton-street. A.R. WETMORE, Esq., Chairman. Several missionaries reported instances of privation among the families of our brave soldiers. The widow of a good German soldier was found industriously toiling on carpet-shoes at thirty cents a dozen, to support herself and children. Some ladies have been, through the missionaries, distributing relief to such worthy cases. Laborers among the Jews, and the immigrants, gave interesting accounts of their work. The chairman referred to the position of the Stanton-street Church, and its relation to the neighborhood, the overflowing population of the Eleventh and Seventeenth Wards, and the value of missionary effort, and the encouragement given to every one to carry the Gospel to the perishing. Among the statistical results, we note 6,792 missionary visits; 300 meetings; 457 persons to church; 276 children to school; 69 temperance pledges, and 66,154 tracts distributed.

abstract: Reporting--French Paragraphists
snippet: Reporting--French Paragraphists
lead_paragraph: It must be confessed that the French nation, while it occasionally makes a mistaken conquest, (as in the case of Mexico,) and seems scarcely able to regulate its public affairs without leaning upon the strong arm of despotism, has yet a fine and excelling touch in some other things. Few people of the present day paint so well as Frenchmen, and the most ravishing ribbons and wall-papers come from France, while the most elegant little unmeaning bronzes and lamps, and parlor ornaments generally, are made there. French novels of society are very good, though French poetry is commonly very bad. As for comedies and other dramas, it is well known how we plunder the ingenious Gauls of them; and we think one might also steal a few notions of journalism from the same people. We do not mean to borrow the local chronique; that has been tried and has failed; and we have not much to learn from them in the grand treatment of events and questions; but they have a nice touch for penny-a-lining which might be studied to advantage here -- a delicacy, a grace, a fitness that touches the incident and turns it, not into an item, but into literature.
headline: {'main': 'Esthetic Reporting The French Paragraphists.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Esthetic Reporting The French Paragraphists.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Harbor Police yesterday brought up thirty-three of the crew of the ship Calhoun, who are charged by the Captain with mutiny. It appeared from the complaint, that on the 21st of September there was a quarrel between the cook and some of the crew. The boatswain interfered to protect the cook, and a joint assault was made on them.
lead_paragraph: The Harbor Police yesterday brought up thirty-three of the crew of the ship Calhoun, who are charged by the Captain with mutiny. It appeared from the complaint, that on the 21st of September there was a quarrel between the cook and some of the crew. The boatswain interfered to protect the cook, and a joint assault was made on them. Seeing the excited state of affairs, the boatswain retreated aft, where he was joined by the second mate. The two officers armed themselves and came back, and, after warning the crew, fired several shots among them, which took fatal effect on two or three of their number. The Captain came out at this juncture, and the crew at once demanded that the officers should be put in irons or they would hang him. The Captain complied with their wishes and ironed the twain. On nearing this port the crew took out the officers and placed them in the wheelhouse, keeping guard over them until they arrived in the harbor.

abstract: A general meeting of the citizens of Paramus, Bergen County, N.J., was held at Union Hall, on Tuesday night, at which much enthusiasm was manifested. There were about twenty-five hundred people present, many of them from the surrounding country. The fair sex was well represented. The National Glee Club was in attendance, and delighted the audience with its melody.
lead_paragraph: A general meeting of the citizens of Paramus, Bergen County, N.J., was held at Union Hall, on Tuesday night, at which much enthusiasm was manifested. There were about twenty-five hundred people present, many of them from the surrounding country. The fair sex was well represented. The National Glee Club was in attendance, and delighted the audience with its melody. The meeting having been called to order, Major-Gen. KILPATRICK was presented, amid loud cheers, which having subsided, he delivered an eloquent address, calling on the Union Democrats of New-Jersey to stand firmly together in the approaching conflict, and he had no doubt they would be successful, and MARCUS L. WARD would be elected the next Governor.

abstract: Efforts to Use in America
snippet: Efforts to Use in America
lead_paragraph: ing made to introduce the camel into this country for service on the great plains; and we understand that an agent will soon depart for the land of camels to make purchases for importation. We warmly approve of the scheme. They would be of the greatest benefit throughout the length and breadth of our enormous territory lying west of the Mississippi. Their habits and character adapt them to every part of it -- to the desert plains this side of the Rocky Mountains, and the barren regions between that range and the Sierra Nevada. Where provender is scarce, where water is scarce, where the qualities of endurance and patience, and great capacity for labor and travel are required, there the camel is an invaluable beast of burden. They would be far more serviceable, far more economical, better fit for extensive use than are the ox-wagons and mule trains that are now employed on the plains. And not only in the barren regions we have mentioned, but in the long lines of travel down to Santa Fe, down to Arizona, down to Texas, and up by the head waters of the Missouri, the camel would be of the highest value. We believe there is profitable work for ten thousand of them west of the Mississippi River.

abstract: Neutrality and the Fenians; Fenians, the, and Neutrality, American and English
snippet: Neutrality and the Fenians; Fenians, the, and Neutrality, American and English
lead_paragraph: The Fenians are putting Ireland in such a ferment, that the British Government is becoming concerned lest serious trouble come from it. It has sent the channel fleet to cruise upon the western coast; has taken steps to increase the police and military forces of the island; has put telegraph lines under surveillance; has suppressed a newspaper; has arrested a considerable number of persons for seditious language and secret drilling; and, at the last advices, a privy council was sitting to determine still further upon the demands of the situation. If it takes blood to mark the starting-point of a rebellion, then a new Irish insurrection has already commenced, for at Dangan a fight has occurred between the people and the constabulary force of the government, in which the latter fired upon the crowd, killing one and wounding others.

abstract: A quarrel occurred yesterday afternoon at the corner of Eighth-avenue and Nineteenth-street, between a young German named ADOLPH GETTER and PATRICK MOORE, a returned soldier. MOORE struck GETTER in the face with his fist, when the latter seized a cleaver and dealt MOORE a powerful blow on the head, inflicting a serious wound. Officer TRAVIS, of the Sixteenth Precinct, arrested GETTER, and Justice LEDWITH committed him to await the result of MOORE's injuries. The latter was removed to Bellevue Hospital.

abstract: The court was occupied yesterday in the trial of one Edward Stelger, for a larceny under somewhat peculiar circumstances. It appeared from the evidence that a friend of the prisoner named Wolge enlisted in the army and received a large bounty, Part of the money he wished to put in the savings bank, and not knowing much about such institutions he took Stelger along with him to the Bowery Bank to manage the affair for him. Stelger deposited the money in his own name and Wolge's jointly, but after Wolge's departure with his regiment, prisoner drew out the money and appropriated it to his own use. When the complainant returned he found all his savings, amounting to $570, had been stolen from him. On this evidence the defence claimed that it amounted to nothing more than a breach of trust, for which there is no punishment, but Judge RUSSEL, determined that the scoundrel should not escape, charged the jury that it was a larceny. He was convicted and sent to the State Prison for three years.

abstract: Fire Department; Progress of Reorganization
snippet: Fire Department; Progress of Reorganization
lead_paragraph: The work of reorganizing the Fire Department of this city, on the basis laid down by the new Fire Law, is now materially progressing toward completion. The Board of Metropolitan Fire Commissioners have kept on their steady course of reorganization, on the basis laid down by the board, and are now considerably more than half done. The difficulties have been great, the work tedious and arduous, and the entire task one requiring great care and discrimination in the proper distribution and localization of the new force.

abstract: At Police Trials, yesterday, before Commissioners ACTON and McMURRAY, one hundred and seven charges were preferred against officers of various grades. The number of complainants and witnesses was far greater than usual, and twice during the day the Trial Chamber seemed too small to accommodate them.
lead_paragraph: At Police Trials, yesterday, before Commissioners ACTON and MCMURRAY, one hundred and seven charges were preferred against officers of various grades. The number of complainants and witnesses was far greater than usual, and twice during the day the Trial Chamber seemed too small to accommodate them. Manhattanville alone sent a host to testify concerning the Lion Park murder. In this case, which was against Patrolmen SOMERSET KINNAIRD and ROBERT B. DENNISON, Capt. BOGERT, of the Thirty-first Precinct, preferred the charge at the request of President ACTON, to whom an appeal had been made by many persons who thought it desirable that the murder should be thoroughly investigated. Officers KINNAIRD and DENNISON, who were defended by Senator THOMAS C. FIELDS, cleared their skirts by showing that when the inebriated assailing party, whom they had once ejected from the Lion Brewery bar-room, burst the doors and reentered, they exerted themselves to protect the place and its inmates. The weight of testimony went to show that the brewery employes, in defending the place, wounded several of the rioters, and killed DANIEL CLAFFY in the struggle. The landlady of a first-class family boarding-house, who appeared, on the 20th inst., against Patrolmen RALPH P. BARKER and JOHN BECHMAN, of the Fifteenth Precinct, resumed her case yesterday, and Mr. EDWARD STERN, of Lafayette-place, her late boarder, testified that, having tired of paying $104 weekly for his family's board, and subsisting upon unsavory meat at that, he had striven to move to other quarters, but that the landlady had sought to detain his household goods; therefore, he had summoned the officers to preserve the peace while he removed his property. The commissioners intimated that their officers had been in error in protecting him in taking goods from the landlady's house, and Mr. STERN, at the suggestion of a representative of the press, volunteered to pay the officers' fine, whatever it might be. Many complaints were entered by civilians who clearly do not comprehend the rights and duties of policemen; and several complainants, dissatisfied with the commissioners' rulings, notified the board that they should bring action against the defending officers in the civil courts.

abstract: Victor Aufert was brought up yesterday morning, charged with being a deserter from the French frigate Themis. The accused, in broken English, said he was an Italian; never spoke French; was never on board the Themis or any other vessel, and, in fact, point blank denied his identity. He was so persistent in his denial that the sous lieutenant, Honevey, became staggered, and declined to swear to his identity.
lead_paragraph: Victor Aufert was brought up yesterday morning, charged with being a deserter from the French frigate Themis. He was so persistent in his denial that the sous lieutenant, Honevey, became staggered, and declined to swear to his identity.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- "Il Poliuto" can hardly be termed a strong opera, although the music in many respects is of that open and general character which pleases the masses and should "draw." People, however, take the work for granted, and are "pleased calmly," as WALPOLE was with the statues at Florence. The opera was revived last evening for the purpose, we presume, of bringing forward Hade. CAROZZI-ZUCCHI and Signor MASSIMILIANI. The rentrees of these tried and valuable artists were, we need barely say, entirely successful. The lady is in excellent condition, and in the second and third acts displayed that intensity of style and abandon for which she is famous. In the earlier scenes her voice did not appear to be thoroughly in command, and it was only in the splendid finale of the second act, and in the famous piece of the last, ("Sounds of Harps Angelical,") that she was at once impassioned and full toned. The acting of Mme. ZUCCHI was statuesque, graceful and spirited. It is always good.

abstract: The present week is by far the most successful of the Fair of the American Institute. New features are added daily, and as the entire mass of machinery on exhibition is in perpetual motion, it cannot fail to render a visit to the rooms both entertaining and instructive. The visit of Major-Gen. HOOKER and his staff was the occasion of a grand demonstration.
lead_paragraph: The present week is by far the most successful of the Fair of the American Institute. New features are added daily, and as the entire mass of machinery on exhibition is in perpetual motion, it cannot fail to render a visit to the rooms both entertaining and instructive. The visit of Major-Gen. HOOKER and his staff was the occasion of a grand demonstration. The superb band heralded the coming of the old Commander of the Army of the Potomac, and, as the brilliant cortege filed into the great hall, where are placed the more ponderous articles of note, cheer upon cheer greeted the gallant soldier, and a thousand voices shouted forth a welcome.

abstract: HENRY HART was arrested yesterday by officer MCGEE, of the Broadway squad, on a charge of cruelty to animals. The accused was engaged in carrying a load of calves through Broadway in a butcher's cart, the animals lying on each other with their heads hanging over the sides and ends of the cart. Justice DOWLING fined the prisoner $10. Officer ROBINSON, of the Broadway squad, arrested JOHN MELTNEY on a similar charge, and Judge DOWLING also fined him $10.

abstract: Patient of, Died after Miscarriage
snippet: Patient of, Died after Miscarriage
lead_paragraph: A mysterious marriage and death, on Tuesday night and yesterday morning, disclosed a startling case of malpractice which had occurred at Dr. GRINDLE's private lying-in hospital, No. 6 Amity-place. The facts came to light yesterday afternoon, through a note signed "A Citizen," which was sent to the Wooster-street Police-station, informing Capt. MILLS that an undertaker took a coffin into No. 160 Laurens-street at daybreak yesterday morning, and that at noon the same coffin, marked "Tivoli," was removed from that house to the Hudson River Railroad depot, whence it was taken by the 1 o'clock train out of the city.

abstract: The Albany Argus says: We were mistaken in stating yesterday that the Supreme Court, at General Term, in this district, were of the opinion that the shares of stock in the National Banks were not taxable under our State law as personal property. The decision was made without deliberation, and only proforma, for the purpose of obtaining the judgement of  the Court of Appeals, and no opinion was written.
lead_paragraph: The Albany Argus says: We were mistaken in stating yesterday that the Supreme Court, at General Term, in this district, were of the opinion that the shares of stock in the National Banks were not taxable under our State law as personal property. The decision was made without deliberation, and only pro forma, for the purpose of obtaining the judgement of the Court of Appeals, and no opinion was written. The case will be argued on appeal at the term of the Court of Appeals, now in session in this city, and it is hoped an early decision may be made, with reference to the adjusting of the taxes of the present year. If these large and most remunerative investments shall escape taxation, the burdens will fall very heavily on the property of individuals.

abstract: Empire vs. Mystie; Wood's vs. Hooley's Minstrels
snippet: Empire vs. Mystie; Wood's vs. Hooley's Minstrels
lead_paragraph: The "grand match" between nines selected from the artists engaged at these noted New-York and Brooklyn minstrel establishments, took place yesterday morning, at Morrisania, on the grounds of the Union Club, near Melrose Station. Quite a numerous assemblage were present, among them a fair delegation of the belles of the village, although the hour -- 11 A.M. -- was early for a base ball match. The contest proved to be a very enjoyable affair throughout, the weather being delightful. Some very good play was shown in numerous instances, although ruffianism prevailed at times to a considerable extent. The game had not proceeded far before it became evident that the Wood's party were altogether the most skillful exponents of the game, the score at the close of the fourth inning standing 13 to 2 in favor of Wood's nine. Afterward Hooley's troupe pulled up a little, but when the total score was called, the figures proved to be 34 to 12 in favor of the New-Yorkers. BEALS and HEWEY specially distinguished themselves in the fielding department on the part of Wood's nine, and FINNEGAN and MCCORD on the other side. BEALS, MUDGE and HEWEY carried the palm in batting, MCCORD's display being the best on the other side. The following is the score:
