abstract: probabilities of Friery's Punishment
snippet: probabilities of Friery's Punishment
lead_paragraph: The conviction of JAMES CLARK as an accessory to the murder of HENRY LAZARUS, recalls to mind the case of FRIERY, and stimulates the public to inquire what probability there is that the most atrocious murder of the year will be adequately punished. The friends of the murderer not only maintain the certainty of his escape from justice, but facetiously declare that they will "run him for the Legislature," as a candidate from the Fourteenth Ward. Their confidence is based upon the fact that from one of the several courts to which the prisoner can appeal he may obtain a new trial. A new trial being granted, the evidence given at the former trial cannot be used, or read to the jury, but the witnesses must be produced by the people, and the case regularly proven as though no other hearing had ever taken place. And here the delays for which his counsel have striven come in to aid the prisoner, with those chances which time always brings forth. The chief witness, the bar-tender in the saloon kept by LAZARUS, is dead; another one of the witnesses has been convicted of a felony and sent to the State Prison; still another person, whose testimony is important, has disappeared and cannot be found. The absence of three witnesses would make it so difficult for the District-Attorney to prove his case, that the confident insolence of the murderer's friends is not without grounds. His escape might work more good than his execution, if the case should compel the Legislature to knit more tightly the meshes of the law. The chief utility of punishment is lost where convenient laws and pernicious precedents bring hope so prominently before the mind of the evil-doer. Any criminal who can command a little money has the power to delay the execution of his sentence for a year or more by appeals from court to court, when, if some technicality grants him a new trial, lapse of time may render it impossible to obtain a second conviction. Under ordinary circumstances, it is an excellent and merciful maxim that it is better to let ninety-nine guilty men escape rather than one innocent person should suffer wrongfully; but in this city, at the present day, it seems to us that the rule might be materially modified with beneficial results to the interests of the community.

abstract: we commented upon a paragraph which a Halifax telegram reported had appeared in a New-York letter to the London News, to the effect that hundreds of negroes had been murdered in the street, in pursuance of a conspiracy to reenslave the blacks, and that "the Abolitionists support Gen. BUTLER's plan, which is to organize a black battalion in every county of the South, " &c. An examination of our files of the News shows that the paragraph making these statements was quoted from the Southern Christian Intelligencer by the News correspondent, who neither indorsed them or made any comment on them, which is a very different thing from making them his own, as the telegraph represented that he did.

abstract: A meeting of the backers of the Turners and their adherents was held at 4 P. M. yesterday, at the house of ANDREW BRUMACHER. abstract: Leach vs. King; continued
snippet: Leach vs. King; continued
lead_paragraph: Anne Larkins vs. Frederick J. King. -- This case is causing considerable interest in the community. The defendant is a lawyer of this city, whose name appeals upon the rolls. He is a Cuban by birth, and we believe he was educated there. His antecedents, and the manner in which he has performed the duties of attorney and counsellor, since he has been admitted, are best known to those who have employed him. Miss Larkins charges him with having swindled her out of a large sum of money, during the time he was transacting her business. A sum of about $80,000 is involved in the litigation. Mr. Fogerty is counsel for Mrs. Larkin, and Mr. Walker for the defendant King. Yesterday morning, at 10 o'clock, the court-room of the Supreme Court was crowded to suffocation. The audience consisted mainly of outsiders who seemed very curious and solicitous as to the result. There were among the number many of foreign birth. The following is the substance of testimony given yesterday.

abstract: extensive repairs in the basement of the Spring-street Church, and the absence from the city of the President, A.A. STARR, Esq., the society did not hold its regular monthly meeting last evening. The next meeting will be held, as usual, in the lecture-room of the Presbyterian Church in Spring-street, near Varick, on the last Wednesday evening of October, at 7:30 o'clock. The subject of uniting with the New-York Academy of Science will come before the meeting. A paper will be read by Prof. HENDRICKSON, of the Grand-street School, on Fungi, and the question whether the Volvocinea belong to we animal or vegetable kingdom will be discussed. A number of rare and beautiful specimens may be expected on exhibition, and the public are respectfully invited to be present.

abstract: Currency, The Uniformity of the
snippet: Currency, The Uniformity of the
lead_paragraph: Four several attempts have been made by certain uneasy spirits among our bank officers to disturb the quiet, uniform and highly satisfactory working of the National Currency, by proscribing and otherwise causing a discrimination in the notes of the National Banks, not contemplated by the Banking Law, and all of which notes are already redeemable at the commercial centres named in the law -- nine-tenths of them in New-York, Philadelphia and Boston. For two months or more a prescriptive plan or machine for assorting, sealing up and running home the country bank notes was in secret preparation, and early in August was matured and presented to the New-York Clearing-house Association. It was received, and laid upon the table. It was also presented to the Boston Clearing-house, and, we believe, unanimously rejected. It was also presented to the Philadelphia Clearing-house, and rejected by more than a two-thirds vote. Thus ended the first effort. The comparatively close vote in New-York encouraged a second attempt, after four or five weeks' delay, and on the 12th inst. the scheme was again brought into the Clearing-house, but immediately and by almost general consent thrown out as impertinent to the objects of the Clearing-houses. Then a meeting of Bank Officers, Local and National, was organized outside the Association. Forty-one Banks out of the sixty-six Banks in the city were represented. The leaders in the scheme refused to consult with the original National Banks, not in the Clearing-house, and succeeded by a vote of 29 to 12, in keeping the subject alive for a third attempt to force it on the majority. This attempt was made on the succeeding Tuesday, Sept. 19. Less than one-half the Clearing-house Banks were represented at the close of the meeting, when a fourth attempt was resolved upon, to be made through the old committee by privately canvassing the National and Local Banks for Tuesday the 26th of September. The result was, that thirty-nine Banks were willing to entertain some acceptable plan for assorting the National Currency, and a meeting was organized of the representatives of these Banks, then present. The old committee and the old plan were thrown overboard, and a new committee ordered to be selected by the Chairman for a fifth trial, on the basis of only thirty-nine banks in place of a general cooperation of all New-York, Philadelphia and Boston as originally contemplated. When this is to be made is now wholly uncertain. The whole affair was uncalled for; irrelevant to the banking law, and mischievous, if not mischievously intended, from the start, and its failure on Tuesday was even more complete, if possible, as a voluntary investment in New-York, than when it was rejected six or eight weeks ago as a Clearing-house obligation in all the three cities. The failure is, in one sense, the more signal because the movement being pushed to the extreme of a private and urgent canvass or drumming up of the banks to only consent to do something or other to disturb the working of the national currency, it has arrayed twelve or fourteen of the very best and most practical, as well as important in point of capital and deposits, of the Clearing-house Banks against it. They stand by National Bank redemption under the law. They stand by the perfect uniformity of the National Bank currency as against discrimination and discount; they stand by the country Banks who are faithfully providing for their notes at the commercial centres, and stand by the merchants, shopkeepers and business people generally of our great metropolis, who recognize this currency as equally national, equally sound, and having the same Treasury seal and pledge of faith and redemption as the greenbacks of the government themselves, and don't mean to be shaved on the one any more than on the other.

abstract: SUICIDE. -- Mr. JOHN MOULTON, a native of Maine, 29 years of age, committed suicide on Wednesday morning by cutting his throat with a razor. It appears that he went to the privy and there perpetrated the deed. The deceased has been in a desponding state of mind for some time, on account of sickness, and finally concluded to terminate his existence. He resided with Mr. JOSEPH VEGEA, on the Coney Island plank-road, beyond the toll-gate. Coroner LYNCH took charge of the body.

abstract: The wagon thieves that infest Washington Market do not appear to drive a thriving business, nearly every one of them having recently been captured in the act. Yesterday, Officer GRAHAM, of the Third Ward, apprehended JOSEPH EASTON, a German, for stealing from Mr. LAWRENCE DALTON, of No. 195 First-avenue, a team and load of vegetables of the value of $700, the horses having been left unfastened in Fulton-street while Mr. DALTON was transacting business in Washington Market. In default of $2,000 bail, the prisoner was committed for trial.

abstract: Last evening a select audience assembled in Dr. Chapin's Church to hear Mrs. C.F. WINDLE's lecture for the advancement of the late Mrs. FARNHAM's novel theory of Woman. Mrs. WINDLE proved herself a graceful speaker, and the lecture was well written, although somewhat dogmatic. The theory upon which she based her lecture was the introduction of woman to new and momentous relations in the Divine plan of human progress. She claimed the grand natural truth that woman was capable of a still higher sphere, by proper culture, than that which she had already attained, and the theory of Mrs. FANNHAM was that the human mind was capable of a grander exaltation than was at present dreamed of by philosophers. The improvement thus set forth could only be produced by natural means, newly discovered, for the perfection of the human race physically and mentally.

abstract: Mr. GRINNELL has received a letter from Capt. HALL, of the Arctic Expedition, written on the 10th of last December, in which the writer states that he has obtained from the natives much valuable information; among other things, Capt. HALL feels certain that he has traced out evidence to show definitely that Capt. RICHARD CROZIER, who commanded FRANKLIN's second ship, the Terror, and three other men, were in communication with the natives, and that CROZIER's life was saved by the judicious nursing of a native. This native says CROZIER was almost starved, but the other men were fat and strong, they having eaten human flesh, which CROZIER would not do. It would seem that these men lived for a long time with the natives on Boothia Felix Peninsula, but finally went away to the south in a boat, and that is all the In[???]uits appear to know of them. Sir JOHN FRANKLIN's ships were last seen on the 6th of July, 1845, in the [???]ce near the middle of Baffin's Bay.

MANN, was to have made its defence yesterday morning; but as Mr. DAVID DUDLEY FIELD, Jr., counsel for Col. MANN, desired that Mr. L.J. abstract: Early yesterday morning DAVID SUFFERN, of No. 182 Clinton-street, and CHRISTIAN WALTER, of No. 205 Division-street, fought in the latter's lager-bier place, and WALTERS shot SUFFERN with a fowling-piece, wounding him in both legs. Policeman POWELL, of the Seventh Ward, subsequently appeared and arrested WALTER and his wife and seven feminine inmates of the den, and Justice MANSFIELD committed WALTER for trial and sent the females to Blackwell's Island. SUFFERN was taken to Bellevue Hospital.

abstract: Protestant Episcopal Convention and Sectional Reconciliation
snippet: Protestant Episcopal Convention and Sectional Reconciliation
lead_paragraph: The spirit which the Northern churches will manifest toward the Southern is awaited with great interest for its political as well as its religious bearings. Upon it greatly depends the early restoration of the cordial reunion of the two sections. The different church organizations embrace a very large portion of the intelligence and moral force of the country. No political scheme or policy for sectional concord can prosper unless they, too, choose to "follow things that make for peace."

abstract: Acceptance of Nomination for Judge of Appeals
snippet: Acceptance of Nomination for Judge of Appeals
lead_paragraph: Hon. MARTIN GROVER accepts the Democratic nomination for Judge of the Court of Appeals, in a letter which we publish in another column. As the Judge has been an out-and-out Republican for the last five or six years, an excess of Democratic zeal was just now necessary to reestablish his firm footing in the Democratic ranks. But the Judge, it seems to us, would have better proved his fitness for a judicial position if he had consulted his self-respect, rather than the emergencies of his political position, and adhered to the truth in defining the position of his new party.

abstract: Mary Maury was tried yesterday for an alleged larceny of money. The complainant testified that he was standing on the sidewalk in Mulberry-street on the 12th of this month, when the prisoner came along and snatched from his hand a pocket-book containing $180. Complainant was sure he lost his money, but not so sure that prisoner took it. The identification not being complete, the jury rendered a verdict of not guilty.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: "DICE, the Gipsy Queen," a deformed negress, that was at one time on exhibition in Chatham-street, and who had been exhibited by various circus companies throughout the country as a mate for BARNUM's "What Is It," died at No. 310 Broome-street, yesterday morning, of debility. She was born in Macon, Georgia, in 1820. Dr. THOS. ROBINSON, who made a post-mortem examination of this remarkable object, found the head and chest well developed, but the extremities curiously deformed, the hands and feet being turned inward and the extremities turned upward. There was marked disproportion between the length of the upper and lower bones of both extremities; the upper extremities measured eleven inches from shoulder to elbow-joint, and three and a half inches from elbow to wrist; the lower extremities measured fourteen inches from hip-joint to knee, and five inches from knee to ankle-joint. The legs were contracted and bent in upon the thigh, and the entire body was but three feet and one inch in stature. The bladder was completely filled with biliary calculi, and in the gall bladder Dr. ROBINSON found no less than one hundred and seven gall stones, several of which are nearly an inch in circumference.

abstract: sells for eleven dollars a ton. In London, with a population of three millions to be supplied from fields two hundred and fifty miles distant, the price of coal is five dollars and a quarter. But this is only the beginning of things. We now pay double what the Londoner pays for his fuel. Before the Winter has fairly set in, the chances are ten to one that we shall pay one-third more than we pay to-day, or about three times as much as the citizen of London. There is not the shadow of a decent reason for this. Instead of honestly competing with each other in their transactions with the public, our dealers combine together against the public. All legitimate competition is thus destroyed as soon as it begins to tell in favor of the consumer.

abstract: ARRIVAL OF THE FIRST CONNECTICUT ARTILLERY. -- The First Connecticut Artillery, which left Washington on Wednesday night, arrived in this city at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon. They were met at the foot of Cortlandt-street by Col. ALMY, the Connecticut State Agent, who escorted them to the Battery Barracks, where they partook of some refreshments. The First Connecticut numbers 1,060 men, and is commanded by Brevet Maj.-Gen. ABBOTT, who was formerly the Colonel of the regiment. They left Hartford in October, 1862, 1,200 strong, under command of Col. WOODHOUSE, and distinguished themselves throughout all the memorable battles on the Peninsula, under MCCLELLAN and GRANT. After the taking of Richmond and Petersburgh, they were ordered to the fortifications at Washington, where they remained until mustered out of service.

abstract: Fashion Course. Gen., Butler, Geo. Wilkes and Lady Emma
snippet: Fashion Course. Gen., Butler, Geo. Wilkes and Lady Emma
lead_paragraph: The excitement attendant on the result of the fall purses of the Fashion Course Association culminated on Thursday. Throughout the early morning there was a rush of the fortunate owners of vehicles; those so unblessed had to rest themselves on the tender mercies of the Flushing Railroad, which, with its accustomed attention, did not fulfil its engagements according to the advertised time. The day was exceedingly fine, and there was a large attendance of the leading patrons of the trotting turf, with whom the interest manifested, culminated in the advancement of their individual favorites.

abstract: In September, 1863, Mr. SOLOMON ANDREWS, of Perth Amboy, N.J., demonstrated by actual experiment that he was able to navigate a balloon of a certain form either with or against the wind. The experiment was witnessed by a large number of scientific and practical men, who admitted that it was perfectly successful. Notwithstanding this, however, the public looked on the invention with distrust, and all Mr. ANDREWS' efforts to get practical men to take hold of it were unavailing. Last evening several scientific gentlemen heard Mr. ANDREWS' explanation of the manner in which his aerial machine was constructed, and witnessed a number of experiments, all of which tended to convince them that the era of successful aerial navigation in not very far distant.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- DONIZETTI's opera of "Lucrezia Borgia" will be given here to-night, with an exceedingly fine distribution. Mme. CAROZZI ZUCCHI is the heroine, a role in which her splendid presence and dramatic skill are alike important Miss ADELAIDE PHILLIPS makes her rentree in the part of the Orsini, being the first time in four years that this favorite contralto has appeared before our public. Signor IRFRE is the Genarro, and Signor ASTONUCCI the Duke. The smaller parts will be sustained by Messrs. LORINI, BARILI and DUBREUIL; the orchestra being under the direction of Signor TORIANI.

abstract: London Times on Canadian Confederation
snippet: London Times on Canadian Confederation
lead_paragraph: -- We publish in another column the main portion of an article from the London Times, on the prospects of Canadian Confederation. Our cotemporary takes a view of the question which is the reverse of flattering to the patriotism and commercial spirit of the Provincials. It seems that Dr. MACKAY, who has been prospecting in Canada on behalf of the London Times, has discovered that, while the local government may be earnest in their desire for Union, with "the mass of the population it is a pecuniary question." The popular reasoning takes this shape: "If England wants Confederation, let her pay for it. We have not the least objection to comply with her wishes, but it must be for an adequate consideration." It must be confessed, if this is the actual view of their political future taken by the Canadians, it is a very low and sordid view, and the British organ may with some reason denounce it, and threaten the colonists with desertion. It does seem like the most stolid kind of indifference to find the Provincial government setting itself first to the task of buying out the Hudson Bay Company's rights with British money, before taking any practical steps to form a closer connection with the maritime colonies. The purchase of these rights is only of immediate account, because there is the prospect of a British loan being granted to make that purchase. Giving that scheme precedence over confederation, certainly does look as if the people of Canada must have an "adequate consideration" at every step they take in carrying out the policy of the central government. They refuse even to deepen their canals -- on the ground of economy -- while they are ready to buy up half a continent of wild territory, provided they are supplied with funds to make the investment.

abstract: John Combs, alias Jack McCune, alias Cobbler Jack, aged 26, a very sprucely dressed young gentleman, was charged with the larceny of a coat from the billiard saloon of Crist Wahlig, No. 245 Third-avenue. The prisoner, although the mildest and most amiable-looking of young men, is perhaps the most dangerous felon in the community. A few years ago he associated only with first-class burglars, and was only concerned in robberies when silks to the amount of ten or fifteen thousand dollars would be taken. Besides serving several terms on the Island, he has served one in the State Prison. A few years ago he had thousands of dollars in the bank, and would think nothing of giving a lawyer a hundred dollars fee to defend him on a preliminary examination. Yesterday, at 26 years of age, he was convicted of stealing a coat worth $12, and no lawyer defended him. He was sent to the Penitentiary for six months.

abstract: A prettier played game, taken as a whole, than that between the Eckford Club, of Brooklyn, and the Mutuals, of New-York, which took place at Hoboken yesterday, we have not seen this season. The Mutuals, fresh from two well-earned triumphs at Kingston -- for a silver ball -- and at Pough[???]eepsie, presented an excellent nine in good trim for action, yesterday; and the Eckfords, too, had a fine nine out; in fact, every thing was propitious for a well-contested match, and those who formed the assemblage of three thousand odd, who were present on the occasion, were repaid for their trouble by witnessing as line a display of fielding as either club have ever shown in any of their matches together.

abstract: Patient's Death
snippet: Patient's Death
lead_paragraph: Having learned, on Wednesday, that a corpse had been suspiciously taken from No. 160 Laurens-street, and by the Hudson River Railroad out of the city, probably to be interred at Tivoli, Capt. NATHANIEL R. MILLS, bearing a warrant from Coroner WILDEY, took the 6 o'clock train for that town, with authority from the managers of the Hudson River Railroad to use their telegraph, and stop the train at Tivoli -- the 6 o'clock train usually passing through that town without stopping. Capt. MILLS ascertained that the corpse was to be taken to an interior town, but knew not whither, and as he feared that it might be removed from the train at some point south of Tivoli, he consulted the telegraph operators at Poughkeepsie and Rhinebeck, and learned that the body had crossed the Hudson to Saugerties at about 6 o'clock. He arrived at Tivoli at 10 o'clock and was rowed across to Saugerties, reaching that town after the undertaker had retired. But observing, opposite the undertaker's, a light and three women at the door, the Captain accosted them, asking when the funeral was to take place, and was informed that 10 o'clock on Thursday morning was the hour be requested them to show him the corpse, and inquired whether Mr. HICKS was there; upon which he was shown in and introduced to Mr. HICKS. With Mr. HICKS he sat up with the corpse on Wednesday night and yesterday returned to the city, bringing the corpse Mr. HICKS, and Miss FANNY GRAY, a young woman who accompanied the husband and body to Saugerties on Wednesday. The body was taken to the Wooster-street Police-station, last evening, and after a postmortem examination had been made by Dr. WOOSTER BEACH, Jr., and the testimony of Mr. HICKS had been recorded, the Coroner dismissed him, and he went with the corpse back to Saugerties. The testimony which was taken last evening was as follows:

abstract: Fisher vs. Brig Plymouth; Claim for Proceeds
snippet: Fisher vs. Brig Plymouth; Claim for Proceeds
lead_paragraph: In the Matter of the Petition of Francis Fisher vs. The Brig Plymouth. -- In this case the facts were as follows: Several libels were filed against the brig for pilotage, supplies, &c. The first one was filed on the 20th of July last. The vessel was seized by the Marshal, who returned that he had so arrested her, and on the return of the processes, on Aug. 15, defaults were entered against the vessel upon all the libels. On the 16th of August a libel against the vessel was filed by the petitioner, but no steps were taken to open the defaults already entered. An order of sale was issued in one of the cases, and the vessel was sold under it on the 19th day of August.

abstract: Plan of Female Emigration to the West
snippet: Plan of Female Emigration to the West
lead_paragraph: For several years past the scheme of female colonization for the Far West and the newly settled Territories on the Pacific slope, has been extensively discussed and widely approved. The fact that a scarcity of women existed in those far away and newly settled regions, while a superabundance of the fairer sex abounded in New-England and the Middle States, naturally led many to believe that any feasible plan looking toward the removal of these two great drawbacks, would be a beneficial and desirable one for both sections. Several schemes have from time to time been set forth with but indifferent success, the projectors not taking that active interest in the enterprise so necessary to a prosperous culmination.

abstract: THE MARCUS L. WARD CLUB -- GRAND DEMONSTRATION AT PATERSON. -- A very large and enthusiastic meeting was held on Thursday evening, at the Wigwam. Although the Democrats had a great deal of firing and noise, yet it did not decrease the attendance, for the old Wigwam was completely filled, a large number being ladies, who seemed to be as much in earnest about the right men being put in office as anyone else. The orators of the evening were Gen. HITE, of Kentucky, and Col. HAWKINS, of Tennessee. Gen. HITE was the first speaker presented to the audience. Gen. HITE, on taking the stand, spoke substantially as follows: Fellow-citizens: When engaged some two years ago in the service of my country, I had the pleasure of appearing before you in the City of Paterson. I told you then that I believed the rebellion would be put down, because our cause was a just one, and the God of our battles was a just God. But as I said to you, if I had been deceived or mistaken, and if it would be the decree of Providence that this government should be severed as strongly and tenaciously as I clung to life I humbly and sincerely prayed that God should not allow me to witness the destruction of this glorious Union, and He has not. [Applause.] And now that our country is once more freed from bloodshed, it becomes you, my fellow-citizens, to buckle on the armor, and put patriotic and faithful men at the head of your State Government -- men who have been trustworthy during the late struggle, for only such will be faithful and trustworthy in time of peace. The speaker then gave a lengthy account of his services under Gen. ROUSSEAU, and the many battles that that able General was engaged in. He said: Ask Gen. ROUSSEAU what he would do with these Copperheads you have up North, and he would say, "I would send them every one over to the rebels." [Cheers.] In relation to the candidates he could say nothing, as he did not know them, except that he had heard that Mr. WARD was the soldier's friend, [cheers -- "That's so,"] and that Gen. RUNYON was always opposed to the Union cause, and therefore he was not his friend. This State is the only one that has not come out boldly for the side of the government, and now it is your duty to come out fearlessly, so that you may have your State free. When you do that, you, as a State, will be prosperous, and we will have a happy and peaceful confederacy, such as the world has never before seen. [Great cheering.] Col. HAWKINS was then presented, and greeted with raptures of applause. He said: As you have heard from Kentucky it would be well to hear from my native State, I have visited the enemy's camp on the corner above before I came here, and I heard a man speaking there whom they call WINDFIELD, but I think there is more wind than field. [Laughter.] He has been speaking against me, and said that the gentlemen now traveling through the State, with their shoulder-straps are Copperheads. [Laughter.] Now I think the best thing we can do is to go down to them and give them battle, as we are three to their one, and before the election in November we will be five to their one. [Cheers.] The Colonel then gave a description of his sufferings in the South, and the horrid effects of slavery. The meeting was continued up till a late hour.

abstract: on Condition and Wants of the South
snippet: on Condition and Wants of the South
lead_paragraph: Hon. E.C. CABELL, formerly member of Congress from Florida, writes from Memphis, Tenn., to the Tribune, an able and sensible letter on the condition of the Southern States, and especially their need of labor. He says that, for the last thirty years, the people of the North and South have been educated to hate each other, and that this studied and systematic mutual villification produced a state of feeling which resulted in the desolating war just closed. Without wasting time in inquiring which party was most at fault in this matter, Mr. CABELL urges it as now the common duty of the people of both sections to obliterate the feelings of bitterness engendered by the past four years of strife, to foster the interests of the whole country, and to devote their united energies to the work of repairing the ravages of the past, and building up new glories for the future. Slavery, he says, is dead, and maintaining it so long was a crime on the part of the South; that crime has been punished with adequate severity in the desolation and ruin that has followed it. The first feeling of the leading southern men, upon the failure of their hopes and plans, was to abandon their country or bury themselves in seclusion. But this, with few exceptions, has passed away, and they are now prepared to accept their situation, and make the best of it Whatever they may have thought of the superior advantage of two governments, all now see that we have now, and must have hereafter forever, but one country, one destiny and one duty, and all feel called upon to devote all their energies to building up its permanent and supreme prosperity. The experiment of free labor must, and will, have a full and fair trial, and for himself, Mr. CABELL says he believes it will be far more successful than is generally believed. But the losses from death and from other causes, among the negroes, renders indispensable, in his judgment, large accessions to the free white laboring population of the Southern States -- and the main object of his letter is to set forth the inducements to such immigration offered by the condition of affairs, and especially by the low price and great fertility of the Southern lands. "The mass of the Southern people," he says, "lost everything in the late revolution but their lands, the larger portion of which they are now unable to cultivate for want of labor. This large surplus they must sell. Hundreds of thousands of acres of good lands are thus offered for sale at the very lowest prices. Many fine plantations may be purchased for a sum much below the cost of the buildings erected on them, and highly improved estates at less than half the price of wild lands in the same vicinity four years ago. There are, besides, millions of acres of unimproved lands to be purchased at prices proportionately low. The lands in the Mississippi Valley, liable to inundation, are capable of producing cotton enough to clothe the civilized world, and corn enough to feed the population of America. The price of many of these lands is nominal. They will some day become of inestimable value.

abstract: The regular weekly meetings of the Polytechnic Association of the American Institute were resumed on Thursday evening at the Cooper Union, a large attendance being present. The evening was spent in examining the novelties now on exhibition at the Fair. The Chairman, in opening the association for this season, dwelt with much effect upon many improvements in the arts during the war, now happily ended. His remarks were listened to with marked attention throughout, and at times he was justly applauded.

abstract: Unionism in
snippet: Unionism in
lead_paragraph: The report we published on Monday last, from our own correspondent, of the opening action of the South Carolina Convention, gave a very encouraging view of the temper and spirit in which that State proposes to resume her place in the National Union. As a matter of course, there was some intemperate talk and a little of the old-fashioned South Carolina bluster and bravado; but it was subdued in tone and was promptly overruled by the good sense of the great body of the convention. Mr. ALDRICH, from the Barnwell district, relieved his overburdened mind by declaring that the people of the State were living under a "military despotism," and offered a resolution to be "patient under evils they could not avert," and to "await calmly the time and opportunity to effect deliverance from unconstitutional rule." But Mr. MCGOWAN, who bore on his body the scars of wounds received in the rebel service, denounced the temper of this proceeding with stirring eloquence, and was greeted with thundering applause; and ex-Gov. PICKENS, of old the fiercest of secession fanatics, calmly remarking that it "did not become the people of South Carolina to bluster now," moved to lay the resolution on the table, which was promptly carried, with but four or five dissenting votes.

lead_paragraph: Elijah W. Carpenter vs. the Steamer Island City. -- This was a libel for a collision. The libelant was the owner of the schooner Peri, which was sunk by a collision with the steamer in Hell Gate. The District Court held that the collision was occasioned by the schooner's own fault, and dismissed the libel, and from this decree the libelant appealed to this Court.

abstract: The World is getting a little uneasy under the failure of its hopes and predictions concerning the action of the Administration Party in this State. It was very certain the Syracuse Convention would break up in a row, -- that there would be a grand fight on "negro suffrage," -- that radicalism generally would be rampant, and that nothing would be left undone there, to enable the Democrats to walk quietly over the course this Fall. In common with the rest of its party it finds itself sadly disappointed. Not one of its confident predictions was verified. Everything went exactly the other way.

abstract: The Pacification of; Juarez' Strategy; On What Republicans "Must" Do
snippet: The Pacification of; Juarez' Strategy; On What Republicans "Must" Do
lead_paragraph: It is now nearly four years since LOUIS NAPOLEON undertook to introduce order and the Empire into Mexico. Since then he has retained an army there numbering at times as high as forty thousand troops, beside an imposing naval force on the coast. An immense amount of fighting on a small scale has been ceaselessly going on, and each side has claimed a vast number of great victories in these actions. MAXIMILIAN has had far the best opportunities for publishing to the world his victories and his version of affairs generally; and he has taken full advantage of them, even going so far as to dispatch special steamships and couriers to Europe to announce to the French Emperor, his master; to the Belgian King, his father-in-law; to the Austrian Emperor, his brother, and to the potentates and princes in general, the circumstance of some petty triumph, or the fall before his brave veterans of some little Mexican town. Nevertheless, it is certain, from the continuous advance of the Imperial forces to the interior of the country, from the capture of successive cities, State capitals and positions of strategical importance, and from the repeated flights of the Republican Government, that the formal military occupation of Mexico has been making steady progress, till now it may be said to be nearly complete.
headline: {'main': 'The Pacification of Mexico.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Pacification of Mexico.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Alabama Convention passed an ordinance providing that all debts created by the State of Alabama in aid of the late war, directly or indirectly, are declared void, and that the General Assembly of the State shall have no authority to ratify or assume to provide for their payment. The convention also decided to submit the amendments to the constitution to a popular vote. The South Carolina Convention has adjourned, after a most harmonious session of fifteen days. They have repealed the ordinance of secession, abolished slavery, equalized the representation of the Senate and taxation throughout the State, giving the election of Governor and Presidential electors to the people, ordered voting in the Legislature by viva voce, indorsed the Administration unanimously, directed a commission to submit a code to the Legislature for the protection of the colored population. The convention has also appointed a committee to intercede with the President on behalf of JEFF. DAVIS and other rebels now in limbo. The election for Governor and members of the Legislature takes place on the 18th of October. JAMES L. ORR is nominated for Governor, and it is understood that Gov. PERRY will be sent to the United States Senate.

abstract: Frank Pohle and Kate Talma were the only prisoners tried at this court yesterday. They were jointly indicted for stealing from Jeremiah Lambert, a dry goods dealer in Greenwich-street, a quantity of calico and cotton cloth of the value of $43. testimony showed that the goods were taken by Kate Talma, the male prisoner only having been seen in the act of helping her to tie them up. The man was acquitted, and the woman convicted of petit larceny and sent to the Penitentiary for six months and fined $100.

abstract: People of N. Y. vs. 3d-av. Railroad Co.; Appeal; Right to lay Switches
snippet: People of N. Y. vs. 3d-av. Railroad Co.; Appeal; Right to lay Switches
lead_paragraph: The People of the State of New-York Resp'ts. vs. The Third-avenue Railroad Company, Appellants. -- This case come up, yesterday, on an appeal taken by the Third-avenue Railroad Company, from a judgment rendered by Justice Clerke, at the Special Term of this court, on the 19th of October, 1864. The action was brought in the name of the people of this State for the purpose of permanently restraining the Third-avenue Railroad Company from operating a certain switch or branch track, which had been by them constructed from Third-avenue up One Hundred and Thirtieth-street toward the Fourth-avenue. The company further claim that this switch or branch track was constructed by them for the better accommodation of the public, and that they were legally authorized to construct and operate the same by virtue of a resolution of the Common Council of the City of New-York, passed on the 28th day of March, 1864. By this resolution they contend that they were required to construct the switch or branch railroad. They did construct it, and undertook to operate it. They claim that it was a necessity resulting from the constantly-increasing travel on that thoroughfare. Soon after the company commenced to operate the branch railroad, the people of the State, through their Attorney-General, Mr. John Cochrane, commenced a suit and obtained a preliminary injunction. The case was tried before Justice Clerke without a jury, and the result was a permanent injunction. The company have now taken an appeal to the General Term for the purpose of getting the judgment reversed and the injunction removed. The case was argued at length yesterday by Mr. C.N. Potter in behalf of the railroad company, and by Mr. Anderson for the people. The first point argued on the part of the appellants was that it nowhere appeared as a matter of fact who the owners of the fee of One Hundred and Thirtieth-street were, or that the people of the State of New-York had any interest therein, there was no proof on that subject. The interest of the people could not be inferred; it must be made to appear in order to maintain the action. To support this position the cases of Davis vs. The Mayor, in the 14th of New-York Reports, and the People vs. Kerr, in the 27th New-York were cited. The second point argued was that the Common Council had power to direct the occupation of One Hundred and Thirtieth-street, as required by their resolutions. Counsel said that it was undoubtedly a temporary occupation at the pleasure of the Common Council, revocable by them at any moment; there was no exclusive right to the switch; not only the railroad company, but any one could use it, and moreover, there was no right to compensation for business done on it; in fact the resolutions of the Common Council expressly forbid compensation. The courts of this State have nowhere declared that such a resolution is beyond the power of the Common Council. In Davis vs. The Mayor, (14 N.Y. Rep.) the distinction between carrying passengers for hire, under an agreement giving permanent, exclusive use to the grantee, and a revocable temporary license is distinctly taken. Three of the justices declared that a revocable license to lay rails in the city would be valid. In Milhau vs. Sharp, the resolutions for a Broadway railroad were decided to be beyond the power of the Common Council, because they conferred an exclusive permanent right to carry passengers on Broadway for hire. Under the general powers of the city over streets, the counsel said, the right of the city to authorize show-cases, stands, booths, tramways to coal-yards, elevators, elevated railways near docks, and temporary rail tracks, to be erected in the streets during the pleasure of the city, has been constantly exercised. In this connection he called the attention of the learned judges to the children's department of the late United States Sanitary Fair, erected on Seventeenth-street; also to the general recruiting-tent formerly situated near WASHINGTON's statue on Union-square. If the Common Council could authorize those erections, why could they not this track? As to his third point, counsel said he should insist that if the Common Council had not otherwise the power, it must be considered that this switch was a necessary incident to the principal subject of the grant, ratified by the act of 1854, and that, in any event, no damage whatever had been shown; no one's rights had been infringed; no human being had been injured in person or property. The court, he said, should take into consideration the increasing interests and the growing necessities of the inhabitants of the upper portion of this great city. In ten years past the population of this island had increased about ten per cent.; but it could be shown by statistics which were above suspicion, that the wants and the necessities of the people in respect to conveyances between the upper and lower part of the city has increased in the proportion of 130 per cent. in the same time.

abstract: Well, it is here. The sultry horrors of Midsummer are (probably) past, and we emerge into the era of soft airs and muskeetoes -- especially muskeetoes, or moskeetos, or moschetoes, or any other skeetoes that this absurd language may toe-lerate. Yet it is (or has been) "which and tother," it is "nip and tuck" (excuse the French) between Summer and Autumn. (Here is a good opportunity to rush into a Bohemian description of "dying Summer" and "auburn Autumn of the sombre locks," but Mr. Jenkins has been "on a dinner" and his spectacles are cloudy. But, revenons, &c.) We must really congratulate ourself upon "the weather," barring the muskeetoes -- and the barring is the best part of it. Yesterday was not particularly cool, however -- indeed, with due respect, we may venture to say it was "hot." Ex gratia -- it was summery -- that is to say, it was calorifically inconsistent with Now. Then, meaning last week, it would have been synchronous -- now, it is anach, &c. But why whine? Sufficient unto the morning is the sunshine thereof, and the afternoons are sublime -- so says LAURA, whose glorious face supplies sunlight to the shady side of Broadway and thereabouts in the P.M. We like, Jenkins says, (and he knows) these early Autumn days. We like the hazy sky, but not the pear-paring on the sidewalks, that trips our light fantastic toe. We like the abundant flush of fair fruit and of fairer flowers that enrich the shop-windows, but not the astounding price of 20 (twenty) cents for a single pear of only one Bartlett. We like the lovely faces of the rising, &c., who are now lingering lazily and long schoolwards, (and getting jessie for not getting in earlier.) We like the little rogues, and if we were schoolmaster we would adjourn every day at noon and go romping after chestnuts and squirrels with our pets. Hang school -- in pleasant weather! Oh! how lovely is Autumn! For then the Great Hand showers down the undeserved benificence that overwhelms complaining and unworthy hearts with floods of gratitude -- such floods of blessings as compel in the most unwilling the sentiment of thankfulness -- such floods as flush the feeling heart with obligations that words may not express. And so, welcome to Autumn, and her generous bounty; and her dear, dreamy, delicious days of dizzy dazzlement; and her solemn nights of starry splendor, with grand Orion riding in unrivaled glory in the vanguard of Heaven; with her stilly and dewy mornings, all garnished with liquid pearls and vocal with the voices of soon-departing birds, whose melancholy music makes monotonous prelude of their early farewell. So, let us be thankful; for the red heat of past days, and the strength to endure it; for the glorious grandeur of the present time, and the heart to enjoy it; for the coming blessings of a favored clime, and the will to accept reverently and acknowledge fervently our countless blessings.
lead_paragraph: Well, it is here. The sultry horrors of Midsummer are (probably) past, and we emerge into the era of soft airs and muskeetoes -- especially muskeetoes, or moskeetos, or moschetoes, or any other skeetoes that this absurd language may toe-lerate. Yet it is (or has been) "which and tother," it is "nip and tuck" (excuse the French) between Summer and Autumn. (Here is a good opportunity to rush into a Bohemian description of "dying Summer" and "auburn Autumn of the sombre locks," but Mr. Jenkins has been "on a dinner" and his spectacles are cloudy. But, revenons, &c.) We must really congratulate ourself upon "the weather," barring the muskeetoes -- and the barring is the best part of it. Yesterday was not particularly cool, however -- indeed, with due respect, we may venture to say it was "hot." Ex gratia -- it was summery -- that is to say, it was calorifically inconsistent with Now. Then, meaning last week, it would have been synchronous -- now, it is anach, &c. But why whine? Sufficient unto the morning is the sunshine thereof, and the afternoons are sublime -- so says LAURA, whose glorious face supplies sunlight to the shady side of Broadway and thereabouts in the P.M. We like, Jenkins says, (and he knows) these early Autumn days. We like the hazy sky, but not the pear-paring on the sidewalks, that trips our light fantastic toe. We like the abundant flush of fair fruit and of fairer flowers that enrich the shop-windows, but not the astounding price of 20 (twenty) cents for a single pear of only one Bartlett. We like the lovely faces of the rising, &c., who are now lingering lazily and long schoolwards, (and getting jessie for not getting in earlier.) We like the little rogues, and if we were schoolmaster we would adjourn every day at noon and go romping after chestnuts and squirrels with our pets. Hang school -- in pleasant weather! Oh! how lovely is Autumn! For then the Great Hand showers down the undeserved benificence that overwhelms complaining and unworthy hearts with floods of gratitude -- such floods of blessings as compel in the most unwilling the sentiment of thankfulness -- such floods as flush the feeling heart with obligations that words may not express. And so, welcome to Autumn, and her generous bounty; and her dear, dreamy, delicious days of dizzy dazzlement; and her solemn nights of starry splendor, with grand Orion riding in unrivaled glory in the vanguard of Heaven; with her stilly and dewy mornings, all garnished with liquid pearls and vocal with the voices of soon-departing birds, whose melancholy music makes monotonous prelude of their early farewell. So, let us be thankful; for the red heat of past days, and the strength to endure it; for the glorious grandeur of the present time, and the heart to enjoy it; for the coming blessings of a favored clime, and the will to accept reverently and acknowledge fervently our countless blessings.

abstract: Calhoun, Ship; Mutiny; Examination
snippet: Calhoun, Ship; Mutiny; Examination
lead_paragraph: The examination, commenced yesterday morning in the alleged mutinous conduct of thirty-one men employed as seamen on the ship Calhoun, attracted a large crowd of the friends of the accused parties. The crew were all brought into court ironed, and, although a rough-looking lot, they appeared to be above the average in intelligence. The charge against them was refusing to do duty and mutinous conduct. The Captain of the Calhoun was the first witness called.

abstract: End of the Great Strike
snippet: End of the Great Strike
lead_paragraph: Late advices from the Lackawanna Valley are to the effect that the men have resumed work, from Carbondale down to Pittston, which takes in the area where operations had been suspended. Below the borough of Wilkesbarre nothing was done for several months in the early part of the season, owing to damages on the canal, the coal thereabouts being shipped to Havre de Grace and Baltimore, but since July the ordinary activity has prevailed thereabouts.

abstract: Judge Hale on Colchester Case
snippet: Judge Hale on Colchester Case
lead_paragraph: Judge HALL's opinion on the motion for a new trial in the case of the spiritual medium COLCHESTER, must be taken everywhere to be not only a conclusive argument against the points urged in his favor by his counsel, but also a very strong argument against the claims of Spiritualism itself; and thus questions involved have an interest far beyond the particular case before the court. The first one was the point urged that COLCHESTER's performances were not public. But the Judge, while obviously strongly inclined to hold that his performances were public in a proper sense, holds that it makes no difference whether they were public or not, the only necessary element being that they constituted the "business" of the defendant, the evidence of publicity and performance for pay being only pertinent to show that this was his business.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. An Unusually equal and creditable performance of "Lucrezia Borgia" was given here, last evening, to another full and fashionable audience. We have rarely heard an old opera create so much genuine applause from a house which, while warm in appreciating the music, was singularly cold toward the singers. The caste was as follows: Lucrezia Borgia, Mme. ZUCCHI; Orsini, Miss A. PHILLIPS; Genarro, Sig. IRFRE; Duke Alfonso, Sig. ANTONUCCI.

abstract: Butchers, Cruel Custom of, Abolished
snippet: Butchers, Cruel Custom of, Abolished
lead_paragraph: -- We are sure there was not a humane citizen who was not gratified on reading the other morning that the police had taken in hand the inhuman butcher-men who have been in the habit of driving through the streets of the city, carts in which were huddled and round which were hanging, in the most painful and revolting style, living calves. We are sure every one was gratified that the judge before whom the culprits were brought, acted promptly in the infliction of a punishment which will soon stop the offence by making it expensive. The wicked custom has been carried on for years, before the eyes of thousands of people, and amid continued remonstrances against it. We trust the last of it has now been seen. And we but give the police deserved credit in expressing public gratification that they have stopped it.

abstract: ELECTION OF COLONEL AND OTHER OFFICERS OF THE THIRTY-SEVENTH REGIMENT. -- An election for Colonel of the Thirty-seventh Regiment National Guard, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Col. O.D. ASHLEY, was held at the regimental armory, corner of Broadway and Thirty-fifth-street, Thursday evening, Gen. WILLIAM HALL presiding. The candidates presented were Mr. JOHN JACOB ASTOR, Jr., and Lieut.-Col. CHARLES M. CATLIN. Lieut.-Col. CATLIN was declared the successful candidate, and accepted the position in a brief speech. Col. CATLIN is a son of J.M. CATLIN, Ex-Colonel of the Seventh Regiment, and has held successively the posts of Adjutant, Major and Lieutenant-Colonel in the Thirty-seventh. The vacancy caused by the promotion of Lieut.-Col. CATLIN was filled by the election of Major N.W.S. CATLIN, and Capt. W.H. FARRAR as Major.
lead_paragraph: ELECTION OF COLONEL AND OTHER OFFICERS OF THE THIRTY-SEVENTH REGIMENT. -- An election for Colonel of the Thirty-seventh Regiment National Guard, to fill the vacancy caused by the resignation of Col. abstract: Yesterday the new screw steamship Leo, belonging to Messrs. MURRAY & NEPHEW, No. 62 South-street, went on a trial trip down the bay. The Leo started from near Wall-street Ferry, and after taking on board a large number of invited guests, about one-half of whom were ladies, proceeded out to the Light Ship. The day was remarkably fine and the water as smooth as a mirror, so that no qualmish stomachs found it necessary to settle accounts with old Neptune. The ship appeared to behave well, so far as her performances could be tested in such remarkably smooth water, and her machinery, which was constructed by the Delamater Iron Works operated to admiration. Soon after the ship had been headed for the city a very appetising collation was served up, to which, it is almost unnecessary to say, full justice was done, the prosperity of the Leo and her owners being drank in bumpers. On arriving off the Battery it was found that such good time had been made that it was proposed to proceed up the North River, and accordingly a trip was taken as far as Guttenberg. On returning a number of the excursionists were landed at the foot of Carlisle-street, and the remainder in Brooklyn.
